Le voy a poner cinco estrellas pero más que por este libro en particular por la saga en general. El primero lo leí hace dos años y ayer terminé el último. Más de cuatro mil páginas repletas de magia, aventura, humor (al menos en su inicio) y grandes personajes. Rowling con el pasar de los libros deja a un lado un estilo literario más cuidado para centrarse en la trama, es más concisa a la hora de describir y dibujar las escenas. Me gustaba más en ese aspecto al inicio, no obstante la trama no te suelta en ningún momento, está hilvanada a la perfección, redonda, increíble aquí el trabajo de la autora. Y vas viendo la evolución de los personajes y conociendo las interioridades y tormentos de muchos de ellos. Dota a todos sus personajes de su propia voz personal, estos es realmente complicado a la hora de escribir pero ella lo logra con gran naturalidad y maestría. Apenas con un par de pinceladas te sirve en bandeja al personaje, su forma de hablar y su personalidad. Me he reído mucho con Hermione y Ron. Se hacen querer. Por otro lado Snape es un personajazo, de mis favoritos. Y aquí podría meter una retahíla de diferentes personajes (los Weasley en general, Sirius, Lupin, Voldemort y sus inicios, la odiosa Dolores Umbridge, Hagrid, Dumbledore, etc…) que alargarían esto más de la cuenta. Así que resumiendo ha sido todo un placer leer esta saga aunque haya sido tan tarde, de la que me he hecho fan y no puedo esperar ya a visitar la Harry Potter: The Exhibition que van a montar en Madrid. El mismo Stephen King se considera fan de estos libros y comenta que incluso le ayudaron a superar una depresión. Y no me cuesta creer que así sea.

Upon further reflection...I think this installment could have been much better. Perhaps Rowling was freaking out under the enormous pressure...never expecting her series to be so wildly adored by so many...Still, this book left something to be desired, I think. Rowling made so many predictable moves...and not even the ones that would have had more of an impact...Snape could have been the hero of the entire series, for example. It would have been rather ironic, considering the fact that he's been the object of every one's disdain--which would have made an outright act of heroism all the more outstanding. I understand that he made a significant contribution to Harry's safety, and Snape's storyline was heartbreaking and interesting...but he could have openly faced Voldermort. He could have raged and fought--he was a powerful wizard, after all... Snape should have gone out with a bang, I think--instead of a blood-soaked whimper. Also..The necklace around Ron's neck...bringing all of his envy and mistrust to the surface...Where have we seen this before? (just take a glance at the Lord of the Rings)...Harry and Ron have already had that fight about inequity in popularity...been there, done that...Why revisit it in such an awkward, hackneyed way?The gratuitous deaths also bother me. If you're going to kill a character off, kill one who is critical to Harry's development. Make Harry a three dimensional character! Do something earth-shattering to him! Also--merely showing a pile of dead bodies on the floor doesn't drive the point home. Some peripheral characters were cast off, as though their deaths were intended to evoke a certain emotion--yet they were clearly not considered important enough to be given more than a page of recognition upon their demise...What does that lead the reader to feel about those characters? Also, why the hell did Harry spend such a huge swath of the book sitting in a tent like a big doofus? Why didn't Rowling use all of those pages to illustrate the maturation of Harry's skill as a wizard--to give us some details as far as Voldemort was concerned...why wasn't there more conflict there? Why am I taking all of this so damn seriously is a better question...bleh.There were some interesting bits in this book. I guess it's time for me to state it--there's better young adult fantasy out there...series that deserve just as much, if not much more recognition...as they are better written, better rendered, etc. I do think of Harry Potter with fondness, however. Perhaps it's the combination of book and film...perhaps it's because so many friends of mine adore the books...I like them for their entertainment value...These are good pleasure reads--and could have been elevated to something much more. Perhaps my expectations were too high for this one.
*cries ugly tears*

Aaaaand it's over. Again.And I'm utterly shattered, but I'm also in a state of ecstasy because of how the many pieces of the puzzle the Harry Potter series is fitted. Seriously, I can't think of no other series of book so cautiously planned, in which all the details are important and everything - everything - makes sense in the way this does in the end.It was about time I truly appreciated what a fantastic world J.K. Rowling created with this series. As I had said before, I didn't really love this series before this reread - I simply liked it, and that was enough for me to not get the fweels and not to be in pain because of all the deaths that happened.Deaths which, by the way, made the book better and worse at the same time. Worse because duh, characters we learned to love no longer were; and better... because well, doesn't that prove how brave an author Rowling is? She doesn't go the safe, sugar-coated way. She goes in the painful and realistic one, even though this was not supposed to be a book for adults.This book is not my favourite in the series (that place goes for both The Goblet of Fire and The Prisoner of Azkaban), but it's still brilliant. The plot gets more complex than before, it's more action-packed and intense, and all the loose strings in the series finally get attached, that is to say, the missing explanations are given and the last twists delivered, some of which include this:Oh, Snape. A complex character, that one was. I never hated him. I admit sometimes I loathed him when he was unfair towards his students, but it was passing anger and I got over it; besides, he was a damn genius in Potion-making and magic in general. Now after reading book 7, I realised I actually feel kind of bad for him. All the life he didn't have... and all because he wallowed in his past.I'm eternally grateful for my decision of rereading this series. During it, I infected my brothers with HP obsession love, and I finally became one of those people who see the world of HP as real as our Muggle world, because as Albus Dumbledore said,Of course it is happening inside your head, Harry, but why on earth should that mean that it is not real?It'd be a lie if I say I'll never get over this series - I've gotten over worse things (i.e. The Monstrumologist) - but nonetheless I'll never forget about this journey, and of course, I'll always keep it in my heart, no matter how cheesy and unlike me that sounds.

Truly the book which gets to me every time I reread it. Of course this also gets 5*s becuase I adore this entire series and there's no reason not to give out 5*s to an entire series. On the reread this one had me crying and babbling in happiness and sadness alike many times. I truly think that the power of love and friendship shine throughout this whole book and I just found it moving and magical. I don't need to go into much detail other than to say I love this series ending, even with all the sadness, and this book is magnificent.

*Take a deep breath, Elena, take a deep breath!*I think I might be rewatching the movies and then rereading the books again and then rewatching the movies and so on for the rest of my life. Seriously I can't deal with having to let these characters and this amazingly epic story go. I just can't.
Thank you JK, for giving me a home away from home.

End of the series. *sobs*Did I finish it in a day???!!!! Amazing me!! Harry, you gave me the power.Dear Cursed Child, I'll be there for you after a book or 2, 3, 4, 5 books or I'm not sure yet.....This book...... is one of my favorite books in the series. I have seven favorite books :p

POSSIBLE SPOILERSRating:After all this book has put me through and has been dragged through itself, it deserves a 5 star rating. Especially since it is the conclusion to such a beautiful series.Plot:My Blurb:Harry Potter, The Boy Who Lived, The Chosen One, is supposed to be in his last year at Hogwarts, enjoying the time with his best friends Ron Weasley and Hermione Granger.Instead, he has been forced to grow up fast, suffering through death, hardships, and even duels.Still stricken by the death of one of the most important people in his life, Harry sets off with Ron and Hermione to find the remaining Horcruxes that will destroy Lord Voldemort.The task proves a daunting one, but with the help of his friends, and some unknown people, he may be able to succeed.If he does, he may finally be able to put an end to the evil in his world, creating a better place for all.My Commentary:This book.This. Book.It killed me.Harry and his friends have to go through a lot of crap in this book. The bias, the society, the prejudice.Harry has to hide his face everywhere he goes, even at Bill and Fleur's wedding. Almost everyone is against him, and those who we think are with him, well, some of them end up betraying the trust. Some of them are people we would never expect that from. And then there are the people who we thought for sure were against Harry but end up being on his side.I can't even express how much this book infuriated, overjoyed, excited, scared, and everything me.Characters:Harry Potter:Harry is still pretty perfect. He forgives Dumbledore, he forgives Snape, he forgives Ron, he tries to save Peter Pettigrew, he saves Draco and his cronies, he even gives Voldemort a chance. I mean, seriously, this guy? Amazing.Harry knows what it takes to save everyone; he knows very well that this could end in his death. But he is willing to sacrifice that if it means keeping everyone else safe.For that, I admire him as a character and as a person. His development throughout this series is incredible and the changes he brings to the Wizarding world are even greater.Ron Weasley:Ron has to once again deal with the pressure of being The Boy Who Lived's best friend. He has to fight his feelings for one of his best friends since he does not want to hurt his other friend. He is struggling still to find his own destiny without being shadowed by Harry Potter's. He's not really sure where he fits into all the plans until he finds it himself.Hermione Granger:Hermione. God, Hermione. She is so fierce, so strong, so passionate. She changes her parents' memories to be like she never existed. If that's not a savage move right there, I don't know what is. She sticks with Harry even when Ron gives up on him, and she does not waver from the quest. She knows what they need to do and she is not ready to surrender.Ginny Weasley:I love this girl. She is not afraid to kick butt or to show that she can. She will defend herself and the people she loves until she can't anymore. She is so much like Harry; they are the perfect match.She, Luna, and Neville, along with a ton of other Hogwarts students, kept the D.A. running so that they could support Harry from afar. That is just so great. I love Ginny.Luna Lovegood:Luna Lovegood? Oh! You mean my favorite character EVER? That Luna Lovegood?She is eccentric and odd, but with that brings her uniqueness and strength. She is her own person completely and does not hesitate to express herself. Even when held captive, Luna does not waver but spends her time trying to find a way to escape with the others. Harry admires her so, Ron thinks she is just the greatest thing, and Hermione is one of her best friends. Luna's personality is so great, and I wish I had someone like her in my life.Neville Longbottom:Neville, the awkward, clumsy, dim Neville Longbottom, has transformed into a hero. He helped Harry defeat Voldemort. Not in a small, cheesy way, but in a HUGE, nessecary way. He was scared and impressionable, but he helped the D.A. and the journey to defeating Voldemort in an incredible way.I just love this chubby, awkward kid. And I love Matthew Lewis in the movies but for reasons other than his personality. . . .Draco Malfoy:He is just one of those villains I can't bring myself to hate. His personality was terrible, yes, but beneath all of that, he was a vulnerable boy whose choices were fogged by his parents. He did not get to choose who he was. His entire life, he spent it shadowed in the legacy of his father, Lucius Malfoy, the Death Eater.He was not evil. He wasn't really a villain.He was the son who never got a choice. He was a young man who needed a second chance. He was a student, like all others, who needed to learn. He was just a boy who needed saving, even if he didn't want to admit it.Plus I ship Dramione, so there's that.Fred Weasley:*sniff**stifles sobs*George Weasley:I cannot express my love for these twins. My sympathy for George is immeasurable. For the whole family it is.I don't think George is ever ok after what happens in the Battle of Hogwarts. I don't think he ever healed wholly, but I do believe that his family helped him. He found a wife, I know, and they had 2 kids. Roxanne and Fred.Of course, there was Fred. Of course he cried, he hurt, he yelled. Of course his children wondered why their dad cried and why their mum had to comfort him. Fred wanted to know whose memeories it was that made his dad smile. George told his kids stories, I'm sure. They know who Uncle Fred is, even if they won't meet him.I hope George got better. I really do.Bill and Fleur Weasley:Geez, The Golden Trio owes Bill and Fleur their lives. He kept them safe when they barely escaped from death. They healed Hermione after she was tortured. They . . . gave up the spot in their yard . . . I can't . . .Percy Weasley:I had honestly forgotten about Percy until he showed up again. In the beginning books, I liked him, then I hated him, and now I love him. He's still not a huge character, but he is sorry, and he has a heart, which is what matters.Molly Weasley:This lady. She accepted Harry as her own even when her family was already so big. She would do anything for her family. She was devestated when she lost one, she was fierce when she fought for one, and she loved when she saw all of them.She was ready to sacrifice herself for her children and she used the only mildly violent curse word in the whole series for herself. Of course, there were Ron's frequent outbursts, but really, Molly gets the fame.She took on Bellatrix for her daughter. And! And! She defeated her!Molly Weasley, everyone.Arthur Weasley:His excitement with the Muggle world is great. He has such a curious mind that wants to explore everything. This is usually something reserved for a child, but Arthur has it too.Remus Lupin:The last Marauder standing. I guess a group that tight knit must all have similar destinies.He is such an amazing guy. All around. Sure there were times where I was annoyed with him because he didn't appreciate Tonks, or he was going to leave his son, or he was going to sacrifice everything, but in the end, I cried for him.When he asked Harry to be the godfather for his son, I was so touched. I had so many feelings combined into one ball of emotion, and I'll admit that I teared up.He would be such a wonderful dad, no matter what he thought.He may have denied his love for Tonks, but it did show in this book. It was a messy, complicated relationship, but beautiful nonetheless.Nymphadora Tonks:Tonks is supportive, protective, and determined. Her first thought in the battle was of her husband's safety, and their journeys finished together. They brought a new life into the world, and yes, their son may be confused as to why his mum and dad left him, but he will be loved. He will have Andromeda, Harry, Hermione, Ron, Ginny, the kids, everyone.Anyway, this is about Tonks, not Teddy. She is hilarious too. Her hair and her features and "Don't call me Nymphadora."Oh, Tonks . . .Severus Snape:Snape, Snape, Severus Snape.So . . . Some of you are going to hate me for saying this but . . .I still don't really like him.*winces* Is it over?I know, I know! His story, Lily, jealousy! Yes, it's all very heartbreaking, and I like him a lot more than I used to, but I still don't really like him.All those years, he was terrible to Harry. Maybe it was to protect him, because he reminded Snape of the Potters. I don't deny that, but at the same time, just because Snape loved Lily, I can't forgive him for all he has done.Snape was Neville's boggart. His biggest fear.Harry was not scared of Snape as Neville was, no, but he was intimidated by him.James Potter may have been a bully when he was a teenager, but Snape grew into a bully. Snape chose the dark arts over Lily; James changed for the woman he loved. That was the difference.Not that I'm glad Snape is gone, because I think he deserved a chance to redeem himself to Harry or prove that he wasn't evil, but I after going through all the tormenting with Harry though the books, I just can't bring myself to forgive him as Harry did.Harry, you are a much more forgiving person than I.Minerva McGonagall:She is such a savage, this lady. Her wizard mind tricks (and physical tricks) are what make her so cool. My love for her can't be expressed in words. And when she was upset about Harry, I loved her even more.She is such a fierce lady and she should he headmaster. I don't know what I would do without her. Haha.Voldemort:He comes last. Ol' Voldy. Probably the most evil of them all. Except for Umbridge of course. But this isn't about her.I think that he thought what he was doing was ok. He thought it was for the good of the Wizarding World. It was not, but he didn't know. His childhood and adulthood were demented and tortured. He didn't know what was wrong and what was right.Harry gave him a chance to apologize for his wrongdoings. Harry gave him a chance to be human again.Voldemort didn't want to be human. He wanted to be the monster he was. But in the end, he died with "mundane finality", showing that he was really just Tom Riddle.Author:Good old JK. She is so brilliant. Her story is an inspiring one that proves to everyone that nothing is really impossible if you have enough nerve. If we're quoting Ginny.She went through such a dark time, but she turned it around. Now she is a wife, a mother, she is happy. And that's all anyone could ever ask for: happiness.Recommended To:I doubt there are many people who haven't read Harry Potter, but I didn't read it for the first time until now, and that's WAY behind everyone else, just like I tell you about below. But everyone needs to read these books.Overall:This was my last read of 2015. It was a great finale. The twists, the turns, and the loops send you for a wild ride in this book. I could not have asked for a better conclusion to Harry Potter and to 2015.I am definitely glad I read them. Most people read these when they were 9 or 10. I did start the first book in 3rd or 4th grade, I think, but I didn't really enjoy it. Now, I am glad I picked them up. Thank God for my neighbor who lent them and the movies to me or I never would have gone back to these books. I would have remembered picking them up and ended it there. Now I have completed the reading, no matter how long it took me, but it finally happened!I may not have grown up with these books or had them shape my life, but they have built within me a deeper appreciation for literature itself, those who did shape their lives around these books, and for the great novelty of this series.Everyone needs to know the story of Harry Potter, his friends, his family, his determination, his passion, his forgiveness, his selflessness, his bravery, his sacrifice, and most of all, his strength. Because his strength, will make you stronger. And everyone could use a little more strength.For lack of any possibly better word, this was a truly magical series.

Završilo se moje druženje sa Harijem i moram priznati da sam pomalo tužna. Ne rastaje mi se od ove čarobne družine.Nije baš sve bilo sjajno... Na trenutke dosadno... Na trenutke frustrirajuće... Nervirala sam se uz nepotrebne stvari i ta „zatišja pred buru“, ali bi mi kraj svake knjige uvek popravio utisak. Sve u svemu, baš sam uživala da jurim za Harijevim stopama, sa ili bez njegovog ogrtača, da virim iz Hermionine torbice, da tiho bodrim Rona da iskaže svoju ljubav...Da ne bih pokvarila doživljaj nekome ko tek počinje da čita ovaj serijal, napisaću samo „zauvek“, a vi ostali ćete znati o kome govorim. Sve vreme sam imala osećaj. Sve vreme sam znala da kod njega ima nešto više nego što se vidi na prvi pogled, da on krije nešto posebno duboko ispod svog lika...19 godina kasnije... Prava divnoća... Kako sam se tu raspekmezila...Pa, to je to, moje magijsko putovanje je završeno. Iskrcavam se iz Hogvorts Ekspresa, gledajući neku novu generaciju čarobnjaka kako započinju svoje putovanje. Krećem ka izlazu sa perona 9 i 3/4 i osvrćem se poslednji put da pogledam svoj magični trio.Zbogom Hari, Rone i Hermiona...Druženje sa vama pamtiću „zauvek“...

It is time to put aside the Harry Potter series for a while and move on again, only to come back to it in a while to re-read it once more. I could never do these books justice by writing a review. What these books mean to so many people couldn't possibly be put into words. It has, once again, been an emotional rollercoaster filled with magic, mystery, moments and more. I feel honoured that I get to be a part of Harry’s life and live with him as he makes friends, loves and solves the big puzzle that is Lord Voldemort. The books take me away from reality, to a better, magical place and make me forget about all my problems. For that, I will always be grateful. Thank you, J.K. Rowling.I will forever be waiting for my Hogwarts acceptance letter.

Relevance AlertThis is not a review of the book.My comments specifically relate to a scene in and a song from the soundtrack to the first Deathly Hallows film.Sexuality Content WarningI originally posted a version of my comments in a GR discussion about sexuality and Harry Potter.If you are the sort of reader who thinks these two issues should never be associated with each other, please do not read on. I don't want to spoil your world view.Sexuality, Adolescence and Harry PotterOne of the funny things about the original discussion and the response to it is the lack of recognition of how important sexuality actually (and overtly) is to HP, especially later in the series.It defies me how people expect someone to write about or think about or progress through adolescence without considering sex or sexuality.Heartstring Wands and Love TrianglesFor me, HP is a love triangle in which there is enormous sexual tension around who will end up with Hermione by the time they escape the chains of adolescence.Obviously, JKR for her own reasons avoids the obvious temptation to let Harry end up with Hermione.However, right up until the last moment, there is some doubt as to whether Ron will get the girl.It's totally misguided to think that HP's adolescent audience isn't right on top of this issue.In fact, they're probably way ahead of most adults in the audience (including me).Let's DanceIn the first Deathly Hallows film, Harry and Hermione dance together, while Ron remains banished in the wild.This was a tipping point in the story, when Hermione might possibly have reversed her sexual selection.When I saw the film, a whole group of kids burst out laughing in this scene.I still don't know whether I missed something (was it Harry's seriousness or clumsiness?), but I was too busy concentrating on the soundtrack and trying to work out its significance.The Ship Song[I wrongly thought] the song was Nick Cave's "The Ship Song", which was the last thing I expected to hear in a HP film.It's a great melody, but if you have a look at the lyrics, you have to wonder what was intended by the director, at least.http://www.stlyrics.com/songs/n/nickc...Did Harry create a "little mystery" with Hermione?Did Hermione loose her dogs on Harry? Or let her hair hang down?Did Harry have to remove her wings, so that she could try to fly in her own right?Did Hermione have to escape Harry's legendary pull, so she could find happiness?I wish I could have asked those kids.Post Script:I just asked my 12 year old daughter why people laughed at that scene, and she said (in this order) "because they weren't together" (i.e., a recognised couple) and "because they were goofy". Original Review: February, 2011

I liked it. I really did. I laughed, I cheered, I said "Holy SHIT!" at least twice.... I even got a little choked up at some points. All in all, I'd say it was a successful end to the series. Ms. Rowling deserves to take a little time off and enjoy basking in the glow of the knowledge that she has not only written seven successful books in ten years, but created an entire world that is big enough to fit hundreds more.Anyway, about this actual book. It felt a lot longer than the rest of them did, probably because of the format change - no more Hogwarts, no more Quidditch, points gained, points lost, detentions with Snape and all that. Our Heroes were kept on the run for pretty much the entire book, so that by the time you get to the climax you think, "Wow, did they do all that in just 500 pages? A wedding, a break-in at the Ministry, a break-in at Gringotts, a major battle in the Malfoy mansion, a brush with death at Godrick's Hollow and all that in just 500 pages? Hot damn...."Speaking of Gringotts, that's one of the many reasons I liked this book. Rowling told us in book one that you'd have to be a fool to break into Gringotts, and most authors would require you to take it on their word. But she went and showed us, and came up with a hell of a scenario.As much fun as it was finding out that Dumbledore was just as obnoxious in his youth as most of us are was cool, it did feel a bit forced. The entire scene where Aunt Muriel lectured Doge on Dumbledore's youthful indiscretions and mysterious family goings-on should have just WARNING: EXPOSITION stamped on it in red. I'm not sure what the purpose of it was, other than to humanize Dumbledore and to give us a lead-in to the Deathly Hallows. Which I'm still of two minds about anyway. As cool as the idea was, I don't think we should have had to wait until this late in the series to find out about them. At the end of Half-Blood Prince, Harry's path is straight and sure - Horicruxes all the way - and now we have this distraction in the Hallows. Also deserving of the EXPOSITION stamp: Snape's final memories in the Pensieve and Harry's last conversation with Dumbledore.I don't know, maybe it was to give him the choice between destroying Voldemort and defeating Voldemort or something. I haven't really processed it all yet, since I did read the book at approximately Mach 4, which is not the recommended reading speed. Perhaps I'll be more comfortable with the Hallows in the re-read.And then there was the camping sequence. I get it - they're lost in more ways than one. I suspect this may have been an artifact of the one book = one year format. It was probably also meant to keep us in a sense of heightened danger, but that's pretty much where I felt the book drag.Okay, now that I'm done nit-picking...DEATH!Ms. Rowling said in an interview that this book "isn't a bloodbath."Oh really? 1. Hedwig - This was Rowling saying, "I'm not fucking around. I've just killed Harry's most faithful companion, his tether to the world in which he belongs. Imagine what else I'm planning." 2. Mad-Eye Mooney - A fallen warrior, just like the chapter title says. I think Mad-Eye would have been surprised to survive this battle - of all the Order of the Phoenix he seemed most in tune with the reality that they faced. 3. Dobby - This was where I got choked up, I don't mind telling you. Dobby didn't deserve a knife in the heart. Hell, he didn't deserve to die at all. Having said that, he died very well, and his death was handled with dignity. It was also another reminder from Rowling - "See? I killed off another completely innocent character. You people have no idea what you're in for...." 4. Wormtail - Devious bastard. Good riddance. I would have liked to have seen more of his super-hand in action, though. What was it truly capable of? 5. Crabbe - We finally hear him speak! And we find out he's been hiding his light under a bushel. Too bad it then proceeded to burn up the bushel, and the room it was in. 6. Fred - I hate being right. Dammit. 7. Snape - Ah yes, Snape. This was done well. She kept us wondering right up to the end, and it paid off. I seriously thought he was on the dark side, but that's probably because I have no faith in real human beings, much less fictional ones. Now since I'm not a fan-fictioner, or a 'shipper, I never caught on to the idea that Snape and Lily might have had any relationship prior to Hogwarts. I thought her reaction to James' hazing was simply out of compassion for her fellow human being. I had no idea. Anyway, it's good to be wrong. Knowing everything will certainly make re-reads a little more interesting.... 8. Remus and 9. Tonks - There seems to be a lot of anger out there about the way they died - off-screen and without much impact. A lot of people appear to have a lot invested in their relationship, which surprised me. I thought they were an interesting couple, and the idea of their child was very fertile ground for future storytelling, but their relationship was never a central storyline to begin with. Every step of it was happing without the reader's knowledge. It was just revealed to us through Harry. Their courtship, their wedding, their child and their death, none of it was meant to be - and I know I'm going to get snapped at for this - important. They were a nice couple, but as we've already seen, "nice" doesn't exempt you from dying in this book. If you want to get analytical about it, it is probable that the orphaning of young Ted Lupin was meant to provide a positive mirror to Harry's own experience: here is another child of a wizarding family whose parents were taken from him before he even knew who they were. Unlike Harry, though, Ted will have a loving, supportive extended family to look after him and see that he's brought up right. For his part, Harry will be able to redeem Sirius in that he can be the godfather that Sirius never was. So while the deaths of Remus and Tonks was regrettable, it was not wrong. 10. Colin Creevey - The grace note. One last reminder from Rowling that she plays no favorites with the supporting cast, and a reminder that being innocent and nice and likable won't be enough to save you. See Remus and Tonks. 11. Voldemort - Definitely dead, if the epilogue is to be believed. So there.That's a pretty impressive body count, not including all the nameless characters who died and the people who only got seriously maimed. And it was this willingness to be brutal to her characters that made me love Rowling all the more....Let's see, what else.... Yes, Mrs. Weasley is my hero, and hopefully we can get Sigourney Weaver to play her in the movie. And Neville finally lived up to his promise. He could have been in Harry 's place, and he finally proved that he could have been every bit the hero that Harry was. Bravo for him. And his grandmother kicks ass in every way, shape and form....I loved the callback to Sorcerer's Stone. In that book, Harry, Ron and Hermione were trying to get past Devil's Snare, which can be repelled by fire. Hermione laments that they don't have any wood, to which Ron replies, "have you gone mad? Are you a witch or not?" In this book, while trying to get past the Whomping Willow, Ron moans that if they only had Crookshanks with them, they could hit the secret knot and freeze the limbs. To which Hermione replies, "Crookshanks? Are you a wizard or what?" Bless Rowling's heart for trusting us to be paying enough attention to get that joke.I really wish we could have seen Dolores Umbridge get her comeuppance. Imagine this scene from chapter 31, The Battle of Hogwarts.... Umbridge dashed as quickly as her legs would take her through the carnage. She was nearly hit by blast after blast of green light coming from wands carelessly aimed. Her thoughts ran on one track - I have to get out of here. She turned the corner and ran into a resilient, pinkish wall. She barely had time to register what it was before Grawp clenched his fist around her. "Release me!" she screamed. "I am the senior assistant to the Minister of -" And then Grawp ate her.Ahh, the poetry. She was an evil word-that-rhymes-with-runt and deserved to be punished.Oh, also, Pansy Parkinson: "But he's right there!" Winner of Hogwarts' first Slowest on the Uptake Award. That was a great moment. I would have liked to have seen a few of her fellow Slytherins stand up as well, but I guess it's tough to go against your own House.The epilogue was a good idea, if rushed. There was a flood of information that needed to be processed in only a few pages, and I see no reason why she couldn't have let it out for a few more pages. It's not like we were going to get to "Nineteen Years Later...." and just give up because the epilogue was too long. But it serves its purpose - it lets us know that after all that we'd seen, everything eventually works out. Not right away, and not perfectly - note that after all the talk about not allowing themselves to be divided, there are still houses at Hogwarts and Slytherin is still the "evil" one - but all in all everything's okay.Which brings us to my final thought, at least for now: I said at the beginning that Rowling has earned herself a nice break. She's put in a lot of work and reaped massive rewards, both tangible and intangible. But I suspect that she won't be able to rest for long. There is so much Story there, just waiting to be told. The fans will certainly take a stab at it, and I wouldn't be surprised if someone's already written a threesome between Albus Potter, Scorpius Malfoy and Teddy Lupin.Anyway, that's a whole lot more than I was planning to write, and I'm pretty sure I left things out. But there it is, my thoughts on Deathly Hallows. A good end to a good series.

After all this time? Always.No tengo palabras para explicar lo mucho que me encantó y ame este libro y toda la saga en general, todo mundo conoce ya esta saga y si no la han leído deberían hacerlo y comprobar porque la mayoría la ama.Este último libro fue simplemente perfecto y lleno de todo lo que un buen libro necesita, sin duda alguna Rowling hizo un gran trabajo y todo se vio reflejado en el éxito que tuvo porque se lo merece. Un gran libro, un gran final de saga y en pocas palabras un libro perfecto.

I wasn't happy with my previous review, and decided to re-write it.I will round all of my dislikings of this book to three things;1. The PlotholesOh, JK Rowling. You and your plotholes. Firstly, we have the issue brought up many times by others -- the time turner. I assume Minerva McGonagall had more of those, since she was able to just give Hermione one. Wouldn't they come in handy when everyone was dying? Why not turn back the clock and warn someone about what was going to happen? After all, as shown in the fourth book time is not set in the Harry Potter world.Secondly, we have the confusion of the ending. How did Harry come back to life? Can someone explain this to me? I thought his mother's love broke when he turned seventeen. How did Voldemort die, but he lived? Why can't Volemort kill a seventeen year old boy with seemingly infinite magical knowledge? The first four books it was cute how Harry kept escaping, but then it started to get confusing. Is there another magic at work here, besides Dumbldedores love? Can we make this more clear? Sigh. Believe me, love is cool and all, but love won't solve all your problems. What about hard work and perseverance? We have a little of that, but not as much as there should be. Love is the answer to everything, I guess, but there comes a time when you need to be practical. That time is when people are dying and you know, you're seventeen and not eleven and you're a chosen one and hey, things are starting to get serious.2. Hermione Granger's Lonely Hearts ClubI really wanted to use that. Moving on,I admit, I ship her with Harry. However, that is not why I'm miffed at her ending up with Ron. From book one, Ronald Weasly has belittled her, underestimated her, called her stupid, annoying, hinted that she was ugly, ignored her, yet begged her to do his homework, and promptly not proved that he deserved her affections at all.And yet, we have book seven, they're supposed to be in love????Now, I'm not going to pretend like she hasn't been mean to him too, but let's face it -- Hermione was never a jerk towards Ron without reason. He usually always did something to provoke her first, like call her a know it all, ask her to the Yule ball at the last moment, say that she has no friends, imitate her, act as if he was above her and generally be a prat with the "emotional range of a teaspoon" as she so fittingly states.We are not given any reason as to why she should be in love with Ron. We are just told that she is. That bugs me.3. Why Do Donuts Have To DieMaybe that last title was a bit random. By donuts, I mean excessive amounts of minor characters.I know it isn't meant to be this way, but to me as the reader, it seems that JK Rowling killed off a lot of minor characters to sub for one major character. Since I didn't like any of the minor characters she killed off, I guess it seemed gratuitous to me. I mean, I just didn't care that much. Granted, there are casualties in war, but it seemed like she was showing this off at the end to seem badass. It didn't work. It was just annoying.BONUS TIME!4. Some Scars Can't Be SeenWhere's the emotional scarring? Everybody ends up happily married at the end, as if a horrible war hadn't taken place but twenty years earlier. They were tortured for the love of god -- some of them were even locked in a dark cellar for weeks on end! Tell me that isn't scarring. Please do.In conclusion,I gave the book one star for a reason. Despite that, there are some things I did like about it;1. Snape!2. Dean, Luna, and Oliver.3. ...Snape?4. We got a lot of Harry/Hermione bonding scenes, even if they were ignored.I'm sure there were other things, but I can't remember them/am too lazy to go into them right now.Keep in mind, I like the Harry Potter series and think JK Rowling is a pretty decent author. But this book just didn't do it for me.

“Every second he breathed, the smell of the grass, the cool air on his face, was so precious: To think that people had years and years, time to waste, so much time it dragged, and he was clinging to each second.” I'm sure everyone knows what I mean when I say it's both a good and a bad thing that I've finished the series. Good because I've experienced it all, bad because it's now over.I knew the plot before going in because the last movie was the freshest in my mind, so I braced myself for the deaths that were coming, revelations that jumped out to reveal themselves, and the creative wrap-up. Rowling used her imagination at top form to show the hidden natures of some of the characters we previously viewed as villains, backstories of heroes, and twists in escaping death and losing for Harry Potter himself.Since it was the last book, it was the darkest as the battle reigned supreme for Hogwarts and Harry and his friends - they finally had to face that final fight, leaving no one unscathed. My favorite part was definitely at the school when the battle was waging. McGonagall remains a favorite, I wish we knew about her story afterward. Bellatrix versus Mrs Weasley was an epic time, Neville standing up for his friends, and of course the sad, sad deaths that happened to some series regulars.Truthfully some of the down parts were a little dull at times - Harry and Hermione and Ron wandering around had some interesting scenes though, such as the snake Nagiri in the Hollows scene being so creepy it was like something written out of a horror book. The scene where Harry finds the sword was awesome as well, but it just seemed like a little magic was missing when the gang was separated so long from the school and other characters. Those characters, classes, school, hiding from teachers...all of that was a strong binding substance for the story being as great as it was. It would be nice to know more in the epilogue about what happened to some surviving characters, such as the Weasley's besides Ron and Percy, Luna and her father, and a few others. Hopefully Harry kept Kreacher around as a personal house elf for life. The resolution was sweet since it showed the future and who the main characters got together with, as well as Harry giving an important tribute to two main characters in the naming of his son, but it did feel a little off for some reason, not sure why. It almost felt a little forced. It answers marriage and kids but what about careers and other stuff? I know some wanted Harry to end up with another girl in the series, but I'm happy with how it ended. Even J.K. Rowling herself now says she wish she had done that differently, but I think she made the right decision the first time.As evil as Voldemort was, he made a memorable villain. On the other side of the coin, Harry and his friends made intelligent and worthy heroes. I'll miss the school and the stories - everything from laughing and learning, to fighting and plotting. I'll miss the characters who were killed off, and wonder what happened to those left behind. I still think it would have been more interesting had a certain professor lived and played a part in the ending.Of course this series couldn't last forever, but it's good the author wrote seven lengthy books that are impossible to forget. Long live in the magic.

What can I say but genius? All along I have considered myself a mild Harry Potter fan, but once you get to the end and Rowling wraps up all the minute details she plants from book one you cannot help but be amazed at her creativity. Building on each of the books, writing each one at a slightly higher level as the characters grow up, all the details, and lets not forget the insignificant matter of the entire world evolving to hold a joint consciousness of Harry Potter. Children's literature has boomed and for that alone I give her immense credit.We are finally rewarded with Ron and Hermione. I am finally justified in Snape being my favorite character. We get to see the emotion to McGonagall and the history of Dumbledore. And of course, we finally, after 4100 pages, get to see the face off between good and evil, see what powers truly lie in Harry, and discover how strong our own allegiance to the boy really are. Rowling satisfies both camps on Harry's fate (without having to scar the boy with a task like Snape's) and even me who cared more about Snape's destiny than Harry's. Yes the book is long and there are a few scenes in the Forest of Deans and at Bill & Fleur's that drag, but they are spaced out and there is so much else packed in to reward you for a few pages spent just as frustrated as the hero trio. Besides my favorite scene happens in that lonely forest when Harry finds the sword. But once the action winds back to Hogwarts, the book is nearly impossible to put down. The wand loyalties could have been explained better, but overall the complexity of the plot and resolution were impressive.The emotion in the book is so strong. Maybe it's that after all these years and all these books, you feel so committed to the characters, but you can't help but feel so full of emotion, and even I'll admit it cry, at the height of the story. I don't think there's an emotion you don't feel in reading this book, but the strongest one is in the end when you have to close the book and say goodbye to the chapter in your life tied up in the story. I can't read this book without feeling sad at the end that it is over.My favorite thing about book 7 is the way it ends, back at King's Cross where your view shifts from seeing Harry's adventures as a lost 11-year-old about to have a fantastic journey to a caring adult guiding a broken boy through the pain and challenges he is about to endure and conquer on this spectacular journey. What can I say but genius?

Say, Harry Potter is not a movie or a series. Say, it's all real and you're part of that magical world.Say, Cedric Diggory was your boyfriend, and Voldemort killed him. Or if your a guy, Moaning Myrtle was your girlfriend and Tom Riddle set a Basilisk on her.You'll hope that DA would win over the Dark Side, and that Harry gets to punish all the Death Eaters with a hundred Cruciatus Curse-for each Death Eater that is- won't you?You'll dream for the day that you'll get to see Bellatrix and Lucius choose Killing curse just because they can't take anymore Cruciatus curse.You're so angry you wanted to kill them yourself. You want to avenge Dumbledore's death.But on your way to Hogsmeade you came across this...................[image error]Oh no!! After all these years they aren't enemies at all! They've been friends all along. All these years of believing they loathed each other. All these years and Voldemort has got a nose all along. Well Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows is something like this. All those years of waiting for that Epic epic finale, you get 2 paragraphs of a fight between Voldemort and Harry. I was expecting Harry would use the killing curse at least. But he didn't. The upside though is he used Cruciatus Curse on the Carrows. HAH!!!!! Ooohh I loved that part. Makes me swell with happiness.I don't mind that J.K killed awful lot of characters,(Although I'd be happy to exchange Cho Chang for Fred) I think it was needed to show that the war was indeed gruesome. Because to NOT kill a lot of characters will make DH a wizarding and early version of Breaking Dawn. Where all the characters lived to tell the tale. No, that would be too painfully idealistic. Idealism is not in any way J.K's way of writing. If Harry Potter was too perfect to the point of unreal-ism, then it wouldn't have been the best selling series of all times.I didn't like the ending so much. But the whole book was so great, still epic. Kept me on the edge of my seat. It would hurt me if I give HP less than five stars, and honestly it doesn't deserve anything less than 5 stars. Hell I would even give it a million stars if I could.

The conclusion to a truly epic series. I’m so happy I made this re-read. All the wonderful memories, the great moments now … Although I usually remember all details the first time, there were some here that I had forgotten about and revisiting them was a delight!After the death of Albus Dumbledore at the end of book #6 Harry, Ron and Hermione have not returned to Hogwarts. Instead, Harry goes back to Privet Drive one last time and then goes to the Burrow. Of course, he is being chased all the time, leading to two tragic deaths right at the beginning of the book (in fact, the casualness with which one of the two was mentioned almost broke my heart). There are some lighter moments in this that give a bit of a respite (like Bill and Fleur’s wedding), but the main tone is that of darkness, loss and action, naturally.While being on the run after the aforementioned wedding, Harry finally puts most of the puzzle pieces together (with the help of not just the smartest witch of his age but also of Kreacher who became mighty sweet) and starts the hunt for the Horcruxes. Between the mad dashes we get a lot of background story, most notably the missing pieces about Albus Dumbledore himself, all the connections to the titular Deathly Hallows and Voldemorts greatest weakness (these bits of history were actually the best part for me, always, not just now that we have the Fantastic Beasts movie(s)).Again, there are some moments that were conveyed better in the movies which came as a bit of a surprise (but it was fun seeing how the movies and books complete each other). Such as the dragon that was chained up in Gringotts giving the impression it knew exactly who freed it and that the kids were sitting on its back so it flew lower to let them off at the lake; the Patronus being such a special feat of magic that not just any happy memory will do to conjure it (a pet peeve of mine with the books ever since book #3); the Grey Lady giving Harry the riddle about the Room Of Requirement; McGonagall being even more kick-ass (without help); and probably most notably (view spoiler)[Dobby’s death that was heartbreaking in the book but translated even better in the movie (which is weird considering that Dobby hadn’t made an appearance between movies #2 and #7.1 so there was never the same kind of redemption as in the books) (hide spoiler)].What I cannot forgive, that they changed for the movies, is the story of Harry’s wand. For anyone who doesn’t remember: Harry’s wand gets snatched almost in half when Harry and Hermione make their escape from Godric’s Hollow – both in the book and the movie. The difference: in the book the core is not broken! And in the end, (view spoiler)[having the Elder Wand, Harry uses it only once – to repair his old and loyal wand (successfully) – before giving it up (in a better/more intelligent/more plausible way than in the movie as well) (hide spoiler)]. That, in my opinion, is crucial. Which is exactly why it borders on blasphemy that it was changed in the movie!Then there were moments that were brilliant but missing from the movies completely, like Neville’s gran (bwahahaha!), Dudley’s goodbye to Harry, Percy finally coming around (and the twins‘ reaction to him coming back). It was small moments like these that glued the action-packed sequences together. Because all the action and the stakes being so high, of course, means that not everyone is going to make it out alive and the readers need to care. In fact, there is quite a number of people who were important supporting characters that didn’t survive the Battle of Hogwarts (most notably (view spoiler)[Fred Weasley (hide spoiler)] for whom I mourned almost the most). And that is one of the greatest strengths of the series if you ask me: even after all these years readers like me cannot stop thinking about this world and its inhabitants, wondering what happened afterwards, obsessing over every little detail throughout the seven books/movies and never waivering in our love for it all. That love means that no matter how many times we read or listen to the books, the tragic events are never less of a blow, the funny moments are never any less funny. The writing is crisp and vivid as it was the very first time and the entire series is a fixed part of the readers‘ life (no matter how old one was when reading it for the first time).

The Harry Potter series as a whole never really impressed me as much as the hype had led me to expect. Or even close.I can't say I was necessarily disappointed by this book, nor was I pleasantly surprised. The Deathly Hallows has its fair share of weaknesses as well as strengths and in the end it's just...meh.That's it.Meh.It left no lasting impression on me. Just meh. Rowling's strengths lie with developing sympathetic characters (albeit not very interesting ones), writing entertainingly enough for the reader to suspend disbelief in spite of all those numerous holes in her world, and, of course, creating something that appeals so largely to its audience.Rowling's world is nothing particularly special, and yet, it's hard not to be a little "awww I wish I can go to Hogwarts!" and "omg that's so cool!" So yes, part of the reason why I like this series is because it appeals to my inner fangirl. You could say I enjoy these books for all the wrong reasons. I don't make much of the "OMG AMAAAAZING PLOT" like its die-hard fans so ardently proclaim, nor do I find much to admire in the so-called "deep, complex, and strong" characters. I mean, yeah, it's all right...but what makes Harry Potter special? Why is it a masterpiece? Why should I like it, see it, approach it as a classic? (Oh, I'm not kidding. We've all heard the repetitive "Harry Potter will withstand the test of time" crap.)Writing, in spite of its subjectivity and diversity, can also be a precise art. You can tell when authors know what they're doing and when they don't. In this case, whether Rowling finds her stride when writing or not is quite obvious to the reader; it fluctuates from time to time, some places being stronger and others being weaker and more lazily written.Many fans would say that Rowling is an excellent prose writer--at the very least, "it's soooo much better than Twilight" etc. etc.--but is she really?Words and language should be well placed with consistency and precision--each word should serve some kind of purpose, regardless of whether it ties into moving the plot forward--but also with style. In this case it's pretty obvious what Rowling was going for: a simplistic style that was nonetheless vibrant and lively, quick, to-the-point, and basically what she sees as the best possible style for children's stories. But as Harold Bloom so eloquently puts it, "Rowling's mind is so governed by clichés and dead metaphors that she has no other style of writing."To add to that, Rowling not only overuses those clichés and dead metaphors, but she uses them so flippantly it's very jarring and irritating to the reader. She doesn't place words with a purpose, she places them with carelessness. And that is what I would call lazy writing.You could, in fact, apply that criticism to the rest of this book. Superficially, it looks like Rowling knows exactly what she's doing. She weaves an unoriginal but complex plot, with elements threading together intricately so on the surface, it looks like a work of art. A masterpiece. Complexity is good...right?Well, no. Complexity in and of itself is not good, nor is it bad. In this case how Rowling applied it I would consider to be more than a little haphazard and...hasty. I found HP to be a bit overcomplicated in some ways. That complexity doesn't have a real justification for it, and therefore feels a little overdone and forced. On the surface, like I said, Rowling is a brilliant and creative author who knows exactly what she's doing, but scrutinizing this book, the text easily betrays her lack of confidence as a writer. She pulls plot devices out of the world on a whim so frequently it becomes extremely annoying after a while. I like characters who get out of bad situations on their own merits, not on the merits of the setting. World-building shouldn't be used as a resource for devices to move the story along, it should be used as exactly what it is: a world. It's not there for the author to be lazy, it's there to enrich the story and the reader's experience.The plot elements and devices--Horcruxes, Hallows, etc.--are so last-minute, it's hard not to imagine Rowling going on the Internet, finding out that people had guessed all her "twists," and throwing in a last-minute punch in an attempt to raise more suspense, in addition to lots of red herrings nearly thrown in the reader's path with a complete lack of subtlety, but in the end it's nothing more than frazzling.Plot twists seem to exist more for shock value instead of being driven from the story. Look, it's really annoying when the author catches you at a "Gotcha suckers!" moment and you feel like you're being cheated. Aside from being rather belittling and insulting to my intelligence, it's ultimately very pointless. Any benefit that could be gotten out of shocking the reader and nothing more is completely short-term. Character development is just the same--uncertain, last-minute, and rushed. I'm not exactly sure how Harry and his friends develop as real people. I mean, sure, it's easy to point out how Rowling puts them through hell and beats them up at every opportunity, but horrifying experiences do not instantly constitute character development. In this book especially, there was also a loss of intimacy with the characters--the emotional distance between me as a reader and them as characters was so great that I just didn't care about them.Rowling seems to have a little trouble manipulating tone and pacing. The lead-in and buildup to the climax was so jostling and distracting I didn't even realize the climax had come until they started celebrating the defeat of Voldemort. The events building up to the climax were dragged out, while the climax itself wasn't fleshed out to be rewarding enough to compensate for all the dullness and dragging that came before it. Combined, it made for a very unbalanced story structure and haphazard book as a whole.The morality and "life lessons that are good for children to learn" are muddled, contrived and forced. Oftentimes I felt that Rowling was deliberately shaping her story and characters to fit the "ideal" book and "strong, likable characters," rather than letting those merits develop naturally as the novel progressed. Doing what she did--trying to force her books to fit the mold of society's standards instead of, if she so desired, letting it happen on their own--just makes the novel look so much more fake and lazy as a result.Basically, my main complaint with this book can be boiled down to this: Rowling doesn't know what she's talking about. She seriously doesn't. Everything is so disjointed and strewn all over the place it's pretty obvious that Rowling wrote this not to write a mind-blowing amazing piece of literature, but because she was afraid to disappoint her fans. She got caught up in that fear and focused more on playing it safe, and guess what? The novel suffered because of it.As a reader, it's frustrating when you can tell the author feels incompetent. Not incompetent, but feels incompetent. Rowling doesn't seem confident as a writer, and her writing betrays that to me personally. If the author is isn't sure, then how will the reader ever be? If Rowling isn't willing to take risks, how will this installment ever be anything but just that--safe? Mediocre? Just okay? Nothing more than that?I liked this book. I truly, honestly did. But my enjoyment did not come from this book being actually amazing, it came from its subjective entertainment value. I would call this book an adequate one, not an extraordinary one.

Too expository, same disjointed plotting as ever. Nothing particularly surprising or shocking. Gains more strength through familiar characters and nostalgia than from new developments or understandings. Smacks of the improbably untragic wars of any happy ending; though Rowling's wealth of secondary characters provides a little fodder.Character growth in the likes of Dumbledore, Neville, Kreacher, and the predictably D'arcy-like Snape provide the most interest in the book. Perhaps Rowling was more concerned with closure than constructing a more complex story. Then again, she may just be glad to be free of it after all these years. I do congratulate her on getting out while the getting was good.The epilogue particularly felt like an attempt to make an utter and unapologetic finish to the story. Unfortunately, it will likely not keep the questions at bay. I, myself, couldn't but wonder if the older Harry might have adopted a fatherly middle-class mustache. I'll have to pen a letter.Despite the claims that the books were plotted out and foreshadowed from the beginning, we get a lot of last-minute additions to the world to build toward a convenient plot coupon ending. Rowling was, more-or-less, beyond the power of editors, and I wish she had used that power to write an interesting, audacious book, but this ending was very safe, and free from the surprising plot twists Rowling sometimes managed.I guess she was trying to please her fans, but she had a lot of people to please. Hopefully she pleased some of them, but I was disappointed that as the series neared its end, it became less quirky and character-driven, and more predictable and cliche.My Fantasy Book Suggestions

A few minutes after midnight on the release day for The Most Overhyped Book Of All Time, I logged in to Wikipedia and skimmed the plot to see which characters did in fact get killed at the end. Evidently some contributor had had it all wrapped up, and was just waiting for the starting pistol. The next day, I told several Potter fans what I'd done, and quite enjoyed the moment of dead silence that typically greeted my announcement.I'm sorry if this was disrespectful towards the author, but I wasn't burning books, or publicly releasing spoilers, or anything like that. I later borrowed my son's copy and actually read it. With competent editing, I think Potter 7 could perhaps have been quite reasonable. I wonder if J.K. Rowling was genuinely pleased with her work, or just with the enormous amount of money it made for her? My impression was that she wasn't really having fun after the third or fourth volume, but I could be wrong.

I waited 9 years for Rowling to do the right thing and kill off the Christ Figure, you know, like the *professional* writers do. Don't get me wrong, Harry was my favorite character--brave, deeply loyal, naturally talented--all wonderful qualities not meant for this foul Earth. I wanted him to die in his prime, to be celebrated in song, like all the great heros before him. Alas...Rowling didn't write so much a novel, as she did a Hollywood screenplay! Complete with lame wincing juvenile lines like the one uttered by Molly Weasley to Bellatrix LeStrange in the Battle for Hogwarts, "Not my daughter, you BITCH!" A line meant to draw applause, cheers, and laughter from a bunch of teenagers in a darkened movie theater, not a line that would have been used by the prim and proper mother, Molly Weasley, that we grew to know and love in books 1-6.The book could have been better edited as there were long stretches of BORING reading throughout. It's as if Rowling just ran out of creative juices in the end and chose to let her fans write the final book for her. She inserted "PotterWatch" as a nod to the PotterCasters(PotterCast and MuggleCast), and she wrote in a nude scene for Harry Potter, as a nod to Daniel Radcliffe's nude stint in Equus. The whole *camping out in the forest waiting for something to happen* part was NOT something I expected after Book 6, when it was shown with such great care how Voldemort had hidden the locket horcrux. I can't believe they are making 2 films out of this, the crappiest book in the series!Oh, and that Epilogue, where to begin? If Rowling sent out apology letters to all her fans for writing it, that still wouldn't be enough of an atonement! The woman should be tarred, feathered, drawn, and quartered for that criminally putrid Epilogue! The visual of a middle aged Harry Potter waiting at the train station to get to his 9 to 5 job was the let-down of the century. I loved Harry because he was special and because of his aura of destiny! I loved that, despite his emotionally abusive childhood, he chose to become a decent human being, instead of following Tom Riddle's path of evil and bitterness! I loved that, when presented with a challenge, he almost always chose to do the right and moral thing, over what was easy. I didn't want to see him become a regular, boring adult, with a lame, humdrum life, he was too talented, too moral, too heroic for all of that mundane crap!

Trigger warnings: death, violence, physical injury, hate speak about minority groups, torture, physical abuse.21/10/2017I started a marathon reread of the Harry Potter series thirteen days ago in preparation for a Harry Potter trivia night (we came second, for those of you who care). I made it to within 15 pages of the end before I had to run out the door or risk missing the tram. HARRUMPH. Anyway. I finished my marathon reread when I got home from trivia at 11pm. I cried over the scene between Harry and Ron. Again. I cried over Fred. Again. I *nearly* cried over Luna and the patronuses scene again, and only didn't because I already had my make up on and no time to fix it if I ended up with mascara all over my damn face. I love everything about this freaking book. The end. 24/12/2016I cried. Again. But over weird things this time?? I cried over the scene where Harry's struggling to produce a patronus because it's the middle of the Battle of Hogwarts and he can't think of anything happy, and Luna - patronus leading the way - tells him that they're all still there, they're all still fighting. FEELINGS. FEEEEEEEEEEEEEEELINGS. 31/12/2015Frankly, I'm impressed that I managed to cram this one into the last three days of the year, because I desperately wanted to finish the series this year. And I did - with four hours to spare. *high fives self*For some reason, this reread brought a hell of a lot of emotions with it. The developing relationship between Ron and Hermione gave me feels. Harry's reaction to Lupin turning up gave me feels. All the deaths gave me feels, obviously. Neville proving himself to be a true Gryffindor and his grandmother's pride in him gave me feels. McGonagall's pride and heartbreak over Harry gave me feels. Dumbledore's backstory gave me feels. And I may have broken down and sobbed during the scene between Ron and Harry that I mentioned below. Basically, this book is perfection, and it's hands down my favourite of the series. Now let's just go ahead and pretend that Snape redemption plot never happened... 29/6/2014Everything I said last time around still stands. But one of the things I find most interesting about Deathly Hallows is getting to see the other side of Dumbledore. In the other six books, he's basically presented as this massive force for good, who would never make dubious decisions or do the wrong thing or endanger his students. But here? Here we see that Dumbledore operated in the grey areas of morality as much as anyone. Which is one of those interesting things that comes with age - realising that your teachers and your heroes aren't infallible. They're human. 18/3/2013There are literally no words for how much I adore this book. It takes a lot in a book to make me cry (almost nothing, however, when it comes to movies and TV shows...), and yet Deathly Hallows reduces me to a weeping mess every time I read it. That said, the epilogue grates a little more every time - it just feels slightly sloppy or a little too neat and tidy or SOMETHING.That said, I love how there are so many tendrils to the story that have been gradually developed over the previous six books, and how expertly they're all pulled together here. Neville becomes more of a BAMF with every reading, and I will never not cheer for Molly Weasley screaming "NOT MY DAUGHTER, YOU BITCH" at Bellatrix. While I know a lot of people get all "Harry Potter and the Prolonged Camping Trip" about the central portion of the book, those same people likely would have been upset or annoyed if they had, as Harry yells at Ron, been finding a Horcrux a week and home safe and sound by Christmas. Besides, the prolonged camping trip leads to what is arguably my favourite moment in the entire series - Ron destroying the locket, then breaking down in tears, and Harry saying "She's like my sister. I love her like a sister and I reckon she feels the same way about me. It's always been like that. I thought you knew." It's such a simple moment, such a small thing. But for me, it says so much about Ron, about Harry, and about the honesty that underpins their friendship. In summary, twenty years from now, people will say to me "After all this time?". And my reply will be "Always."
