5++++++++++++++++++++++++++2001'de annemle sinemaya girdikten sonra 'hayır çıkmak istemiyorum, bir daha izleyelim!' dediğimi dün gibi hatırlarım. Hatta biz çıkarken karşı komşumuz Zeynep ablalar filme giriyordu. Ama konumuz bu değil :D Sırlar Odası'nı defalarca bir CD'ciden kiralayıp kuzenimle kaç kere izlediğimizi asla unutamam. Benim hayatımın büyük bir parçasıydı bu filmler. 5. filme kadar hiç aksatmadan izledim filmleri ama daha sonra kitaplarını okumaya karar verdim ve en az filmleri kadar iyi olduğunu gördüm.Bu son kitaba da başlarken çok heyecanlı ama aynı zamanda buruktum. J.K. Rowling'in beni hayal kırıklığına uğratmayacağını biliyordum. Seri müthiş, şanına yakışır bir finalle bitti fakat aklımda bir kaç soru var. Bir insan nasıl oluyor da tek başına her açıdan bu kadar kusursuz bir dünya yaratabiliyor? Bu nasıl bir hayal gücüdür? Rowling'in nasıl yetiştirildiğini merak ediyorum. Nasıl bir ortamda büyüdü? Bu son kitap ağzıma sıçtı. Bildiğin mahvetti beni. Tüm seri öyle bir bağlanmış, öyle bir kurgulanmış ki inanamıyorsunuz. 'Bir şey olmalı! Bir yerde bir kusur olmalı!' Ta ilk iki kitaba kadar geri dönüşlerin yapıldığı, burada başlayan olayların sonuçlandırıldığı ve aslında her şeyin çok farklı olduğunu mantıklı bir şekilde anlatılması kurgunun kusursuzluğu değil de nedir?Geriye dönüp baktığımda bir hazine görüyorum. Daima benimle olacak ve unutulmayacak bir hazine... Son 90 sayfada göz yaşlarıma engel olamadım. Tekrar tekrar ağladım. En çok Snape mahvetti beni sanırım. Başından beri nefret ettiğim o adam... Son 5 sayfayı ise zor okudum. Tek diyebileceğim orada keşke Luna'yı da görebilseydik. Ve teşekkürler J.K. Rowling... Keşke gerçek olsa dediğim kusursuz bir dünya yarattığın için teşekkürler. Her şey yolunda.
WHAT DO I DO NOW WITHOUT U??????????????

“Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all those who live without love.”
I want to make this final review about 
  Neville Longbottom
Let me explain why. A couple years ago, I had a very disturbing conversation with a Potterhead friend.Crazy friend of mine: "Did you know that Neville Longbottom was actually the real hero in Harry Potter's book?"Me: "WTF ?! O_o"This sounding more and more crazy friend of mine: "Yes, I read a theory that says that JK Rowling wrote this book to make us think that Harry was the hero, but in the end you realize that it has been Neville all along"After laughing at him and calling him crazy I went back to my business. But this idea stayed in my head for several days. I called all my Harry Potter's fan friends in the middle of the night and they all told me that this was nonsense and that I should go back to sleep.But this wasn't enough to get this theory out of my head, therefore, I decided back then to do a Potter-movies-athlon (I always need a good excuse). And I started to understand what he meant. Then I re-read all the books and I thought I needed Internet to help me understand better.I found an awesome article online which made me realize that might be right (you can check it here if you want), but basically it all starts with Sybill Trelawney's first prophecy that you can find below: 
  "The one with the power to vanquish the Dark Lord approaches... born to those who have thrice defied him, born as the seventh month dies... and the Dark Lord will mark him as his equal, but he will have power the Dark Lord knows not... and either must die at the hand of the other for neither can live while the other survives... the one with the power to vanquish the Dark Lord will be born as the seventh month dies..."
During the prophecy, Trelawney specified that the requirements for the boy of the prophecy who was capable of (but not necessary would) defeating the Dark Lord are the followings:- Male,- Born in the closing days of July of 1980,- His parents had defied Voldemort three times and lived to tell about it,- He would have a power that Voldemort was unable or unwilling to comprehend.And of course, the book being called Harry Potter, and him meeting all the requirements, we all assumed it refers to our Harry, but Neville Longbottom also meets all the requirements: he was born on 30 July, 1980, his parents Frank and Alice Longbottoms, are Aurors who had directly defied Voldemort on three separate occasions. However, on the contrary of James and Lilly Potter, Neville parent's are still alive, they were tortured into insanity with the Cruciatus Curse by a group of Death Eaters and were placed at St Mungo's Hospital for Magical Maladies and Injuries.Moreover, Neville proved himself by standing up to Voldemort and destroying his last Horcrux, Nagini. Harry couldn't have defeated Voldemort without Neville's action in the first place.
  “We’re all going to keep fighting, Harry. You know that?”
The second point that we can make us think that Neville is the true hero is the following idea, based on the fact that Harry Potter's generation is modeled on James Potter's. You can see it follows the same pattern with the following points:- Harry is like James, a leader of the group- Ron is like Sirus, a faithful friend- Hermione like Remus is really smart, a little bit outcast at first but then fully part of the group- And then Neville is Peter Pettigrew. Everyone is making fun of him. Clumsy and chubby.(- According to that theory, Ginny Weasley is Lilly Potter)But this is where the story change. Neville is loyal to Harry where Peter has been a coward. He stands by Harry no matter what, even when Voldemort asked him to join his side. This theory says that JKR wanted to show that only one "side character" changes the whole story. Instead of darkness and terror, Neville is the one who kills the last Horcrux (Nagini) and allowing Harry to defeat Voldemort. Instead of joining him and betraying his friends, instead of choosing the easy path, life above all moral, he chooses to be faithful.
  “It takes a great deal of bravery to stand up to our enemies, but just as much to stand up to our friends.”
Just think about it, if Neville would have acted like Peter did, the ending would have been probably the opposite.We clearly see how his character grow during those 7 books/8 films. I personally find this theory very convincing, I'm eager to read your opinion on it!

The last of the Harry Potter books, and the ultimate showdown between Harry and Voldemort. I admit, I love the different tone to this book compared to the previous novels. Harry and co. are very isolated for a lot of the novel, only returning to their beloved Hogwarts at the end. With the new Fantastic Bewst novels, Dumbledores backstory also finds a new interesting spin. I do find that the search for the Horcruxes is a little bit too easy, but I can overlook this for the wonderful way the series is concluded.Returning to these books has felt a little like revisiting an old friend. There's something so deliciously comforting about these characters, that they never fail to envelope me in warmth.

3.5 StarsGenerally, I'm not a big fan of continuous-storyline series, and the Harry Potter series is a good example of why. I'm too much of a completionist, too OCD for this shit. Even though I rated most of these books below three stars, I felt compelled to finish them because I started them. Even after it took me six months to read GOBLET OF FIRE, I pressed forward. Even though I one-starred ORDER OF THE PHOENIX, I continued on. I had to know why people love these books as much as they do. At least I got my answer.J.K. Rowling did one major thing right with this series. Her writing matured along with her readers. As Potter got older and wiser, so did Rowling's style. This helped her quite a bit because the first three novels are horribly formulaic. But how many middle-grade kids are going to dissect overused plot points and cliched story structure? Not many. And by the time her audience was old enough to start questioning the borrowed ideas and storylines, Rowling had already established her characters and readied her pawns for battle. Had the series maintained the goofy middle-grade tone throughout, it would have likely failed. Had the first three books been as dark as the final four, the series wouldn't have seen half the success it did. In the end, it became a phenomenon because it spoke to the proper age groups at the proper times.I give this series a lot of grief, but not even my cynical ass can ignore Rowling's accomplishments. After writing this series, she went from homeless mother to one of the richest people on the face of the planet. Good for her. But I think her greatest success was getting kids reading again. And while I do not fan flail over these books, I do understand the draw. I understand the nostalgia and fond memories they invoke in their readers. THE DEATHLY HALLOWS was a little heavy in the middle. Its belly meandered and dragged some, but I was never bored to the point I was with PHOENIX. Then again, I think a lot of what I enjoyed about this book stemmed from the knowledge that I was reading the last one in the series. That thought alone made me smile and was a big reason I didn't want to put the book down.I'm glad Neville got his time in the sun, but Snape's story arc was my favorite of the bunch. Luna was another one I liked. Harry didn't really shine for me until book six, and I fucking loathed everything about Ron. I wanted Hermione and Draco to end up together, as they seemed hellbent for each other, but maybe that was just me reading too much into their hatred of one another. I kept expecting Harry to catch them rage fucking in a closet between classes.Finally, I'm pretty sure Peeves and Trelawney were screwing each other every time they were able. Next time you reread this, see if you can catch why I say that. The scene I remember the best out of the entire series is the underwater stuff in GOBLET. In summation: Six easy reads and one big pile of shit equal a series that owes a lot to young readers and nostalgia. Books six and seven are clearly the best of the bunch. If I had to rate the series as a whole, I'd have to give it three stars. Final Judgment: Done at last. Done at last. Thank Tom Cruise almighty I'm done at last!A rundown of my ratings for each book:The Sorcerer's Stone ***The Chamber of Secrets ***The Prisoner of Azkaban **The Goblet of Fire **** (Wow... I don't remember liking this one enough to give it 4 stars... Odd.)The Order of the Phoenix * (I want to give this book zero stars, or, preferably, a minus 3)The Half-Blood Prince ****The Deathly Hallows ***1/2

Harry Potter is Harry Potter, but I struggled to like this final book for several reasons. They're the same things that bothered me the first time I read it, but the final confrontation and brilliant revelations and reversals of certain characters wiped them from my memory back then. Now the second time, I find that these reasons linger. 1. So many deaths. Right from the beginning, starting with (view spoiler)[Hedwig (hide spoiler)]. Somehow that really got to me this time!2. So much speculation about Dumbledore and his true motivations and shortcomings. I do like how this was resolved in the end, but didn't enjoy the maligning of Dumbledore, or Harry's doubts about him.3. So much time spent with only Harry, Ron and Hermione running around the forest. I miss their interactions with other characters and the wizarding world.4. No Hogwarts until 75%. This is kind of the same as the previous point except that Hogwarts simply deserves its own line. I've realized that the setting is a huge part of my enjoyment of this series, and I was impatient with the book until the story returned there. I missed all of the extra characters - teachers, ghosts, portrait-dwellers, fellow students - as well as the magic of the castle itself.I still love the series. There's nothing else like it. It's darker than I would have liked, even knowing where it was going the second time around, but like I said, I just wanted to live at Hogwarts and not watch the whole world being destroyed, along with so many people that Harry could possibly consider family. The ending is really great. It's one of those endings that is actually epic, and some of the minor characters have great moments in the battle at Hogwarts. But I found this finale bitter enough that I might avoid any future re-reads and stick to the earlier books for the nostalgia of simply hanging out at Hogwarts.

I won't get this right because I'm in two places at once. I'm finished and yet I'm starting. I feel as though I have returned from a great journey. A journey that’s only begun. I finished the last book this morning and yet I feel I don’t know the whole story yet. I know there are people who make a hobby, an obsession, maybe even a career about Harry Potter lore and now I can understand why. This is not a story, it’s an experience. This is the masterpiece of a truly gifted author who understands what it means to be a great storyteller. Rowling understands that it’s not enough to throw action and plot at a reader, but to draw them, gently and unobtrusively, into a new, believable world. Her world doesn’t play by the rules of ours, but no matter. From the first chapter of book one, we are taken under Rowling’s cloak of invisibility as an ordinary human and she doesn’t insult our intelligence nor write down to us. She gains our trust, word by word, tale by tale. She gives us rich background, complex characters, deep emotion. At every page, we find something we relate to—whether an action or a feeling. Until we are under the spell and our trust in her is absolute. Like Dumbledore’s Army follows Harry, we are willing to follow wherever Rowling leads. Because we believe in her world.There are things I don’t fully understand. Things I want to explore further. And this is why the ending is only the beginning. It’s like reaching the last level of a difficult video game, winning the prize, and now the game is open for “free play.” You can go explore to your heart’s content without peril.And I will.After all this time.Always.

I've just finished rereading this for the fourth or fifth time, eight years after its release. Still, I found myself an absolute teary mess during chapter 34 - 'The Forest Again'. Coincidentally, Rowling has stated this is her own favourite chapter. The Prince's Tale and the deaths of Fred and Lupin still make my eyes water, but nothing compares to those scenes in the forest. Rowling deserves every little bit of her success. This is a fantastic conclusion to an unbelievable story. She is a true rarity; a fantastic author and an even better storyteller. “Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all, those who live without love.”

I'll be honest, when I went to the midnight release for this book and was waiting in line to purchase it, it made me so incredibly happy to open the book and realize there wasn't a blurb in the front cover-flap. Instead there was this:       The        dedication           of this book       is split    seven ways:to Neil,    to Jessica,        to David,            to Kenzie,                   to Di,               to Anne,            and to you,       if you have         stuck             with Harry                  until the                 very               end.It made me so incredibly happy. I had dreaded this book, and anticipated it like no other. And to open to where the blur normally is and see, instead, a dedication made me relieved. There would be no chance of me spoiling even the smallest instance of this book for myself; I would read it as it was intended.I don't want to say too much about the book itself, because - well - spoilers. Even now, years later, it's hard for me to speak about the plot, about the things that happened, if I'm not absolutely sure that the people I'm talking with have read it.I remember there being some complaints about certain aspects of this story dragging a bit - you know what I'm talking about - but I actually feel like it flowed beautifully well. There were very few down moments, very few moments where we were allowed to catch our breath while Harry learned what he needed to know, figured out the mysteries and the puzzles left, and determined how best to accomplish them.The first time I read it, and every time since (this is only my second re-read), I was rapt with attention. Not bored for a moment.I said in my review for Half-Blood Prince that it was probably the most satisfying book to re-read after having finished the series. This is the second most satisfying. I will readily admit that there are some very detailed machinations that occur in Deathly Hallows, and - at first - it can be a bit confusing while you try to catch up to the revelations. But they're clear as day on the re-read, when you, again, catch the little hints, moments, and details that lead to those revelations. J.K. Rowling is as on-form here as she ever was, probably more so.After the losses and emotions of Order of the Phoenix and Half-Blood Prince, I wasn't sure that my emotions could take anymore. But they did. And it just might have been the most heart-wrenching moment I've experienced in this series yet. My heart was ripped out several times over, twisted and stabbed, and then put - painfully - back into my chest.This series means something incredibly special to me. I can't even fully articulate it. It just is. I've loved it from the beginning. I love it still.After all this time?Always.Previous thoughts:This book.This series.J.K. Rowling is amazing. The absolute genius of the world, the characters, the story blows my mind.If I have any complaint it's only that I want more. (view spoiler)[My one complaint is really that I wish the Slytherins had taken a more prominent role in the battle against Voldemort. (hide spoiler)]This is the first time I've re-read this book since immediately after its release. In fact this series re-read is my first since Deathly Hallows came out. In many ways it was like a first read all over again. There were so many small details, so many little things that make the world and the characters that I'd forgotten. I admit to being slightly worried that somewhere along the way this series wouldn't live up to the incredible love I have for it. It holds such a special place in my heart and I didn't want to ruin that. But as I continued and read further and kept going, those fears were quickly avada kedavra'd. I love this series even more now than I did the first time. Funnily enough, even though I wasn't a child when I started the Harry Potter series I learned that there was a lot that I didn't fully appreciate when I read it way back when. Things that I can only truly appreciate now that I'm an adult and can look back.That's the genius of Rowling; that she creates a world and story that's enthralling to children, teenagers, and just as beautiful and entrancing to adults. The magic of these books touches my soul.

Ho finalmente deciso di rompere il silenzio stampa sulla saga Harry Potter, e lo faccio perché infastidita da un accanimento che trovo abbastanza ridicolo, sia dalla parte di chi quest'opera la vuole boicottare, sia da quella che invece la vuole osannare.Premetto che questo è un commento da attribuire a ben sette libri e non soltanto ad uno, per cui è molto probabile che quello che scrivo riguardi solo passaggi particolari o non rifletta a pieno ciò che penso di un particolare volume.Detto questo... ho notato che sembra di gran moda ultimamente (e inspiegabilmente: voglio dire, sono passati anni dalla pubblicazione dell'ultimo volume eh, posso capire lo scoppio ritardato, ma a volte si esagera) denigrare una delle saghe letterarie che ha avuto più successo e fama a livello planetario e storico. Che possa piacere o non piacere, rimane insindacabilmente un parere personale, libero, soggettivo e indiscutibile. Però ho letto molto frequentemente, negli ultimi tempi, attacchi alla saga di Harry Potter come se questa fosse colpevole della decadenza letteraria del nuovo millennio, o dell'imbarbarimento culturale dell'intera umanità, o che so, dell'ingiustificabile demerito di aver abissato opere migliori ma, ahimè, meno visibili e popolari.Io non voglio dire assolutamente che i sette romanzi della Rowling siano esenti da imprecisioni; "si poteva fare meglio" vale praticamente per qualsiasi cosa nell'universo, e di sicuro vale a maggior ragione per quelli che sono probabilmente tra i libri più famosi e popolari di sempre. E tuttavia stare a sottolineare gli errori, le forzature, i difetti, le cose-che-semplicemente-non-tornano, le macchinazioni di quella che alla fin fine è pur sempre una saga per ragazzi, mi sembra un tantino pretenzioso e a tratti ridicolo.Che ci siano opere in circolazione che "avrebbero meritato di stare al posto di Harry Potter" (per i motivi che volete) è un ritornello che ormai sento ovunque, e tuttavia non posso che chiedermi: non si può evitare una classifica? Se qualcuno mi chiede un parere su Harry Potter, non posso che rispondere che la sua storia mi è piaciuta molto, che lo trovo un simbolo della crescita dei ragazzi degli anni Novanta, e che conservo il ricordo di quando mi emozionavo per l'uscita del nuovo volume con estrema dolcezza. Questo vuol dire che non è vero forse che ci sono opere migliori? Ma chi l'ha detto. Mica mi metto a pensare male di qualcosa che ho letto solo perché poi ne leggo un'altra che mi è piaciuta... Mi sono piaciute tutte e due.Ho letto nella mia vita molte cose scritte meglio di Harry Potter, molte storie più appassionanti, molte cose più "molto"; eppure fa parte di me, e quando penso all'opera lo faccio con una tenerezza che mi stupisce tuttora. Per quanto riguarda le "forzature" tanto additate, non posso che dire che alcune le condivido, altre semplicemente non le ho notate. Tuttavia (e questo è vero per tantissimi libri che ho letto), io non costruisco il mio indice di gradimento soltanto su questo: voglio dire, la letteratura non è un'equazione, e se leggo lo faccio per svariati motivi, ma di certo non per trovare certezze scientifico-matematiche che devono portarmi alla soluzione di una differenziale di secondo ordine. In alcuni casi, ci sono sbavature inammissibili, d'accordo, ma semplicemente non credo che Harry Potter rientri in questa casistica (parere personale).La cosa che probabilmente mi rende così attaccata alla saga è la trattazione del tema dell'amicizia. Quindi no, non mi interessa se la storia della mappa del Malandrino sia un po' una trovata per far quadrare i conti, o se Voldemort sia un po' troppo caricaturale, o che il finale con gli Horcrux poteva essere pensato meglio. Quando leggi di Ron, Hermione e Harry e stai crescendo, questa storia ti lascia un segno indelebile, e di storie così purtroppo ce ne sono poche. Se penso a tutta la commozione genuina e sincera, alle lacrime e i sorrisi che questi sette libri mi hanno regalato, penso anche che il mio pensiero sull'amicizia, il valore che le attribuisco, l'ideale che ne costruisco, nascono anche su queste pagine. Quando penso alla storia di Neville, che si è costruito il coraggio sulle orme dei pochi compagni che gli hanno dato fiducia ed è riuscito a sbocciare, a Luna, ha trovato il suo posto nel mondo grazie all'affetto e nonostante le sue stranezze, alla storia di Lunastorta, Codaliscia, Felpato e Ramoso... Beh... non mi trattengo. L'altalenante inimicizia tra Draco e Harry, poi, la trovo semplicemente meravigliosa (forse è per questo che se penso a quello scempio della Maledizione dell'erede vado proprio in bestia, anzi no, è senz'altro per questo).Harry Potter è forse, insieme a poche altre cose come One Piece, ad esempio, un caso di rara bellezza in cui l'amicizia riesce a trionfare su tutto, anche e soprattutto sull'amore, ed è per questo motivo che sarà sempre con me, indelebile, eterno, ed apprezzato compagno di vita.

"After all this time?""Always," said Snape.
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows broke me. I CAN'T DEAL WITH THE DEATHS OF MY FAVOURITE CHARACTERS. . . This "review" isn't going to be a review at all, it's more of a Snape appreciation post. If you don't like him, please see yourself out right about now.Severus Snape is my favourite character of all time. He is such a complex and interesting character, so obbbbviously The Prince's Tale is my favourite chapter.I loved Snape even before the big reveal in the last book. He is very clever and sly, and I just love his sarcasm and his bitterness about the world.Snape isn't the dictionary definition of either "good" or "bad". He's in the grey area between those two polar opposites. His character taught me that it's human to make mistakes and be imperfect. Most of us aren't the chosen ones or the perfect Prince Charmings; we all have flaws, it's what makes us human. . ....My Review of Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince

It took me over 3 months to complete this book. I was currently on a reading slump, but i am back at it. Anyways, I couldn't have asked for a better ending to the series. This book was the most eventful one in my opinion. It had its moments when it was slow paced, but other times it was all happening very fast (not in a bad way). This wasn't my favorite book of the whole series, but i still thought it was well written. My favorite scene was the battle at Hogwarts. It was as if i was physically there watching the events unfold until it reached the climax. I know i will have to revisit the series again someday due to all the minor details I could've missed. I will forever be thankful to J.K. Rowling for creating this iconic world and for entertaining millions of people. I find it fascinating how one person can come up with so much content and make an incredible story. If i had the chance to visit any fictional place, my answer would be Hogwarts.

THE BOY WHO LIVED!!!!!And love you J.K Rowling...For making this real to us.

I was stunned and dismayed by the time I finished this book. I have been a fan of the HP series since about 2000, when a friend recommended Book 1 to me as a cute little book that she was tutoring 5th graders with. I read it, liked it, and figured I'd pick up the next book when it came out.As each book came out, many critics and fans commented that JK had a unique style of approaching her series; the way that her books grew with her targeted audience. The series became darker and more complex, the writing more intense as the series continued.By the 5th book, I was well and truly hooked, and read each book voraciously when it came out. I re-read the entire available series just before the next book was released, and enjoyed them immensely.When Book 7 came out, I was disappointed, but only in the way that a fan is when what they have enjoyed so long is at an end. There would be no more HP books to look forward to. As I had not been part of HP online communities, nor did I enjoy the movies, this was the end of the series for me.Then I read the book, and I was furious. Six books she spent preaching about house unity, and how Hogwarts must unite or fall. Six books she spent warning of a terrible and devastating war that Harry would be in the thick of. Six books that were well enough written between plot and description that I could overlook her lack of characterization for antagonists or the fact that Ginny was essentially a flat character. And then book 7, where she completely ignores everything she spent 6 books setting up, skips around the reality of war by having Harry wander around lost on the moors for a bit, and then pulls a religious analogy out of her hat. Although the religious analogy did make me laugh -- I can't help but wonder if all those who said HP was the devil's work will be praising it like it's Narnia in 10 years.Still, I couldn't believe what she'd done to her work. I don't know if that honestly was her vision from the beginning, as she claims -- if it was, then the entire series suffers for it, and her vision is severely limited. The other alternative is that she sold out or simply didn't care because she's already richer than a queen. Whatever the reasoning, it was an awful, disappointing end to a beautifully textured series.---EDITED TO ADD---I still dislike book 7, although I love the rest of the series. I love how JK structured the books, right? I mean, she's a genius with the foreshadowing and with dropping in information about the characters backgrounds without being heavy handed. She's just a brilliant writer who structured these very rich, well-crafted worlds that hold up to multiple re-readings. I love how the books "grow" with the reader, with the first books being written for a younger reader and the later books being written for an older reader. Most of all, I love how she foreshadows across the books, so things that happen in, say, Book 5 are foreshadowed in Books 1 and 2. It's AMAZING. She's so incredibly talented, and it makes reading her books a real treat. Which was why I am still so incredibly upset at reading book 7. See, in Book 7, she brings up this whole notion of those three items (the Elder Wand, Invisibility Cloak, and Philosophers Stone) being tied together by the myth of the three brothers. That's the part that pissed me off. It felt ... cobbled in. Pulled out of a hat, last minute. Like, JK had told us about the numberless clock in the Weasley's house warning us about danger, about hunting for garden gnomes, about the time Ron's teddy bear got turned into a spider ... but she didn't mention this apparently incredibly common wizarding childrens story? She talks about all these daily aspects of wizarding life on a regular basis, introduced through Ron's family, but never once -- never once in 6 entire books does Ron or Ginny or anyone even let out a breath of a whisper about this apparently common wizarding fable? Think about how often you reference common fairy stories and fables in your life. Cinderella, Red Riding Hood, Big Bad Wold, etc. So if JK Rowling actually had this idea of a wizarding fable/myth as a major plot in her overarching series, I think she would have woven it in as foreshadowing much more effectively. What I think happened is this:Right around the time Book 7 was being written, all these internet/ social media/ fanboard sites were really taking off. They weren't huge before then, but they were really taking off as she'd released Books 5 & 6 and was writing book 7. I think that the fans had pretty much figured out what was happening, plot wise -- which is a mark of what a great writer JK Rowling is -- and JK felt bad about that -- which is a natural creative response.I think her publisher advised her to keep quiet about reading the fanboards for legal reasons, which she wisely did, but I fully believe she read them, and that she wasn't happy about two things:(1) The proliferation of fanfic and noncanon fanfic pairings(2) How thoroughly the fans had guessed the key points of the plot (particularly what would be happening with Snape and Dumbledore and the Horcruxes).So I think that JK just sort of pulled that bit about the 3 Wizarding brothers and the ancient fairy tale and 3 legendary items out of her hat (with no foreshadowing regarding this plotline in the previous 6 books) because she wanted to surprise her fans with a sort of "gotcha"/ surprise moment. Furthermore, I suspect she wrote in the epilogue as a sort of middle finger to the proliferation of fanfic writers, as though to say, "And by the way, no. That is not how it happens. Harry and Hermoine do not end up together. Harry and Draco do not end up together. Ron and Pansy do not end up together. These people end up together, in these pairs. I do so decree it, and thus it shall be."So that's why I don't like Book: 7. I feel like it's less true to the ethos of the series than the rest of the books. I feel like JK Rowling kind of strayed from herself as a writer ... that she reacted (poorly) to her fans, and that it reflects badly on her work. I can't really enjoy reading the book even now. It feels out of step with the rest of the series.I've mostly moved on. I've forgiven her (even if the insult is imagined). She's a truly talented writer and generous and compassionate woman. She's an inspiration to me, as a writer. And it was a weird time in fandom and for the internet, when that book was being written. Everyone makes mistakes. I think JK has more than made up for the upset of book 7, though -- she wrote 6 other amazing books, she's gracious and considerate in the fandom community, and she's a principled and compassionate woman. A true role model. What's one book in comparison to the rest of her legacy?

I have finished my 2017 Harry Potter reread!This review contains unmarked spoilersAs the other 6 reviews I have done for this series this review will also be all over the place. Because so much happens in this book I think I will shorten the review by only talking about the things I really want to talk about and keeping it kind of short. First off the Dursley's are going into hiding. I sometimes wonder if Mr. Dursley has any sense because he says we are leaving then nope we aren't. Dudley was like screw it dad I want to leave. Petunia just wants Dudley to be safe and at the end they did leave Private Drive. Dudley's last words to Harry was I didn't think you were a waste of space or something along those lines. I keep forgetting that. Harry leaves Private Drive with the Order and of course they had a master plan that they would turn 6 people into Harry as they escaped into safe houses. Each one different. Harry rode with Hagrid which is very emotional because Hagrid is the one to bring Harry there and he is the one taking him away. The twins, Ron, Hermione, Fluer, and Mundungus turn into Harry and they are off into the night to the different safe houses. Apparently the Death Eaters knew that they were traveling that night which we later learned how and why they knew. Hedwig dies which is extremely sad and Hagrid fell from the sky trying to protect Harry. The first time I read it I though Hagrid was dead but he is alive and well and I am glad Hagrid is okay. They arrive at Tonk's house and then take a porkey to the Burrow. Bill and Fluer's wedding take place in the Burrow and during the wedding the Death Eaters took over the ministry. Hermione disapperates with Ron and Harry into the city where they are met by Death Eaters. I don't think it was ever com firmed whether or not Harry still had the trace on him. They spent the night in Grimmauld place and later learned Kreacher's story. We figure out that R.A.B is Regulus Black and he allowed Voldemort to use Kreacher to drink the potion to hide his Horcrux. Regulas of course with the help of Kreacher goes to the cave and drinks the potion and tells Kreacher to destroy it before dying. It was honestly a heartbreaking moment. Regulus unlike Sirius treated Kreacher with more respect and Kreacher does love Regulus more. Harry gives Kreacher the fake Horcrux and Kreacher looses it and after that treats Harry, Ron, and Hermione more kindly. He also find Mundungus and they discover that he sold the locket to Umbridge. I am pretty sure when everyone read that part for the first time they are all, including me, this lady again? I thought she was gone. With careful planning and with the help of polyjuice potion the three of them manage to get into the ministry and find the locket but like Kreacher, could not destroy it. Later on Ron will stab it with the word of Gryffindor. Speaking of the sword, Neville proves himself as a worthy Griffindor as he mamages to pull the sword out of the hat just like Harry. Neville I feel like thought he didn't belong in this hout but he proved he is brave and courageous. Not being able to return to Sirius's house they start camping out in the woods, Ron leaves but comes back Harry ignore's Ron's warning and says Voldemort's name and they get captured. Hermione is tortured and honestly that scene was very scary because Bellatrix is cruel and I didn't know the first time I read it whether or not Hermione survived. She does and recovers in shell cottage where Bill and Fluer now live. Dobby rescues the trio plus a few others including Luna and Dobby dies in the process. It is a sad moment and even Harry is so devastated that he had trouble saying anything but Goodbye at Dobby's funeral. Way before that when the met Bathilda and learned she was actually a snake Hermione breaks Harry's wand. Harry feels like a part of him is missing. Told by Ollivander his wand is repairable he later tries to fix it with the elder wand and it works. At shell cottage they made an agreement with Griphook the goblin and pulled off an epic break in into Gringotts. I loved that part and it was my favourite moment in this book. The battle of Hogwarts was more sad and more epic this time I read it. Grawp threw Hagrid through the window so he could join the fight. I really wished we could of seen that scene in the movie. Percy comes back and learns his lesson that family is very important and he witnessed his brother die. Honestly it was heartbreaking to see Percy, who finally wanted to see and hep his family again only to lose one of them. I mean I cried reading that part too.Lets not forget at the end that the house elves lead by Kreacher also helped fight. And Mrs. Weasley fighting Bellatrix was insane. Bellatrix almost killed Ginny and Mrs. Weasley was mad. I don't think I ever saw her that mad ever. People tried to help her but she reused any help and they all stared to watch. I feel like everyone stopped fighting or were half fighting but watching them fight.That's it for now and I probably add more later because I still have a lot to say.

Not a review, just a commentary since this is my 2nd time reading the series, and, well I found some issues with the last book. Also it dragged on forever... I felt I was reading it for way too long. But I sound way too negative right now, I still love it, I just wish some things were done differently. - The part of the trio being on the run was extremely over stretched and plain boring. It felt as because they were not at Hogwarts anymore and had no classes to go to, or homework to do, well they didn't know what to do with themselves. Also while all of them were good and quite brilliant while at school, on the run they seemed rather dim witted. - The fact that it was so incredibly hard for them to believe in Deathly Hallows was stupid. Wizards, goblins, unicorns, souls splitting.... all the magical stuff and they cannot believe in something just as magical?! Say what ?! - I have been liking Fleur for a while (ever since she appeared basically) but this book solidified my liking for her character. She seemed real, composed and an excellent image of a great wife. - Remus Lupin is forever my favorite character of the whole series. And while it was hard to read the part where Harry yelled at him for wanting to leave Tonks, I think that it was a great point of Rowling's saying that adults should listen to children more often, because sometimes they know what's best better than adults with all of their life experience do. - Reading second time around I have to agree with Ron. Dumbledore was quite mental. The book should have been named Dumbledore's games or something... I enjoyed Aberforth though, little that we got of him. - At the final battle of Hogwarts when house-elves joined the battle, what was up with them poking enemies with their kitchen knives??? They are house elves, they have strong magic on their own! But the best they could do is poke with knives?... what? - Voldemort is even more of a coward second time reading. - The whole book to me seemed stretched and drawn out, but I did enjoy the beginning a lot. The wedding part was very interesting. Also all of the lore on Dumbledore's and Riddle's young lives was great. And obviously Snape's (sob, sob, sob).- The epilogue, ehhh. I feel like a lot of important characters were left out of it. The whole series had such an extensive character count, and all of them were built exceptionally well. Leaving them out seemed a little like taking the chocolate chips out of chocolate chip cookies. I would much rather read about what George was doing, how were Bill and Fleur , where was Luna... than to see what cliche of names Harry + Ginny and Ron + Hermione named their kids.... That was just so unrealistic! - While I loved Ginny's character in all other books, she didn't have much page time in this book and thus was pretty blah.My WEBSITEMy INSTAGRAMMy WORDPRESS BLOG

I will never find the perfect words to describe how I feel about the Harry Potter series. It's an incredible story, everybody knows that.I am not unique in my connection with these books. When I was younger, I would wait with excited anticipation for the next HP book to come out. When it did, I would hole myself up in my room and devour it in a day. I had read other books that I'd liked well enough prior to HP, but this was different. It was that feverish feeling you get when you're so wrapped up in a story. It's the absolute love you have for the characters, and the spectacular world-building that stretches your imagination. It cemented my love for reading.Twelve years later, I re-read the series, finishing with this last installment. This time, I read it slower. I wanted to savor every bit of it. And it was exactly as good as I remembered.

I just completely finished this series for the first time ever and it feels so so weird to say it out loud. I loved every single one of these books with all my heart and I can't believe I've waited this long to actually get around to finishing them. But now that I did...WOW, DOES IT FEEL GOOD. As many and as powerful as the deaths were in this book, the moment when Harry is forced to confront it himself, forced to feel the fear and crippling anxiety and horror that comes with the inevitability of death, the moment when he asks the ones he loves who have already passed on if it hurts and if they'll stay with him, THAT was what had me in tears more than anything. THAT was the moment that had my family giving me strange looks. But to hell if I regret a single bit of it.

Well, I've finished the Harry Potter series, and it's the first time for me. I say first time because most people have read and reread them several times. Maybe I will too, I don't know. Of course I've known for years how the story ends, what with the movies, family, etc. But this final book was special, a fitting end to the story. Five stars, and overall I give the series five stars as well. They all weren't perfect, but like a mosaic, they fit together to form a masterpiece, a phenomenon that will endure for decades, maybe centuries.

I loved it....everything in it. like in all the other books in the series, Rowling is just amazing in creating a world that is so complete and engaging. only thing I would have preferred is if she was to split the story of this book in at least 5 more volumes!

This book settles it: Dumbledore may be one of the greatest characters ever created in the world of fiction. As Rowling turns her universe upside-down and reveals the past of a man who is fully accepted as the greatest wizard of all time, she reveals a character depth beyond belief. Dumbledore is made out to be a sinner, a villain, a God-like figure who does not stand in the way for an innocent sacrifice. He is good, but he is focused on the greater good, sacrificing individuals in order to achieve his goal. He loves Harry, heart and soul, but he still needs him dead. And worst of all? He has coldblodily known it all the time. While people has celebrated Snape's surprising sacrifice, I will always celebrate Dumbledore's betrayal. Purity and peace doesn't come without a price, and Dumbledore is willing to pay. He is a brilliant exception in Rowling's black-and-white universe. (view spoiler)[Along with Harry Potter of course. The part of Voldemort that lives in him reminds us that no one is pure. That we all hold a bit of evil – even though it has been attached to us by accidental spells and curses. (hide spoiler)]One thing that has been clear to me on rereading these books, is how black-and-white Rowling usually operates. Like the sorting hat, she conveniently divides her characters into good and evil and very few outsteps this path. I have always found it cowardly, how this book dismisses Slytherin-pupils for instance. An entire house of people, thrown out of the defining battle because they happen to be wearing green and silver. Rowling spends the entire series preaching how Slytherin isn't necessarily defined by evil – and yet, she chooses to dismiss them, when the fight is about to come. I've always hated it. I have always hated how the Slytherins in the end only seem to be allowed a single character trait. This time around, I also had a bit of trouble grasping the scope of Voldemort's evil. Is he about to destroy the universe? Will his rise to power mean the end of muggle-life? And if so, will it mean the end of every muggle in the world, or is his power restricted to Britain only? Why does the world not send help to fight him – why does the Order not include African, American or even European wizards? Voldemort's power and evil seems unlimited, and yet he is fought by an underground army consisting of Britains only, fighting the ultimate battle at a schoolground. I am confused by the perspective; Voldemort could rule the world, crush every offender – and yet he is at Hogwarts, fighting children. The suspense is however undeniable. We don't have time for so many strategic questions while reading this book, because it is nerve-wracking to read. Rowling makes you forget time and space – and even plot holes – as she drags you along for break-in's, wandlore, secret missions and treasure hunts for pieces of an evil soul.I have always loved the horcruxes and the psychological insight they provide into both Harry and Voldemort's soul. Little by little, you become fascinated with Voldemort's anger and his desire to be accepted, and you even come to understand the darkest corners of Harry's soul. While the treasure hunt itself is a bit tedious at times, its ultimate goal is breathtaking. However, as much as I've always loved the horcruxes, I've always hated the Deathly Hallows. It's puzzling why no one has ever mention Beedle the Bard earlier, as his tales are supposed to be the mythic pillars of the wizarding world. Why has Hermione, who has read about every book of wizardry, never stumbled upon these ancient tales – and why has Ron, who has grown up with these stories and loved them forever, never mentioned them? Why isn't there a magic frog card with Beedle the Bard? Why has Rowling never let a bit of the enthralling tales slip earlier? It's all so sudden. And to me, it's a bit implausible. As is wandlore itself.Wandlore is mythical, wonderful to read about, and impossible to understand. I'm still not sure about the whole allegiance thing; how exactly a wand's power is transferred or why. It's messy and I'd have loved a bit more explanation.But of course, I'd loved a bit more of everything. I love this book – mostly because of Dumbledore's character development (even beyond his death), and because it is so actionpacked and gratifying. Seven books, read in the dark with a galloping heart, and then this wonderful ending, where only a few characters are spared, and all are forever marked. This book may be filled with errors, but I am willing to overlook them. It is hard not to as these wonderful characters has been part of my life for so long.The Harry Potter-books are magical. And magic is hard to define. (view spoiler)[ A final note: I hate the ending relationships. This is perhaps more related to book six than book seven, but I've never understood Ginny and Harry. We get no explanation, no gradual falling-in-love process; suddenly Harry is in love with Ginny, while one moment earlier he wasn't. There was so much potential; so many scenes at the Burrow, Rowling could have used in order to build these feelings. Instead Harry falls in love out of jealousy.And then there's Ron and Hermione – another relationship enabled by hurt and jealousy. I can understand why Ron loves Hermione, but I can't understand why she loves him. He has been mean to her, ridiculing her, never appreciated her and even hinted she was ugly on several occasions. Would you fall in love with someone, who asked you out as a last resort, and loudly exclaimed that no one else wanted to go out with you? Would you fall in love with someone who got angry on the same occasion, because you actually went with someone else? Someone who ignored you, because he didn't appreciate you enough to ask? Someone who created an entire relationship with another girl, because he was jealous of a relationship you had before he had even shown interest in you? I think not. Ron is a lovely person, but he never treated Hermione well. At least not in my opinion. (hide spoiler)]

As a whole series, my average rating for the series ends up roughly around 4 stars. This is purely because once the series gets over its initial roughness, keeping the charm and developing the characters it becomes a very solid and imaginative series. It may not be the 'epic' that some people are looking for in their fantasy - but like The Chronicles of Narnia its a quirky and appealing little series. Let's be honest: nothing I say or do not say about this series will persuade or dissuade anyone from reading these books if they put their mind to either standpoint. All I can say is how I found the novels and with all honesty I found that they improved so much that I think I will actually miss not having another book in the series to move on and read. I'm a huge reader of fantasy and have been since my mother read The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe to me as a six year old child (I went on to read the novel for myself the following year). There's something about the way a truly great fantasy novel can take you to a whole other world (same with sci-fi) and yet remind you about real world concepts, themes, emotions and values that is appealing. So, I admit that when other children grew up on Harry Potter, I grew up on the novels which preceded Harry Potter. I grew up in Narnia, Middle Earth, Wonderland, Neverland and so on. So as I saw the hype for the Harry Potter series (coupled with the fact that my parents thought the books a touch too dark for my age) I may have decided to avoid reading them, thinking that they were copycats of other, better, books. How snobbish of me.I would easily add this series (for the improvement, character building, world etc.) to my list of unique fantasy series. Of course this would be a list featuring the before mentioned books and also anything by Brandon Sanderson (particularly his Mistborn books), The Wheel of Time (if you don't mind looooong drawn out epic fantasy tales) and The Name of the Wind (as far as it has gone till now). I definitely am willing to recommend any books that you might like if you grew up on Harry Potter or anything similar. Pardon my ramblings, all I wish to say is that I was very impressed with the series after being less than so with the first two and a half books. The other four fully make the most of the promise of the first few books however and therefore create works of fiction which perform all that I believe literature should do.In the novels there are subtle and nuanced reflections on education and the influence of governments and politics on daily life. Rowling seems to imply that while government is a great thing behind the scenes to keep the world running there are times when it meddles in the greater good. Leonard Nimoy (RIP) passed away earlier and he once said (in character) that 'the needs of the many outweigh the needs of the few'. I believe this is the concept that Rowling wished to convey about education and government. The few are in power and authority and it is their job to fulfill the needs of the many, not their own.I also love the final part of this novel with its very Christian message. In some ways Harry becomes a rough Christ figure in these novels (which has lead to the book's fair share of criticism such as how can you mix a message of faith with magic etc.) with how his love and sacrifice for his friends enables him to be able to defeat dark magic. It's a similar theme to that used in The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe but in a different way and I loved how it was used here. I was often told that the books were so non-Christian with the magic and everything but this conclusion is very Christian in how it conveys that evil is created through fear and a desire to become like God (all-powerful like Voldemort attempts to become) and that only sacrificial love can truly defeat the curse of evil. It's a great message and I would definitely not hide these books or ban them, I would encourage children to read them and then ask them questions about those themes!All in all, I definitely enjoyed the books and have also been enjoying the movies simultaneously. I wish in some senses that I had read them sooner and definitely recommend them for the story. Don't be sucked in by the hype, but do read them for their beautiful little story and thematic expression!

WELL I FINISHED THE HARRY POTTER SERIES!!!Three years ago I decided to finally pick up a little book called, "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone." Granted I wasn't in middle school or being read to before bed: nope I was 21 years old and enjoyed them just as much if maybe not more for waiting. I know this has been said plenty of times before me, but JK Rowling created a legacy for herself with writing these books. The first four were so wonderful and even though the next 3 books (plot-wise) went downhill for me, this ending had me smiling and reminded me why these books are so much more than children's tales. There are so many great moments throughout this series and these characters are some I am never going to find and love in other books as much as I do in these books. Hagrid always remained a favorite, along with Ron Weasley and of course Dumbledore!! The boarding of the scarlet train to Hogwarts scenes were another magical yet simply beautiful piece to the story. HEDWIG!! Hermonine and the house elves, Christmas at Hogwarts, Hagrid's dragon Norbert, and the wise and wonderful words of Dumbledore about love for each other. It's a bittersweet feeling completing this series. ALL WAS WELL.

I closed this book and finished my reread last night at about midnight. My heart was heavy and I've been in a bit of a funk ever since. What am I going to do now? I've been going to Hogwarts, fighting off dementors, meeting up with my friends from the DA, and knocking about with Harry, Ron and Hermione for the past 3 1/2 months!! And now....? I have no more Harry Potter books to read. Even though I had several other books I should have been reading, Harry won me over, and my brain couldn't focus on anything else unless I gave in and just picked up whatever HP book I was reading. I'm so thankful that J K Rowling has decided to continue with this world and we have 3 more movies of Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them and a play about Harry's youngest son. Whew. Maybe I'll be out of my funk by then.

This review can also be found on my blog here.I can’t believe it’s over, these past two months i have been completely consumed in the wizarding world and now, its over and it feels so finalised! Throughout reading these books i continued to ask myself “why did you not read these books earlier?” but now i am actually happy i waited till now at a time in my life when i can truly understand everything that Harry goes through and pick up on the lessons that you learn throughout. Such a gripping and empowering book that i will probably cherish forever.I think with being her last book, J.K Rowlings writing flourishes here. It still has everything we expect from her, the comradery, love, adventure and humour, but with so much more feeling to it, that in just the way she wrote out certain moments could change my mood. It was incredible. I also found her writing expanding to areas she had only touched on before. Things concerning grief, power struggles and the strains of friendship that i think she worked through really well. Super impressed with the writing in this one.I can’t get over how much I loved this story. the last book ends with them planning a quest to find the Horcruxes and this is exactly what the majority of the story focuses on. It really is the be all end all kind of thing, because if they don’t find them, then all is lost, and you definitely feel that pressure on the trio throughout the book.Many parts were a bit slow and depressing when they felt they had nowhere to turn and didn’t know what to do next, but again, that despair makes it more real for the reader in understanding what they’re going through. So that didn’t bother me too much. However, there were some lovely moments that we get to see of everyone in the order together again, the Weasley family, Harry’s trip down memory lane and of course the DA members coming back a little. J.K Rowling really knows how to tug at your heartstrings and it is no different in this book!The plot is actually so encapsulating, due to it really being the end of Harry’s story and as it progresses you feel it building up and you know the defining moment is coming but you still don’t know what that will be. It’s all just so much to deal with at once and it felt overpowering towards the end of the book. It was perfect though, because i know that is exactly the way Harry feels at the time, and J.K Rowling did that on purpose so we would understand how much of a toll everything is taking on him. SOOOO many emotions guys, i can’t even begin to explain how this book made me feel.As far as “character developments” go i thought there wouldn’t really be more considering this is the seventh and final book, but this is the point in which Harry truly becomes a man and we see how different he really is from not only Voldemort but Dumbledore also. Harry really is a unique and realistic character who i have come to adore. He makes mistakes, he gets confused, he is brave but still terrified of things he has to do and i have come to appreciate it all.We get a lot of Hermione and Ron in this book, being that they are with Harry for the majority of the story on his travels and for the first time we really see a crack in their relationship, but what i love is how J.K Rowling works with this to make them all the better friends. So much love and determination from these two and they really are what makes the book all that more special.One thing i definitely wanted to talk about are the deaths. There is a lot of death in this book. Some big blows and some small but all are very significant to Harry in this battle he is fighting. I think because there is seven books and we get that time to really bond with the secondary characters that when one of them dies, it feels like someone you actually know. This book had me bawling for the last 100 pages and i just couldn’t believe what i was reading. You know someone is a great author when they can do that to you!Lastly, i just want to say how impressed i am that J.K Rowling made it possible to do her traditional end of the book info dump on us in such an extraordinary way in the “Kings Cross” place. What a cheeky author making that possible but I love her all the more for it. Love those conversations, we learn so much!Honestly, such a freaking fantastic series and it all came to a very poetic end, that personally suited me just fine. I adored the story of Harry’s crazy, daring and loving life and i feel like i am apart of it in some way, as is everyone who reads these books and goes on the adventures with Harry. Loved it.

4.5 out of 5 stars    "Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all those who live without love." A great ending to a great series! As far as last books go, it's rare to find one that's this satisfying. Any imperfections can be put aside because this was a pretty epic finale.

Rereading all the books back to back made this series even better and I noticed so many details that I had missed the first time. Now I'm trying to fight the post-HP depression by finally reading "The Cursed Child" and maybe also "Fantastic Beasts" and I already know that I'm going to miss Jim Dale's amazing narration.

I have so many feelings inside of me !.It's always bittersweet to finish a series and, above all, to finish a series as incredibly famous as this one.It will be very difficult for me to review these wonderful books, which I'll probably do next year.I can anticipate that it has been a magical journey, full of teachings, growth, a fantastic story that will not be easy to forget, with some characters as original as few, and for which I have always had a special affection.As some know I'm a follower of the movies but for some reason I have always been intimidated to start with the books, but hey, that ends up happening. And I don't regret at all, always a book is richer in content than a movie, in this case I think the movies are wonderful but of course, a little more are the books .I want to summarize by saying that I don't consider myself as a big fan of HP, because that I feel that would be disrespecting those who really are, I know they are books that have a great fandom and I would never say that I'm part of it , if I don't really am, on the other hand I would say that I'm an admirer, because yes I have admired them, the writing style is beautiful , the plot as well, in short I have loved it, but I wouldn't call myself a fan.I hope to be able to write a properly review soon about these beautiful books, I'll be very sincere as I always try to be and I can't wait to do it :).

Eto nek sam i ja napokon završila ovaj serijal (tj. ima još osmi nastavak ali taj još ne doživljavam kao dio svega ovoga jer je tek nedavno objavljen, ali ću ga svakako pročitat). Još u osnovnoj sam počela čitat Pottera ali nakon otkrića Tolkiena zaboravila sam na malog čarobnjaka pa eto ''malo'' kasnim s čitanjem, iako smatram da za dobre knjige nikad nije kasno. Ne znam uopće šta bi napisala jer je svaka moja riječ suvišna. Iako je u samom početku Harry Potter namijenjen mlađoj publici, serijal je zaludia sve generacije. Nakon četvrtog nastavka knjige više i nisu dječje, i Rowlingica laganini počinje ubijat svoje likove a čitatelj pokušava suspregnut emocije. Svaki dio je priča za sebe, svaki je dobar na svoj način, priča se polako raspetljava kako se bližite kraju, napetosti i misterije ne fali. Nekako se povežete sa svim tim likovima, pa Vam gubitci teško padaju. Uglavnom, skidam kapu ovoj ženi jer je genijalac. Inače se divim svim ljudima koji pišu fantasy i stvaraju nove svjetove. I veliko Vam hvala za to. Moja velika preporuka za sve one koji nisu čitali jer je Harry Potter puno više od samog imena. Najviše me se dojmilo opisivanje likova i njihove prošlosti, nijedan dio nema nekog praznog hoda (jedino malo Red feniksa jer je Harry u pubertetu pa ne kontrolira emocije :D ) i svaka joj priča drži vodu. SVAKA ČAST J.K. Rowling!!! I moja dica će čitat Pottera ♥

I just can't believe it's over.This fantastic series has given me so incredibly much - I don't even know how to describe it. It has helped me through some really bad days, and it has made me feel a lot better on so many occasions. I just love the world, its characters, the friendships, the plot, the humor - everything! Absolutely everything. And I actually think that Harry Potter is my number one favorite series of all time, and that it somehow always will be. Just the fact that this series exists in the world makes me so extremely happy to think about - that a lot of children, teenagers and adults can enjoy them over and over again, laugh and cry at the same parts, fall in love with the same characters, be highly engaged in the same world and all its happenings, and just take part in an amazing journey and feel all the magic for themselves. As said, these books existence simply makes me so very happy just to think about, and that says quite a lot about my love for them.I can't wait to reread this series again - and again and again and again.

*spoilers*This is officially my very first time I’ve completely re-read this series and it’s quite possible that I love it even more than I did before. Reading all books back to back (I started the first one in October and finished the last one in January) only made it even more apparent what an incredible saga that Rowling gifted us. All the linked parts, the character development, and just how astonishing it was to see it all unfold. Somehow it still managed to leave me awed even knowing how it all ends. While my opinions of the series as a whole didn’t change (other than the fact that my favorite book is now officially Half-Blood Prince and I’ve gotten over my irritation with Dobby) there is one aspect in these stories that I paid a lot more attention to this go around: Dumbledore and Snape.First and foremost, I’m team Snape (and a Slytherin if you were curious). Yes, I am fully aware that he was a horrible shithead to a bunch of children, primarily Harry, and the only reason was because he loved Harry’s mother and she didn’t love him. Boo-hoo. I’m also aware that he was a Death Eater doing terrible things on behalf of Voldemort before he joined up with Dumbeldore. I’m aware of all these things but I can still appreciate the bravery and risks he took in the name of love, even it was misguided. It doesn’t necessarily make him a hero in my eyes and his actions don’t make up for the wrong he did, but it is still worthy of mention. Don’t agree?hahaha Kidding. But on to an even more controversial topic: Dumbledore was kind of a dick. Sure, at first he’s that kind, fatherly figure that Harry can’t help but look up to. But when year after year at Hogwarts passes and poor young Harry is dealing with shit that he can barely comprehend, does Dumbledore make it a point to educate him on the ways of the wizarding world? Nope. And when we finally realize what’s been going on this entire time? That he’s known from the very beginning that Harry was going to have to die for the “greater good”?!Sure, if he had told Harry at an early age he could have lost his marbles at the prospect of an early death so I understand why he didn’t tell him but I definitely don’t agree with it because he didn’t treat Harry like a pawn; he treated him like he was someone special to him. Think of all the times that Harry was touting Dumbledore’s greatness while from the very beginning he’s known the endgame all along.Leave an infant on a doorstep, don’t even ring the doorbell. They’ll find him in the morning. Know Harry’s living in a goddamn cupboard under the stairs, constantly abused by the Dursley’s–does nothing. Let Snape continue to mistreat him unnecessarily. Blames it on the fact he developed feelings for the reason why he’s lied to Harry his entire life… talk about emotional manipulation. Not letting Harry in on the secret of the horcruxes until after he was doomed to die because his dumbass, for personal advancement reasons, put it on because it was also a Hallow. Dick move, Dumbledore. /rantRowling really achieved greatness with this final installment. Each installment has progressively gotten darker as Harry and all other characters take step after step into adulthood. This world that Rowling has created is both horrible and mesmerizing in equal measure. A world where there are creatures that can suck out your very soul, but also wondrous creatures like unicorns and Hippogriffs. A world where you can be struck down with two simple words, but also where owls deliver your mail and paintings talk. But the most wondrous thing that Rowling accomplished with these stories is just how many lives she transformed, mine included. It’s enough to make anyone believe in magic.

IT IS NOT FOR ALL CHILDREN some SHELTERED CHILDREN might not be permitted by parents to read such harsh language and killing scenes.Some CHILDREN might not be educated enough to understand the plot and deep messages this book does have, which are intended for adult readers.Yes, some CHILDREN may be ready for this type of story, but many are not, due to parental restrictions in their lives.I firmly believe if a child has lived through horrid events then they will be able to read this.I guess sometimes it was hard for me to imagine that there was someone writing these remarkable stories. I really started to feel the characters after seeing the movies. I could hear them in my head their accents and everything!I forgot that there was a WOMAN behind the scenes. Someone a lot like me.J.K. Rowling was a single mother of two kids and on welfare! She started the books not really understanding what an impact they would make in people's lives!She never thought her books would be banned and hated my many people.Or that many billions more would LOVE her and her brilliant writing skills.I have learned that we all are magical beings. No matter what religion we are, we have love, bravery and imaginations...we are creative and romantic...There is a story in all of our hearts. I found that I have been fighting DEMENTORS and Voldemort's for a long time. I found that my own life struggles are a lesson for me. A journey I must take sometimes alone and sometimes with friends or family.Before I read Deathly Hallows I understood something, Death is a part of our Lives. We cannot survive one without the other. If we are not born we would not die.We must do both.I knew this before reading the last book.I have the Magic in me to survive death, by walking right into it when the time comes.It will not be a terrible thing, only leaving behind the ones we love and knowing that they will miss us sorely. Knowing that and end of our journey here the end of our story...the book will be replaced on the shelve and maybe not read again for a long time...When someone we love takes a photo of us or a letter we wrote long ago while we lived, and read it and for a moment remember us and we will be alive again in a memory in a heart beat in the tears...We will be once more remembered and for a few moments alive...and then we will rest again...a memory for another day. Inside the hearts of those who love us we will remain alive and warm and LOVED...Our spirit will have long journeyed on to a new place a new time making more friends and families and stories...I love my mind how it is.I might not be societies perfect person but who is?I have flaws.I am moody and emotional. I love too much and give of myself. I am a great friend and mother. A healer and artist and creator of stories and I grow plants and care for animals...I am human.I am me.And J.K. Rowling where ever you may be, THANKS I did enjoy my travels with you and Harry and ALL those wonderful people you created to become a part of my life and memories. Because it will add some excitement to the pages of my life-book! I am sure my girls will always remember my nerdish obsession with HARRY POTTER.THIS BOOK: HARRY POTTER AND THE DEATHLY HALLOWS Is not for ALL children under the age of oh let's say 10.It is full of death and killing. Of course it was coming, all this drastic drama, but I really do not see a reason for J.K. Rowling to feel she needed to kill certain people.I will not spoil WHO gets the axe, but I have never cried so much in any of these books!However in LIFE there comes DEATH, and some people must stand up and choose between what is RIGHT and what is EASY!And I will always remember the ones who gave their lives in this book to make the Witch & Wizarding world safe once more!A great read, I am planning to keep this as all the books in my collection for as long as I live. I will re read them all again and again.I wait for the MOVIES 6 and 7!THANKS! Nikki Jo
