"After all this time? Always."I've been staring at this blank box for over 10 minutes trying to think of a way to start reviewing the majesty of a book that was Deathly Hallows.There are truly too many emotions clouding my judgement at the moment, just give me a sec.First off I want to say that I'm utterly heartbroken, not only because this book was heartbreaking itself, but because I've just finished reading the Harry Potter series for the first time. I had seen the movies, many, many, MANY times, but I'd never picked up the books, don't ask me, I honestly don't know why. Now that it's over, I truly don't know what to do with myself, I'm so invested in this world, and in this story...to not have another book to look forward to is the most saddening thing. But, still, it was an indescribable experience, and I'm so glad I decided to start this journey back on September. I remember that I actually read Harry's first September 1st scene, on September 1st. I don't know why that brings me so much happiness. The coincidence made it feel like fate, and I DON'T CARE IF IT'S CHEESY, IT'S REAL.On to the good stuff: THIS BOOK WAS UNREAL. Everything, literally EVERYTHING was pure magic. Pun intended. This epic conclusion was, by far, the best series closer I've ever read in my life, nothing could beat this magnificent ending. Everything was so well explained, and thought-out, many loose-ends from other books were corrected in this conclusion, making every book essential, every pointless detail was taken into consideration, and made part of something bigger. That's where J. K. Rowling's true magic lies: being able to forge simple details and conversations into something so big, none of us could see it coming.Harry's, Ron's and Hermione's friendship was severely tested in this book, and their weaknesses were enhanced, so we got to witness the good, the bad, and the ugly that each character has, part because of the environment they endured for basically the whole book (being hunted 24/7, and having to live in the woods for a ridiculously long period of time) and because of the Horcruxes' effect. The whole deal with the Horcruxes was utterly fascinating, every aspect of it intrigued me, from Voldemort's fascination with conquering death, to how he came to know about the Horcruxes, to how he started making them, to the importance of his past, to the though-out locations where he hid them, to the effect they had on people, to how they had to be destroyed, and to the fact that he made a seventh unintended Horcrux that lived inside the boy he most desired to kill. The irony in all of it made me relish with amazement. Something I'd missed with the movies were the lengthy explanations that we get with the book, the explanations of why this Horcrux lived inside Harry, why he lived through two Killing Curses, and how Dumbledore wasn't truly the great man we thought he was.I'm not going to go into a lot of details about the book in case some of you haven't read it, or don't know what happens. Basically, I loved all of this:1. RON AND HERMIONE. -- this the book where Ron's actively trying to start things up with Hermione, with his love advice book at the beginning, and his distraught at Voldemort's Harry/Hermione ship (the scene when he destroys the Horcrux), and protecting her at EVERY moment. This book made Ron shine so much, through the ups and downs, we say an incredible, loyal man.2. HARRY AND GINNY. -- I mean. MUST I SAY MORE? I LOVE THEM.3. THAT EPILOGUE, MAN. -- Perfection. I do wish we'd gotten intel about what became of our three main characters: did Harry become an Auror? What did Hermione & Ron end up doing?4. The EPIC HOGWARTS BATTLE -- Neville. UGH what a SWEETHEART.5. EVERYTHING THAT HAD TO DO WITH HORCRUXES -- finding them, their locations, what they were, how to destroy them, their meaning, EVERYTHING.6. DEATHLY HALLOWS -- I ESPECIALLY loved the scene where they share the myth revolving the three objects.7. HAGRID -- THAT MAN KILLS ME. He's a sweetheart, and everything he does and says will always be beautiful to me. The scene where he has to carry Harry's body. Jesus. That scene is powerful. It brings everything full circle. 8. Kreacher's redemption: DEAR LORD, this elf was the death of me. I used to hate his GUTS, and in the movie, his redemption didn't happen, but in the book it did, and it was beautiful. He helped Harry, Ron & Hermione get one of the Horcruxes, and he had a hand in the final epic battle, where he led the elves against Voldemort's army.9. Dobby: Dobby was very painful. I can't quite put into words how much I loved this character and the sadness his ending caused me. 10. I LOVED the breaking into the Ministry's scene. EPIC. And breaking into Gringotts was SO MUCH FUN, Hermione's impression of Bellatrix was everything.11. SNAPE'S TRUTH: This was my absolute favorite part of the book. When we (FINALLY!) get to see his memories, and see how he's been protecting Harry all this time, was truly on our side, and beautiful his character actually was... He wasn't perfect. He wasn't a great guy. He had his flaws. But he was real. He was loyal, to a fault. He protected, even when sometimes he shouldn't. He was a magnificent character with an incredible arc, without a doubt my favorite character of all-time. Watching him during this book was heartbreaking, but the end was worth it. When Harry finally found out the truth...it was worth it. Silver doe. SILVER DOE. Enough said. I'm done. No more.12. "Not my daughter, YOU BITCH" -- epic.When Percy came back, to help in the Hogwarts battle... I broke down. I broke down BAD. And his stunning scene with Fred... where Perce made that joke. I still can't quite put into words how much it affected me. My heart breaks. Every time.As I said, this was an amazing experience, I can't wait to reread them, and then re-read all my reviews. It's been amazing.I really can't say more, I keep crying every time I write a new bullet, so I'm gonna go, watch the final two movies, and cry some more. If you're still here, thank you for reading. You're the best. <3

The bar of expectation has been set phenomenally high for Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows. And the book not only meets the expectations, but exceeds them.The themes examined in this book are quite mature: how governments twist the truth, how newspapers and media, as the voice of the government, feed misinformation for all sorts of reasons, how trusted adults may have dark pasts and not-so-pure motives. We're past the "simple" issues of revenge and love and well into far more complex agendas.Many children's books (fairy tales) have clear sets of morals and well-defined heroes and enemies: the wicked stepmother, the beautiful princess, the knight in shining armor. This final volume is much more grey; the lines of black and white, good and evil, are not so clear-cut in this book. This is probably very unsettling for younger readers who need to feel secure in a world where grown-ups can be trusted. For more mature readers, this is a beautiful example of peeling back the layers of the onion of life. The series began with a very innocent view of the world, from the viewpoint of a young Harry Potter. As he aged and matured, so did our ability to see what was happening, and we saw his attempts to understand the reason for the actions of his teachers, his friends' parents, and other characters in his ever-expanding world.In Deathly Hallows, Harry is now an adult. He has turned 17, age of adulthood for wizards. He is no longer safe with his aunt and uncle, the protective spell now removed. He can take control of his own actions and path in life. As we all know (and maybe even learned the hard way), this is hardly the freedom that teenagers think it will be. That freedom to rule your own life brings the responsibility for how your actions will affect those around you, the ones that you care for. Harry's choices have a huge impact on Hermoine and Ron, and many, many others who valiantly stand by their friend.In one sense, Harry has been set on a path by Dumbledore, and perhaps all that happens is Dumbledore's fault. On the other hand, Harry has free will, and Dumbledore's instructions have always been vague at best. Harry has quite a range of choice in what he does and does not do. Almost every one of those choices are difficult at best.There are meditations here on the meaning of death and life, on the value of sacrifice. Every character has known pain and has made decisions for selfish reasons. There are celebrations of new beginnings, and there are some endings as well. These mediations shows up often in fine literature; this imagery has been around since mankind began civilization and it is an integral part of how our society works. It is central to this Deathly Hollows, and the book wouldn't be nearly as successful if Ms. Rowling didn't address these thoughts.People looking for non-stop high school hijinks and game competitions will be disappointed. This final novel has none of that. In fact, there are long stretches where the characters feel stymied, and it feels like no progress is being made. The book forces the reader to slow down, to think deeply about what is going on, to feel the strain and pressure of achieving extremely difficult goals. There are action sequences and well-described battles, but these are the exception, not the rule. Deathly Hallows is about intense internal struggles and deeply emotional challenges.The vocabulary reflects this as well. This book is not meant to be skimmed or jumped through. The wording and the sentence structure encourage the reader to go slowly, to contemplate, to think about what is being said. While Harry spends weeks contemplating issues and trying to figure out how he feels about an issue, the reader is encouraged to do the same. It's an adventure of self-exploration.As I already mentioned, the bar was set exceedingly high for this book. It was expected to be exactly perfect, a stunning work of literature appropriate for every age group. It was expected to satisfy both those who wanted a blockbuster "Hollywood Ending" as well as those who feel realism requires death, destruction, and bleak despair. While it did not quite achieve all of those goals (it came REALLY close), it is an outstanding book which has exposed millions of people to questions and issues they might not have otherwise encountered. It encourages people to think about the world they live in. You cannot ask any book to do much more than that.

Pocas veces sufrí tanto como en éste último libro, no se dan una idea de lo que me costó terminarlo. Intenté retrasarlo, pero adentro mío sabía que por más doloroso que fuera, tenía que darle fin a una hermosa saga. Usualmente, la gente me decía cosas como "vas a llorarte la vida cuando lo termines, vas a ver", e incluso antes de iniciar la saga, con ojos como platos "¿Nunca leíste Harry Potter? Te los presto, pero leelos, lo vas a amar" y cosas de esa índole, y yo decía "no creo, dudo que vaya a ponerme tan sentimental". Nunca pensé que el asunto fuera tan literal, ni tampoco imaginé que iba a pasar todo lo que pasó, no solo en el libro, sino en mi vida en general durante los momentos en los que me sumergía en la lectura. Y a medida que leía, más cuenta me daba de que me había encariñado con absolutamente todos los personajes, y que por consiguiente, más duro iba a ser el final.Es increíble lo que un buen libro le puede hacer al corazón, y me resulta casi inconcebible pensar que en algún momento de mi vida me prohibí la saga simplemente por haberme dejado abrumar por el fanatismo ajeno. Ahora veo con claridad por qué ese fanatismo, ahora veo por qué la gente siente fascinación por el mundo mágico de J.K. Rowling, y hasta me atrevo a decir que me siento parte de esa pasión. Sin embargo, siempre aprecié que fuera una autora que dio vida a la lectura en una generación que quizá no estaba tanto en la literatura. Eso es algo que te guste o no la idea de sus libros, se valora enormemente, al menos todo aquél que ame la lectura y tenga deseos de compartir éste buen hábito. Trascendió, rompió con todo, y ahora acá estoy, todavía conmocionada. Lo único que sé con certeza es que voy a volver a leerla en algún momento, porque quiero volver a sentir todo lo que sentí cuando recurrí a la saga por primera vez. Estoy gratamente sorprendida de que nadie me haya spoileado nada (las únicas veces que leí spoilers fue porque me tenté de leer artículos sobre HP, mala, muy mala mía), porque es así como mejor se vive la experiencia. Estoy triste porque no puedo creer que todo haya terminado, pero contenta de ser ahora otra afortunada que conoce éste maravilloso mundo, es una historia que quedará por siempre en mi corazón.

Η άνοιξη του 2016 ηταν για μένα η άνοιξη του Χάρι Ποτερ. Ξεκίνησα την ανάγνωση της σειράς απο καθαρή περιέργεια λόγω όλων αυτών που άκουγα και διάβαζα για τα βιβλια κ με μια διαθεση "ελα μωρε τωρα υπερβολές...βιβλια για παιδάκια με μαγικά και χαζά". Άσε που με πιάνει γενικα μια άρνηση για τα πολυσυζητημένα και τα πολυ προβαλλόμενα βιβλια. Με τούτα και με τ'αλλα ομως ξεκίνησα...Και δεν άφησα τα βιβλια απο τα χέρια μου μέχρι την τελευταια σειρα. Το πρώτα σίγουρα που μπορω να πω ηταν οτι η ανάγνωση ηταν εθιστική. Είχα στη διαθεση μου όλη τη σειρα εξ αρχής και απλά δεν μπορούσα να σταματήσω! Διαβασα τα δυο πρώτα βιβλια στα ελληνικά και όλα τα υπόλοιπα στα αγγλικά. Η γραφή της Rowling έρεε σα νεράκι, με συνεχεία, λυρικότητα, χιούμορ. Όσο περνούσαν τα βιβλια, όσο ωριμαζαν οι ήρωες, ωρίμαζε και η γραφή. Τα δυο πρώτα σίγουρα ειναι απλά, αν οχι απλοϊκά, αλλα απο το τρίτο και μετα, η υπόθεση και η γραφή σοβαρεύουν και γίνονται συναρπαστικά.Τα ένιωσα τα βιβλια. Με έκαναν να τα νιώσω. Κατακλύστηκα απο συναισθήματα, συμπονουσα τους ήρωες, έπασχα μαζι τους, γελούσα, στεναχώριομουν, αγχωνόμουν. Δεν θα ξεχάσω την ανάγνωση του Τάγματος του Φοίνικα..Πως με έβαλε απο την πρώτη στιγμή στην μαύρη και δυσοίωνη ατμόσφαιρα, αυτο το σφίξιμο στο στομάχι που ένιωθα καθόλη τη διάρκεια της ανάγνωσης...Και το Κύπελλο της Φωτιάς (το αγαπημένο μου όλων) με τις τόσες ανατροπές πλοκής και συναισθημάτων..Η Rowling με έβαλε σε έναν μαγικό-απ' όλες τις απόψεις-κόσμο και δε μα άφησε να βγω ως το τελος. Ένας κοσμος καινούριος, με μαγικά πλάσματα, μάγους, ξωτικά, ξόρκια, ενα σχολείο διαφορετικό απο όλα τα αλλα, ενα άθλημα-λατρεία και τα λοιπά και τα λοιπά...Ένας τέλεια φτιαγμένος κοσμος τόσο διαφορετικός και τόσο ίδιος με τον κόσμο μας (δυστυχώς ειμαι κι εγω μια ταπεινή muggle). Γιατι και σε εκείνον τον κόσμο, υπαρχει το καλο και το κακό, η τιμιότητα και η διαφθορά, η άνευ όρων φιλια, η θυσία, η αγάπη, ο έρωτας, τα νεανικά σκιρτήματα, οι αγωνιες..όλα. Και οφείλω να πω οτι η συγγραφέας κατάφερε να περάσει τόσα μηνύματα μέσα απο αυτόν τον μαγικό κόσμο που πραγματικά με εξέπληξε. Δεν θα πω τίποτα για την υπόθεση αλλωστε ειναι λίγο πολυ γνωστή. Αλλα οι ήρωες ειναι τόσο δουλεμένοι, έχουν βάθος, δίκη τους προσωπικότητα, μεγαλώνουν κατα τη διάρκεια της σειράς και εμεις το βλεπουμε αυτο, το νιώθουμε, το ζούμε. Αν μη τι άλλο, ειναι ένας συγγραφικος άθλος αυτο. Σε κάθε περίπτωση, και πιστέψτε με γελάω με τον εαυτό μου που το λεω αυτο, ο Χάρι Ποτερ ειναι μια αναγνωστική εμπειρία που πρεπει να τη ζήσετε. P.S.1 Με χάλασε λίγο το τελος, αλλα το ταξίδι ηταν υπέροχο και δεν μπορω να στερήσω ούτε μισό αστεράκι απο αυτο!!!P.S. 2 RIP to the bravest man in the world!P.S 3 Θα τα ξαναδιαβασω ΣΙΓΟΥΡΑ (Άκου που κατάντησα, εγω, ποιος εγω, που γελούσα με τους χαριποτερικους

"'Hogwarts is threatened!' shouted McGonagall. 'Man the boundaries, protect us, do your duty to our school!'" I was so emotional throughout this whole thing. From the happiness of Harry reuniting with his friends, to the sadness of when so many dearly beloved characters died, and not to mention the anger at Dumbledore for his intricate web of lies, and the hopefulness when Dumbledore explained himself, and I realized he could be forgiven. "'Of course it is happening inside your head, Harry, but why on earth should that mean that it is not real?'" Everything came to a close perfectly. I don't really think JK Rowling could have done better. Hedwig, Mad-Eye, Ted, Fred, Lupin, and Tonks will all, forever be missed. But that was what was so brilliant about this book. It was emotional, and raw, and real. And I am forever thankful for it. "'Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all, those who live without love." Do I love this series with all my heart? Will I read it again and again? Will it be a part of me from now on?The answer is simple. "'Always.'" Because, "All was well." Initial reaction:"All was well."And with this book, I cried many a time. It was wonderful. It was emotional. It was everything a conclusion should be.I guess it's true what they say. The ending is the best part. So, JK Rowling presents the best part of her epic story that I will love until the end of time.

Review before finishing the book (page 603) because ALL THE FEELS. It will contain spoilers......- LUPIN AS A DAD. HE WAS SO HAPPY AND I WAS CRYING OF JOY. TEDDY REMUS LUPIN *crying hard*. - I LOVE IT WHEN GOOD WIZARDS USE THE UNFORGIVABLE CURSES. SO EXCITING!- I LOVE MINERVA MCGONAGALL AND POMONA SPROUT AND FILIUS FLITWICK.- ALSO, I LOVE ALL THE DA MEMBERS AND THE ORDER OF THE PHOENIX.- AND PERCY, PERCY CAME BACK *still crying*.I can't cointaing myself! The battle of Howarts is just starting and I'm so thrilled! I know from the movies what'll be the final outcome, but reading it is so different and much more exciting! ...UPDATE ON PAGE 632: I'M AS PROUD OF NEVILLE AS HER GRAN <3.

Until the very endDamn, this took me very long to finish :( I struggled with the last 200 pages over 3 weeks :( not because it was so awful, it definitely isn't at all :) but this book broke my heart the first time reading it, so I was very afraid about this re-read :)and let me tell you... after turning the last page...my heart shattered into thousand pieces :(The Harry Potter series will always be my favourite book series of all time and Jo will always be my Queen :) ALWAYS ! ! !
For me if the final book isn't amazing (the ending itself), then all of it usually flops. But this one is so freaking amazing that it became part of my favorites shelf.

Full review available at https://jazza1997.wixsite.com/thebook...Amazing. Loved every minute of it. I couldn’t put it down for a single second. I couldn’t believe that Snape, Tonks, Lupin and Fred were all killed. I was so angry about that. But oh well. I’m looking forward to seeing what the cursed child will be like.
Awesome! I can't wait to watch the movies!!

نه سال بعد نوشت:«آخرین دشمنی که نابود می‌‍شود مرگ است»شروع کردن ریویو برای آخرین جلد از مجموعه‌ای که باهاش به معنی واقعی کلمه زندگی کردی، خیلی سخت‌تر از اون چیزیه که فکرش رو می‌کردم. هری‌پاتر و یادگاران مرگ برام جزو کتاب‌های دوست‌داشتنی این مجموعه بود. روند داستان تقریبا خوب و سریع بود. البته قبل از فصل گرینگوتز ریتمش کندتر بود اما این ریتم کندتر باعث می‍‌‌‍‌شد بیشتر نحسی و شومی قاب‌آویز رو حس کنم.شخصیت پردازی مثل اون چیزی که از رولینگ سراغ داشتم، عالی بود. جوری با شخصیت‌ها زندگی می‌کنی که وقتی کتاب تموم میشه انگار یه خلا بزرگی توی روابطت ایجاد شده. من جلد هفت رو از همه جلدهای دیگه بیشتر خوندم. اون اوایل که اومده بود با دو سه ترجمه مختلف خوندم و این بار هم که به لطف گودریدز و پاک شدن سهوی ریویوم، برای نوشتن ریویویی که واقعا حسم رو بتونه بیان کنه دوبار خوندمش و به جرئت می‌تونم بگم هیچ زمانی به اندازه الان حسم بهش مثبت نبوده.کتاب هفت کتاب قدرتمندی بود. واقعا با محتوا بود و لحظه به لحظه تا صفحات آخر بهت اطلاعات جدید می‌داد. غافلگیری توی این کتاب از همه کتاب‌های دیگه بیشتر بود و آدم هی پشت سر هم از اتفاقات جا میخوره. قلم رولینگ هم که واقعا فوق‌العاده است. مرگ‌ و میرهای متناوب کتاب، اونو یکی از غم‌انگیزترین کتاب‌ها و البته جذاب‌ترینشون کرده. من به شخصه طرفدار مجموعه‌هایی با پایان خون‌‍بار هستم و برای همینه که پایان «حماسه دارن شان» رو یکی از بهترین پایان‌های فانتزی می‌دونم. با اینکه به نظر می‌رسه پایان این مجموعه می‌شد به شکل دیگه‌ای باشه، اما این‌طور نیست. من تا همین دفعه که البته مجموعه رو برای بار دوم بخونم، احساس می‌کردم پایان کتاب کاملا سرهم بندی شده است. (نمونه‌اش رو می‌تونین توی ریویو بسیار کوتاهی که چندسال پیش موقع عضو شدن توی گودریدز نوشتم و اخر همین ریویو هست، ببینید.) با این حال حالا که با یه دید برتر به کتاب نگاه می‌کنم، حالا که با علم به پایان داستان مجموعه رو دوباره خوندم و حالا که سنم هم بالاتر رفته و اون هیجان انتشار کتاب آخر رو ندارم، به جرئت می‌گم که رولینگ از روز اولی که شروع به نوشتن کتاب اول کرده، آخر کتاب هفتم رو می‌دونسته. یعنی چیزی نبوده که حین نوشتن مجموعه در موردش تصمیم بگیره. حتی معتقدم مسیر اصلی رسیدن به این پایان رو توی ذهنش رسم کرده. جداً این هفت کتاب از نظر روایی آنچنان انسجامی دارند که چیزی جز این نمیتونه باشه. برای همین هم واقعا به نظرم پایانی جز این برای مجموعه بهتر نبود. اینطوری اون افکار خالص نویسنده روی برگه‌ها اومده چه ما دوست داشته باشیم و چه نداشته باشیم.هری‌پاتر از اون مجموعه‌های عجیب و تاثیرگذار زندگی من بود. اولین مجموعه فانتزی نبود که میخوندم اما توی روزهایی و با شرایط عجیب و غریبی اونو خوندم که برام هر لحظه‌اش خاطره‌انگیزه (حالا کار ندارم که خاطره تلخ یا شیرین). بعد حدود 10 سال که دوباره مجموعه‌اش رو شروع کردم هرگز فکر نمی‌کردم که مثل روز اول کتاب‌ها رو دوست داشته باشم. اگر بخوام اعترافی کنم باید بگم دوستشون داشتم و حتی بیشتر! حتی بیشتر! الان که دارم این ریویو رو می‌نویسم نمی‌دونم چقدر عمر می‌کنم، دقیقه‌ای دیگه می‌میرم یا سال‌ها عمر می‌کنم. نمیدونم که چقدر کتاب خواهم خوند و نمیدونم که تا چه زمانی از فانتزی و ادبیات لذت می‌برم اما میتونم به جرئت بگم که بعید میدونم هیچ کتابی بتونه جای هری پاتر رو برای من بگیره. من چندین سال دیگه به شرط بقای عمر دوباره به سراغ هری‌پاتر میام و از همین الان مطمئنم که لذتم از خوندنش حتی از الان هم بیشتره! میدونید، یه حس عجیب وصف نشدنی. و از همین الان که کتاب رو می‌بندم دلم داره براشون تنگ می‌شه. برای هری و جسارت‌هاش، برای رون و حماقت‌هاش، برای هرمیون و هوشش، برای لونا و عجیب بودنش، برای نویل و شهامت پنهانش، برای هاگرید و تمام کارهای رو اعصابش، برای فردی که نموند و جرجی که گوششو از دست داد، برای ارتش دامبلدور، هاگوارتز، هاگزمید، پناهگاه و حتی برای خانه شماره چهار پریوت درایو! برای اسنیپ و صد البته، دامبلدور...از نسل ما گذشت که روزهای انتشار کتاب رو دیدیم، ما می‌ریم و نسل‌های جدید هری‌پاتر خوان جای ما رو می‌گیرن و باز هم از دنبال کردن ماجراهای پسر برگزیده لذت می‌برن. پسری که فکر می‌کنم برای نسل‌ها خاطره‌سازی کنه و همدم لحظات تنهایی خیلی از آدم‌ها باشه. همونطور که برای من کرد و همدم روزهای سخت من شد، حالا و آخر داستان باید بگم که ازت ممونم هری، پسری که زنده موند...پ.ن 1: اگر این ریویو بیشتر از اینکه شبیه ریویو بوده باشه، شبیه مرثیه‌ای برای هری‌پاتر شده و شما تا اینجا خوندینش و چندان خوشتون نیومده، ازتون معذرت می‌خوام اما دوست داشتم یه جایی و یه جوری بتونم حسم نسبت به این مجموعه رو بیرون بریزم.پ.ن 2: این بار خیلی برام عجیب بود سر مرگ دابی خیلی گریه کردم! عجیبه که برای خودم بلند بلند میخوندم و اشک می‌ریختم. نمیدونم شاید وقتی یه غمی رو بشنوی به جای اینکه بخونی، بیشتر دلت می‌گیره.پ.ن 3: بازگشت هری از مرگ و صحنه مرگش به شدت منو به یاد صحنه مرگ اصلان روی میز سنگی به دست جادیس میندازه. حتی نحوه توصیف فضا و به نظرم میاد که رولینگ از این داستان بی تاثیر نبوده.پ.ن 4: همیشه موقع خوندن داستان آرزو داشتم یکی مثل رون و هرمیون رو کنارم داشته باشم. برای آدمی مثل من چنین چیزی همیشه مثل یه توهم خوش‌آیند بود اما الان واقعا یه رون و هرمیون کنارم دارم! این شاید یکی از بزرگترین موهبت‌هایی باشه که به من داده شده...«در دنیای زنده‌ها چیزهایی هست که خیلی خیلی بدتر از مردنه»جمعه 26 شهریور 1395 -------------قبلاها نوشت:آخرین کتاب. اونطور که انتظار میرفت پیش نرفت . اگه یکی از سه شخصیت اصلی میمردن جالب تر میشد.هرچند همینجوریش هم جالب بود و جزو بهترین کتابای مجموعه.رولینگ برای تموم کردن کتاب یکسری مسائل رو انگار از جیبش درآورد!کاملا معلوم بود کتاب سرو تهش بسته شده و جا داشت که یک کتاب دیگه ادامه پیدا کنه .

Well ahh, I'm the 26,372nd person to review this, so I guess there's not much I can say that hasn't already been said. So, Harry Potter. I finally finished reading all of them. It took me forever and a day, but I did it! For some reason this one took me a particularly long time. Don't know why. I kept being like, "*Reads five pages* .... OKAY! Off to do something else." I guess because it was a little slow starting out. The first half of it was a lot of sitting around in the woods and being like *ARGUE ARGUE ARGUE* But, it got a lot better as it went along. I know J.K. Rowling did have to tie up a lot of things, so that's probably why it was so long and had so much information, etc.Anyway. So I read the second half of it in the car on a 2-hour ride home from Connecticut about a week ago. And toward the end it was getting dark outside, so I had to use my iPod as a flashlight and it was rather difficult and I was getting a headache. But I was like, "MUST. FINISH." It was a good ending. Very satisfying. I've heard people complain about the ending being too happy and whatnot, but it wasn't really ... I mean, half the characters died. (Well, okay, not half. But a lot.) It was bittersweet. And heck, after all that crap he went through, HARRY POTTER DESERVES TO BE HAPPY.Blah blah blah. Still wracking my brain for things to say. I don't know. The thing is, the series was a bit ruined for me because I waited so long to read them; hence, I pretty much knew everything that was going to happen and was mentally/emotionally prepared for everything. So it's kind of hard to evaluate.UMMMM well. I know everyone says this but ... oh my gosh, this series has so much detail. As a writer I utterly fail at details. I'm like, "I should probably explain this more. Nah. I should give this character some kind of backstory. Nah." Whereas, J.K. Rowling has some crazy detailed history for every single one of her characters. AGGGHHH. How did she write these books in less than a hundred years? There's a purpose for everyone and everything in these books. And evidently, she had the last book planned even when she was writing the first book. A lot of series fall flat on the planning aspect; they seem like the author says to his/herself, "Meh, I don't have any other ideas so I'll just write some crappy sequel to that other thing I wrote!" But with Harry Potter, there's a reason for every book, and for everything that happens––even the smallest details. Just .... GAHHH GAHHHHHH HHHAAHGKL;KLDJ. I don't know how to express my awe. It's not fair. I now feel the need to write 100-page outlines for everything I'm writing ... which I guess is a good thing. Anyway, so, the characters. Well, as I said, there's a reason for all of them. And they all have such cool backstories. Except Harry Potter is kind of annoying. And I wish Ginny had been more interesting and that Harry's interest in her hadn't been so random. But, whatevs. I like everyone else. Ron and Hermione are an adorable couple. Voldemort is really creepy (but I love his backstory). Dobby is awesome *cries*. And OHMYGOSH I love Snape. He's so cool. I was the most sad about his death. Especially afterward when you find out his whole backstory. He and Lily had such a sweet relationship. It was so sad. AGGGH. That was the only part that almost made me cry. (Don't get me wrong, a lot of other parts made me sad, it's just that books rarely make me shed actual tears.)Recently I read this thing on Cracked.com about how it would have been cool if it turned out Neville had been the Chosen One all along. Haha. That would've been kind of awesome. But oh well. The ending was still awesome. (This has nothing to do with anything, I just wanted to mention it.)Sorry this review has pretty much no thought or structure to it whatsoever. I'm just not sure how to sum up my thoughts on all seven books. I should read them again sometime to find any cool details I might have missed––now that I know everything that happens, yada yada. Right now I just feel kinda overwhelmed by the series as a whole though, so I probably won't be rereading them for a while. But anyway, they were great.I kind of wonder whether Rowling will ever write anything else. Maybe she's the Harper Lee type and only had one good story to tell. Also I feel like if she writes about anything else, everyone will be like, "THIS IS NOT AS GOOD AS HARRY POTTER." But, oh well. I'm sure the Harry Potter legacy will live on. People will keep reading these books to their kids. J.K. Rowling is probably set for life. So, WOOHOOOO!ONE MORE THING.I solemnly swear that I am up to no good.I just love saying that. :] Heh heh.

BLOG REVIEW:https://passthefeels.wordpress.com/20...Well, I had written half of this review and it just decided to delete itself, so heres take 2 I guess. It was much more poetic the first time... *fumes*I usually don't know where to start with reviews, however this time I feel both like I'll never be able to start, as much as I feel like I'll never be able to stop.I guess I'll just start by simply saying:
  I love Harry Potter.
I would, without a doubt, not be the person I am today without it.I grew up with the films, and read the books later on in life, which I do not regret, as I believe it allowed me to have full understanding and appreciation for the novels, at this age.Anyway, this is not a shrine, it's a review, sooo, here we go.This book was incredible. More so than I ever imagined. I loved it, and it's going straight to the favourites of all time shelf.I don't even really know exactly what to say, all I know is it was amazing from start to finish, but I'll try to form coherent sentences through my shock that I've actually finished reading these now...Looking back on the novel whilst trying to write this review has made me realise how every chapter is like a mini book. Each named appropriately to it's contents, which have taken up little places in my mind, as if they've been filed into categories.From the very beginning, when Harry finally departed from the Dursleys, my heart swelled. Rowling could not have written that scene any better. I just feel it was done perfectly to solidify the way in which they and Harry felt about each other, truly, in the end.I found the entire quest for the horcruxes to be so enthralling. The three friends and their voyage to take down Voldemort, as well as help each other. Especially Hermione and Harry's time in Godric's Hollow, that swelled my heart.The Tale of the Three Brothers. The Deathly Hallows! I have always been fascinated with this, and have never quite fully understood them simply through the film, but reading about it just gave me this whole new insight into the stories and history behind this brilliant idea Rowling had. I absolutely loved this huge aspect of the novel.Severus! The worldly conflict, the never ending debate on whether or not he was a good man... I have finally made up my mind on whether I love him or hate him, and have decided that I love him. Yep. One of the other millions of favourite moments throughout this book has to be the Pensieve scene, surrounding Snapes memories. Harry's journey through Snapes mind was so incredibly interesting, and certainly both made and broke my heart. To finally understand why Snape was the way he was, ahh, just, yes.The Battle of Hogwarts. Do I really need to say more? Wow. The ending, the whole last section was just brilliant. I think it may even be my favourite last part of a book ever. It was executed so well, and tied everything together so well. Once again, the appreciation for Fred and Georges humour, even in times of sorrow, was one of the many highlights of this entire series. As well as Harry, Hermione and Ron's friendship. Their friendship, I believe, is one of the most, if not the most, important aspects of the entire series. I am obsessed with them, in-fact all of the relationships Rowling manages to create are so intricate, and really tug on the heart strings.We got to see the continued relationship between Harry and Dumbledore, which was so nice. I even found myself warming to Kreacher! Oh how unexpected, but lovely.19 years later...Ahhh, I could not deal with this part! It was everything. I feel so lucky to have finally been able to read it. Also, to now be able to continue on with The Cursed Child.Anyway, this is definitely the longest review I have ever done, and I think it's time to stop.If you made it this far, thank you for reading, and I hope (I'm sure) you loved this book as much as I did (or are excited to read it).I'm going to go wipe my tears, watch the Deathly Hallows movies, and fantasise about starting the whole series again... I might just do that. Bye!Order of favourite to least favourite HP book:1. Deathly Hallows2. Half Blood Prince3. Order of the Phoenix4. Philosophers Stone5. Prisoner of Azkaban6. Goblet of Fire7. Chamber of Secrets

I DID IT! I CAN'T BELIEVE I'VE FINISHED THE COMPLETE HARRY POTTER SERIES, AHHH! I didn't really enjoy The Deathly Hallows as much as I enjoyed the previous books (although I did still thoroughly enjoy it) it was lacking Beloved characters and settings the previous books had until the very end. I missed Hogwarts, I missed Hagrid, Dumbledore, Neville, Luna. The first half of the book up until Harry, Ron and Hermione arrived at Hogwarts was a little too slow for me!On the other hand, the second half of the book was fantastic! The battle of Hogwarts was written so well, I was on edge the whole time! There was a lot of deaths that broke my heart and a lot of twists (that I actually saw coming because I saw the movie first, haha.) My favorite chapter has to be 'The Princes Tale' Snape is such a wonderful character and JK. Rowling wrote the characters story so so well!Overall, I did really enjoy this even though it lacked a lot in the first half. It was beautifully written and the ending was perfect! I loved the whole 19 years later chapter, it was an amazing end to a fantastic series! My favorite -> least favorite #1 Half Blood Prince #2 The Order of the phoenix #3 The Prisoner Of Azkaban#4 The Goblet of Fire #5 The Philosophers Stone #6 The Chambers of Secrets #7 The Deathly Hallows

I finished late last night. I stayed awake to finish, because how could anyone stop reading during the epic epic epic end battle of this series!?Rereading Harry potter has been an amazing experience and I love how Rowie and I shared every step of the way. Rereading together also made sure I picked up the next book every month, otherwise my reread would have taken me 3 years or something, but I loved how we did this!This book is now my favorite of all. it gave me all the feels now I remember from all the other books the first time I've read them. in the other books, I had a lot of things that I did not really liked. Still all 5* of course, but I was not head over heels again with this series. This book gave me all those feelings, and made me fall head over heels completely in love with this world. I absolutely love how this book ends and concludes it all. I love the battle.I'm currently rewatching the movies, I've seen the first two, and I'm already excited to be watching the last two movies because I love this book so much now haha!What an amazing job Rowling has done to let the books grow with you. I will allow my children to read one every year from 11 y/o so that they also grow with them :)

Es increíble este libro, tan lleno de acción, suspenso y apesar de todo me hizo reír bastante, quede satisfecha con este final, esta manera de llevar la valentía, la inteligencia, la responsabilidad y sobre todo el amor, es... asombroso. He de adimitir que quiero más de este saga ;'( No puedo creer que he acabado esta saga, es impresionante y tan emocional. Se me saltaron las lágrimas, reír a carcajadas, y por supuesto ame a cada uno de los personajes (excepto a Umbridge, ja), le estoy muy agradecida a J.K Rowling por hacer de estos libros una reliquia para mí. Thank you.“After all this time?”  “Always,” said Snape.

Y con esto termina mi enésima relectura de Harry Potter, aunque esta vez con el añadido de haberla hecho en inglés por primera vez. Me ha encantado releer toda la historia en su lenguaje original y aunque a ratos me ha costado mucho (algunos personajes hablan de una forma muy peculiar, como Hagrid) me ha servido para aprender un montón y para coger todavía más soltura con un tipo de ficción que pensé que sería más complicada de leer en inglés. No tardaré mucho en volver a Hogwarts, no sé en qué idioma, pero volveré pronto, porque Hogwart ha sido mi casa desde la primera página.

This is the first book I have read in 2018 and I couldn’t think of a better book to do me the honour of kicking the year off with a BANG!Oh my goodness, my heart is dangling by a thread inside my rib cage, it has been brutally beaten up and has suffered SO. MUCH. PAIN. throughout these 607 pages, but it was so worth it.The final Harry Potter book, I’ve done it. I’ve finally read the Harry Potter series! I cannot believe I haven’t read this infamous series years ago. The magic, the characters, the world, the plot....absolute genius. I tip my hat to you J. K. Rowling. 🎩I don’t know how to express my all of my geelings into words because this finale has rendered me speechless.HOW am I supposed to pretend like everything is okay? I can’t just go back to facing reality, not when I know that’s it. No more Harry Potter (I don’t plan on reading the Cursed Child for the time being but that could change in the future), nothing new from these characters ever again.I will be rereading the series (or at least I hope I will) this December, and if all goes to plan, I want to reread the series every December/Winter or every other December/Winter.I have enjoyed my journey throughout reading Harry Potter, and this isn’t the end of my journey, NOPE! This is only the beginning.And I look forward to reuniting with Harry and the gang for many more years yet to come.

I feel like this isn't a Harry Potter novel. It doesn't follow Rowling's typical formula of following Harry's rule-breaking antics at Hogwarts and there is a crap ton of stuff that happens in this book. To read this book as a Harry Potter lover is a very emotional journey; it is truly heart breaking. For me, when this book first came out it marked the end of my childhood. I was in 5th grade when the first one came out and a freshman in college when this one finally hit shelves. My heart has never recovered from the ending of this series...I don't know where this ranks on my "Harry Potter list" because it's sort of an outlier to the series and it's a hard book to read (there should be a warning label that tissues are required). Here is my list of Harry Potter novels in order of my most favorite to my least favorite (for those who care...I guess! ha ha): 1.)Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince2.)Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire3.)Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban4.)Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix5.)Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone6.)Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets*Honorable mention - Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (seriously I can't rank this one)What a journey it was re-reading these! Till next time....

Este libro es sufrimiento puro, más allá de ciertos momentos de dicha que resultan ser una bocanada de aire fresco entre tantas desdichas. Coincido con muchos en que Rowling desató su lado malvado en esta historia, porque hay sucesos que pueden solo justificarse de esa manera. Por otro lado, los misterios que se van desenrollando a lo largo de las páginas resultan uno más macabro que otro, y eso no es que logre aplacar nuestros nervios ante lo que pueda sucederle a nuestros queridos personajes. Además, hay una cosa en la que coincido y a la vez disiento con muchas personas. Creo que una acción buena puede justificar alguna que otra mala, pero no años de maldad, aunque entiendo a aquellos que piensan que un último acto de bondad lo puede todo. En principio podría decirse que en este séptimo libro de la saga, Harry, Ron y Hermione viven una nueva aventura, pero al ser ya adultos, esa aventura no es necesariamente divertida e inofensiva. Por último, este libro me ha roto el corazón, me lo ha dejado en cachitos y me lo ha vuelto a armar, pero el daño ya estaba hecho. Por supuesto es más que recomendable.

I did not discover as many new things reading this for the first time after seeing the movies. That being said, this is one of my favorite books of the series. It contains so much wizarding lore and emotional sincerity. I cried a couple of times. The epilogue didn't even bother me that much. I do wish we had seen more of the immediate aftermath of the war with Voldemort rather than ending hours after the battle and then jumping nineteen years.

AyyyyFin de esta relectura de la saga y hay puro amor en mí por esta historia <3!!La primera vez que lo leí sentí que en este libro pasaban demasiadas cosas y todo el tiempo. esta vez, sólo puedo confirmarlo. La cantidad de veces que me reí, que lloré, que me emocioné fueron interminables. Aparte con toda esta relectura y en especial con este último libro tengo que afirmar, una vez más, que Rowling sabía demasiado bien lo que estaba haciendo al construir la historia. Hay tantos indicios de lo que se venía y tantos otros que explican cosas a las que normalmente la gente no pone mucha atención.Si alguien no ha leído el libro(debajo de qué piedra viven?), aviso altiro que no taparé los spoilers.Creo que la mayoría recuerda las cosas importantes de este libro, por lo que me voy a centrar en cosas más específicas esta vez. Obvio que de nuevo sufrí eñe en muchas partes, la historia de Kreacher, cómo Voldemort lo usó para probar la protección del relicario y cómo desestimó al pobre, pensando que moriría ahí, Dios, ese momento como que te desgarra y lo más maravilloso es cómo Harry se porta con él después, o sea lo de regalarle el relicario de Regulus y cómo después cambia toda la actitud del elfo con ellos, es hermoso, siempre sufriré por el pastel de carne y riñones que no alcanzaron a comer. También está el momento en que Ron se va. ODIO ese momento, es tan triste ver cómo se rompe el vínculo que une a Harry y Ron, fue como volver al cuarto libro cuando no se hablaban. Al mismo tiempo, es genial cómo se arma la historia de Ron y cómo uno puede entender porqué le afecta tanto la situación de andar sin rumbo fijo, pasar hambre y frío, que el horrocrux lo afectara tanto; y también ver cómo llega de vuelta a ellos, ese momento maravilloso en que rescata a Harry del pozo donde estaba la espada de Gryffindor y después destruye el horrocrux, me encanta.Cuando uno llega a cierto momento en este libro, no puede parar, porque empieza a desencadenarse una serie de acontecimientos que te arrastran a seguir la lectura, como que ya no depende de ti parar, sino que es casi una fuerza mayor la que te tira. A mí me pasa desde la Mansión Malfoy en adelante o incluso antes, cuando van a ver a Xenophilius Lovegood.Sé que mucha gente no le ve el sentido a las Reliquias en la historia, pero sin ellas, sin que las hubiesen explicado, muchas cosas no se habrían solucionado en este libro. Solo por dar un ejemplo, cuando Harry va finalmente al Bosque a entregarse a Voldemort, no habría podido pasar a los dementores si no hubiese sido porque usó la Piedra de la Resurrección y se acompañó por sus papás, Sirius y Lupin. Ni empezar a hablar del entendimiento que tuvo Harry de cómo funcionaba la Varita de Saúco jamás habría tenido la seguridad que tuvo al vencer a Voldemort al final. Es por esto mismo que amo mucho la conversación con Dumbledore en King's Cross. Me voy a detener aquí, porque si no, escribiría por siempre jajajaDescargos:FRED!! por qué tuvo que morir Fred T.T?Snape, nunca te querré y odio infinito a quienes le dieron el perdonazo.Me encantan los momentos en que aparece Draco, siento que su transformación es muy notoria desde el libro anterior. El crucio de Harry <3!McGonagall, te amo.Quise cachetear a Hermione unas cuantas veces.Amo que Harry reparara su varita.JK, maestra.

Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all, those who live without love.5/5 starsAnd it all comes to an end. This book is the fantastic finale of Harry Potter series. I can’t be more satisfied. From the beginning, it’s full of breathtaking actions. Finally it’s an all out war for both sides. And I’m glad even though the story mostly set in various places, they still went back to Hogwarts in the end because I love the school. The final battle was just epic. Everyone involved. The students, Order of Phoenix, Dumbledore’s Army, graduated students , the statues, the ghosts, even Peeves the poltergeist. It’s like a horrible reunion. Sure there’re deaths, and there were some characters I like among them T.T but there were also surprises, things that I didn’t expect. Malfoy became kind heroic for a brief moment when he saved Goyle’s life. Neville Longbottom became awesome. He’s not only lead Hogwarts’ resistance against the Carrows but he fought fearlessly that even Voldemort was impressed with him. And remember Neville’s boggart? It’s seemed that he was scared if his grandmother with a good reason. The old lady was truly scary when she’s angry. The twist is just cruel. I can’t say much without spoil it but.. well, it’s cruel. I can’t find other words for it. I love how Harry turned to be the big hero here. I admit that there were times in previous books where I was a bit disappointed on Harry’s character development but at the end, he’s wonderful in this book. Usually Hermione was the one played big roles in solving mysteries but Harry did it by himself here. I don’t know how to express what I think about this book but that it’s exceed my expectations. A wonderful book. Really recommended for all fantasy reader. :D

“Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and above all those who live without love.” Started reading the Harry Potter series on Christmas 2016 and ended it on New Year's Eve 2017. Couldn't have made it better. I loved every second of it, every dialogue between Harry and Ron and Hermione, every character, every member of the Weasley Family and the Order of the Phoenix and Dumbledores Army. Every fighting scene. Every death scene. Every love scene. This is just the best series ever written and it has a special place in my heart with The Mortal Instruments. I know I could tattoo these two series on my body and I would still love them as dearly in 50 years. They just mean the world to me. Now to this book: It was definitely my favorite of the series. I didn't expect it to be since there is not a lot of Hogwarts and my favorite characters and it's frustrating and hard, but I loved it the most. I just couldn't stop reading. I knew what was gonna happen, I've watched every movie at least 30 times, but I still stopped breathing at so many pages. I am so sad this has come to an end, I know I can reread it whenever I feel like it but it still won't be the same as the first time. Now to end this last Harry Potter review, I want to quote Dumbledore:“Of course it is happening inside your head, Harry, but why on earth should that mean that it is not real?”

Lo termine ayer, pero tuve que tomarme un tiempo para reflexionar, para poner en orden mis ideas.El libro me ha encantado♥Sin lugar a dudas me da pena terminar esta saga, aunque se que Hogwarts siempre estará con las puertas abiertas esperándome. Y pienso volver.Es un mundo lleno de magia, y aventuras. Y no puedo terminar esta reseña sin agradecer a Flor, quien se ha convertido en una persona muy importante en mi vida, a través de esta saga. Con ella leí los libros, con ella disfrute de las aventuras, ella me acompaño en las lágrimas y en las risas. Se banco mi amor por Remus♥. A veces se nos complicaba con el tiempo y nuestras actividades pero LO LOGRAMOS. Asique gracias Parabatai♥, no hubiera sido lo mismo sin vos, no hubiera sido tan entretenido, tan divertido, tan desgarrador, tan perfecto. Y vamos por más♥Y como te dije hace unos meses, en un futuro haremos maratones de las películas juntas, y haremos pijamadas con nuestros hijos y les leeremos los libros♥ (con la excusa de poder volver a estar juntas leyendolos). Gracias por acompañarme y animarte a compartir vagón conmigo en el Expreso Hogwarts!

I'm lacking of words right now, but I'll try and form a decent review for such a decent, marvellous, outstanding book.As a series, it is completely obvious that J.K. Rowling beat herself writing this beauty, creating a whole new world out of scratch, with all its details and personalities is just awe inspiring. Listening to this at work probably wasn't the best of decisions. At various times within the story, I found myself choking back tears! Every loss felt as if I experienced it for the first time. And after every re-read, I find myself appreciating how flawed all these characters were. All these characters felt real because they embodied real human behavior. "...The world isn't split between good people and death eaters. We've all got good and bad inside us. What matters is the part we choose to act on. That's who we really are." Jo's writing exhibited this at every turn. This truly was a magical world, full of life and possibility, and a place where I can call home.

And with the turning of the final page, I have once again finished this amazing series. All questions were answered, and as this series was basically my childhood the nostalgia was greatly felt. The experiences I have with these books, like the others before it, just keeps getting better with each read. I might have a slight book hangover from this, however I am very much looking forward to discovering (or maybe even rediscovering) other worlds until such time I might consider revisting this one once again in the future. Until next time...

If anyone has not read this series I would without a doubt suggest them as they're absolutely breathtaking and every single character worms their way into your heart.

This is my second time reading this series, and I don't think this book really needs a review. 99% of the people who've read it, love it. And the rest are crazy. And those who haven't read it? Well, they're even crazier.This series will forever remain one of, if not my all time favourite series, and I cannot express my wholehearted adoration for every single page of every single book. I cried like a baby at the end, just because it's over. Hogwarts is my home.

Yesterday I read 
  Harry Potter and The Deathly Hallows
 for what seemed like the gazillionth time. I didn’t want to write a review. Again. It’s been done and it was a gushing, brimming with love and adulation write-up.Today, I just wanted to make a mini-keepsake. A little something for all my Potterhead friends. Something that encapsulated all the key moments in the books...moments that moved me...moments that made me smirk gleefully..moments that broke my heart (in a nice way, if that’s even possible). So here goes:——————————————————————————————-MOMENT #1:
  ‘I don’t think you’re a waste of space.’
——————————————————————————————-MOMENT #2:
  “Are you planning to follow a career in Magical Law, Miss Granger?’ asked Scrimgeour. ‘No I’m not,’ retorted Hermione. ‘I’m hoping to do some good in the world!’
——————————————————————————————-MOMENT #3:
  On this spot, on the night of 31 October 1981, Lily and James Potter lost their lives. Their son, Harry, remains the only wizard ever to have survived the Killing Curse. This house, invisible to Muggles, has been left in it’s ruined state as a monument to the Potters and as a reminder of the violence that tore apart their family.
——————————————————————————————-MOMENT #4:
  RON:’He knew what he was doing when he gave me the Deluminator, didn’t he? He - well, he must’ve known I’d run out on you.’HARRY:’No, he must’ve known that you’d always want to come back.'
——————————————————————————————-Moment #5:
  ‘Dobby has no master!’ squealed the elf. ‘Dobby is a free elf, and Dobby has come to save Harry Potter and his friends!’
——————————————————————————————-Moment #6:
  Here lies Dobby, a Free Elf.
——————————————————————————————-Moment #7:
  ‘The wand chooses the wizard,’ said Ollivander.
——————————————————————————————-Moment #8:
  ‘PIERTOTUM LOCOMOTOR!’And all along the corridor the statues and suits of armour jumped down from their plinths, and from the echoing crashes from the floors above and below, Harry knew that their fellows throughout the castle had done the same.‘Hogwarts is threatened! Man the boundaries, protect us, do your duty to our school!’
 ——————————————————————————————-Moment #9:
  ‘No,’ said Ron seriously, ’ I mean we should tell them to get out. We don’t want any more Dobbys, do we? We can’t order them to die for us -‘There was a clatter as the Basilisk fangs cascaded out of Hermione’s arms. Running at Ron, she flung them around his neck and kissed him full on the mouth.
——————————————————————————————-Moment #10:
  And Percy was shaking his brother, and Ron was kneeling beside them, and Fred’s eyes stared without seeing, the ghost of his last laugh still etched upon his face.
——————————————————————————————-Moment #11:
  - CHAPTER THIRTY-THREE -The Prince’s Tale
——————————————————————————————-Moment #12:
  ‘Have you grown to care for the boy, after all?’‘For him?’ shouted Snape. ‘Expecto Patronum!’From the tip of his wand burst the silver doe:she landed on the office floor, bounded once across the office and soared out of the window. Dumbledore watched her fly away, and as her silvery glow faded he turned back to Snape, and his eyes were full of tears.‘After all this time?’Always,’ said Snape.
——————————————————————————————-Moment #13:
  ‘You’ll stay with me?’‘Until the very end,’
——————————————————————————————-Moment #14:
  ‘Tell me one last thing,’ said Harry. ‘Is this real? Or has this been happening inside my head?’‘Ofcourse it is happening inside your head, Harry, but why on earth should that mean that it is not real?’
——————————————————————————————-Moment #15:
  ‘He is dead!’ Narcissa Malfoy called to the watchers.
——————————————————————————————-Moment #16:
  ‘I’ll join you when hell freezes over,’ said Neville.‘Dumbledore’s Army!’ he shouted.
——————————————————————————————-Moment #17:
  ‘NOT MY DAUGHTER, YOU BITCH!’
——————————————————————————————-Moment #18:
  ‘Avada Kedavra!’
‘Expelliarmus!’——————————————————————————————-Moment #19: (…and I liked the fact that it was appropriately enough, the 19th moment)
  The scar had not pained Harry for nineteen years. All was well.

STORY:Harry finally realizes what it takes to defeat Voldemort – but it is no easy solution. What choice will he make?ENJOYMENT FACTOR:I started this over a year and a half ago and hated it so much I left it unfinished 1/3 of the way. I finally coerced myself to finish it before seeing the final HP movie. I didn’t hate it as much the 2nd time around (I think the loathing may have been partly due to the bad taste that Book 6 left in my mouth) and despite myself I enjoyed the story (for the most part). Rowling fleshes out her characters, showing the good and bad in them (prime example: Dumbledore). Rowling also aces at raising the stakes, shrouding the plot in mystery, getting her characters in trouble and out again. The plotline is convoluted and it sags heavily in the middle but the secrets kept this reader plodding along.WRITING STYLE:Rowling’s love of adverbs borders on the obscene. The greatest affront is in the last chapter:Harry to his son: “Albus Severus, you were named for two headmasters of Hogwarts. One of them was a Slytherin and he was probably the bravest man I have ever known.”Really, Rowling? Snape worked as a double-agent to the two most powerful wizards at great personal cost, duped Death Eaters and Order members alike, endured the hate and distrust of all, sacrificed his life for love, and HARRY CAN’T EVEN BE FREAKING SURE that he was the bravest!??!Fortunately the movie’s scriptwriters promptly fixed this oversight.OTHER OBSERVATIONS (The X Factor):As I watched the movie soon after finishing the book, it’s difficult for me to divorce the two. I LOVED the movie. If only for those 5 minutes of Snape’s memories in the pensieve, the most moving performance I have seen in recent years. (All hail Alan Rickman!) I know people are complaining about all the revisions, but I actually appreciated most of the things they changed in the movie. They cut out the plodding (and unnecessary parts), focused on the meat and bones, and fixed all the inconsistencies and awkward plotting I noticed in the book. For example:1)	Ravenclaw’s diadem (a horcrux) was accidentally destroyed in the book by Fiendyre. The explanation being that the cursed fire was so potent it was one of the few things that could destroy a horcrux. Sorry but I don’t buy that. If so, Harry and co. shouldn’t have wasted their time and energy looking for a magical object (Sword of Gryffindor) to destroy the horcrux when they could have used their energies to learn the Fiendfyre curse instead. They fixed this in the movie by using a Basilisk fang to destroy the horcrux instead of Fiendfyre.2)	In the book I had no idea how Neville pulled the Sword of Gryffindor from the Sorting Hat – wasn’t it stolen by Griphook? The movie makes this clearer. 3)	I liked the scene where Harry realizes what he MUST do to defeat Voldemort (I believe it’s the climax of the entire series), but I found Harry’s face-off with his archnemesis cheesy to the point of being ridiculous. He duels with the most murderous and evil Wizard in history in full view of the entire school because, as he tells Voldy: ’I sacrificed my life for them so now they’re immune to you. You can’t hurt them!’ I understand the rationale (same principle as his mother’s sacrifice) but that doesn’t stop me from rolling my eyes. They fixed this in the movie by moving the duel in a private area with no spectators and not giving anyone ‘magic immunity’. (Although I doubt if the light saber rays shooting from the duelers’ wands was an improvement).4)	The plot point of an Ultimate Elder Wand didn’t sit well with me. I thought by this time Harry and Voldemort would face off in a true test of skill – I expected something along wandless magic. But why bother when you can win by technicality and have an Elder Wand to Rule Them All (a.k.a. deus ex machina). Unfortunately this plot hole was beyond the scope of the movie to fix.That said, I think the book and movie complement each other perfectly. The movie highlights the best parts and improves on the story, while the book gives a thorough explanation of everything. COMMENT ON THE HP SERIES AS A WHOLE:Rowling’s greatest achievement is in creating memorable, distinctive characters and a magical world readers would want to live in again and again. I remember being struck with awe when I read Book One nearly a decade ago. However, I found Rowling’s stories increasingly diluted and un-enjoyable from Book 4. Not because of the dark tone, but because the convoluted plot lines made it harder to figure out the true story beneath. Coincidentally, this was also the time Rowling probably fired her editor and her books afflicted with elephantiasis syndrome.My major disappointment with the series, however, is the uselessness of its main character. Harry Potter never improved in his abilities— his achievements are from pure luck and genetics. He doesn’t study, he doesn’t practice, he doesn’t make the effort. Even his questionable talents in wizardry and Parseltongue could be directly attributed to Voldemort. Harry Potter is mediocre, and remained a mediocre pawn of Dumbledore all through out.

December 2017This is the first time I have listened to the series on audiobook, and I think I got something new from them as I do with every re-read. July 2009After my second reading of this book, I have so many more feelings and comments about it than I did after the first reading. But I think those comments mainly deal with the series as a whole, rather than just this book, and this book (being the conclusion of the saga) just brings some of the brilliance of the entire series more fully into focus. I may take a page from Madeleine's book and write a review of the entire series. I also think that this is a series I could read once a year. July 2007Wow. I cannot believe it's over! This book was an absolute emotional roller coaster. I don't even know where to start so I'm just going to list some random thoughts:1. I am exceedingly happy (and surprised) that the trio survived. I was sure Ron or Hermione was going to die. In the scene where Bellatrix is torturing Hermione, I thought that was going to be it and I was pissed that Ron never got the chance to tell her how much he loved her. 2. Along those same lines, I didn't really like how LONG it took Ron and Hermione to finally get together. I understand this is war, and there were more pressing things on their minds than dating, but they escaped death so many times that I thought they'd declare their love for each other out of the heat of the moment. It was cute how, once Ron finally embraced Hermione's passion for S.P.E.W., she lays one on him.3. The death of Dobby was very sad. But Dobby would have wanted to die saving Harry Potter. This was not the first time he risked everything to come to Harry Potter's aid. I think it'll be harder for me to read the second time, though, The first time, I was so worried that Hermione was going to die that it numbed the pain of Dobby's death. But the funeral scene was very sad.4. I was very saddened by Fred's death, but I wasn't altogether surprised. I never thought that all of the Weasleys would survive, and I figured it would be Fred or George. I was really happy to see Ginny, Hagrid, and Neville live. I was also sad about Tonks and Lupin, but I think it's intersting that Harry's godson was orphaned in the fight to defeat Voldemort just as Harry was. It'll definitely give Harry some insight into his godson's feelings. But my question is, who raised him? Clearly, he didn't grow up living with Harry, so did he get raised by Tonks' mother? 5. My "Yay for you!" character moments: Dudley shaking Harry's hand. Mrs. Weasley calling Bellatrix a bitch. Percy redeeming himself. NEVILLE stepping up and becoming a full-on leader with the DA, and then drawing the sword out of the hat and killing Nagini, allowing Harry to defeat Voldemort once and for all!6. I wish we'd have had a few more clues throughout the series as to Dumbledore's past. I never even knew he had a sister, did anyone else? Even just a passing mention of her somewhere... I understand now why Dumbledore had to die. I mean, I knew it would have something to do with Harry needing to go it alone, but it was more than that. Had Dumbledore been around for Harry to ask about the Deathly Hallows, I think things would have turned out differently.7. Voldemort's arrogance was his undoing. He was too arrogant to think there would be more to the prophecy, so he went after baby Harry, thereby fulfilling his own prophecy and equipping Harry with his own power, his own soul. He was arrogant enough to think that Harry's blood in his own veins would give him Lily's protection without giving Harry any ties to him. He was arrogant enough to think that his own wand would work against Harry, arrogant enough to think Lucius' wand would work against Harry, arrogant enough to think he could just steal the Elder Wand without earning it.8. Let the Christ/Messiah comparisons continue: not only did Harry willingly sacrifice himself for all of mankind, but he even was, in a way, resurrected.9. Didn't Rowling say that a non-magic person would use magic late in life? Who was it? DId I miss something?10. And finally... SNAPE! I knew he was good, I knew it, I knew it!! Brent and I had just discussed Snape carrying a torch for Lily. Brent even called it that Voldemort was going to spare Lily because Snape asked him to, and that when Lily died, Snape left Voldemort forever. I was disappointed that we learned all about Snape at the end, though, I would have liked to find out little by little, and have Harry piecing it together. I guess this way was more dramatic though. I definitely teared up when Harry named his son Albus Severus and told him that Severus Snape was probably the bravest man he ever knew.

“Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all those who live without love.”  (You're such a wise man, Dumbledore.)A million of stars will never be enough to rate this book.No Spoilers! (I promise!)Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows is by far, my favorite book of the entire series. Hands down. I'm very, VERY happy I come to the end of the series, but also sad since the series is over now. It was my 2012 summer goal and I have finally accomplished it! With help and support from my dear friends, Keertana, Jordyn, Inge, and Olivia, they all convinced me to keep reading the series and assured me that the series will keep getting better and it did! This book changed me...It had changed me in a postive way. It's one of those books that changed me and make a lasting impression upon your life. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows suprised me, made me laugh, and made me weep silent tears for an hour. There's never a single book that can changed me and I'm proud to say this is the 1st life-changers book. Why didn't I read this sooner?! Everybody gave raving and positive reviews on it, but crazy me ignored it. I'm very happy that I read the entire series. It has been one hell of a ride! :D I predict in the future when I'm old and wrinkly, I will still read this series over again and again...The characters again were smart, cunning, and well-developed from beginning to end. Lots of tragic deaths has occured in this book which will impacted lots of readers, but I'm not going to name names because it will spoiled the story for those who haven't read the series. My favorite character would have to be Snape besides Harry and his friends. I finally get to see his good/evil intentions present in the last installment. The word "Always" that Snape said had shown a new light in its name. This finale shows us that even the evil (bad) guys have good intentions as well and can be refer as the good guy in some cases. Snape is one of them. The ending to the book was spectacular and unforgettable to a remarkable series. The action was fast-paced and very addicting. You will find in no time you'll finish this book sooner than expected! Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows is just so epic! :) Enough, said.Overall, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows is a phenomenal. It will always engages readers and give us a sense of belonging and emotions that follow with it. I will never forget this series because it had brought possiblities to a new light and changed me in a very, very good way. (I'm almost certain it will change others as well) And for that, I will always be eternally grateful. Thank you, J.K Rowling, for writing such a phenomenal series, one that readers all over the world will never forget and will treasure beyond all else....P.S Plus, a box of tissues would be helpful to read this book....:(I STRONGLY encourage reading this series if you HAVEN'T AlREADY! YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT!!And last, my contribution to Snape...(Thanks Snape.)______________________________________If you want to read my previous reviews of 1st-6th books of Harry Potter, just click the link below.-Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone's review -Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets's review-Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban's review-Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire's review -Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix's review-Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince's review

I just wanted to say that I loved it and it exceeded all my expectations. I know most people finished their books weeks ago, but I didn't have that luxury with everything else I had going on this summer. The Girl and I decided that we wanted to reread some of the more recent books and we thought it'd be neat if we did it together. So, with her hard cover copy we read aloud the 6th book, beginning it the night we bought the 7th. Yes, it was hard not starting that right away. And even harder that I was reading it out loud, since that would take more time. But it was a whole lot more fun. I would do all the voices and inflections. I even did some of the voices with their accents (not all, my British Isles accents are limited). Of course, at the end of the 6th and several times during the 7th, I had to close the book and try to compose myself. I'm a guy and should never been seen weeping. Especially from reading! Now, if I were kicked in the nuts or my favorite team lost or my life long dog died, then it would be acceptable to openly weep. Definitely not from a book. So I had to read a line and I would see the next line and I'd have to take a few moments, while The Girl was agonized. She would exclaim, "Well? What happened?" And I would see what happened. I could see the next few lines. But I just couldn't say them aloud just yet. It was quite emotional. And just a few short years ago, I couldn't stand anything Harry Potter. Of course I hadn't read any of the books or seen any of the movies. I just didn't like the mass hysteria surrounding it. So I avoided it. And then people I trusted and respected began to scoff at me. The couldn't understand why I hadn't joined the Harry Potter bandwagon. The promised me that if I made it through the first two books, I would love the third. So I picked up the first book and read it in a day. I thought it was cute. I picked up the second book. And read it in a day. I thought it was cute. Then I picked up the third book. And read it in a day. I thought it was good. No. Really good. This was no Scooby Doo with magic adventure anymore. This actually had a larger story. After that, I read all the books, watched all the movies and had my own sort of theories about what was going to happen in the last book. I made my own death list (people sure to die). I made my survivor list (people sure to live). And finally The Girl and I read the last book. Of course, I went in with high expectations, but with a realistic goal of being mildly disappointed. Isn't it always the case that anything and everything that you highly anticipate never reaches the level that you thought it'd be. The last book, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows was everything I wanted from the ending to the series. I laughed. I (almost) cried. I smiled all through it at the joy of reading it. If you haven't yet gotten into Harry Potter, move out of the cave and go to a bookstore. This is a bandwagon that I'm not ashamed to have jumped on.

The conclusion to a truly epic series. I’m so happy I made this re-read. All the wonderful memories, the great moments now … Although I usually remember all details the first time, there were some here that I had forgotten about and revisiting them was a delight!Dumbledore is dead but Harry finally has at least some faint idea of how to defeat Voldemort so after returning to Privet Drive one last time, visiting the Burrow, running from the wedding there after a Death Eater attack and hiding at Grimauld Place for a while, he embarks on the mad search for the Horcruxes and important pieces of history. There are lots of small moments of sweetness (like Kreacher coming around) but the overall atmosphere is, of course, that of dreadful loss and action. It’s a chase, basically, but not just that. It’s also a hunt for history, the complete picture emphasizing the importance of knowledge and that was the best part for me (apart from the chapter when Harry sees Snape’s memories). I have said it so many times that many might already be fed up but I don’t care: it needs pointing out that the brilliance of Stephen Fry as a narrator never waivered. It doesn’t matter if it was quiet moments or full-on action like the Battle of Hogwarts. Fry was brilliant. Female characters, male characters, creatures; funny moments, tragic moments, shocking moments. I soon stopped picturing Fry behind a microphone but saw all the different witches and wizards, the castle and all the other places. I’ve listened to a number of audiobooks this year. In fact, I’ve come to like them very much although I never thought it possible, and many narrators were fantastic (Zara Ramm comes to mind). But not one of them came close to the quirky and brilliant Britishness of Stephen Fry and his signature narration of this series.
