“Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all, those who live without love.” 
The seventh book of the Harry Potter series, what else can I say, in my this state of bewilderment , other than  is a Masterpiece of the ages.The innate theme of tragedy rears it’s head here . the loss of characters too dear to our hearts and the continuous hum in the background of "it all ends here" , our journey that lasted too long and has had the best of our hearts would actually end here . you should expect tears , a great deal of heart ache ,emotional breakdown moments , life threatening events with danger breathing down our character's necks. action packed ,violent and deathly battles and a few days sleepwalking hangover in the least of chances, in this incredible groundbreaking finale of the Harry Potter saga .the Deathly Hallows is one of the greatest fantasy books I have ever read, the characters shine the brightest in this book , it is magnificent to follow the huge character development undergoing, leaving no doubt as to the value of nobility and morality. it pulses with the sense of maturity as much as of bravery inspite of the characters youth and lack of experience , i may quote from A Torch Against the Night that i finished not long ago “Callow is the hope of our youth" .I am not in the realm of discussing events or writing about what actually happens in the plot , because either you know every moment by heart or you most definitely should discover them yourself , but i am to talk about the wonders and the awes the book offers , about the prodigiousness of this saga , about J. K. Rowling casting a Confundus Charm on every reader of hers to end this book, then to close it whispering to themselves 
  " Woah " .
The themes of true friendship , genuine love and self-sacrifice are so touching , it portrays how false pride ,hunger for power and selfishness always go hand in hand with evil , even in the noblest of characters . i love that Kreacher was the one who led the house elves in their fight in the Hogwarts battle , isn't it one more powerful message of Rowling's books ? that people change if we change our attitude toward them , this series believes in second chances , in true everlasting love , believes that people are actually good at heart .And even with the final book in the series ,the one where Rowling was unlikely to surprise us, she pulls up her sleeves and writes a most incredible sequel to her previous 6 books , the awaited moment when Harry is expected to step out at forefront of the battle , to kill the Lord Voldmort and survive as he always did with a most unexpected skill, Rowling chooses not to walk down that tried and predictable path . Instead, harry's survival is to be seized this time by the acceptance of his own death , from the bravery not in fighting his way through battles but in the self-sacrifice. she shows again that the power of love is to overcome any other .It breaks my heart that no sock is efficient to free Dobby from the grasps of death , it breaks my heart that Sirius, Lupin , Tonks and Dumbledore are no more , it breaks my heart that Snape had never showed the best of him , his winningly helplessly genuinely beating heart , it breaks my heart that for George every mirror would ever be the mirror of Ersid .But, yet, I am to borrow Jhon Green's words " it would be a privilege to have my heart broken by you " . oh,yes . most definitely.This series means too much to me. maybe i feel like it took me too long to start reading the books , it doesn't even make sense , may be i even feel a little bit ashamed and confused about this fact , but since i was eleven , since that very year in which i watched the first harry potter movie for the first time ever and bought that schoolbag with Harry, Ron and Hermione faces on it , i loved it , I can’t fully articulate it. It just is so special and it feels weird that all these people around the world share my very same passion . I've always loved that world ,but now i do more profoundly , from a place much deeper much more sincere in my heart , i love it still and i will always do ."After all this time?Always."

As Harry Potter celebrates his seventeenth birthday, he leaves Privet Drive knowing that the protective charms that kept him hidden from Lord Voldemort no longer work. With the help of Ron and Hermione, Harry is ready to carry out Dumbledore's last request. He must find the Horcruxes and destroy Voldemort.The seventh book in J.K. Rowling's Harry Potter series leaves me asking one question...is there a rating higher than 5 Stars? If so, this is one of those books that deserves it. Rowling winds up the series with a fantastic story. Nearly all of the major characters that we were introduced to throughout the series are back. I was happy to see some of my favorites...Hagrid, Lupin, Fred and George Weasley, and Professor MacGonagall. I was even happy to see one of the characters I actually despised, Dolores Umbridge, was back in this book. Some characters live to the end of the book, but some don't. I actually cried at one point. Kudos to the narrator of the audio version, Jim Dale, for his fantastic work in this series. My rating: 5 Stars.

Reading this for the first time as I abandoned the series after the release of HBP so this review is my liveblog.In no particular order, good things:1. Harry's death scene2. Snape dying at the hands of Voldemort (very appropriate)3. The Dursleys (always good, tbh)4. Draco 5. Kreacher, to a degree. It's a nice idea, but it's profoundly unconvincing.6. Remus guessing that the death eaters knew which Harry was Harry Potter as expelliarmus is seen as Harry's signature move. Hilarious. And true. One of the 5 duelling spells he knows. Terrible things1. The epilogue2. The writing. 'All was well.' 'It is I, Remus J Lupin.' Harry regretting that he will never be 'pierced' by Dumbledore's eyes again. Harry describing Voldemort's eye in a locket as 'handsome' (JKR falling over herself to use the same adjectives over and over again to describe Tom vs Voldemort is really irritating....)3. Voldemort's complete lack of menace and dignity. He's soaring around the skies trying to curse Harry? He's also forgotten that Harry can access his mind - in fact, in this book Harry actually reads Voldemort's thoughts which is something he never could do before and is extremely convenient, to say the least. 4. The long period of time that Harry, Ron and Hermione run around in improbable scenarios, achieving nothing5. The Ron-Harry fallout - it felt completely pasted in as did its resolution - Voldemort sending Ron visions of Harry and Hermione kissing? Really, it underscored what a pathetic sap Ron is - it didn't feel like him overcoming anything, just like him continuing to be a useless, sad sap. Speaking of which 'All's fair in love and war'? Rolling my eyes. Go away, Ron.6. Ron opening the Chamber of Secrets? It's an old bathroom. If random hissing sounds could open the chamber, it would have happened before now.7. The cheap deaths in this book. I call them cheap because they were just pointless sacrifices to underscore that shit was getting real without actually meaning anything or making sense with that character's plotline - apart from Dobby, really. You look at the deaths and a random Weasley, Tonks, Lupin, Ted Tonks, Madeye, Hedgwig? 8. Umbridge's return. So improbable given that she was Fudge's number 2 and no one would want her back & given that her ending in OOTP was actually imo, perfectly resolved.9. The break-in at Gringott's was underwhelming for something that the reader has been anticipating since PS.10. There should have been more dragons. Charlie's whole thing is dragons. Dragons. 11. Voldemort's goals make no sense at all. Even for a megalomaniac. Also his obsession with Hogwarts really makes him a pathetic villain.12. The focus on Dumbledore's backstory - last book it was people trying to reconstruct Voldemort's soap opera of a life and in this book it's Dumbledore, and what a waste of time. Also it's so ridiculous that JKR didn't put Dumbledore's affair with Grindelwald in the book. She had the perfect opportunity to plant even a small suspicion of that with Rita Skeeter's book and chose not to. 13. Percy's comeback made no sense. Percy is the only Weasley I've ever liked and I wanted him obviously to stop being pro-Ministry, but Aberforth became very deus ex machina.14. Everything about Lupin.15. Snape. Enough said.16. That the SPEW plot culminates in Ron and Hermione kissing instead of anything meaningful.17. That Harry is still mediocre and profoundly uninterested in magic. Why doesn't he get better at it? Why doesn't he learn nonverbal magic? When he was going on about how he wanted to meet Snape - lol, last book you couldn't even get out a curse. Come on.18. That at age 17, Harry still cannot recognize people as being complex individuals. He focuses only on his latest perception of them - i.e. for a bit Dumbledore was the worst because he hung out with an evil wizard for two months, nevermind that he's a gazillion years old; and Snape is redeemed for all his sins by his creepy devotion to Harry's mother despite all the fuckery he's been responsible for during Harry's time at Hogwarts and Voldemort attacking him in the first place. Where is your child named after Sirius?19. I cannot believe that there isn't a respectable and notable contingent of Slytherins fighting against Voldemort because despite being traditionalists with their blood purity mumbo jumbo, they don't want to be ruled by an immortal megalomaniac who kills people on whim. How did that not occur to the Malfoys before their involvement, I mean, really. The idea was floated about in GOF briefly but nothing seems to come of it.20. Because Harry was willing to die for EVERYONE, everyone is protected by his love? But he didn't even think that killing himself would save everyone - there was still corporeal Voldemort and Nagini? Ridiculous. It kind of deflates the notion of parental love as well, which I liked.21. Neville should have killed Bellatrix instead of JKR forcing her good femininity vs bad femininity ideas down our throats once again.22. Voldemort's death was absurd. The Elder Wand stuff? What even. And Harry's speechifying ....

When I first read this book, my only caveat was what I thought of as the protracted, sagging middle of the story, in which the trio travel around the country, trying to figure out what to do without really doing much. They break into the Ministry, they revisit Godric's Hollow, they obtain the sword of Gryffindor, but mostly they just relocate, camp in the woods, and try to interpret the intentions of the dead and departed, or deal with their legacies by interpreting the artifactual evidence they left behind. Regulus and the locket; Grindewald and Dumbledore and the fragments of their story indirectly derived from Belinda Bagshot; Lily's letter to Sirius; the deer patronus; the anonymous missives of support left at the grave of Harry's parents in Godric's Hollow; learning about the DA and the Order through the Potterwatch broadcasts, etc.One example of this was the scene at the Lovegood's, when Harry discovers Luna's private mural of himself, Ron, Hermione, Neville, and Ginny, intertwined with a golden ribbon of the word "friends" repeated over and over. There were some other important narrative elements introduced in this scene, and some action, but the description of this mural had me tearing up. As I read that passage, Luna transformed from an adorably oblivious but ultimately irrelevant side character to this formerly lonely, abandoned human being for whom the DA's friendship was as novel as it was profoundly essential. And I was actually filled with grief that Harry learned this too late, that this crisis was exposing the unbreakable strength underlying all Harry's friendships too late to acknowledge and cherish those bonds for what they were worth. Except... it wasn't too late, because Luna and many of the others were still alive, and still fighting. So why did I feel like they were dead? This brought to mind a passage from Netherland (which I now feel more inclined to finish):An ancient discovery was now mine to make: to leave is to take nothing less than a mortal action. [...] after Mama's cremation I could not rid myself of the notion that she had been placed in the furnace of memory even when alive and, by extension, that one's dealings with others, ostensibly vital, at a certain point become dealings with the dead.For me, this cast the middle section of the book in a completely new light. Now it became an examination of the way the departed, both dead and alive, continue to touch us and affect our lives through the memories and thoughts they leave behind. In Netherland, O'Neil was pointing out the tragedy of this, how even the living can become as distant from us as the dead, but I think Rowling wants the reader to see this as a profoundly important part of being alive, that seeking out and understanding these kinds of evidence makes bearable the void left by the absent. The influence of the dead is important throughout this book and throughout this series, but in this seemingly humdrum plateau of the novel, I think it becomes paramount.There are lots of other incoherent things I could blather on about, mostly the difference between self-sacrifice and martyrdom and the merits of happy endings, but this review is approaching the edge of "long" with "pointlessly long" well in sight, so I'll finish. I loved this book as I love the whole series, and its existence has made my life better.

Relectura 05/08/2016Desde que leí este libro por primera vez se convirtió en uno de mis favoritos de la saga. Incluso a veces pienso que podría ser mi favorito. La verdad es que podría dividirse la saga en dos partes: una más infantil que abarcaría los tres primeros libros, y otra más oscura, con los cuatro restantes. Mi libro favorito de la parte infantil siempre ha sido El prisionero de Azkaban, pero de la parte oscura me encantan los dos últimos, y en especial Las Reliquias de la Muerte siempre ha tenido algo muy hipnotizante para mí.Es el épico y esperado desenlace de una saga inolvidable en la que no me canso de sumergir mis narices una y otra vez. Es curioso, pero ya no recuerdo las veces que he releído Harry Potter y siempre que lo acabo me quedo vacía. A pesar de las reiteradas relecturas y de no contar ya a estas alturas con el factor sorpresa, siempre, siempre, siempre, cuando paso la última página me sobreviene una severa resaca literaria.En libros anteriores a este vimos ya mucha oscuridad, pero Las Reliquias de la Muerte se lleva el premio gordo. Es un libro serio, triste, solemne, en algunos momentos incluso escalofriante, pero sobre todo, es el libro revelador en el que conocemos la verdad definitiva de tantos enigmas abiertos en libros anteriores. También es una entrega muy diferente a las aventuras precursoras de Harry y sus amigos (y enemigos): en esta novela no les seguimos durante el curso escolar, pues el negro telón de Voldemort ha caído definitivamente sobre el mundo mágico, que se encuentra sometido a su tenebrosa voluntad, mientras Harry y sus seguidores tratan de llevar a cabo una siniestra misión por todo el país, que deben realizar antes de poder acabar con quien-vosotros-sabéis. Si me remonto a mi primera vez con este libro recuerdo lo mucho que me sorprendieron ciertos momentos, lo mucho que lloré con algunas muertes... Y lo sigo haciendo, porque hay cosas que no cambian. Siempre lo he dicho y siempre lo diré: leer y releer a Harry Potter es sentirse en casa, es volver al hogar después de un largo viaje, lo que explica el vacío que queda al acabar estos libros.Pero a pesar del vacío siempre acabo Harry Potter feliz y emocionada, porque, sí, a mí me gusta el final de la saga tanto como el camino. Podéis juzgarme si queréis, no sabéis lo poquísimo que me importa y lo absurdo que encuentro tener que justificarme. Me gusta el final, me gusta el epílogo y me emociona incluso en la película. Soy la rara de turno a quien le encantan las películas de Harry Potter, sí, ¿y qué? En este momento de mi vida ya no procede avergonzarme de ello ni negarlo, sino que me enorgullece, porque así es como soy.Poco más puedo añadir, solo que tengo el presentimiento de que esta no será la última vez que cruce mi camino con el de Mr. Potter.Un saludo,Carol Rodríguez

সাড়ে তিন।চমৎকার সব মোচড় থাকার পরও মনে হয়েছে, সোর্সারার্স স্টোন থেকে শুরু করে হাফ-ব্লাড প্রিন্স পর্যন্ত পুরো গল্পের প্রবাহের প্রায় সমতুল্য "গল্প" ডেথলি হ্যালোজে চলে এসেছে। হরক্রাক্স আর হ্যালোজ মিলে গল্পবলাটা একটু "ঘিঞ্জি" হয়ে গেছে। গল্পের শুরুর দিকে অভ্যাসবশত গল্পের অনেকগুলো চাবি রাখেন রোলিং, যেগুলো সাধারণত গল্পের শেষদিকে বা পরবর্তী বইতে তালা খুঁজে পায়, কিন্তু এ বইতে সেরকম বেশকিছু চাবির আভাস থাকার পরও তালা আর মেলেনি। আরিয়ানা ডাম্বলডোরের করুণ ইতিহাসে যা আভাস, "ফ্যান্টাস্টিক বিস্টস অ্যান্ড হোয়্যার টু ফাইন্ড দেম" সিনেমায় সেটাই মূল দ্রষ্টব্য, কিন্তু হ্যারি পটার সিরিজের অন্তিম বই হিসেবে ডেথলি হ্যালোজ সামান্য পানসে হয়ে গেছে।বেশ সন্তর্পণে ওয়্যারউল্ফ আর ভ্যাম্পায়ার চরিত্র (আভাসে) হাজির করার পরও তাদের নিয়ে খুব বেশি নাড়াচাড়া করেননি রোলিং, এটা কোনো ত্রুটি নয়, কিন্তু সামান্য আশাভঙ্গ ঘটিয়েছে। লুপিন যেমন প্রিজনার অফ আজকাবানে বেশ বড় জায়গা পেয়েছে, তেমনটা পরে আর পায়নি কখনো, ফেনরির গ্রেব্যাকেও বর্ষণের চেয়ে গর্জন বেশি হয়েছে। সম্ভবত টোল্কিনেস্ক ফ্যান্টাসি উপাদানের বাইরে যেতে স্বস্তি পাননি রোলিং। হাফ-ব্লাড প্রিন্সে এসে জোম্বিদের সামান্য পরিচয় করিয়ে দিয়েছেন, কিন্তু একটি দৃশ্যের বাইরে তাদের দেখা আর মেলেনি (খুব ভালো লেগেছিলো জোম্বির বদলে নতুন একটা শব্দ - ইনফেরিয়াস - প্রণয়ন করায়, গল্পের মেজাজটা তাতে খোলতাই হয়েছিলো)। প্র্যাচেট যেমন ফ্যান্টাসির মধ্যইয়োরোপীয় উপাদানগুলো (ওয়্যারউল্ফ, ভ্যাম্পায়ার, গোলেম) নিজের মতো ছেনেঘেঁটে কাজ করেছেন, রোলিংও তেমন করলে বেশ উপভোগ্য হতো, কিন্তু আঙিনাটা তিনি ভ্যাম্পায়ারকুণ্ঠ টোল্কিনের হাত থেকে খড়ি নিয়েই দাগিয়েছেন শেষমেশ।হগওয়ার্টসের দুই বিপরীতচরিত্রের হেডমাস্টার, "অ্যালবাস (সাদা)" আর "ব্ল্যাক"কে জায়গা দিয়ে রোলিং যেন "ইন" আর "ইয়াং"-এর ভারসাম্যের আভাস দিয়েছেন, অশুভের বিরুদ্ধে শেষ দুর্গেও যে টুকিটাকি ধূর্ততা আর খলত্বের জায়গা আছে, সেটা শেষ বিচারে হ্যারির মতোই। পাঠকের জন্যে ওটা একটা মোজায় লুকানো টেইক হোম মেসেজের মতো: দুনিয়ায় কেউই শতকরা একশো ভাগ ভালো হয় না। তবে একদম শেষ পর্যন্ত হ্যারিকে একটা সীমার এপাশে রেখেছেন রোলিং, অ্যাভাডা কেডাভ্রা বলাননি তাকে দিয়ে। বোকাচো ভল্ডুর সাপটা বাউন্স করেছে, মেনে নেওয়া যায়, কিন্তু শাপটা বাউন্স করায় দেজাভুটা বেশি চোখে লেগেছে। দ্য বয় হু লিভড একটু পাতলা হয়ে যায় দ্য ড্যুড হু মিসডের কারণে।পুরো সিরিজে খুব অল্প জায়গা পাওয়া দুটো চরিত্রকে খুব পছন্দ হয়েছে, লি জর্ডান আর ফিনেয়াস ব্ল্যাক। রোলিঙের কলমে কাহিনীর বুনোট এতো চমৎকার যে খুব সামান্য আঁচড়েই এক একটা চরিত্র প্রাণ পায়। বুড়ো বয়সেও দুঃখ পেয়েছি ডবি আর ফ্রেডের জন্যে। পরিশিষ্টটা একটু বেশি নাটুকে হয়েছে, ঠিক যেন মানায়নি। চরিত্রনির্ভর হাই ফ্যান্টাসি সিরিজের একটা সমস্যা, মূল চরিত্র তার অন্তিম পরিণতি পেয়ে গেলে ফ্যান্টাসি দুনিয়াটা কোটি কোটি টন ডিটেইল নিয়ে বেকার পড়ে থাকে। গুপী গাইন বাঘা বাইনের মতো হ্যারি পটারের ক্ষেত্রেও, এটা একটা ট্র্যাজেডি।

Honestly, if I could give this more stars--I totally would. I literally JUST finished this. I'm crying. And I'm laughing. And as much as I "hated" JKR (I mean, c'mon, who could really hate her?!) at times throughout this series, I love her so much right now! Not to sound completely cliché, but this is seriously THE BEST BOOK I HAVE EVER READ. Like I said...I laughed. I cried. I sobbed. I gasped. I hated. I screamed. I yelled. In other words, I have NEVER felt so much as I did while I read this book. It takes an amazing author to move me the way that JKR did with not only this book, but this entire series. J.K. Rowling, I must say you have done a fantastic job. I flew through this book. I couldn't put it down. There were times that I honestly doubted JKR throughout this book--I remember thinking: "Seriously? You're really gonna do this? Do you KNOW what you're doing?" Well, it wasn't until the ending that I realized she knew (more than any of us could ever have) exactly what she was doing--with amazing results. As a whole, with this series, JKR has created a cast of characters and a world that I know I won't forget anytime soon. Fortunately, I was able to grow up with Harry Potter, so this entire phenomenon that she has created is like home to me, in much the same way that Hogwarts was like a home to Harry. I cannot wait to see what J.K. Rowling comes out with next...I will be eagerly waiting and anticipating...

EDIT: reading this review two weeks later, that doesn't look like a very healthy reaction.I'm kind of dead at the moment. My heart is beating at a breakneck speed but I'm breathing once a minute. I'm dizzy, too.I've cried my heart out today.It frustrates me to no end, having so many thoughts and feeling jumbled in my head and not being able to express them clearly - or in any way.I can't - not that I don't want to, I'm actually unable to - talk about the plot of this book in detail, or about the characters, but I'd like to say that I have never, in my entire life, read a book or series that had such an enormous impact on my life. Aside from the fact that it completely transported me away from real life, to the point that people were actually worried about me, it's quite simply a huge accomplishment. It gives a feeling of change throughout the years that makes me feel as if my existence had changed, as if I had been through such life-altering experiences.I've grown with these characters, I've felt what they've felt, I've seen every little change or adventure they've been through, and now that it's over, I feel as if I'd just been ripped apart limb from limb.I'm going to actually be mourning those who have died in this war.

The first time I read this book I did it in one take, in an 18 hours frenzy or so. Just because I needed to know what happened. Then after a month or so, I re-read it and got more of the book in, something I wasn’t able to do the first time because of my super quick pace.Well I loved it, and I still love it every time I read it. I read the Harry Potters every three of four years, when I feel I’ve forgotten enough about them to enjoy them once more. The only bad thing I can say about this book is that, being it the last in the saga, when I finish it, I feel a bitter disappointment at not having more. It is so good every time that after it, I just need to stay away from every other book for a while because well, nothing is like Harry Potter. If it is your first time reading it, lucky you, my advice to you is take it slow, I know it is impossible, but try to relish every page because at the end of it you won’t get more, sigh. The book has everything: suspense, adventure, struggle, deceit, loss, and most of all retribution! It is spectacular, breath taking, finger twisting, moving, and well, it’s just a masterpiece.The chapter about Snape makes me cry every time!

“Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all those who live without love.”  Molly Weasley and Hermione Granger are the real deals, pass it on!! Hermione Granger is my role model, she's everything a book character should be, in my opinion. She's brave, loyal to her friends, always figures out everything, she's ten steps ahead of everyone and she's hands-down a queen. Was I happy about her endgame? Well, yes, I suppose. Though, I'm a huge Dramione fan (I blame fanfiction for that) !!!  The plot was amazing in this one, I was worried for them all during many plot twists. I almost cried at certain deaths, it's not even a hp book if your favourite characters ain't dying. *you're an evil genius, J.K.Rowling* Even though I'm late to reading this series (I'm late to the party *cry*), I really came to love all these characters and I will miss them dearly.

This reread have left me feeling quite content for now and at least for the next half decade. Fucking ingenuity all around.Before this reread, Godric's Hollow was my favorite chapter but wow, The Forest Again changed that and of course, King's Cross is one of the most brilliant chapters of the series. Mentor goals: Dumbledore.(view spoiler)[However, the name Albus Severes Potter will always bother me because he was not the bravest man Harry knew. Sure, he had the skills to fool Voldemort, but that doesn't discount his actions towards Harry because he expected him to be like is father when he was so much like his mother. Wouldn't Snape have spotted that at once if he was so in love with Lily. Guess his sole redeeming point failed him there. (hide spoiler)]

Ve bitti...Sanki içimde koca bir delik açılmış sanki bir parçam benden alınmış gibi hissediyorum. O kadar çabaladım ki bitirmemek için ama kitabı elimden de düşüremedim. Son kitabın tüm seriyi berbat ettiğini söyleyenler var. Onlara şunu demek istiyorum: Siz çok büyük bir şeyi gözden kaçırmışsınız! Son kitapta her ne olduysa bir amaca hizmet içindi, onurlu bir hareketti. Böyle bir ortamda bunların olmamasını ummak ya da oldular diye kitaba rezalet demek tek bir şeyi gösterir, siz boşuna okumuşsunuz Tom Riddle gibi siz de fak edememişsiniz. Her kelimesinden ayrı zevk aldığım bol bol göz yaşı döktüğüm en güzel bitiş kitabı ve serideki kesinlikle favori kitabım. En başından beri Snape'i sevmiştim en sevdiğim karakterdi eh kitabı okuyanlar neler hissettiğimi çok iyi anlıyordur.

Now I have officially finished reading the Harry Potter series for the first time ever.I don't know why I've never read them as a child, considering that I'm a reader since I learned to read in school and I loved the HP movies as a child. (Maybe because the German covers of the HP books aren't looking that childfriendly?...) Anyways I'm SO grateful I still got the chance to read them because, even if I already knew the plot, reading the story was still a different experience <3 I love the world around Harry even more now.Edit: Oh yeah and I've read the last half of the book today :D

So fucking brilliant! The Great Hall final battle scene from The Flaw in the Plan chapter was literally heaven on paper. I'll never everget tired of reading that chapter and I still think Snape deserved better. Kbye.Oh and Happy 20th Birthday Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone! Who would've thought I'd finish my re-read of the whole series on PoA's anniversary! Color me surprised but pleased af.

Awesome. This is the perfect ending to an amazing journey. There is so much you can say, from the evolution of JK as a writer, the epic story that inspires young readers to learn to love reading, and many other things that you can learn from the experience of reading this series. Now I will go watch the movies again :)

Well, it's here folks. The final showdown, at least for me. The final review and the finish to my self-imposed Harry Potter summer challenge. Much like many people, I read the whole series, only in my case, it wasn't in preparation for the movie. Rather, it was me finally coming back to finish what I started ten years ago with these books.And what's the final verdict?It wasn't so bad.*total outrage*Yes, yes, I imagine you expected me to spew venom all over the place, or, maybe you didn't and are now sniggering at my having fallen, once again, under Rowling's spell.To both camps: KEEP YOUR SHORTS ON, I'm not finished.Yes, it wasn't so bad. For instance, we finally, finally, finally see some character development in Harry, and even the Ron/Hermione romance wasn't as bad as I thought it might be. SNAPE! NEVILLE! DRACO! Those three alone are enough of a motivation for anyone to read the series. In fact, I'd like to point them out as examples of how to write good male characters. Alyson Noel, take note!And yes, I was also very much emotionally vested in these characters. I loved all of them, and how wonderfully they interact. I was pleasantly surprised with Percy, who experienced some very impressive character development, as well as Dumbledore, who finally got knocked off his pedestal and was shown, rather, like a character and not some flawless Yoda-like saint. That said, there are shortcomings in this book. In fact, some of its greatest strengths are also its greatest weaknesses.#1 HarryAlright, so we finally get to see the Boy Who Lived to Be a Pain in the Arse to evolve into a character. I loved how Harry grew more responsible in this book, and how he learned that sometimes you have to do what you have to do. My question, though, is this: Why did it take him six and a half books to get there? I know he grows throughout the series, but it's only in this one where he drops the whining and mans up. In a way, throughout the series, he's very much a child, even with all the ordeals he has experienced.#2 Ron/HermioneI still maintain that Hermione is a superior character to both Harry and Ron. I mean, for the love of God, she (view spoiler)[ removes herself from her parents' memories just to keep them safe, and doesn't break down, even when she's being tortured  (hide spoiler)]. Not to mention the dozens of times she has saved everyone's lives, and how she focuses on the bigger picture instead of on her own feelings when the situation calls for it. Rowling really worked on making the romance between Ron and Hermione more believable in this book, but much like Harry, it comes about six and a half books too late. And don't tell me Ron was a prat to her because it's in the character of teenage boys and they bonded through trauma - if that's the case, then explain the epilogue (which I will get to in a minute).#3 DumbledoreSo in book 6 we were seeing the cracks in Dumbledore's saint-like image, but it's not until book 7 that we get a glimpse of the man that he really was. I loved this development, as it showed a lot about his motivation and past.As for the matter of Dumbledore's homesexuality... I admit I was sceptic when I heard it first. Now that I read the book, I think I kinda see it. There is definitely something there, and I can also see it couldn't really be obvious - at the time, it was very unlikely that Dumbledore could have acted on his feelings, and then afterwards... yeah.Now that I read it, I realize Rowling couldn't have elaborated on that aspect of Dumbledore because that's not the point of the series. The point of the series is the power of love and humanity over evil, not the romantic subplots. Although, again, that doesn't fit in with the epilogue, which I will get to... eventually.#4 The Amount of Hammy Deaths in the BookWhere do I begin with this? Okay, you know how Mockingjay is sometimes referred to as 'tragedy porn'? Well, this book borders on it. I mean in the first fifty pages, the owl dies. THE OWL DIES! Right after Harry gives her a nice tour down memory lane. I mean, poor Hedwig![image error] Um, not that one, but... actually... yeah, poor Hedwig. And that's not even the worst of it. The battle for Hogwarts, in its own right, is as horrible as it comes. The deaths of so many wonderful characters (view spoiler)[ Oh, Lupin! Oh, Tonks! Oh, Colin!!! Oh, FRED!  (hide spoiler)] alone are enough to bring tear to the eye. A friend of mine accused me once of wishing some character or another had died in the place of another, and I guess that's not wholly fair because even the most annoying ones shine during the battle. But... some of those deaths were so grisly, and then followed by a moment that was supposed to be... cute? (view spoiler)[ One moment, we have Lavender being savaged by a werewolf, and in the next, Treloni is killing Death Eaters by tossing spheres! What. The. Fuck!  (hide spoiler)] How is this even remotely acceptable? What was Rowling going for with this? I've heard people say that the series grew with the books, but this? Are we trying to write REALISTICALLY here? Because... um...#5 The PlotholesRowling's clearly not squeamish about killing off her characters. And she's not afraid of making the series dark. So why the hell is Harry alive? There was this huge buildup towards a heroic sacrifice which would save the whole world, and then we get this ridiculous cop-out that is so convoluted I'm not even going to try and get in to. Of course, it allows us a whole chapter where Dumbledore's ghost explains everything to our clueless hero, who, instead of letting his feelings run free and telling him to go fuck himself, forgives him nicely and goes back to the land of the living. And so on, and so on. If I went back to explain every plothole of this book, we'd be here till tomorrow. My point is, this victory seems to be based on quite a lot of nice little conveniences. I mean, how nice of Harry to explain how he's won to Voldemort right before he kills him, or that his self-sacrifice (even if he never died) protected the whole frickin' school!#6 The EpilogueHow many people have complained about this? Can't count? Neither can I? So we get this victory which came along through the bloody sacrifice of so many, and then, nineteen years later, our heroes are living the dream, with children and white picket fences? Really?Say what you will about the ending of Mockingjay, but at least it was sensitive to the trauma of war and the horrors the heroes went through. The Deathly Hallows is a tale of pain and loss which ends with an overly cute pink bow on top. Like Severus Lawliet said in her review, where's the emotional scarring? Hermione was tortured in the same manner as Neville's parents. Did Bellatrix just not have enough time to scar her permanently? I realize that all this makes me look like a... rather unpleasant person. Yeah... But I just don't get what Rowling was going for with this book. Did she want the series to grow from one genre to another, like her characters? From a fun children's book to a dark, fantasy epic? Is the story really that realistic? Dragons and goblins and magic aside, I mean. I see the merits of her book. I'm just saying that if she went through the trouble of setting up a tragic ending, maybe she should have gone through with it. So that was the end of my little HP challenge. What do I think of the series as a whole? Decent. I'm sure it'll go down as a children's classic. And, as with most classics, it's best not read too much into it.Now, if you'll excuse me, I'll go read some happy endings.SnapeLupin and TonksDraco and Hermione

I thought that this was a fitting end to the series, though two major weaknesses persist. 1)That most of the book concerns Harry, Ron, and Hermione whining in the forest while the wizarding world burns around them, and 2) Many of the deaths were poorly executed. I don't mind when authors kill off popular characters (I prefer the realism of bittersweet endings), as long as they do it right, and so in that spirit I bring you Harry Potter and the Respectable Body Count:1. Charity Burbage, page twelve.If you don’t recognize her swinging from her heels, naked, over the Malfoy’s dinner table, it’s probably because you skipped over all those muggle studies chapters. Because they weren’t important enough to exist. Not only is the first direct kill of It Who Shall be Last not Voldemorts’ personally, I can’t come up with an appropriate snakes on a plane reference.2. Hedwig, page fifty-six.Flies engulfed in the eerie glow of a bug zapper are accorded more respect in death – at least there’s a glimmer of will in that tiny brain. But as bad as being locked in a cage that also just happens to be in the way of Random Green Curse #1, there are lamer deaths to come.3. Mad-Eye Moody, page fifty-five (or seventy-eight, whatever).Speak of the devil; the most justifiably paranoid survivalist in the Potterverse isn’t ready for a surprise attack? After swallowing whole someone else’s battle plan? From the one guy he had to physically drag along? Why not bring him back during the final charge as a cybernetic half-centaur/house elf, his stolen eye replaced with a gatling plasma cannon? Better or worse than carving a cute little cross over his buried crazy eye?4. Death Eater #1, page fifty-nine.Exploding owl-cage sidecar!!! Note to Chris Columbus: Don’t cut Hedwigs’ Fawkes impression out of the movie.5. Death Eater #2, page sixty-one.Again, Hagrid tackling the guy trying to run him off the sky is cinematic gold, even if the death is merely implied.6. Rufus Scrimgeour etc, page 159.Finally! One of the few ‘good-guys’ we’ve been made to want dead since his first line, dies. Kind of like how Gorman died in Aliens, only without the selfless, redeeming act of heroism slash Alien disposal. Oh, but he didn’t give away Harry’s location while they tortured him. Whoop-de-friggin-do.There were some other ministry blokes there too; I would have enjoyed reading more than one line about it, but I can understand why JK didn’t want to sacrifice a moment of angsty bickering for yet another dreary battle scene.7. Random Muggle Family #1, page 232.A one-dimensional villain can’t go too many pages without slaughtering innocents; the underlings begin to lose respect.8. Gregorovich, page 280.Again, nice that Harry gets to see Voldemort at his most cruel. As opposed to buying groceries, haggling with his insurance adjustor, etc.9. Bathilda Bagshot, page 340.While technically not a ‘death’ she died during the months HHR were wandering in the snow.10. James and Lily Potter, page 344.11. Voldemort, page 345.The first rule of retconning is, you do not talk about retconning. The second rule of retconning is, you do NOT TALK about retconning. To maintain any sense of plausibility you have to bury the groundwork for the end in something the reader already thinks they understand, such as what happened the night Harry got his scar.Michael Frayn’s Copenhagen explores the uncertainty of memory in great detail. How a larger context (WWII) can warp it with equal direction, how difficult it can be for two people to reconstruct the simplest details such as where they walked and for how long. At a minimum the play leaves you with the idea that you can never know something with absolute precision, and that knowing isn’t as important as keeping that awareness in the back of your mind. Worst case, it means I can write whatever I want to fit whatever ending I’ve concocted, and nobody can say I’ve contradicted myself or that I’m just making this nonsense up on the fly, because the facts are in a constant state of distortion.So now Voldemort is Harry, Harry is Voldemort. Whatever. Although it’s one a them ironical sitchialations that James and Lilys’ final moments have been preserved by Voldemort in ways he isn’t aware of.12. Ted Tonks, Dirk Cresswell, Gornuk, page 439.This was pointless. Not pointless in the sense that death is very real and pointless sometimes, but in the sense that if you’re only going to give these people a few insignificant lines (We can wander through the woods too! Yay!), I’m not going to care when they die over the radio. Death should, you know, impact the reader in possibly a different way. 13. Peter “Wormtail” Pettigrew, page 471.Draco, is this Harry Potter? Draco, fetch the goblin! What was that noise? Draco! Go check it out, oh, wait, no, we’ll send Wormtail instead. He hasn’t been in the book yet, why not? Yeah, that’s it, Wormtail. Bumbling villians aside though, Wormtail needed to redeem himself in a small way, and then he needed to understand that it was too little, too late. Good job, enjoy your cookie.14. Dobby, page 476.Seriously, JK, this was the best you could come up with? Bellatrix flinging her knife to kill a disapparating house elf, after letting Harry and Co walk all over her and all her lame henchmen, is bullshit.But beyond that, although I can understand how you don’t want Harry or the reader to know that the elder Dumbledore is involved, killing Dobby to safeguard your plot contrivance for less than one hundred more pages is a savage weakness. Dobby and your readership deserved better.15. Nameless goblin # 47, etc, etc. page 549.Sometimes it sucks to be the messenger. Or within the blast radius.16. Crabbe, page #633-ish.Fiendfyre, like exploding owl-cages, will look epic on screen. 17. Fred Weasley, page 637.The Weasleys have too many family members for all of them to survive, but I'm still trying to figure out which twin was which and why I should care.18. Severus Snape, page 658.Finally, the truth. Although I’m not surprised Dumbledore had a plan all along, the extent to which Snape pined for Lily is a bit disturbing. Sweet, but a little stalkerish. Still, you can’t question his devotion or valor. People say there’s no greater love than to lay down your life for your friends, but I say dying is the easy way out. Snape gave up his soul, his bloodline, and his reputation, even after she became Lily Potter, and though it’s sad he had to die, he doesn’t strike me as a person who could ever have been happy with life afterwards. Again, a little twisted, a little predictable, and he didn’t take anyone with him, but still a good death.19. Colin Creevy, page 694.This did surprise me, and thinking about it later made me realize that Rowling really isn’t going to write any more Potter books, as Colin was one of the characters she seemed to be seeding for the future. Though there was a lot for me to hate about HP7 I still enjoyed it immensely, so here’s to going out on top rather than wringing every last drop of blood from your fantasy series until each book is more withered than the last (*cough* Wheel of Time *cough*).20. Harry, page 704.We’ve been wondering about this for years; Will Harry die? Will Voldemort die? Or both? Having it both ways is an old literary cop-out. Meh.21. Nagini, page 733.Enough is Enough!22. Bellatrix Lestrange, page 737.23. Voldemort, page 744.This was a bit overdone.24. Tonks and Lupin, page 745.Worst Deaths ever.

Instead of reviewing each Harry Potter book individually, I have decided review the series as a whole. So if you have read this review for one book in the series, you have read them all. Interestingly, the age range for YA fiction is actually undefined and rather subjective: varying age ranges from 12 to 18 or 15 to early 20s or 18 to 30.On that note, the Harry Potter series begins at the lower age range and graduates as the series progresses. Much like the young reading audience grows older with each year passing, the books themselves mature in step with it's readership.As an older reader I began reading the much shorter Sorcerer's Stone to my daughters. They quickly progressed and outgrew bedtime stories and soon were reading Harry Potter on their own. To be honest, with my introduction to Harry Potter through my children, I didn't really understand what the fuss was all about.To me, the first few books were not that great (again in the context of an older reader) and I really had to slog through them by myself to try and futilely keep up with my eldest daughter who quickly finished the entire Harry Potter series within a single month. She left me far behind and it took me a year or two to get though the first half of the series. But then it all change, the Harry Potter universe matured, became darker and I was finally hooked. Finally understanding all the hoopla surrounding this series. I don't think there are many authors that can claim to have instilled the love of reading in children as much as J.K. Rowling has. If nothing else matters, the fact that children these days are tearing their eyes away from cellphones and ipads to genuinely reading books again, now that, ladies and gentleman, is the real magic!

I'm always filled with sadness, grief and joy--heartbroken yet in love all over again. It's always a magical journey with Harry.Tons of thoughts are swirling into my head right now. But one takeaway from Alan Rickman:

[THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS, SO PLEASE DON'T READ IF YOU STILL HAVEN'T READ THE BOOK!]I must say that the time waiting for the book was a lot more torturous than the actual read. there were all those forums and newsletters wondering 'would harry live or die?' 'is snape good or bad?' 'what if hogwarts burns to the ground and everyone dies?!' and furthermore, 'how long would it take for spoilers to come out in the media and from random mean people?'The book didn't arrive on my doorstep till the following week 'cause I chose free shipping at amazon, but miraculously enough I avoided all spoilers. the ones on my newsletter were easy enough by just scrolling real fast with my hand on the monitor as the thread appeared and disappeared. this easy avoidance of spoilers had me worried the book had no thrills whatsoever. especially reading enough at first to know people liked the book. no one would like if Harry were dead.I was not one of those fast readers who finished it in about one second. no, it took me about four days which is a miracle to me. I fell asleep a lot during the camping phase of the story... well, at least till Harry had to jump in and get the sword and Ron showed back up. that made me loosen up a bit.. become one with the characters again. for awhile, it was just a surface read. see, I also wasn't one of the ones who reread the old books before starting, so I really needed a refresher on some of the lesser characters thus stopped in the midst of reading several times to google this info. at least I read enough threads from those who did read the other books over again, to keep certain clues in mind for the big finale.Towards the end, when things heated up, I got a tad worried for Harry 'cause his death would seem courageous and the whole walking ghosts beside him through the woods bit really brought a tear to my eye.. this would be acceptable to all who read if he died this way, right? I thought about having to walk in (since it was around 6am by this time) with a tear in my eye to say Harry died. this idea sounded pathetic, but c'mon, climatic bit! too early to still be awake and reading! the Dumbledore appearance in 'his head'! (I liked this line most of all: "Of course it is happening inside your head, Harry, but why on earth should that mean that it is not real?" mom constantly tries to tell me that there isn't a difference between your inner world and your outer world.. what's the difference? what difference would it make if all life were just one big dream? anyway, I won't get too philosophical with this, but beyond what certain people may've thought about how Dumbledore was brought back to talk to Harry -- I had read this wasn't necessary -- I really enjoyed it)So yes, it may've been a bit weak to bring Harry back from possible death, but I'd rather Harry live and get his happy ending than naught. I mean, who would've defeated Voldemort otherwise?One small issue I had--though I am happy I got the Trust Snape sticker at Borders.. I knew better!-- was that Snape wasn't brought to rest at the end. he was just left apparently at Whomping Willow. does this mean he could possibly still be alive? ..the epilogue kind've proves otherwise though. I felt after all he did, he deserves more respect than just to have a namesake. I felt the most compassion for him during 'The Prince's Tale' chapter especially.Beyond that, I didn't regret reading it (since I didn't really have any real wants and needs beyond the quality of the writing) or throw it across the room as apparently some people did (wtf?). one day I'll reread all the books again since I hear it's fun to see how connected they all really are. I think that's brilliant. this is the best children's / YA series I've ever had the chance of reading and am glad I picked it up when I did even if I didn't grow up with Harry.

This review first appeared on Readers in WonderlandINITIAL REACTION:5 THINGS ABOUT HARRY POTTER AND THE DEATHLY HALLOWS
  I wasn’t prepared
I’ve known for a long time which characters die (Tumblr has spoilers everywhere when your a billion years behind everyone else). I thought I would be braced for the emotional turmoil. HAHAHAHAHAHA WHO WAS I KIDDING! In some ways I think knowing who died but not when or how made it worse. There were so many feels and deaths and intense fights.
  Everyone is grey
One of my favourite parts of DEATHLY HALLOWS was learning more about Dumbledore and Snape and their pasts. I love how it made them more grey, not simply good and evil. It made them more real, more complex, more questionable and admirable.
  My favourite book of the series
This book had everything I’ve been waiting for since book one. Minimal romantic angst, intensity and fast pacing from the first chapter. I could barely put it down, especially once the Battle of Hogwarts began. There was so much plot, so many answers, so many epic fight scenes and feels.
  What do I do now?
I’m kind of lost. I can’t believe I’ve finished this series, and I only started it in January this year. It’s weird that it’s over. If I feel like this after only six months, how did those of you who grew up with Harry and the gang ever recover?
  I cannot wait to reread them
This is a series I will revisit again one day. I want to read them in physical form and find all the little clues and foreshadowing I missed this first time round. And I expect it will be just as magical the next time round.
  In Summary
HARRY POTTER AND THE DEATHLY HALLOWS was my favourite Harry Potter book. So much plot, so much action, so little romantic angst. I loved it.

Entire series review.I never intended to write a book per book review. Why bother? There's nothing I could have said that almost everybody doesn't know. But also, I was part of that almost up until now.Anyway, I started reading this series for a bunch of reasons, most of them obvious but also there was this sort of question on the back of my head: Can somebody be 17 and still like a middle-grade intended book series? It's tied with a lot of people's childhood or first read series and I have read a bunch of series by now and yeah, I loved it but I'm not gonna be like "I misss it so much" because I just read it.Because also I read Chronicles of Narnia last year and  I hated it. It's older and it has many different things with HP but it's like one of those series. The characters were so stupid, seriously but instead in this series I found flawed, heart-warming, hard-not-to-love characters. That's probably why I loved it the most because J.K rowling really gave some reality to her characters and understood them.It was better than I expected-- even though my expectations were high--- but one thing I didn't expect was 1) That I wouldn't like the movies as much after it. It just never went through my head.2) That I'd be shipping Ron and Hermione and Harry and Ginny. When I saw the last movie and saw that Ron and Hermione kiss it was a big WTF for me, it was like out of nowhere in my head. it makes more sense when you read the books but you didn't see it that much on the movies. I was like: But Harry and Hermione...? (There's like nothing between them in the books.) I didn't mind Harry and Ginny that much but now I just really ship them.There are probably more things I'd like to say about it but I just can't think of anything right now but it was as good as promised.

☆☆☆☆☆ No Spoilers! August 1st 2007 I was 22 years old and finishing up my summer courses so I could graduate early. I had recently broken up with a long term boyfriend, was living with roommates, and was on the verge of throwing out everything I owned and taking my dog and my backpack on an adventure. I was on the cusp of a great change, one I somewhat understood and equally couldn't begin to understand. It is only now that many years has past that I can see that was when I chose my path on the kind of life I wanted to lead: one based on fear or one motivated by a challenge. I have a distinct memory of being absolutely wrecked when I read this the first time and I reread it immediately after I finished. There was something about Neville's journey most of all that spoke to me and was reflected in my life at the time but I struggled putting it all together. It is only now that I have reread this series in it's entirety as an adult that it became clear. We are a sum of our choices. No matter what events unfold in our journey ultimately we are in charge of the outcome, to be true to our moral fiber, and to continue to live an inspired life on your terms. I'm not going to talk about this book, there is nothing I can say that has not been said a thousand times over. I will simply suggest that if you find yourself on the cusp of a great change and are hesitant to take the next steps, please remember:

Initial thoughts: This was a really full book!!! Lots of different emotions. Lots of action. Lots of tidying up various plot pieces. I'm sad to see the story end, but I approve of the ending. Review to come. Review:Actual rating: 5 I-Wish-It-Wasn't-Over stars. No spoilers. 
  It's over. I can't believe it's over. I put off finishing the last few in the series because I didn't want to see it end. I hate watching a world I've loved with characters I've bonded to end. 
  But alas, I'm going to keep my chin up on this one because I can always reread the series if I miss them too much. :0)There's a million reviews out there on this book/series. Nothing I say will be new or enlightening. I'm keeping this short and sweet. I felt a whole gamut of emotions in this final installment. Lots of puzzle pieces fell into place. Rowling tidied up everything really well. I'm happy with the way it ended. She redeemed herself from the rage she made me feel in the previous installment.

IT'S OVER.The feels, man. The feels.What's left to say?I will propably always be in denial about my favorite book series ever really coming to an end.But I loved everything about this book. It was... perfect. It was pretty sad, yes. I hated that J.K. killed off some of the characters, but I still think it was nessecary and it needed to be done for the book to stay believable - I mean, come on! It just wouldn't make the whole good guys vs. bad guys work if NONE of the good ones died (looking at you, Cassandra Clare and your book City of Heavenly Fire).So, will I reread this book thousands and thousands of times ?

This is the Series of our time.These seven books changed lifes. I am sure they did. They thaught us (the ones who read it) a lot. About life. About people. About the world in general. All the seven books have incredible messages waiting for us. They contain a whole new world to discover and still it is one that is similar to ours. J.K. Rowling shows in these books how to live. How to change the world and oneself. She shows all the types of persons. Really all of them. In each and every you discover similarities with yourself. Everyone in these books is real, is living. And Hogwarts will indeed be always there to welcome you home. It simply is like a home. Always there, always waiting for you...I mean... Honestly, I cannot even write a proper review. You cannot comment on a legend. On something magnificient and magical. At least I cannot. The books left me damaged that it ended and still happy that I could experience it.

Do not pity the dead, Harry. Pity the living, and, above all those who live without love. The ending of my childhood and favourite series of all time and the amount of times i read this series over and over i will never get sick of it. The finale of this series to me was just the perfect fit for me and i know not a lot of people enjoyed it. I can honestly say J.K Rowling wrapped up the series the best way she could and she did one magnificent job at it thats in my opinion. I laughed and i certainly did CRY thank you Mrs Rowling you were the first author to make me cry like a little baby.so many favourite quotes in this book. After all this time...? Always... This final book wraps up the whole series and finally ties up loose ends, we get to visit our favourite places one last time and rowling also does quite a bit of referencing from other parts of the book which i found very clever!there is a lot of death in this last and final book of the series as you would expect and of course J.K Rowling delivered on this very well. I BLAME YOU MS ROWLING FOR MAKING ME CRY ! LOL

I detest Harry Potter. I was working in a bookstore when this book came out -- a tiny independent bookstore with floor displays of Cormac McCarthy and Jung. I don't even want to tell you how many boxes my boss ordered of this.* (He had to sign a nondisclosure agreement that was about ten pages long.) And then I had to sell them to people all day long, and I had to giftwrap them. Nobody had said anything about giftwrapping being part of selling books! I can sell books all day long! I could recommend books til your ears fall off! Giftwrapping?.....yeah no. I still remember one elderly couple, obviously buying a present for a young relative, whose annoyance turned to visible pity as they watched, who then murmured, "That's all right, we'll just do that at home, dear."My friends (that should be "friends") still think this is funny.*And then I had to listen to him complain about how Costco et al selling it as a loss leader meant he wouldn't be able to rake in a ton of money selling thousands of copies like he'd done up until Vol 5, or whatever.

I always get a little sad whenever I finish this book, even though it's been years since the series came to a close. I hate that it's over, but that is the only thing I hate about it.I love finding out about the wand lore, not just because of it's importance to the end of the book, but because it is very fascinating. I'd like to think that if I lived in the wizarding world, this is were I would work. I love Draco's story line. It makes me happy that after all this time, he (and his family) realize that they aren't exactly on the right side. I do with they had done more to help Harry in the end, but beggars can't be choosers. The deaths in the story break my heart. Every. Single. Time. I feel like I am losing people I love every time I read them, and although I know they died for a greater cause, that doesn't mean it doesn't hurt.I will forever love the Harry Potter series.

I seriously love this book. It has its flaws though. Harry Potter was probably one of the best things about the 2000s along with Dir en grey and other assorted good music. It brings back good memories of happily reading to awesome music and getting drawn into the lives of these fascinating characters.JK Rowling does an excellent job with characters. She makes you feel for them. She makes you love Snape even though he's really a jerk. (You can't tell me he didn't put that sword in ice on purpose just to make Harry extra miserable.) She redeems the Malfoys. Unfortunately she makes you love so many characters and then cruelly kills them. No one is safe. It is a war of love vs fear of fearing death vs. accepting it and love and its risk of loss and pain.Also, I did not hate the epilogue, but I did want more details about what happened afterwards. Harry Potter. Folks can ask me, you're STILL in love with this series? After all this time?Always.Yes. I still love this series.

It ended in a bittersweet "All was well". I cannot fathom so many emotions. I loved the hole series. It had its up and downs (not too down though). I loved the characters. I think you can really learn and relate to them all. I felt like I had to finished this book, in the middle of the night, instead of sleeping, but, at the same time, I felt like I did want to. This series makes it so real and makes me feel sad that I am a Muggle and did not get my letter (no problem, I can always go to Orlando, right?). I always knew I would like this series. Always. I always had high expectations. This book did not meet them. But he broke them. It was what I expected in the end with different means. Do I make myself clear?Well, the main thing is: I loved it as everyone else and I am happy I did.

word count: 198,227rating: it's the pure fun of the idea, that magic could be just around the corner*sobbing uncontrollably* How can people not understand the craze? The shortest explanation I can give is a quote from one of my favourite books, which someone added pretty spot-on gifs to, so it would be a shame not to share it ^^ (*I take no credit)"It's like in the great stories, Mr. Frodo.The ones that really mattered.Full of darkness and danger they were.And sometimes you didn't want to know the end.Because how could the end be happy?How could the world go back to the way it was when so much bad had happened?But in the end, it's only a passing thing, this shadow.[image error]Even darkness must pass.A new day will come.And when the sun shines, it will shine out the clearer.Those were the stories that stayed with you.That meant something, even if you were too small to understand why.But I think, Mr. Frodo, I do understand. I know now.Folk in those stories had lots of chances of turning back,only they didn't.they kept goingBecause they were holding on to something...There's some good in this world, Mr. Frodo.And it's worth fighting for."It's over. And I feel empty. Hogwarts it truly my home. This story is a precious part of me, as real as any other experience. I believe it will stay with me forever. It's not perfect, of course it's not, but to us that grew up alongside those characters it's special.If you wish to read some of my random thoughts on this book, go there: http://anhec.booklikes.com/post/75043...Here I'll mention only two things.Neville: that one is beyond words. I think there's a bit of Neville living in each one of us. He's a true underdog of the story. He's scared, full of doubts, doesn't believe in himself, tries to meet the expectations of family and teachers, but always falls short. He can never quite measure up. Always insecure, always struggling. And yet he knows the difference between right and wrong and is willing to fight for it. To die for it. He knows who he is, who he wants to be. He finds his strength, he finds passion, he finds what he's good at and makes friends. The way he wasn't willing to compromise and stood up to his friends (after risking first a lot to warn them) is commendable. That is something Lupin didn't know how to do. He's got what young Dumbledor was missing. Ron, George, Harry... they all lose the sight of their goal, of priorities upon witnessing death and tragedy. What does Neville do? What Harry asked him to. He stands up to Voldemort and in this precarious situation, with a burning hat on his head, when he's about to die, he kills the snake. He decides to do what Harry asked him to do even if it's the last thing he'll do in his life, even though he has no idea why was it important at all. Harry wanted to know, needed to know 'why'. He felt entitled to this knowledge.The more I think about Neville the more I love and admire him. "In a world of leaders and followers, there are some who don’t attempt to fit either mold, and it is those distinct few who really determine the future of us all. That is what Neville Longbottom can teach us."Snape: do I even have to tell you? He isn't a good guy - he's an asshole with serious anger management problems. Does he love Lily? Yes and no, he's kind of obsessed, but she always represented something good in his life. It's not empty. Is he, as a young man, compassionate at all? Pff, nope. Does he change completely? NO! He hates Harry! To the very end! He's not angry abut the boy dying, but about feeling cheated out of his purpose in life! Something he was holding on to. Or is he? We never truly know! We don't ever learn the whole truth about him; we can only guess and assume. This is one of the most wonderfully complex characters I've ever encountered. You kind of hate him, but also admire his determination and dedication. Not to mention - you feel sorry for him, sorry for a boy that grew emotionally far, far too late. But in his twisted way he cared, he cared about the Order of the Phoenix, he cared about Dumbledore, he cared about the difference between right and wrong (after years of growing and changing, but still, he got there). What he did... It's beyond comprehension. Harry was ready to die, but before that he had lived. People knew him, loved him. Snape gave up EVERYTHING, ended up alone and despised, carrying great responsibility on his shoulders. I hope the extent of Snape's sacrifice was appreciated in the end. I really do.

There's a line in Firefly. The crew is going to rescue Mal from Niska. Wash is piloting Serenity into Niska's space station. Zoe describes it as "hitting a bullseye six thousand miles away."More than not, this is how I always think about endings. When you begin, you fire the shot, and when it ends you hope that it lands exactly where you want it to. The more complex the story, the more complex it becomes to hitting a bullseye. And ending a single novel is hard. Giving it a suitable ending and a fantastic climax is really, really difficult. Now add two novels to that. Now you need four endings, a suitable ending for each novel and an ending for all three collectively. And doing that is really hard. Suzanne Collins couldn't do it. Veronica Roth sure as shit couldn't do it.And it's hard for a TV show. I'm a massive LOST fan, and I think hitting that ending as hard as they did, from as far away as they did, is next level writing. They had entire elements of the show they couldn't use (Mr. Eko is the best example), things that couldn't happen, plans that 100% changed and meant guessing at a different version of their already guessed ending.And it's hard for this, the final(ish) installment of the Harry Potter series. Seven books. Minimum eight endings (I'd argue it's nine ...). Tons of characters to say goodbye to... a gigantic mythology to wrap up.... And Rowling, being the insanely ambitious, amazing writer that she is, basically goes completely off the reservation here. Hogwarts doesn't show up until the third act. The entire middle of the book is essentially a camping trip around England. The first act (even from page one) shifts the entire book into a status quo none of us really, actually, truly anticipated. AND THEN halfway through the she goes and introduces a completely new branch of the mythology around which the whole climax of the novel pivots.It is, to say, the sort of thing that probably shouldn't work. I love how much the last installment is the "light-it-on-fire, go-for-broke" installment, but this is literally the stuff of absolute legend. And Rowling pulls it off. She pulls it off she pulls it off she pulls it off with finesse and grace, giving the ultimate capstone to what is probably the single most influential storytelling event in western pop culture since Star Wars.It is, to put it simply, basically perfect.It's hard to describe how much I love this book. I adore this book. If I had to pick a Harry Potter book that best shows off why I love the series, this would be it. It's a fucking masterpiece. Watching all of the elements come back once again (noticing every single nostalgia reference is easier once you've had time to absorb it for a while), seeing her weave and out in a victory lap tour of the series, seeing how well she treats every single character who she could possibly squeeze into this book, the continued awfulness of Umbridge, the redemption of Percy, the delicateness with which she treats Severus Snape, the coming-around of Dudley, the hubris of Voldemort.... It is.... so perfect.Truly, this is the book that has everything, only let down by the fact that Harry and his friends don't go to Hogwarts for another year. But after Half-Blood Prince what is there left to do at Hogwarts? How would they be expected to defeat a fully empowered adult wizard without acting like fully empowered and independent adults? It has two massive heist sequences, a thrilling as all hell chase scene, a chapter that's basically as taut a thriller as I've ever seen her write (Malfoy Manor), one of the best extended flashback sequences I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing, a brand new mythology that it's easy to forget SHE MADE UP FROM SCRATCH (Three Brothers), a massive war story on the Hogwarts grounds.... It has the origin story of Albus Dumbledore (providing the layers to his character that make him my favorite character in the series)... It has the best thing J.K. Rowling has ever written (The Forest Again).It is a novel about generational divides, a beacon of progress and humanity, a statement that the old must pass that the new might inherit the earth, because whatever current generation is on top can't save the world. All things change and evolve. The world can only be saved and shaped by those who will inherit it. The last image is of even the next generation who will take over once Harry and his friends are done and dusted.Deathly Hallows is about the best thing you could hope for at the end of a series. It has heartbreak, it has laughs, it has moments of sheer badassery, it has entire chapters that makes us all weep. It is devastating, it is empowering, it sees Harry torn to his utter lowest point and then built up into the hero we all knew he would eventually become. It is massive and epic and yet impossibly small and understated, with gigantic moments flying by as personal and quick in the blink of an eye and feeling impossibly mythic just a few pages later. It ends with a magic trick and its ultimate victory is unabashedly a celebration (and bittersweet) but undeniable in its euphoria.It is perfect children's literature. It is everything I could possibly want from an ending or final installment. And it only gets better every single time, which, in a final installment, shouldn't happen.
  Harry Potter Rankings
1) Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows2) Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix3) Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince4) Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban5) Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire6) Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets7) Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone.

Harry Potter: Deathly HallowsI think my resolution of the year would be to stop whining about my job and just live by what it has to offer instead and work my ass off here with all my readers and pals!Hi, How are you guys? I have bee avoiding writing/ reading books and just when it hit me- I ONLY READ 57 books, I was shattered. (Trust me it isn't a lot, at least not to the number of books I purchased this year.)Anywho. Here today we are talking about Deathly Hallows which I read 2 months back. I AM WAAYYYY TOO SLOWWW.I am a snail and I have got to recollect my thoughts as to talk about the book not that people don't know what the book is, or have read reviews about it already? haha!It is taken for granted that everyone and anyone know about Harry Potter and people who don't like Harry Potter- well, I don't want to know you, people.Oh-- I am a Slytherin-- So you know if you disagree with me or anything else.......I don't want to put it into words but BAD Things can happen.Wheeeeeere do I even start with this? WHERE.Controversial statement. I love this book, I do. I love Harry Potter but I didn't like this book as much as Goblet of fire. Even though it has more of Dumbledore, one person we all want to know more about. Yet.I kind of have some issues, not a lot but some- I gave it 5 stars, clearly, those issues aren't a big deal. xD But because I am not going to stop whining until I speak of them..so.MY ISSUES, MY WRATH, THE REASON WHICH IS WHY I WAS SO SLOW.I just like to be dramatic with my headlines.THE PACING.The pacing is ridiculous. Seriously, it was like oh now that we don’t have any homework and Draco bothering us with his petty issues, we will create some random problems and misleading adventures. NOT FUN, I was bored. I wanted to kill Voldemort in the first 5 pages itself. Yeah and then I would have cribbed about how small the book was.Maybe it’s not the author’s fault at all, maybe it’s me, maybe’s that’s who I am as a person!No wait, the pacing was slow anyhow picks up fine and then we go on a roller coaster ride for our life.HATE SLYTHERINS?Why are we the baddies always? yeah yeah, I know in the end Harry Potter defends us and all.. but has it changed anybody’s perception? Is there anyone from Slytherin who is good, who we consider good? Please do not talk about Snape to me. No. Other than that tell me! Tell me!Am I wrong? Huh? Don’t call me a baddie- I will come and slit your throat off and then laugh like Bellatrix.WHY IS DUMBELDORE SO SECRETIVE? I NEED MORE.I encourage good characters, with good storylines, with back stories with so much detail that we are able to have theories and all that. BUT, DUMBLEDORE? OH, MY GOD? You really can’t tell anything about him, do you? We respect him and all but do we really know him? Harry wasn’t alone in all of this, I was there with him too and I felt bad about all of it.I WANT TO KNOW MORE ABOUT DUMBLEDORE, his life, his work, his secrets. That is one thing which wasn’t given to us properly and it bugs me as well as intrigues me, SO SO SO VERY MUCH.I will appreciate if I am given 10 volumes on Dumbledore asap. Thank you very much.OTHER CHARACTERS? I WANT MORE OF THEM.I wish and hope we had more of the twins.More of Ginny.More of Luna.More of Neville.Actually, more of other characters because they deserve it.(Low key demanding more pages in the book) HARRY IS A GRUMPY CAT.After book 5, Harry is so grumpy all the time, UUGGHHH- I dislike him more than Ron at times, Jesus.Anywho he is back to his normal self towards the end. I would have died if you wouldn’t have.MY LOVE, MY LIGHT, AND EVERYTHING ELSE GOOD.CHARACTER DEVELOPMENTS? OH MY GOD.THE PLOT TWIST?It’s clever.The revelations, the build it’s clever, honest and beautiful.THE DECEIT–And by that I mean the characters, the story the way J.K. Rowling wants us to think but then parallelly show goes like peek-a-boo.I was in awe of that.THE INTRICATE STORY BUILDINGWho can build a world like that? Characters in depth like that? With not only just back stories but family history, place history and what not, we have everything (except Dumbledore and I are sure she has a lot of stories there to tell us).Clearly, a lot of time, effort and patience have gone in and I applaud it.THE CHARACTERS ARE GORGEOUS- EACH ONE OF THEM DESERVES A BOOK FOR THEMSELVES.Don’t you agree? We know so many of them and we know them as f we met them, that’s how brilliantly it is done.I AM A SADIST- BUT THE DEATHS <3- THEY ARE BOLD AND GOOD.I have read books, great books.What I have noticed is- until and unless we see death, we really do not appreciate the fight, the support and hard work we have put in. Until and unless we are made to think of what we have lost, it feels pointless. (Wow, I sound like a schmuck.) But don’t you agree? If everyone lived, every good character- what was even the point?And.. that’s all. Can there be something else to talk about?Everything is great, everything is awesome, everything makes sense. Only thing is I want more of this comforting world (It’s weird because in all the stories we are losing someone or the another and yet we find love, peace and comfort here.)Let me know your thoughts and feelings in the comments down below.Buy Harry potter here.Which part is your favourite? Which scene is your favourite? Which character is your favourite?RATING- 5/5 STARS.
