The Hunger Games is an exciting dystopian fantasy-thriller, The story is set in the future, after the destruction of North America. The country is called Panem. There are twelve poor districts governed by the rich Capitol, The Capitol organises the Hunger Games every year to punish the districts. One boy and one girl aged 12 to 18 fight in a battle. Only one person will live. The chosen teenagers are called “tributes”, Surprisingly I loved this movie a lot more than I thought I would.“May the odds be ever in your favor!” Katniss manages a meager living with her mother and sister "Prim", till one day her sister was chosen to be a “tribute”, but Katniss volunteers to go instead, The other “tribute” from District 12 was Peeta. "The boy with the bread" “If Peeta and I were both to die, or they thought we were....My fingers fumble with the pouch on my belt, freeing it. Peeta sees it and his hand clamps on my wrist. "No, I won't let you." "Trust me," I whisper. He holds my gaze for a long moment then lets go. I loosen the top of the pouch and pour a few spoonfuls of berries into his palm. Then I fill my own. "On the count of three?" Peeta leans down and kisses me once, very gently. "The count of three," he says. We stand, our backs pressed together, our empty hands locked tight. "Hold them out. I want everyone to see," he says. I spread out my fingers, and the dark berries glisten in the sun. I give Peeta's hand one last squeeze as a signal, as a good-bye, and we begin counting. "One." Maybe I'm wrong. "Two." Maybe they don't care if we both die. "Three!" It's too late to change my mind. I lift my hand to my mouth taking one last look at the world. The berries have just passed my lips when the trumpets begin to blare. The frantic voice of Claudius Templesmith shouts above them. "Stop! Stop! Ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to present the victors of the 74th Hunger Games, Katniss Everdeen and Peeta Mellark! I give you - the tributes of District 12!”

Voy a detallar los puntos más importantes que le juegan en contra a este libro. Lo único bueno es, básicamente, que es entretenido.* Los personajes: muy sosos, mal desarrollados, sin gracia. Si vas a escribir un libro en el que sus protagonistas estén cara a cara con la muerte en todo momento, es necesario que estos tengan una buena definición. Debido a lo planos que son, me dio igual si se morían todos. Jamás me interesé por ninguno. * La narración de Collins es entre pesada, ligera e insoportable. La primera parte del libro se me hizo muy incómoda de leer por lo mal que estaba escrito. Ya en la segunda mitad no pude parar hasta llegar a la última página, quizá por costumbre. No me gusta cómo escribe.* No es original. Esto de "personas matándose entre sí y quien queda es la ganadora" es una idea muy simplona, básica. * Falta de profundidad en las emociones. Esto quizá tendría que entrar en el primer punto (la falta de desarrollo de los personajes), pero quiero resaltar el hecho de que haya poca introspección. Si Katniss quiere demostrar que no es una pieza de un juego, sino una persona con sentimientos, sueños, miedos, bueno... entonces debería habernos mostrado eso. Hubo pocas partes en las que se ve un plano emocional de la protagonista, y estas fueron superficiales.A pesar de lo dicho, es un libro para pasar el rato. Se lee rápido, es entretenido y muy adictivo. Pero no es nada especial y deja mucho que desear.

By now most people have formed an opinion of this book based on it or on the movie, and you've gathered my rating that I liked it a great deal. I do have some thoughts I want to share.Plenty of people have pointed out (or complained) that the moviemakers go to a great deal of trouble not to show the contestants, including Katniss, killing one another. If you think about it, though, Katniss doesn't do a lot of killing herself. I think Collins was being very careful--if Katniss had been more of a killer in these games, parents would have screamed the ceiling down.But here's the thought I want to put out there. I wonder if Collins wasn't thinking more of Joan of Arc when she wrote Katniss: Joan, whose family was brutalized by English soldiers, who had a vision of a free France. Admittedly, the vision isn't Katniss's, but it's almost as if the vision of Katniss is the spark that the crushed people of Panem need to rise up. They'd had Games before and there wasn't a vision that caught them until the warrior girl was put before her. Yes, Katniss is maneuvered into things by the men in her life, particularly Haymitch, but once she gets mad, she has a knack for drawing people to her banner--like Joan.So call me bersorkey, I don't mind. Just thinkin me thinks. Back to my own war (on paper).

I enjoyed this book more than I thought I would. This was addictive and highly entertaining. I couldn't put it down. I watched the movie before ever knowing they were based on books so I knew what would happen, and yet it didn't really effect my reading experience. I didn't like Peeta in the movie. I dunno, but I really didn't. Book Peeta on the other hand, is really interesting and lovable. I really liked him. Katniss though, I'm very neutral about her. I was a bit bothered by somethings she thought of. The writing isn't really that great though. It was more tell than show, and I wasn't a fan of it. It was pretty devoid of emotion whatsoever. Anyway, I really want to continue on the series, not only since I already own the rest and that would be a waste of money, but because I really did enjoy it!

First, welcome to reading, I'm glad this could be one of 5 books you read this year along with The Help. Please stick around, there are many more worlds to explore and adventures to have. But I'm glad peer pressure can at least get you to read something. I know this is super elitist, I'm sorry, but I don't like pop music either and this is the Katy Perry of the literary world. I know, reading is always good blah blah blah it's still a good book blah blah you're kind of being a jerk here. I know but does anyone feel the same sometimes?This is my review from a couple years ago, forgot to post it here from the blog:I have this obsession, and I know it drives my wife nuts, but I can't stand wasting time. That's why audiobooks are by friends. Anytime I'm driving, taking the bus, walking to school, it's all good book-reading time. It's all forward progression, especially since I usually have goals to read so many books a month, quarter, year, etc. And I've found that most libraries have a decent selection of audiobooks since they tend to be a bit pricey.Now getting to the review. I'm terrible with peer pressure, I know. Everyone else seems to be reading this series and then I found it in the library. From there it was settled. (I'm still impressed I've resisted the Twilight fad for this long)Goodreads blurb: In a future North America, where the rulers of Panem maintain control through an annual televised survival competition pitting young people from each of the twelve districts against one another, sixteen-year-old Katniss's skills are put to the test when she voluntarily takes her younger sister's place.I came really close to giving up on The Hunger Games (Book 1 of 3) after the first few CDs. It was really frustrating how subservient these people are who live in each of the districts. They're on the brink of starvation, the rulers make it illegal to go hunting (although that's one place they actually break the rules), they can't say anything remotely seditious against the ruling class and to top it off they send two kids from each of their districts to compete in a "game" where they have to kill each other off - the winner is the one who out-survives the rest.The book explains that no one fights back because the elusive District 13 was utterly decimated. But seriously? People who are starving anyway have nothing to lose, a quick death by decimation is much better than slowly wasting away. Not only that, you have the parents. Who would continue to let their children go off to fight to the death and not do something about it, or at least just not be so submissive to everything?The kids arrive at the compound where they train and get ready for the games and yet again, they are completely afraid to break any rules. And yet again, what do they have to lose? They're about to go try to kill each other, why don't they do something? This is somewhat explained away because "sponsors" can help you throughout the game by sending you things you need and they'll only do that if they like you and you're in compliance with the rules.Yet, I couldn't help but think that people would still be fighting back. But anyway, once I got over these couple niggles, I did I promise, The Hunger Games was a fairly enjoyable read.Collins has created an interesting futuristic world where the ruling class keeps the people under their firm grasp by subjecting them to the horrible atrocities that are the Hunger Games. I thought she did a great job showing the intrigue of the games - that they were about more than just who's the biggest, strongest, fastest.Once the Hunger Games themselves began, I was sucked in. The game designers plan a number of surprises and tricks to not only weaken the players but to bring them together. Whatever gives the most entertainment for the legions of crowds watching the grisly show. These were all really interesting and helped to move the plot forward very quickly, because I, like the insensitive crowd, like my entertainment too. :)Almost immediately, the players created alliances (Survivor style) and it was interesting to see the dynamic especially since they all knew only one person would live. This was done quite well and even created some interesting twists.It's interesting to note that The Hunger Games have been optioned by Lions Gate films and I'll be interested to see the movie. You always have to see if they got it right. :)When Should You Read The Hunger Games?When you're in the mood for something light and definitely young adult, The Hunger Games may be the way to go. I'm probably the only one who had the issues I had with the book, so don't let that hold you back.3 out of 5 Stars (liked it)

Ok, so I realize I might be committing career suicide by not gushing from every orifice about the holiest of dystopian holies. I almost didn't write this review, because it's safer for new authors to just keep their heads down and say nothing because they might piss somebody off. But this world has enough liars already.I liked the Hunger Games. There were parts of it that were genuinely excellent. But would I name my firstborn daughter Katniss? Negative Ghost Rider, the pattern is full.(view spoiler)[Unlike most people who 3-star this book, my complaint isn't with the first act. I actually thought act 1 was the strongest of the three. I thought the Girl on Fire sequence made a great statement about the objectification of women in our society - in order to get sponsors and win over the crowd's affections, Katniss isn't made to look fierce or competent or badass - she's made to look PRETTY. This is a great analogy about the crap women deal with every day in professional and social circles. I also found the pace of the first act pretty brisk. By the end of it, I was thinking 'this book is kicking ass'.But then, the Games. Oh, the Games. Leave aside the blatant... homage to Koushun Takami's BATTLE ROYALE, or Stephen King's THE RUNNING MAN. I found the actual GAMES part of the HUNGER GAMES pretty dull. Which, I guess, is a big problem. I understand the author wanted to make Katniss a sympathetic hero. But unless I missed a murder somewhere, the victor of the 74th Hunger games kills exactly ONE PERSON in the whole book, and only after she's given moral permission when her victim brutally murders a 12 year old girl. This felt like Collins was passing the buck. You're writing a book about children slaughtering each other. We understand Katniss doesn't want to be there - we've forgiven her for anything she needs to do to survive. You don't need to justify her act of murder by flashing a big neon "CHILD KILLER" sign over the head of her (only) victim.So, without a truckful of murder, how do we fill in space? We've got two acts to fill, and there's only so much space you can take up with "looking for water" and "eating". The answer? Romance. In the middle of a murder zone. Bathed in the blood of innocent children. Lets make some moo cow eyes. /headdesk. I'm not raining on the romance parade, but Jesus, time and place, Peeta, neh?As for the finale? Again, these seemed an attempt to keep Katniss' hands clean. The competitors have conveniently polished each other off, leaving K, Peeta and a brutal soulless killer type, Cato. But Collins can't even seem to have Katniss punch the clock on this type 1 a-hole. Instead, she has some weird wolfoid things do the deed for her. PULL THE TRIGGER GIRL, FFS. It's ok, I don't want you to die! I give you permission to murder someone who's actively trying to PUT YOU IN THE GROUND. Look, the language was sparse, but tense. The action (when it actually happened - there's surprisingly little) is great. I really liked Katniss as a heroine - she's prickly, and hard and cold. She's not peaches and creamy and fuzzy bunnies - wonderful stuff and all too rare in the arena of YA. But if you're going to write a book about a group of children thrown into a bloody gladatorial contest, then DO IT. Don't drop a heroine into the thick of this world of pain, then have her hang around the periphery while the competitors all conveniently stab each other's faces to dying, and then finish off the remaining threat with a deus ex machina. (hide spoiler)]After I first put down this book, I really genuinely loved it. But on closer reflection, the things that bugged me remained, while the things I liked seemed to fade. And I guess the lasting impressions, rather than the fleeting ones, are the ones that count.

After two years of hearing that this book is a new classic and that I simply MUST read it, i have finally given it a chance. I even spent a week listening to a very passionate woman insist that books like the Harry Potter series and "The Giver" and "The Handmaid's Tale" would soon be forgotten as "The Hunger Games" becomes the new standard, not only for Young Adult Literature but for all dystopian literature. Believing such claims invariably leads to disappointment, so I didn't expect to be blown away; i simply expected "The Hunger Games" to be a good piece of fast-paced YA pulp.Five pages in, I was not merely unimpressed, but legitimately sick of this novel. One of my more moderate friends admitted "Well, the writing isn't great, but the story is good. You have to stick with it." That was always a possibility, so I soldiered on, determined to give Collins a chance, and read all 374 pages. I even gave it a full day to simmer after finishing it. Alas, my initial impression stands, augmented and broadened by having read the other 369 pages: this is not a good book.The protagonist is, i am given to understand, supposed to be a strong, independent young woman; but as with Vin in the "Mistborn" series, she actually feels flat and lifeless, like a cardboard cut-out of what the author thinks a character is supposed to be. A lot of authors make this mistake when writing what are supposed to be strong female leads, and it is certainly not a "male authors only" problem. So for every Sabriel (Garth Nix) or Aerin (Robin McKinley) or Tiffany Aching (Terry Pratchett) there is also a Vin or a Bella or a Katniss Everdeen. By comparison, the love interest in "Brazil" felt stronger and better developed.The author's decision to write it in the first-person present-tense disconnects me from both the character and the narrative because the way she goes about it is so clumsy and irritatingly contrived. I actually believe i could excuse the terrible metaphors and the awful framing and the unnecessary sentence fragments if this were written in the past-tense as a sort of memoir; then all the errors and absurd word-choices and poor syntax could be written off as a product of the narrator herself. The choice of present tense eliminates that possibility however. Instead it seems to be a bizarre combination of inner-monologue and epistle, directed at someone outside of the author who requires explanations about things she or a resident of their world should already know, yet narrated as though it is a blow-by-blow account of what is happening to her right now.Things that struck me as I read this book: 1) Everything that other reviewers have pointed out. For instance:http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/...http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/...2) If she's from a poor, backwoods region with a single, largely-absentee parent and has suffered poor hygiene and repeated starvation...why aren't her teeth rotten? It may seem like a silly little quibble, but we're supposed to understand that her family can't even afford the most basic supplies and is reliant on her hunting and selling in the blackmarket, and yet she's kept her teeth healthy and shiny enough that her stylists in the Capitol have nothing to say about them during the extended makeover scene?3) Why are there apparently SO MANY predatory animals and so few prey animals? She speaks repeatedly about how dangerous it is to go beyond the fence due to the wild predators, but also talks about how time-consuming and arduous it is trying to find a prey animal -- prey animals, by the way, that have evidently rarely-if-ever seen a human. That's not how it works! But apparently in the world of this book, you have to search all day to even kill a squirrel, while wolves and bears and cougars are all thriving...despite being squashed between a chemical-ravaged wasteland and human settlements.4) Does this world follow Harry Potter/My Little Pony: Friendship is Magic rules by having people's fates defined by the names they're given at birth? Why else would the baker boy be named "Peeta" and the girl who becomes an archer be named after the Sagittaria flower and the woman in charge of athletic training be named "Atala" and the guy in charge of the (fire-related!) makeover be named "Cinna" and the majority of the people in the Capitol be named after Roman aristocrats? I am reminded of one of my favorite sequences on The Simpsons: CLETUS: We always figured someday Mary would marry. That's why we called her "Mary." We name all our kids after what we think's gonna happen to 'em. Ain't that right, Stabbed-In-Jail?STABBED-IN-JAIL: [whittling a spear] We'll see who stabs who!5) If the story had focused on the minor character "Rue" it would have been a far more interesting and compelling book. She was the only character that actually elicited anything resembling an emotional reaction from me.6) The first 100 pages of the book were immensely uneven, plodding inexplicably as though through molasses at points, then breezing past parts where more information would have been appreciated.7) Was the fey male stylist character REALLY necessary?8) Apparently the arena is some sort of domed, man-made ecosystem a la "The Truman Show" and the people running it have an almost god-like level of environmental control which they only exercise at convenient moments in the narrative, and the people of the Capitol now only use their amazing indistinguishable-from-magic command of genetic engineering to create mutations for the games. There are probably plausible explanations (rationalizations) for all of that, but it just felt entirely too convenient that these things were only mentioned or deployed at specific points in the narrative -- as though Collins had written herself into a corner or thought "Ooh, this would be neat!" and just threw in a hasty bit of exposition in an attempt to hand-wave it all away. 9) Despite living in what amounts to the "ghetto" of an oppressive totalitarian state, and despite having no sources for history other than her state-mandated schooling, the protagonist somehow knows that the state is lying and covering up the true history of the very rebellion that led to her region being a "ghetto"? Riiiiiiiiiiiiight...Overall, the pace is uneven, the characters lack both depth and emotional resonance (especially the protagonist/narrator), the obligatory adolescent love-triangle feels forced and ham-fisted, and I get the feeling that the author has very little understanding of the natural world. Elements are mentioned, then forgotten or ignored (for instance, there are apparently numerous predatory animals in the "arena" but none of the combatants ever face them -- except for mutated ones at the end which are unleashed specifically for the climax -- and the normal predators are only ever seen in the scene with the fire). I'm told by reliable sources that the series gets better with later books, but I don't think that's a risk I'm willing to take after this one. The first book should suck you in -- this one spat me out.For what it's worth though, it looks like they've made a genuinely compelling film out of this mediocre book!

The Hunger Games didn't impress me. When I'm reading a book, especially a speculative fiction book, the first thing I look for is illogical plot holes. I hate them. They ruin books for me. Take Death Note for instance, or even Glee. They are so full of plot holes and illogical inconsistencies, they aren't worth my time. If the author was too lazy to do a bit of research why should I invest myself in their work? That is how I feel about the Hunger Games. Sure, the writing isn't bad. I guess Katniss could be considered a strong female character. She kept it together and didn't freak out. She was tough and resilient. But sometimes you want more than that. I like snark, I like humor, I like cynicism. I know there isn't a place for that in most dystopian novels, but you have to make me love the characters. You have to give them some heart. Look at the Animorphs. We had humor and science. I think that's the thing most serious writers miss out on.But I digress. I started the Hunger Games with high expectations. I thought it would be mind blowing. It wasn't. Anyone who's read Octavia Butler or Philip K. Dick won't be impressed. Sure it's YA but honestly, is that an excuse for lazy world building?Panem is the remnants of the US divided into thirteen districts. The entire political and economical situation of Panem is highly illogical. This is my problem with Avatar: The Last Airbender. When you try to make sense out of the world, nothing fits. Then you're told that you're looking too hard into things, that it's a fantasy world. Sure it's a fantasy world, but we still have rules. If this were and alien world with an alien culture, maybe I'd agree. But this is still Earth. Last time I checked, they were still human. During slavery times in the US, slaves were looked at as less than human. Now I know the people of Panem aren't slaves. So why are they following this system? In Santa Domingo, the people were enslaved and forced to work for 300 years. They didn't have the freedom the people of Panem have. They rebelled, and after 10 years or so they won. They had to fight again and again, but they maintained their freedom from the French. Those people are the Haitians of today.Let's look at any civil war situation on the globe. The closest situation I can think of is in Southern Africa. There, children are forced to fight in wars and carry guns. They kill each other. There, they have their hands cut off if they refuse to fight. Did I mention that they're also in a complete system of disarray? I don't believe that Americans can safely travel there. Why isn't Panem like this? I could have accepted the Hunger Games as a whole if, and only if, their country was in a complete state of havoc. It isn't. Apparently each of the districts get along just fine, supplying the capital with goods. What's with that?And the kicker is, their Ghandi figure, their Martin Luther King Jr., is a teenage girl and her boyfriend. This is our symbol to teens. Apparently, teen love does stop wars, the Earth, and the universe. Look over here, teens fall in love and the gods present us with peace and tranquility for years to come. Yes, the books only continue to get even more illogical. For a system like this to work, I'd have to have a lot of back story to explain the country's situation. I understand that district 13 was blown off the face of the Earth. So was part of Japan for a period of time. You know, some say they don't even teach their kids about WWII over there. But did that stop the Korean War? Did that stop Vietnam? No. And you can bet those wars weren't started by the love of two teens. This series could have been brilliant. It had excellent potential. Unfortunately, besides the illogical world building and the gaping plot holes, there's a problem with pacing.The actual Hunger Games doesn't start until at least one third of the book is over. That's bad pacing. If this were a movie, that's like Nemo getting kidnapped one third of the way into the movie. Also, we waste time building up Gale and Priss, only to find out that they're not even major players in this book. I know it's a series, but a book should be able to stand on it's own. The Chronicles of Narnia do. The first three Harry Potter books do. Instead, we're stuck with Peeta. He's okay, but he's not interesting. The romance felt tacked on. If the capital is swayed by their ridiculous love story, I swear, they're no better than a bunch of Rose/Dimitri fan girls. Also, we're introduced to interesting characters, such as Haymitch, Cinna, and so on, only for them to be left out of the rest of the book. Either this is a post-apocalyptic/action novel or a character study. It can't be both unless you write it well. It certainly can't be a romance if the heroine isn't even sure she likes the Hero. It was kind of obvious from the first few chapters that Katniss liked Gale. It was even more obvious that he liked her. Of course it has to be strung out into a love triangle for the next few books. *Spoiler* Of course he goes evil and she ends up with Peeta.*End Spoiler*There was so much hype behind this book, I expected it to be fantastic. Maybe if it wasn't so popular, I'd have a different opinion. But as it is, bad pacing and stupid world building are not the hallmarks of a fabulous novel.3.0 stars. It's about as average as they come.

This is my very first reread ever, and also my very first audiobook. I was expecting to enjoy it a lot more, but sadly the book didn't have that same effect on me the first time around. Almost everyone knows what the Hunger Games is about. I don't see it necessary to discuss or give a short summary of it anymore. There are 100,000+ reviews on it already, and it has the highest number of ratings here on goodreads. In short, this is the most read book here on goodreads. There is one reason why I chose to reread this. My favorite author is Stephen King, and the reason how that happened was because of this book. After reading this and the second book, the hype was not that prominent then, so I haven't heard much of the series from people. People were talking about other hyped up series, but I stumbled upon this accidentally. I had to research on people's reaction toward the third novel, and I saw this review that said  This is a complete ripoff of Stephen King's The Long Walk and The Green Mile.  I enjoyed the series a lot then, but that certain review made me curious on who this King guy was. I was 14 years old then, so I wasn't reading much adult/horror material then. After finishing Mockingjay, I decided to go ahead and try out The Long Walk (it was 2013 then, so I was 17), and I loved it. I ended up reading a lot more King novels and that resulted to me considering King as my favorite author. So in a way, this series introduced me to Stephen King, so I decided that I owed it a reread and a review at least.My rating when I first read this was 4 stars, maybe even a 4.5, but my reading preference had change over the years. I'm not trying to be part of the minority here by hating on YA books, but almost all of the YAs I've read lately were terrible and shallow. This does not fall under the terrible and shallow pile, but it wasn't as good as it was before. The characters were still pretty decent, but I realized how the plot wasn't as violent anymore. Realistically speaking it is quite terrifying, but I realized that the execution was not. Rather than concentrating on the horrors of what the games can offer, Collins decided to build up the relationship of Katniss and Peeta. I'm not particularly fond of that, but I guess other teenagers are.I believe another factor that affected my rating would be the fact that I listened to this. I'm not a fan of audiobooks, that I can conclude. It might be because I didn't like the one who narrated this, but I think it's really audiobooks in general. The one who narrated this used a robotic voice that was fun at first, but got old quick. I might try out another audiobook and see if I'll change my opinion. I'm not going to listen to the second and third book anymore though.3.5/5 stars. It wasn't as awesome as it was before, but I guess it was still a good novel, and one of the good YA ones. If you're an avid YA reader and you haven't read this, then you're missing out on a lot. Everyone should at least give this one a try and see if they'll enjoy it or not.

What's the point of living in goodness , if you're going to die as a monster? The Hunger Games trilogy was the first YA story I read that treated youngs with both respect and coldness, without filters and right to the point. It set the bar so high for me that after it, every book in the genre I have read is simply not good enough. This first installment gives us an incredibly strong, fierce, human main charachter with a perfect development, a society eerily allegorical to our reality, with a moral of respect and love among the most desperate of situations. The Hunger Games is a very complete story and a perfect first-book-in-series. No recuerdo como me entere de la existencia de este libro, creo que fue cuando adquirieron los derechos para la película, o no recuerdo, pero tras haberlo leído, encendió una chispa por la lectura que hasta la fecha no he podido apagar. A la fregada, le daré las 5 estrellas por que se las merece, punto final. Me he leído libros muy buenos en toda mi vida, de verdad, libros mucho muy buenos, pero la gran mayoría solo se quedan en eso, y luego están estos otros que hacen que me meta tanto en la historia, que hacen que me preocupe tanto por sus personajes que al final solo quiero que todo acabe bien para ellos.  Los Juegos del Hambre es ESE tipo de libros. Collins hace un gran trabajo como escritora, el primer libro siempre es el más difícil, hay que saber dar a entender la trama general y el personaje principal de manera al menos buena, o todo se cae. Y Collins lo hace estupendamente. En muy pocas hojas te das cuenta de la situación de Panem como país, del Distrito 12 como comunidad y de Katniss Everdeen como personaje. Entiendes la perversidad detrás de los juegos, pero no es si no hasta mas adelante, como a la mitad del libro que te das cuenta de porque le han funcionado tan bien al Capitolio por 74 años. Es tan fácil manipular cuando se juega con el instinto mas poderoso y arcaico de todos; el de supervivencia.Me gustan los personajes con metas simples pero importantes en la vida, y Katniss no es mas que eso, una persona con tan poco, que puede contar las personas que le importan con los dedos de las manos, que no puede aspirar a algo grande. Y leer como pasa de ser una chica de mente cerrada, distante y con solo un objetivo que seguir a este personaje fuerte pero con emociones, inteligente pero con necesidad, arrogante pero con caridad y con una visión más amplia del mundo en el que habita es simplemente fascinante. Su cambio de ACTITUD conforme pasa el libro me hace tenerle más y más respeto a pesar de no estar de acuerdo con muchos de sus pensamientos o acciones.Katniss aprende gracias a Rue y Peeta que la única manera de vencer a los Juegos del Hambre es mediante la unión, respetar y defender la vida de otra persona como respetas y defiendes la tuya. Que se puede ser humano aun cuando todo a tu alrededor te impide que lo seas. Y un libro que es capaz darte pensamientos tan positivos creando un mundo con tanta negatividad y dolor merece todas las buenas críticas que tiene.  #HungerGamesFanAndProud El libro tiene otra cosa muy importante a resaltar y es: LA TELEVISION! Los reality TV Shows y toda esa mierda asquerosa! Nombren el que ustedes quieran, da igual porque ES UNA MIERDA! Enserio, cual es el siguiente paso?. Da tanto miedo saber lo fácil con que se manipula a las masas por medio de la televisión. Y así puedo seguir, todo el día, hablando sobre porque este libro y esta historia es tan buena y perfecta dentro de toda su imperfección. En cuanto a los personajes secundarios, aunque no se ve mucho crecimiento por su parte, me gusta que sean todos tan variados. Me encantan las personalidades tan distintas de Katniss y Peeta, me encanta todo lo que aprende de el, y como se complementan. Soy una fan de las parejas con personalidades distintas, o tal vez no soy fan de las parejas con personalidades iguales, no lo se, el punto es que hay muy pocas historias románticas que me llenen y la de Katniss y Peeta es una de ellas. :'DAgregándole que el libro tiene muy buena información de supervivencia, y buenas escenas de acción, un ritmo muy fluido y una seguridad en su propia historia digna de aplaudirse. No creo que tenga que decir esto dado todo lo que ha crecido esta historia por si sola y ahora con las películas (que me encantan por cierto) pero si por alguna razón extraña no lo has leído, dale una oportunidad. Altamente recomendado.Como le hace? Enserio, como le hace esta mujer Suzanne Collins? Dios mío! Había olvidado por completo lo tristes, crueles y horribles que eran los últimos capítulos. Lo mucho que tocan la fibra sentimental. La autora termina el libro con un desgarro emocional impresionante. Y es que en la película no es tan intenso el final. En tan pocas hojas, te hace llorar, enojar, odiar y querer. Te da esperanza, te la quita, te la vuelve a dar, te la vuelve a quitar, y de paso, destroza todos los corazones Everlark! Te deja llorando en posición fetal. D: y con muchas, muchas ganas de leer el siguiente.*ni yo me la creo*LA PELÍCULA:Me gusto. Bastante. Salí de esa sala muy feliz y contenta con la adaptación, las actuaciones, etc. No, no fue perfecta, pero es sin duda el mejor inicio de franquicia que he visto. Mucha gente se queja de que la cámara se movía mucho, pero yo nunca lo sentí, al contrario hacia que todo se viera mas real, como si estuvieras ahí detrás de Katniss corriendo. Sin duda lo mas fuerte es el casting, sobretodo Katniss y Snow. Si alguno de los dos hubiera fallado, TODA esta franquicia hubiera muerto, pero esos dos lo LOGRARON! Hice todo lo que una fangirl haría, grite, se me salieron lagrimas, reí, salte, aplaudí, pero lo mejor de todo, después al salir de la película e intentar verla con ojo critico, pude decir, ES UNA BUENA PELÍCULA! No todos los fandoms pueden decir eso gente, así que por favor agradezcan!

Re-read: 21/03/2012 to.... oh who am I kidding? I read this book in a day.--------------------------------------------Dear Ms Collins,I think I speak on behalf of most young adult readers when I say thank you for writing a series that allows us to say “I told you so” when every single person we recommend the book to devours it within a day and adores it.I may be speaking for myself here but when I say “I read the books before I saw the film” about the Hunger Games, I will say it loud and proud and smugly.Thank you for showing everyone that it’s OK to be a Katniss kinda gal.Forever a fan,Jo.x------------------------------------------Dear Katniss,Compassionate. Brutal. Awkward. Strong. Loyal. Looks good with a side plait. [It’s a difficult look to pull off, believe you me.]It’s all been said before and I hope it gets said again and again. With you, we readers finally got a heroine who wasn’t afraid to stand up for what they believe in. And also, a heroine who didn’t just believe in boys and kissing.You are the ultimate.Yours always,Jo.xxxps. I have also been keeping track of the boy with the bread. When I say ‘keep track of’ I mean ‘fancied the pants off’….------------------------------------Dear Peeta,It struck me when I read Katniss’ 100% true memoir the entirely fictional account of the 74th Hunger Games how hilarious you are. For some reason, I forgot this in the lull between the first reading of the book and the second reading. I like how you are actually a character with your own personality and not just one of the tired YA boy clichés that get paraded out when the heroine needs to look ‘feminine’ and ‘normal’ and less “squirrel-killery”. Because, obviously, kissing boys is the only way this can be done, right?Anyway, I think I have done you a great disservice by describing you as the ‘nice’ guy when I have been recommending this book to my family and my friends and that weird woman who wouldn’t leave me alone when I was waiting at the train station.So, for that, I apologise.I mean, you are nice but you also have an incredibly dry humour which I adore so much.“You here to finish me off, sweetheart?”“Yes, frosting. The final defence of the dying.”“Remember, we’re madly in love, so it’s all right to kiss me any time you feel like it.”You’re also so incredibly swoony and I would like to cuddle in a cave with you while you whisper sweet nothings into my ear.And when I say ‘cuddle in a cave’ I mean in a fancy restaurant where an oddly attractive psychopath isn’t out for our blood. And there would probably be profiteroles.And when I say ‘sweet nothings’ I mean recipes for delicious cakes...It will be a cold day in hell when I don’t fancy a boy who can provide me with regular baked products.I LOVE BREAD AND I LOVE YOU.Lots of love,Jo.xxx--------------------------G-I always root for the underdog.“Catnip”*sigh*Also, I always root for the tall, fit hunter-gatherer type who would always be there to protect the heroine but lets her protect herself because he knows she could do it just as well, if not better, than he could and he respects that and encourages her strength.Probs just me.--------------------------Haymitch, mate, you need to ring me.You left your phone at my house and god it’s been ringing off the hook. Effie really wanted to speak to you, dunno what about. I listened to some of the messages (God, she’s shrill, isn’t she?) and all I got from it was that Katniss needed you to get her something. Something about Katniss not being able to find water and needing you to send her some? Or else she was gonna die? Ha. Effie is such a drama queen, isn’t she?Does that make any sense to you?Nah, I didn’t get it either.Anyway, last Friday was BRILLIANT. Remember? We got really drunk and we ended up on that pedalo? And then we were in that club and you requested Mysterious Girl by Peter Andre from the DJ and I was like “THIS SONG IS ALL ABOUT ME!” and you were like “OMG THIS SONG REALLY IS ALL ABOUT YOU!!…..You really don’t remember?Anyway, we need to do that again because us two, H? We’re in it for the long haul. I know what happens in the Capitol stays in the Capitol but I guess it’s also the law…‘Til Sambuca do us part,Jo.xxxps. Do you have my left shoe? I’ve looked all over Panem and I can’t find it.-----------------------------Dearest Cin,Can I call you Cin? You never replied to my other letter so I’m guessing it’s OK. Anyway, Cin… speaking of those other letters, do you have an answer for me?Would you be willing to be my Life Coach? I know it would be a bit of a task because, well, I’m pretty much failing at all things life-related but this is where you come in.Just picture it, we could go shopping. We could talk about make-up. You could diagnose what the hell is going on with my hair. We could talk about politics.Me and Katniss are practically best friends too, so you could go ahead and book is in on the same session.It’ll be glorious and just think how satisfying it would be to succeed. We could do a Before and After kind of thing. Or make it into a reality TV show?!?!We could be the next Audrey and Rex!Anyway, I’ve included a self-addressed envelope just in case you lost my address.Can’t wait to hear back from you!xoxoxops. I spent about three hours in Boots looking at gold eye-liner last weekend. I just couldn’t decide whether I would suit it or not. I think it takes a certain kind of person to wear that colour, you know? So instead I went to get a meal deal but the woman on the til said I couldn’t have two brownies and a Diet Coke instead of a sandwich, a brownie and a Diet Coke. So I glowered at her for a bit and bought the two brownies anyway and then added another one to my basket IN PROTEST. And I refused to get an advantage card. TO SPITE HER.pps. See? Life failing, thy name is Jo. HELP.----------------------------Dear Rue,You know when you’re trying to sleep in in the mornings and there’s that bloody annoying bird outside your window that is just screeching and squawking and you’re just like “HOLY MOCKINGJAY WOULD YOU SHUT UP?!?!?”That was me trying to send you a message via a wood pigeon. I learnt too late that they are not Mockingjays and they do not have the ability to send messages.So… um.. sorry for the squawking and disturbing your Sunday lie-ins.Basically, I just wanted to say that you’re a wonderful little girl and if I think about it really hard, you’re the starting point for everything that happens in this book.Love you,Jo.xxx----------------------------Dearest Finnick,Yes, I know you’re not in this book but I wanted to just let you know that I will be reading Catching Fire again in the near future and I am SO EXCITED because you are one of my favourite real life fictional boys ever.Also, I have missed it when you take off your top randomly and show your abs.KISSES AND ETERNAL LOVE FOREVER AND EVER,Jo.xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx---------------------------------Dear Jennifer Lawrence,I can’t decide whether I am more in love with your boyfriend or you.Who am I kidding? It's totally you.I don’t know what this means.Best wishes,Jo.xxxps. You don’t happen to still have Michael Fassbender’s number, do you?You can read this review and lots of other exciting things on Wear the Old Coat.

*****spoilers*****Like everyone else, I was drawn to the underdog of The Hunger Games. The unfairness of the games is probably the thing that bothered me the most, how some of the contestants were so much better prepared than others.Look, here you have a bunch of kids, yanked from their homes, sent to fight to the death. There is the underdog contestant. She had little chance of winning. And there's that other contestant who's by far the most qualified to win, and has basically been trained from birth, fully hard-ass enough to survive. This other character has such astonishing intuition that it is almost on par with Edward Cullen's mind reading skills (oddly though, except when something is completely obvious). Further, any moral dilemmas - such as having to kill friends - are taken care of by outside forces. And cornered? No problem, there'll be something handy within reach to solve the problem. Talk about born under a lucky star.So yeah, things always worked out for Katniss.Then you have that other contestant who is far less lucky. Smaller, yet shrewd, observant, intelligent, able to replicate complicated patterns, at first able to avoid getting killed. Not attacking the others. Having no weapon skills, just hoping to survive by default. Her clever and risky idea at the Cornucopia worked so well that it brought on a fit of jealousy from Katniss - probably in the same mean spirit that inspired her to come up with the nickname "Foxface". Why not something less catty, say for example "Vixen" - which still plays on the fox reference yet also to female beauty and cleverness. Vixie for short, I should think. Vixie never, ever called Katniss "Arrowheadface". Nor Peeta "Doughface". I felt the full weight of the evil of this contest when Vixie died so tragically and so very ironically. Her laughter, her unique abilities, her sleek red hair, gone, gone with a handful of berries. The mean trick fate played on her with those berries was so opposite to the luck that always went to Katniss. Here I felt the pain of living in a dystopia like Panem, where some are given advantages and others are not. My tears were flowing as I read Miss V's final moment: "What’s left of Foxface’s emaciated body is lifted into the air. I can see the red glint of her hair in the sunlight."And then later when attacked by the mutts, all Katniss can think of is “It’s her!” continuing her weird jealous obsession with the one girl that could've beaten her - if the games hadn't been so fixed in Katniss's favour.Poor poor, unlucky thing. No fantastic Mr. Fox for you, no Jamie, no D. H. Lawrence, dear Miss Vixie. No, life is not Fair & Balanced.I leave this  musical tribute  for you.

Okay, so as Milan pointed out everybody and their dog is reading this series, so I did too! It sounded exciting, fast-paced with action, romance and adventure, set in a dystopian society where children are forced to participate in deatchmatches which are a form of official entertainment. What more could a reader want?Well, it turned out that this reader could want quite a lot more. Since I am a well known reading snob who only reads mass-markets found in drugstores and at bus stops I'm going to bitch what I didn't like, but first I'll say what I liked. Well, the cover is nice, and so is the title, but that's about it.Set in post-apocalyptic North America, The Hunger Games instantly brings to mind Battle Royale, the book or the film. Add to these cool teenage protagonists, some sort of Anime cosplay costumes designed by cool designers (in this book you go to the scaffold with style!) and you should have the latest teen craze which would disappear from shelves like my grandmother's homemade pierogies when I'm in her town. And, of course, you'd be right.Only The Hunger Games is nowhere near as meaty as good pierogies, even those with cheese stuffing. It's a very quick read, because the writing style is rather simplistic. The present tense narrative should allow for closeness and attachment to the main character, Katniss, and her feelings and emotions, only either I'm getting old or am a bastard because I found it hard to give a crap about what she thinks or feels. Maybe the character was just flat as a board, or I'm getting to old for this, since this is a book aimed at teenagers. I failed to care about any of the characters and found most events to be unsurprising except for a weird thing which occured near the end of the book, but it was not quite enough to save it as a whole for me. I found the romance part to be quite emotionless and the only chemistry to be found was in the big apple which I ate when reading this book because it was as big as a tire. So, the straight forward writing serves the action scenes well, and to give the author credit there's a lot of them but they're all that there is to it, and such themes and motives have been carried out earlier by other writers.To sum up: The Hunger Games reads like a bag of chips, meaning you can devour it in several short bites but it will leave you unnourished and aside from some gas won't have much effect. If you'll pardon the pun, it left me hungry. I might still read the other two books in the series because they read so fast and you can always do with more bragging about the number of books you've read, and there's supposed to be a rebellion or something in the second one and the third one has a cool title. Stay tuned!

Just in under the wire! In about three-and-a-half hours the midnight showings of The Hunger Games will begin on the east coast—and now I can officially state that I read the book before it was ruined by those Hollywood bastards and avoid being classified as a johnny-come-lately, if only by a ridiculously infantile technicality. So what I was thinking was this: What the world needs now isn't love, sweet love; it's another review of The Hunger Games. You see, beating a dead horse is for amateurs. I like to beat a bottle of glue. (Now that's takin' passé to a whole 'nother level.)Does loving The Hunger Games make me a humungous girl? Well, then, you better install my fallopian tubes pronto—because this book thrilled and engrossed me. I spent hours when I could have been masturbating to internet porn reading The Hunger Games instead. I just couldn't stop reading this dagnab thing. Katniss Everdeen—the heroine of said young adult dystopian novel—bewitched me with her archery, her flaming headgear, and her knowledge of mutant wasps. What I really liked about her was that she wasn't a complete moron like another female heroine of a YA literary phenomenon who shall remain nameless. She's actually complex in a way that klutzy, weather-obsessed Phoenix transplant could never be.

مباريات الجوع عندما قرأت عن هذه الرواية، ومن ثم قرأتها فيما بعد، كان أول ما طرأ على بالي هو أن الفكرة ليست جديدة تماما ً، فقد استخدمها (ستيفن كينج) في روايته (الرجل الراكض) والتي نشرت سنة 1982 م – ترجمها بنفس العنوان د. أحمد خالد توفيق في سلسلة روايات عالمية، بينما ترجمت ونشرت مؤخرا ً عن طريق مكتبة جرير تحت عنوان (الهارب) -، استخدمها أيضا ً الياباني كوشون تاكامي سنة 1999 م في روايته (معركة رويال) التي شاهدت الفيلم المقتبس منها، هذا غير تشابه الفكرة مع حفنة أخرى من الروايات إما بشكل أو بآخر. رغم كل هذا، إلا أن العبقرية دائما ً تكمن في التفاصيل، وهذا يعلمنا أن الفكرة لا تموت، نعم تهرم من كثرة الاستخدام، ولكنها لا تموت، بل هي تنتظر الكاتب الذكي الذي سيأتي وينشب فيها أظفاره بحيث يجلو عنها كل الطبقات التي غطتها، سيأتي ويفتتح طريقا ً جديدا ً للفكرة، شيئا ً يأخذها إلى أبعد مما فعل الآخرون. هل فعلت سوزان كولينز هذا في روايتها هذه؟ أو لنقل هل هذا ما ستفعله في ثلاثيتها عن (مباريات الجوع)؟ لا يمكنني أن أقول رأيا ً كاملا ً، وأنا لم اقرأ إلا الجزء الأول فقط، وينتظرني (ألسنة اللهب) و(الطائر المقلد)، وهما الجزءان اللذان أتطلع إلى قراءتهما، ولكنني سأعتمد على هذا الجزء الأول لأظهر الجديد والجميل في هذا الشكل الأحدث من الفكرة. ولكن ما هي الفكرة؟ ما الذي أغرى كل هؤلاء الكتاب وجعلهم يكتبونها؟تنبيه: ما سيأتي قد يكشف شيئا ً من أحداث هذه الرواية وروايات أخرى مشابهة. الفكرة هي عن مستقبل مظلم للبشرية، مستقبل يتفكك فيه المجتمع بحيث يصل إلى مرحلة يستعيد فيها تقاليد رومانية بادئة، ولكن هذه المرة بإهاب عصري، حيث يعيد الناس افتتاح كوليسيوم عصري، يلقى فيه المجالدون حتفهم فقط لإسعاد الجمهور الجديد، الذي لم يعد يثيره إلا الرعب الحقيقي، ومشاهد الدماء الحقيقية. تقول المؤلفة أن فكرة الكتاب جاءتها وهي تقلب قنوات التلفاز ذات يوم، حيث ترابطت القنوات التي تعرض برامج الواقع، مع القنوات الإخبارية التي تعرض تغطيات الحروب، هذا غير ذكرى الأسطورة اليونانية عن المونيتور، حيث كانت أثينا مرغمة على إرسال أبنائها إلى كريت حيث يلتهمهم وحش أسطوري يعيش في متاهة مرعبة، هذا طبعا ً قبل أن يقصم عمره ثيسوس. قد تبدو لنا في الوقت الحالي فكرة عودة مثل هذه التجارب المرعبة التي عاشتها البشرية زمنا ً مستحيلة، ولكننا في الواقع على بعد خطوة واحدة من ذلك، فشغف الناس بأفلام الرعب، وأفلام الحركة حيث يموت العشرات على الشاشة، وحيث يصل العنف ذروته، هذا غير ألعاب الفيديو التي تجعل الشخص يمارس العنف بنفسه، ثم الاهتمام بالرياضات التنافسية التي يضرب فيها المشارك خصمه إلى حدود الموت تقريبا ً، مثل الملاكمة والمصارعة، وأخيرا ً برامج تلفزيون الواقع التي يستمتع فيها المشاهد بتخطي المشاركين لحدود الوضع البشري الطبيعي، إما بالفضائح أو محاولة البقاء والتغلب على الآخرين، كل هذا يعلمنا أن بذرة العنف موجودة في النفس البشرية، وأن تغييرا ً سياسيا ً يزيل الغطاء المجتمعي قد يولد من العنف ما لا يمكن تخيله. ندع هذا كله ونعود إلى الفكرة، طرح ستيفن كينج هذه الفكرة كما قلت في روايته (الرجل الراكض)، حيث يشترك البطل في إحدى هذه المسابقات الجحيمية ليوفر ثمن الدواء لطفلته المريضة وليعيل زوجته التي تحولت إلى عاهرة لتوفر لهم المال، حيث لا يستطيع هو العمل لأنه بكل بساطة على قائمة سوداء، تمنعه من العمل، فكرة اللعبة التي يشارك فيها والتي تحمل اسم الرجل الراكض أو الهارب، هي أن يعطى مبلغا ً صغيرا ً من المال وكاميرة فيديو، يجب أن يستخدمها ليرسل رسالتين مسجلتين يوميا ً أثناء فترة هروبه، حيث تنطلق بعد 12 ساعة من بداية اللعبة، قوات متخصصة تتعقبه وتحاول قتله، يربح المشارك 100 دولار عن كل ساعة تمضي، و100 دولار عن كل رجل شرطة يقتله، وإن استطاع الصمود والبقاء حتى 30 يوما ً، يحصل على الجائزة الكبرى وهي مليار دولار، يبدع ستيفن كينج كثيرا ً في هذا الكتاب حتى نهايته المفاجئة بل والعبقرية. في المقابل كانت رواية الياباني تاكامي عبارة عن يابان مستقبلية، يخطف فيها الجيش طلاب مدرسة ثانوية، ويقوم بإخضاعهم لتجربة تجعلهم يقاتلون فيها بعضهم البعض حتى الموت. عندما نكون قد قرءنا وشاهدنا هذه الفكرة من قبل، ما الذي نريده من رواية جديدة تعيد طرح الفكرة ذاتها من جديد؟ دائما ً وأبدا ً التفاصيل هي من يصنع الفرق، قدرة الروائي على إعادة تركيب الفكرة بطريقة مبدعة، وإثرائها بأفكار وتفاصيل جديدة، هي ما يصنع الفارق لدى القارئ. في هذه الرواية نحن في المستقبل من جديد، أمريكا تفككت وحلت مكانها دولة تدعى بانيم، وهي عبارة عن 13 مقاطعة تحكمها مدينة حصينة بنيت على جبال روكي، تسمى الكابيتول، حاولت هذه المقاطعات الثورة على الكابيتول، ولكن تم سحق التمرد، وأبيدت المقاطعة الثالثة عشرة تماما ً، وفرض على المقاطعات الباقية إرسال فتى وفتاة سنويا ً للمشاركة في (مباريات الجوع)، ومباريات الجوع هي ميدان واسع يلقى فيه المشاركون ويتركون ليقتلوا بعضهم البعض حتى لا يعود هناك إلا منتصر واحد، يحصل على الثروة والمجد ويعود إلى مقاطعته، التي تنال بدورها نصيبا ً وافرا ً من الطعام لذلك العام، كيف يتم اختيار المشاركين؟ بالقرعة بين كل أبناء المقاطعة الذين تتراوح أعمارهم ما بين 12 و18 عاما ً، أو بأن يتطوع أحدهم للمشاركة، وهذا ما يفعله عادة ً المحترفون من أبناء المقاطعات الغنية، والذين تم تدريبهم جيدا ً بحيث تحولوا إلى آلات للقتل، طبعا ً كل ما يجري في الميدان ينقل مباشرة إلى جميع أرجاء بانيم. في العام الرابع والسبعين من بداية مباريات الجوع، نتعرف على (كاتنيس ايفردين) فتاة في السادسة عشرة من عمرها، توفي والدها وتركها ووالدتها وأختها الصغيرة بريم، ولأن الأم دخلت في حالة من الاكتئاب الحاد، صارت كاتنيس هي من يعيل العائلة الصغيرة عن طريق الصيد في الغابة، رغم أن القانون يمنع هذا، حيث كانت المقاطعة الثانية عشرة وهي أفقر المقاطعات مكلفة بتوفير الفحم، يضع حظ بريم السيئ، الفتاة الصغيرة في مواجهة الموت من أول سنة تشارك فيها، فتتطوع كاتنيس لتحل مكانها، ويقع الاختيار على صبي خباز يدعى (بيتا ميلارك) ليكون الفتى المرشح من المقاطعة الثانية عشرة التي ينتمي لها الاثنان. تأخذنا المؤلفة إلى الكابيتول حيث نعايش ما يحدث خطوة بخطوة، من تقديم المشاركين للجمهور إلى تحضيرهم للقتال، وحتى اللحظة التي يدفعون فيها إلى الميدان، حيث نتابع القتال الشرس الذي يدور، ونتابع بكل إعجاب شخصيتي كاتنيس وبيتا الجذابتين، وتحالفهما ونكتشف الحب الذي كان بيتا يكنه لكاتنيس منذ طفولته، وكيف أنقذهما هذا الحب من الموت مرات. القصة لم تنتهي بالطبع، لازال هناك جزءين، صحيح أن كاتنيس وبيتا انتصرا في مباريات الجوع، ولكنهما الآن يواجهان ما هو أخطر، يواجهان الكابيتول الذي تحدياه والذي سيتأكد بأن هذه الثورة الصغيرة لابد أن تنتهي بأسرع ما يمكن. تميزت الرواية كما قلت باهتمام المؤلفة بتفاصيل المباريات، وبناءها للشخصيات وخاصة شخصية كاتنيس، والتي ستؤدي دورها في الفيلم المقتبس من الرواية، الموهوبة (جينيفر لورنس) التي تميزت في العام الماضي في فيلم (Winter's Bone).

Review: THIS BOOK! My second read and I'm keeping my original rating. ALL THE STARS! I devoured it again in less than 24 hours.Everyone has read and reviewed this, so I'll keep it brief. I just think this is one of the best books ever. The whole package: story, writing, characters, pacing... it hits all my feels and is everything I'm looking for in a book. There was nothing that annoyed me. There is a hint of a love triangle, but it's so minor in this first book that it's almost not even a factor whatsoever. The author really succeeded in making the reader care for the characters very quickly and easily. I was drawn right into the story from the very beginning.I just think it's freaking brilliant. Young adult, but certainly doesn't read like YA. Just a damn fine story, period.And that's all I have to say about it since everything has already been said. :DBuddy Re-read with Buddies Books and Baubles starting March 1, 2016.

“Happy Hunger Games! And may the odds be ever in your favor.”So I read this book first when the movie came out, in Dutch, and it has always been one of my favorite books ever. This is actually one of the first books I’ve ever read for fun in my life and I’m so excited that I can talk about it in a review for the first time. After reading this I realized again why it is my favorite book again, and it’s only flaw is that I wanted more. From everything.Note: Since I already read the book and have seen the movie like four times I won’t go into detail to much about the plot and the twists since I know them like the back of my hand.Contains spoilers for the whole ‘The Hunger Games’ series (but who hasn’t read this?) !
  Design (5,0 stars) 
One of the main reasons for reading this book again, besides it being my favorite and wanting to re-experience it again, was because I have wanted the beautiful hardbacks for years now, and I was finally able to get my hands on them. They are absolutely gorgeous and I love the design so much. I’m so in love with the mockingjay on the front of the naked hardcovers and I just love the designs inside the book that matches the contents of this book really well.Start of the book (5,0 stars) From the first word in this book I was just sucked in the world again. The writing style was amazing, Katniss was amazing, the world building. I was so happy to be back reading this plot again.
  The writing style (5,0 stars) 
So since it is technically the first time I read Suzanne Collin’s words, without being translated, I can judge that fairly. The writing style in this book was perfect, it had the right amount of anything. The right amount of world building, of humor, of character building, of descriptions, of main character thinking, of tension, of combat, of pacing etc… It made me laugh, it made me cry, it was just prefect! She can tell so much on one page, and write action so well and clear. I also want to comment how much I loved being in Katniss her head, it felt like a story she was telling me personally. Even after knowing what the next page would contain, I still couldn’t stop reading. I do have one tiny remark though (but it wasn’t really necessary because maybe it would have made the book longwinded), that I as a diehard fan of this trilogy would have appreciated. That was more information about the other candidates and districts. I mean we only get to hear like 6 challenge scores, we only know 10 names, we only get 5 outfit descriptions here and there out of the 24 contestants so that was a missed opportunity I thought to make it more personal and rememberable. 
  The world building (5,0 stars) 
I completely forgot how great this world building is. How much history is put in this book to back up all the current cruelty. I absolutely love the design of the hunger games and the capitol with the surrounding districts and all the other details. I also loved the addition of the muttants, they were so cleaver thought through and I was so impressed about the vivid writing of them. I’m still haunted by the wold/bear like creatures with the tributes eyes and I loved the mocking jays and their singing talents but also the trackerjackers. And who in their right mind can make me fall in love with a book about child murder.. Just the way the words are written about the world suggests that the writer thinks this is not okay and that was one of the things I love most about this book and that really made me laugh.
  Main Character (5,0 stars) 
 “Katniss, the girl who was on fire!” Katniss is and will always be one of my favorite character. She is a bit cynical, but also super badass. She makes right decisions always knows what to do, keeps her head clear, protects who she loves. I’m still so impressed with how flawed Collins can make a character and also made me love her from the first sentence. I love how much Katniss doubts about her and Peeta in this book though the reader can see it is genuine. I also loved in this book that the girl is the protector and the provider and she is in no way dependent on Peeta.
  Other characters (5,0 stars) 
 Like I said before I would have liked to know more about the other tributes. But this is only because I seriously love all the others. Every character whether they were a villain or a hero was perfect in character. I’m so obsessed with the career tributes; how can a person be willing to risk their life like this willingly. I’m so curious about the situations in district 1 through 6 (I don’t believe we get to hear anything from them in the next books). I absolutely love how the careers are this evil villains that train their whole life. I’m so in love with Rue and Prim they are both adorable, I found the bond that Katniss forms with the girls really realistic. I also found Haymitch and Effy super realistic. They are both in their own way super unique personalities I’ve never come across in a book. I love that they both deal with their feelings in their own way and I also really like the character development the both of them make. I also really like the characters from the capitol. I think the people are put down so haughtily and naive that you kind of feel sorry for them even though they are one of the reasons the hunger games still continues. And of course Cinna, what a hero, one of my favorite characters in this book. Peeta is just amazing, I loved how supportive he is of Katniss. 
  Romance (5,0 stars) 
 “Remember, we're madly in love, so it's all right to kiss me anytime you feel like it.” Like so many, I’m not a fan of love triangles. And I skipped over most off the parts where Katniss compares Gale and Peeta, although I must admit this aren’t much. I loved to slowly experience Katniss fall in love with Peeta, even when she’s not realizing it. And that is one of the things I love most about this book, the realistically falling in love.
  Plot (5,0 stars) 
This plot, it never stops, never halts, never slows and certainly never bores. Every single aspect about this book is so thought through and cleverly designed that there just isn’t a flaw to detect. I loved the political aspect that’s woven in this series, the tactics that behind picking a ‘simple’ dress was so awesome to read. I loved the involvement of clothing in this book so much, it adds so much more dimension and reality and shows the differences between districts and capitol so well. I loved to read about what Cinna designs and creates and found it so clever of Collins to also add these dimensions (only thing again was that I missed some more costume descriptions of all the other tributes). I enjoyed this plot so so much and I realized that I had forgotten some details that aren’t in the movie. The thing about the muttations their eyes, gave me goosbumps all over again. And also the story line from the Avox girl! I also LOVE the including of some really original aspects that are going to be associated with the Hunger Games forever. Like the three fingers in the air kiss and the mockingjay symbol.The only thing that was kind of a shame, and that is done pretty good in the movie, is to enlighten the motives of the capitol and game makers a bit more. The decisions behind some things are a bit vague and in the movie it shows really clear what happens everywhere in the arena and capitol. I for example have no clue how Thresh died and I wanted so much more to know about the bloody opening battle and I found it a missed opportunity to not include this. Some favorite scenes:-	Katniss volunteering (still tearing up with this)-	Katniss her dress-	Katniss scoring her 11-	The interviews-	The opening from the hunger games -	Rue O Rue:([image error]-	Katniss finding Peeta near the water-	Katniss dropping the nest on the carreers-	Being chased by the wolf/bear like muttants-	The final scene with the berries
  The ending (5,0 stars) 
This ending has so much tension and though it concludes this book it urges you to keep on reading. The way Katniss plays the capitol is absolutely amazing and I love how she outsmarted them. I also really like that the last interview got included in this one and that Peeta’s leg shows that not everything can be healed. I’m looking forward to re-reading the other books! “You don’t forget the face of the person who was your last hope.”

as a general rule, in fact pretty much as a rule period, i don't read young adult/teen fiction.the few that i've tried have seemed to me to be, well, basically simple.so i haven't read any of the twilight books, and let me digress for a moment to say that i think this vampire craze that has swept over north america the last few years to be completely ridiculous.and i haven't read any of the harry potter books either, even though i've had many adult friends tell me how great they are.and no other y/a books either.so karen is taking a teen fiction course, and i told her i don't read any of that stuff, and she tells me i have to read the hunger games trilogy.now if it had been pretty much anybody else on the planet, i would have just ignored her and went on my merry way, just like i ignored the harry potter promoters.however karen has yet to steer me wrong on any books she has recommended to me.i've lost count of how many books/authors she has recommended to me, but it's getting to be quite a few, and she's been right every time.so i said, ok i'll try the first one.but even so ( and i didn't tell karen this), it was very reluctantly. it was like, oh if you reeeeeealy want me to, i'll give the stupid thing a try.then to make matters worse, i was going to take book one out of the library but there were 154 people on the waiting list, so i wouldn't have got it forever.so i decided to buy it, and then it turned out to be more economical to buy the whole trilogy in a boxed set than to but the books separately.so basically, here i am, having just spent $40, and i'm thinking i'll read one chapter of book one, decide it's dreck, and that will be the end of that.well guess what? to my complete surprise, it's a fabulous fucking book!in fact, if i hadn't know anything about it, i wouldn't have known it was teen fiction at all, it reads just like an "adult" book.so teen fiction,adult, whatever, it's just a really great, very entertaining, well written story that should appeal to just about anybody who likes reading at all.so if you haven't already read this,and i realize many people have,you should ruch out and but the damn thing right away.thanks again karen.

I know everything has already been said about this amazing book, but I also need to express my feelings towards it.Dear Hunger Games,When I first heard about you, I actually thought you were sadist and crazy. So damn crazy... I mean, people killing each other in an arena? No thanks. Then I saw all my friends reading you, so I was like what's happening on this planet?! I must say that your popularity won me over. I came across you at the shopping center and you were so present that I convinced myself to try you. I must admit that you excited me a bit. Just a bit. So there I was, in my room, starting to read you (one month after I purchased you by the way). My statuses that day:1PM: Started reading Hunger Games.2PM: Reading Hunger Games.4PM: OMG, KATNISS NOOOOOOOO! (Reading Hunger Games).6PM: Mooooom leave me alone, I'll eat later!! (Still reading Hunger Games).7PM: I'm so hungry. (Went to take a snack and returned in the world of Hunger Games).8PM: Aaaaah, my body is so still (haven't exercise all day because of Hunger Games).9PM: OMG! WHAT DID I JUST READ? OOOOOOOH! (Finished reading Hunger Games).You completely hooked me, there is nothing more I can say. (I might love you, I don't know).Yours truly,Lola xoxo

Here is one I read back before the hype began! My library had one copy and I did not even have to put it on hold.Since it was before the movies were even planned, I was able to approach this book with an open mind. Also, the trend of dystopian young adult novels hadn't really ramped up yet (the trend didn't catch on with The Giver back in the 90s).I really got into this book and couldn't put it down. I know at least two people who had never heard of it that read it right way after my recommendation (can you believe that, a time when someone had not heard of The Hunger Games!?!).Needless to say, even if dystopian YA is super saturated now or you are suffering from Hunger Games fatigue, this was a pretty good book!

Everyone's reviewed The Hunger Games. It's time someone reviewed the setting, specifically, mine.*I take the book and head to my bed, attempting to worm my way in between the edge and my dog, who is grumpy and doesn't want to be disturbed. I'm left with about eighteen inches of blanket between him and the edge of the covers, so I draw a throw over the exposed parts and start reading. I soon find myself lost in imagining the hardscrabble life of District 12 and wondering if the 'meat-eaters' Katniss refers to outside the fence mean zombies. I hope so, but I'm doubtful, because otherwise the reviews would have mentioned zombies. Most reviewers don't just forget to mention something like that in a review if the book has them. Like vampires, they are hard to ignore. So she probably means cougars and such. Oh well. Still, note to self: look out for 'meat eaters.'Katniss' has just the sort of self-reliance and composure I love to see in a character. I understand her anger at her mother, although I sigh a little at yet another female who has an Oedipus complex. I am glad that Prim is used to humanize her, even if it is a tried and true technique. I find myself interested in Buttercup, the antagonistic, ill-named cat. Still, my own canine Buttercup isn't budging, despite my attempts to gradually use my leg as a wedge to drive him further toward the middle of the bed. I'm getting colder, since the throw isn't compensating for the house cooling. Since it is late and I'm cold, I decide a hot bath would be just the setting for the next stage of the journey.Alas, while the water is satisfactorily warm to start with, it never reaches the truly steaming temperature that is worth a prolonged soak. I try to read quickly. Leaving the District, headed toward the Capitol, and the wider world in this post-apocalypic setting is becoming clear, as well as Collins starting to detail revolutionary underpinnings. Still, it's subtle, and I rather like that in a book, especially a teen one. The city setting is unsurprising, although it seems like quite a tech contrast from the districts, and the connection Katniss develops with the understated stylist Cinna is warming. I wonder if he is supposed to be referencing a real-world designer? Except all the ones I've heard of seem quite flamboyant. I wonder if Collins is trying to say something about character in the city? It is here, immersed in rapidly cooling water that I wonder a bit if I'm reading too fast, because I find myself hitting more areas that I don't think Collins explained and I find it a little odd when Katniss suddenly drops these bits of knowledge for the reader. Except why does she seem clueless at times? But despite running more water, the bathwater isn't getting much warmer, so I can't be bothered to go back and re-read to see if I missed some subtle hint. I'm a little irritated from being chilled, so it's time to get out before I start picking further at the story.Changed into pajamas, dogs sprawled on the bed but with a spare third left for me. I weasel my way under the covers and nudge a dog aside. The contestants have entered the arena, poised in their metal circles. The writing is done well enough to give a sense of place and yet pull action forward. The firewall unleashed by the gamemasters seems a bit unfair and reminds me of (insert any reality show here) but it reminds me I have a heating pad in the bed, so I turn it on to warm me up faster. The action in the arena is captivating, and is isn't until Katniss is hallucinating that I realize I am also experiencing a bit of double-vision. My new bookshelf arrived yesterday, and it didn't get more than a day to air out before I impatiently hauled it inside, spending a number of happy hours rearranging my books. Unfortunately, it had been so tightly wrapped that the stain hadn't really finished out-gassing, and I was starting to get headachey. As Katniss tried to recover, I decided timing was right for my own move. Besides, I knew she would survive--it's a trilogy. I turned on the ceiling fan and headed to the living room where there was a nice thick comforter and couch just waiting for me.Wrapped up in the comforter, I prepared to finish the book. I liked the way Collins gradually brought about Katniss' political awakening. Using Rue was a particularly smart move that helped it feel organic with character and story. No zombies--I don't think, although that appears to be a question for another time. I certainly understand complaints about the nature of the games and how Collins wrote herself a number of very easy ways out of a truly ethically ambiguous situation, and I confess that goes against my story preference. I find myself agreeing with Jocelyn's emphasis on the story as a fairy tale. Still, in that context, it was enjoyable and well-paced, if not riveting. And, after all, I was finally warm, snug in the feather comforter with only hands and head exposed. Three and a half warm stars.Cross posted at http://clsiewert.wordpress.com/2013/0...*Edit thoughtfully provide by Richard.

I don't really know what I should say. Should I agree with all the sheep in my generation and say that The Hunger Games is "a beautiful, dark world and a vision of a realistic dystopian future and a wonderful teen series", or should I tell the truth?Well, I can't repeat all the swearing I have racing through my mind when I think back to what I read, but I can say it absolutely sucked. It was depressing, not in a way that makes you intellectually stimulated and thinking about the world around you, but depressing in that somewhere some lady is filthy-rich off of a book series that is boring, overrated and unoriginal. Reading about the main characters was like reading a really sloppy, bad anime with nothing original, all flash and no substance. The main character is annoying, I pictured her as being incredibly ugly too from the given descriptions of her, and she's clad with a dorky bow-and-arrow with a goofy braid in her hair. Nothing makes the characters stand out at all, they're flat, boring and have nothing you can enjoy or sympathize with. Katniss herself is lazy, boring, superficial and self-absorbed.I don't really care about the amount of violence; I've read and watched so much worse and if the author was trying to make some sort of point by just having death as a quick, straightforward solution to all problems, well that's just disturbing and I wonder why she wasn't questioned about that.I HATE THE NAME KATNISS! I don't know why, it's just childish and grating to think about, it's like a word a two-year-old makes up.I don't understand why people think this series is so wonderful, if it was trying to raise a point about society it didn't do a very good job. I'm going to leave now and try and get my mental coherence back by reading books that are actually good. The Ice Storm by Rick Moody and 1984 by George Orwell, I'll start with those and hope I can forget reading The Hunger Games forever.

  Book Review:Even my eyes are just too heavy and I really wanted to sleep, I can't resist myself to read the book from start to finish just so I can know how it end. Entertaining and thrilling, I cannot put it down!I guess the not so good thing about it is that it's like a rip-off from battle royale. Though I think the love story in it is much better, the love triangle between Katniss, Peeta and Gale. Its like I'm torn like Katniss to whom I love more Peeta or Gale. The games (chapter 2) is my favorite. The fight for survival, not only that the other tributes are your enemy, but it also you against the hunger, thirst, the game makers and vicious creatures. How Katniss survives because of her hunting abilities and that Rue allied with her. It's detailed, the herbs, the hunting for food, the weapons and that's make it more realistic for me. It also has plot twists that I never see coming. It has drama, action, romance and comedy so I think it will appeal to a lot of readers out there. It also has a depth in it because it's a story about human versus society. PS:Hey I have written a fan-fic and you've got to read it: Peeta Mellark in Real Life

About three years ago I brought this book on a cruise that my husband and I took for our anniversary. He chuckled at my characteristic inability to stop reading for the whole trip, and when I started gushing about this book (which I couldn’t even put down long enough to snarf one of those melty chocolate lava cakes that they have) he was all, “blah blah, it sounds weird, whatever.”Let me just explain that my husband loves to read nonfiction of the science and political sort primarily, with the occasional nerdy sci-fi or fantasy thrown in. His books have titles that reflect the degree to which various people believe this Earth is going to hell in a hand basket. I completely agree with this, but I don’t particularly like reading about it because I get too depressed. I think that he assumed this book would be too young or too fluffy, and he had no intention of ever picking it up.However, I had a plan.Two and half years ago I recommended this book to his brother, who promptly read it and then consumed the following books as they were released.Two years ago his sister, following his brother’s lead, picked up these books and became just as hooked.One year ago, when Mockingjay came out, I had a few gushing type conversations about this series within my husband’s audible range.Six months ago, both his brother and his sister asked for hardback copies of this series for Christmas, and as the family’s drug book dealer I had to be the one to get them.About two weeks ago, he picked this book out of my bookshelf and casually mentioned that he might give it a go.Yesterday at around 1:00 PM he picked it up.At 7:00 PM, he said (out loud, which is highly uncharacteristic), “god, that’s depressing.”At 10:00 PM I remarked that he had been reading for quite some time and that he might even finish it today. To which he replied, “Oh…no, I can’t read that fast. I have other things that I want to do tonight.”At 11:30 PM I went to bed, leaving him on the couch, still reading.At 1:30 AM We were both awakened for a middle of the night potty break with our three year old. When I got back in bed, he says, all casually, “Yeah, so…I finished that book.”“And?”“Mmmm…it was okay.”“…”“So…uh…do you have the next one?”GOT YOU TOM!! Welcome to the world of crack literature!Perfect Musical PairingMetric – Stadium LoveBesides giving me an opportunity to passive aggressively crow about my triumph, I wanted to write this review because this song came up on my ipod the other day and I realized that it is the perfect match for this book!

I can't wait to read Catching Fire and Mockingjay! Thankfully I only have to wait 10 days for Mockingjay to be released. Oh I nearly forgot, definitely TEAM PEETA!!!!
