Note, September 5, 2015 --I edited this review just now to correct two misspelled words.For me, the extremely dark premise of this novel, as set out in the Goodreads description above, was a deterrent to reading it. While I'm a fan of brave heroines who can physically fight the forces of (adult) evil, the dynamic is different when the heroine we're asked to root for is thrown into an arena with 23 other 12-18 year old kids and told that only one can come out alive, all for the entertainment of adult sickos, and for the intimidation of their home districts. It's to Collins' credit as an author that she takes this premise and molds it into a tale that's profoundly morally conscious, and testifies to the strength of the human spirit and humane feelings. The book definitely does not pander to the tastes of the kind of people who would relish seeing (or visualizing) teens and pre-teens forced to kill each other. It does bring us face-to-face with gut-wrenching ethical questions. Would YOU volunteer to put yourself into that arena, to save a sibling? How far would you go to keep yourself alive in that setting? How far should you go? Would you take the lives of other innocents, who didn't want to be there any more than you do --but who will also be viewing you as someone who has to die if they're going to live? (Granted, not all these kids are so innocent --the Career tributes tend to be volunteers who like the idea of killing to win a life of wealth and ease; they're sadistic sociopaths now, who'd likely grow up to be adult sadistic sociopaths. But they're still kids at the moment, realistically shaped by a very brutal society.) Would you kill someone you genuinely like, who's not trying to hurt you? Would you kill someone who loves you? Someone YOU love? Could you accept your own death voluntarily, or even commit suicide? These questions aren't academic for Katniss, and fellow District 12 tribute Peeta. The thing that changes this book from the total downer it could have been to one that's in a real way uplifting is the fact that Collins' main characters, and some others, don't check their sense of decency and their humanity at the arena entrance; they try to retain both, and manage to display both, as a light against the pitch black darkness of the situation. "I don't want them to change me in there," Peeta says at one point. "Turn me into some kind of monster that I'm not." At a fundamental level, this is a book about not becoming a monster, in the face of a social order that's out to make you one.That social order is another major theme of the book. We're looking here at a future America where the government is a completely self-serving law unto itself, which has subjects (not citizens) with, as far as it's concerned, no intrinsic rights, and which has no regard at all for human life as such; a society where inequalities of wealth and power are maintained by the vicious use of unrestrained force, and where the enormous resources of society are wasted on frivolous and even harmful projects while the working populace lacks basic medical care and is stalked by starvation. It's an America where dissent is criminalized and intimidated into silence, where the economic order is a dead-end of peonage and servitude for all but a few, with no hope of advancement, and where real human beings are simply grist for an entertainment industry that's all about manipulation and exploitation, without any concern for the human cost. An argument has been made to the effect that this novel isn't a true dystopian novel like 1984 or Brave New World because the people of Panem aren't that badly off (though I suspect they'd dispute that!), and because Collins supposedly doesn't clearly articulate what present-day trends she sees as setting the stage for this future. I would submit that every tendency described above is already present in our time in germinal form. If Collins doesn't explicitly articulate how pre-apocalyptic America --where the ultimate expression of these trends is restrained by (waning) morality, a vestigial Constitution and somewhat contested elections, even if they're manipulated-- devolves into her post-apocalyptic America where all restraints are removed, maybe it's because she prefers to let us connect the dots.For the type of plot and premise we have here, this isn't as grisly and gory as it could be; Collins shows us the ugliness and viciousness of the Games and their human cost, but she shows restraint in direct description, so that this doesn't become the "pornography of violence" the Capitol residents (and some of their present-day counterparts) revel in. There's no bad language or unwholesome sexual content. The writing is compulsively readable, a page-turner with no dull moments, and the situation and events make it one of the most evocative reads I've ever experienced --painful, harrowing, terrible and beautiful. Collins chooses to write through Katniss' eyes, in first-person present; this puts us right inside the protagonist's head and gives the narrative an immediacy that grabs you by the throat. To my surprise, it didn't feel gimmicky or awkward at all, but flowed like a stream --or, more accuately, a whitewater torrent!-- from the opening sentence. Katniss and Peeta are wonderfully realized characters, whom I found wholly believable, liked, admired and rooted for from the get-go.In the view of some of my Goodreads friends who've read the whole trilogy, the third book really pulls the entire series down, and ruins the portrait of Katniss that Collins constructed earlier. But be that as it may, this first book is, by itself, a powerful and compelling read that I would highly recommend.

I cracked and finally picked this up. Very enjoyable quick read - couldn't put it down - it was like crack. I'm a bit bothered by the lack of backstory of how Panem and the Hunger Games come about. It is just kind of explained away in a few paragraphs and we are left to accept this very strange world where teenagers are pitted into an arena each year to kill each other? I was expecting it because I've seen Battle Royale, but I would have appreciated knowing more of the backstory of how the world could have come into such a odd state.I suppose what makes a book like this interesting is thinking about the strategy of it all. The players are going to be statistically encouraged to band together because they will last longer that way, but by definition of course any partnership will be broken, and the drama of how that unfolds is always interesting and full of friendships broken and betrayal. Each character approached the game in their own way. Some banded together in larger coalitions, some were loners initially and banded together later. And some were just loners, like Foxface. A lot depended on your survival skill: could you find food and water on your own? Self-dependence is highly valued - and of course our hero was strong there.All in all, a fun read, but I feel kind of dirty for having read it.

This is not easy. The book was so useless and poorly written it nearly broke my heart to think that this mediocrity is so popular. Well, let's do this:The decision to tell this book in both first person and the present tense is a gimmick to pull the gullible into a limping narrative that could not work in the past tense. This shoves the reader into a narrow, if not tiresome, pov that dispenses with what the rest of us call prose and employs rather a line by line in-progress description of events that never show us anything. We are told this boring story with little regard for environment, coloration, or even useful description that might be used to draw even the slightly intellectual reader into this lame excuse for a narrative. Oh, I know. The defenders will say, "it's just a kids book. Don't you have an imagination?"I do. A big honken one. But there is some onus on the writer to make an effort at the suspension of my disbelief. I thought the Potter books were fantastic and well written. If you enjoyed this book, good for you. But let's not pretend that it is anything more than a Nickelodeon script writers lame attempt at real art. As art goes, it's a big FAIL. Can you imagine the list of greats like this:Tolkien, Zelazny, Rowling, Wolfe, Asimov...Collins?Probably not. If you insist on reading this book anyway, turn your brain off. It's the only way you're going to enjoy this edition of Crapsterpiece Theatre.

I haven't been so shocked since I read Ishiguro's Never Let Me Go. This is such a provocative, intriguing, beguiling, addictive, unique book that you simply can't put out of your mind after finishing it; It is going to haunt you for weeks, even months to come. Many great reviews have been written for it, so I'm not gonna try to add anything more. I just want to thank my fellow GR friends for bringing this book into my notice -in the romance forums none the less!- because I'd never have bought it based on the synopsis alone. And surprisingly, there is some romance in this one along with a sweet, caring, tender, self-sacrifising, selfless young hero who unfortunately is only one part of a love triangle. The fact that not one of my GR friends, has rated it with less than 4 stars is what convinced me to try this out and I'm SO glad I did! Holy cow, I think I need this day to cool off and think about what I read. I'm way too moved and stunned to start another book right now:)PS: I bought this as an audiobook and I highly recommend it; the narrator did a fantastic job with it.

JKHSAKDHADKSJHASDKJHDASKJADSHKJDAS I am dying of laughter! I love looking back at my English, I excelled in the grammar. (I also committed the sin of watching catching fire before the hunger games, and know perhaps thinking a love interest was not necessary)LOVE.....LOVE....LOVE This book, is just so amazing, this dystopian book have everything action, love, fiction... I am expecting that the other books of the trilogy are more better than this.I like Katniss character so much, I think she is very similar to me. And I just can say that I LOVE PEETA... he is so cute, and he is very lovely.Highly recommend this trilogy is perfect even you had seen the movie... I think read the books is better. <3
By now if you haven't already read the Hunger Games, seen the movies or even know what this is about, GO DO IT ALL! READ THE BOOKS, WATCH THE MOVIES and then come back so we can discuss it together.
Coming back to this book always feels like coming back home. It reminds me why I love reading so much, how this story was the spark. All the stars to my favorite book❤️

Ανέκαθεν ήθελα πολύ να κάνω μια κριτική στο αγαπημένο μου βιβλίο όμως είχε περάσει καιρός και είχα ξεχάσει πολλές λεπτομέρειες.Τώρα λοιπόν που το ξαναδιάβασα είμαι έτοιμη να γράψω γι’αυτό αν και δεν ξέρω πόσο αντικειμενική θα είμαι αφού το υπεραγαπώ αυτό το βιβλίο αλλά νομίζω πως όλοι όσοι το έχουν διαβάσει το λατρεύουν εξίσου.Η ιστορία και η υπόθεση των αγώνων πείνας είναι μια από τις πιο αυθεντικές και πρωτότυπες που έχω διαβάσει.Η Susanne Collins είχε πραγματικά μια φανταστική ιδέα αλλά την εξέλιξε με τόσο ωραίο τρόπο που απλά απογείωσε το συγκεκριμένο βιβλίο.Δεν χριεάζεται πραγματικά να πω τίποτε παραπάνω για το πόσο καταπληκτική συγγραφέας είναι ελπίζω και εύχομαι απλά στο μέλλον να ξαναγράψει κάτι!Ειλικρινά τι μπορώ να πω για τους ήρωες του βιβλίου;Πραγματικά είναι όπως το είπα είναι ήρωες.Η Κάτνις είναι η αγαπημένη μου ηρωίδα όλων των εποχών και δύσκολα να με εντυπωσιάσει περισσότερο κάποια άλλη.Είναι πραγματικά τόσο γενναία και έξυπνη, σκλήρη εκεί που πρέπει αλλά και γεμάτη αφοσίωση και αγάπη για την περιοχή της και την οικογένεια της.Είναι υπέροχο πόσο μαγευτική φαίνεται και συνάμα ανθρώπινη κάποια με την οποία μπορείς να ταυτιστείς παρόλο που δεν ζεις την ζοφερή πραγματικότητα της.Ο Πίτα είναι εξίσου υπέροχος ευγενικός και καλόκαρδος μα ταυτόχρονα γενναίος δεν θα μπορούσα κάποιον άλλο αντάξιο της Κάτνις ακόμη και αν ο Γκέιλ ήταν εξίσου πολύ κοντά της.Όσο για τους τους υπόλοιπους τι να πω;Για την γλυκιά Πριμρόουζ,για τον σκληρό μα ειλικιρνή Χέιμιτς,για την Έφι και τα φανταχτερά Ρούχα της,για τον στοργικό Σίννα,για τον ειρωνικό Φίνικ και για όλους τους άλλους;Δεν χριεάζεται πραγματικά να πω τίποτε παραπάνω είναι όλοι απλά καταπληκτικοί.Αναρωτιέμαι πολλές φορές γιατί αυτό είναι το αγαπημένο μου βιβλίο, γιατί ανάμεσα σε τόσο πολλά βιβλία που έχω διαβάσει αυτό είναι που με εντυπωσίασε περισσότερο.Πέρα από την φοβερή ιστορία και πλοκή νομίζω πως ο λόγος για τον οποίο αυτό το βιβλίο μου άρεσε τόσο είναι τα μηνύματα που περνάει.Πως ακόμα και στις πιο δύσκολες στιγμές οι άνθρωποι δεν πρέπει να χάνουμε την ανθρωπιά μας, πως η δύναμη και η γενναιότητα είναι στη ψυχή και όχι στο σώμα όπως επίσης και τα μηνύματα που περνάει για την αξία της οικογένειας, της ελευθερίας και της ισότητας.Για μένα δεν είναι απλά ένα ακόμη δυστοπικό μυθιστόρημα για εφήβους αλλά ένα βιβλίο που θα πρέπει να το διαβάσουν όλοι και να προβληματιστούν πάνω σε αυτά που θέλει να πει.Δεν θα το έλεγα εύκολα για άλλο βιβλίο αλλά είμαι σίγουρη ότι οι αγώνες πείνας θα μείνουν στην ιστορία και πολλά χρόνια μετά θα θεωρείται ένα κλασσικό διαχρονικό μυθιστόρημα και θα βρίσκεται στις πρώτες θέσεις σε όλες τις λίστες με σημαντικά βιβλία όπως άλλωστε και τώρα!Ελπίζω στο μέλλον να καταφέρω να το διαβάσω αμέτρητες φορές και να νιώσω ξανά και ξανά εκείνα τα πρώτα συναισθήματα την πρώτη φορά που διάβαζα την τελευταία σελίδα του.Αυτό το βιβλίο με άλλαξε και με επηρέασε με τον πιο μοναδικό και ξεχωριστό τρόπο!

Began to read this on Friday evening after 'mastermind' at 830pm and before the great comedy that is 'twentytwelve' at 10pm. It shows how much I got into it that I almost opted to not turn the tv on again at 10pm. Praise indeed Ms Collins. This has a simple storyline. Twelve divisions of a post apocalyptic country, defeated decades before in an attempt at revolution, are punished annually by a tribute. This monstrosity is to provide two children between the ages of 12 and 18, male and female, to fight it out in a battle to the death where only one of the 24 survives. This spectacle serves to remind the 12 oppressed states that they are under the rule of the 'Capitol', the ruling power. Our heroine takes the place of her beloved sister and ends up accompanying into this horror a young lad of her own age of whom she knows nothing except she begins to realize that he has flitted in the background of her life in a number of unobtrusive ways. Questions of trust, of truth, of fidelity to self and of preparadness to sacrifice fly back and forth. What is it to be real, to be genuine ? Is it more important to survive at all costs no matter what you give up to do so, or is the real you unalloyed goodness.This is not great literature in the sense that my great grandchildren, were I against all odds to gain some, are highly unlikely to be reading this but Collins has created a world which is horrendously believeable. A callous disregard for justice and compassion, a situation in which ratings and the visual are far more important than the twisted logic or vicious cruelty which went into their construction, a superficiality which can enable moodswings because of a pretty face or a heartstring tugging storyline..........sound familiar ? Collins has cleverly shone a light on stardom and celebrity and puerile shows in which the eating of a kangaroo's bollocks are seen as high drama and taken it far beyond what even those shows would envisage but she has left enough of the gaudy tackiness draped in soiled, tattered embarrassment to make her point.I found the story totally enthralling. Unusually for me I did not retch at the insertion of the inevitable 'love interest' purely because in Collins' story it was not inevitable. It was not the ridiculously badly written love at first sight crap ....yes Pittacus Lore, you know who you are....that is sometimes inflicted upon the unwary traveller. The two main characters were people you felt for and were rooting for. Collins managed to move me over the death of totally minor characters and the expressions of loving support that came each time Katniss showed her humanity and her kindness was genuinely startling.Does anymore need to be said. Enthralling, exciting and very 'page-turnery'

I won't bother to summarise plot and characters since The Hunger Games and its sequels are so high profile. After many recommendations from friends I trust, I bought the first book and read it in a couple of days. The concept of deadly competitive games in a dystopic society is not new, but Collins gives it a new spin, making comment on the society we live in where 'reality' television is devoured by couch potato viewers with little sense of what is real and what is orchestrated for the cameras. Some people have criticised the level of violence in the story but it's well-handled and never gratuitous. Without it we wouldn't get a true idea of the horrific scenario in which Katniss and Peeta find themselves. As a writer, I found much to admire in Collins' mastery of pace and tension in this story, and her ability to inject humour into very dark situations. I found Katniss a strong and interesting protagonist, but was not entirely convinced by her blindness to Peeta's true feelings (or her own feelings, for that matter.) I did enjoy The Hunger Games very much, but having peeked at the synopses of books two and three, I am not completely convinced that I will find them as satisfying. I hope Collins manages to keep the arbitrary changes of Games rules convincing. Will review again when I've read the second book.

Impressive. Often these types of stories fall into cliche, but the concept of revolution against an oppressive power starting within a system designed to maintain control is ingenious.I just watched Maze Runner (have not read the book) and was not impressed. Nor with Divergent. But this book, and the first movie, touched on deeper subjects.I think any totalitarian regime eventually fails. And government that has an elite with most of the resources has a built in failure. Because people are equal. I've heard that the concept of the games themselves was done in another book from Japan-- possible, but also, as a writer, I know every idea has been done. Not every story. The two are not the same. My wife and I, who write together, came up with the idea for Burners quite a while ago. The same basic concept of a regime tilted toward one small group, ruling over the masses. It could be with money, a system we see in our country now with most of the wealth clustered in less than 1% or, as we speculate in burners, in time-- what is worse than an inequality in lifespan?The very title of this book-- Hunger Games-- indicates that when one takes from another, you leave them hungry-- whether for food, freedom, or simply time.
I can't get this book out of my head; it is phenomenal.

Second time reading this. Summary: Catnis everdeen lives in a world divided into 12 districts. Once a year, in a dystopian future, an oppressive, ruling district randomly picks 2 kids, ages 12-18 from each district to compete in the Hunger Games, which is a battle to the death. 24 kids start, one survives and his/her district receives additional rations for a year. This year, Catnis's 12 year old sister is chosen who would surely be killed. Catnis volunteers to take her place and we fall in love with her. The boy chosen, Peta, has been secretly in love with her for years. Only one of the two of them can survive. No matter how Peta figures it, his relationship with Catnis must perish.Good: Collins sets up an interesting and convincing world of brutal oppression. Catnis is a great character and all of the people in the story are interesting. It's first person POV and we really do find Catnis likeable. It's hard to imagine a novel of teens killing one another to be palatable. This in itself is a major achievement. There are, of course, the villians (the oppressors) and the favored contestants (from districts 1 and 2), which makes Catnis an underdog. We like underdogs. We also like Catnis's skill at archery. Collins does a great job pitting Catnis and Peta against one another in a fight to the death in spite of the fact that Peta has loved her since he was very young. The people who live as aristocrats in "the capitol" come off as likeable, if affected, because they empathize with and try their best to support Catnis and Peta in this game to the death.A lot of the killings are inventive and Catnis is properly challenged beyond her abilities and is a winner. The plot moves well and the ending feels earned. This novel is a story of survival and Collins maintains that tension throughout. The intertwined love story is uncomplicated but interesting.Not as good: We don't see much soul searching on the page. The love story and issue of surviving is emotionally captivating. But a little more depth in Catnis would have put the cherry on top.Bottom line: You've probably already seen the movie. The novel is better than the movie although the movie is very faithful to the novel. I reread this novel to read a woman's first person POV for the purposes of the writing I'm doing. What surprised me is how well the novel holds up on second reading and after seeing the movie. So, it's a thumb's up!

The Hunger Games was much different of a book then I expected.I was told it was about kids killing each other. As much as that's what it centers around, that is not the purpose of the book.I respect this book, a lot even. I feel bad that I didn't give it a chance until I decided to read it. I brushed it off as if it was just another mainstream book, and expected it to be full of things I didn't want to read.But it wasn't, and I am so glad. No swearing, and no inappropriate scenes. It was clean.I have to say, as more and more popular the dystopian genre is becoming, this is quite a unique book.I didn't find it overly gory or disgusting, really, because come on, this is a book with lots of deaths and I expected it to be heavily described. I was prepared for that, though it didn't end up being that way very much. Some of the TV shows I watch are much more violent than this is, really.And like I said, as much as death is a central characteristic, the books aren't about the killing.Murder is NEVER portrayed as right. Neither Katniss nor Peeta ever want to kill anyone. Katniss is a girl with high morals. She's self-sacrificing. For goodness sake, she took her sister's place in The Games, and was absolutely ready to die for her. She sees the evil of the Capitol and hates it. She's modest and has a pure heart, and puts her family first before anything or anyone else.And although she doesn't love Peeta romantically in this book, he earns her begrudging respect. She learns what his love for her looks like, and doesn't intentionally take advantage of that - she grows to love him as a friend.I enjoyed this book because it blew my expectations away. I didn't know this before I started it, but THG is not about the killing. It's about doing what's right even if you could die for it. It's about making the most of what you've been given, and never giving up even when it's difficult.The writing was unique. Collins uses a lot of fragments in her writing, but it works. It's down-to-earth, and not stiff at all.I don't understand why people say that Katniss is cold. She cares deeply about her mother and her sister Prim. She cares about Gale and about Peeta, and Cinna, and Haymitch and Effie too. She's scared, yeah. But not for herself. She's scared for everyone that she would leave behind when she doesn't come back. But of course, she does come back. And they need her. It's not a Christian book, but it's still a good book. A book that I respect and will definitely read again.

Still one of the best books I've ever read. Incredibly gripping and absolutely epic even this third or fourth time around. ❤️

So I know this is totally not an ACTUAL review (so don't get your panties in a twist) - and I read this book a loooooong time ago - but I saw this picture today:"Hunger Games: Cat Version."And I thought I would share the LOLZ...because FUNNY.
Just finished this a third time in preparation for the midnight premiere. I love it so much.

This is a YA. This is a YA. This is a YA...While reading this book, I was repeating that as a mantra to remind me that I have to be shallow (mababaw) so that my P759 (courtesy of my 13th month pay) would not go to waste. This book was recommended by a couple of a Filipino teens in our blog here in Goodreads as January's Book of the Month. I also heard 89.9 Magic's Mo Twister raving about this in his morning program as his book-for-the-holiday break. As I always listen to him in my way to the office in the morning, I did not want to be left out so what the hell, why not buy and read this book.It is a gripping and a edge-of-the-seat futuristic escapist novel. It rides in the current wave of reality shows. Think of the Survivor but the participants are teenagers (12 to 18 boys and girls) killing each other in the wilderness - forest, in the book's batch. That fighting in the forest readily reminded me of another fiction - historical, this time - that I read last year: Ken Follett's THE PILLARS OF THE EARTH (1996) and I liked it. It reminds me of our vacations in the barrio where we lived by eating the fruits and vegetables straight from our farm and we had no electricity so we either read books while the sun was still up late in the afternoon or play cards using a homemade kerosene lamp. Cool.Anyway, there's a handful reasons why this is not getting a five star: First, is the unbelievable plot. For example, Thresh letting go of Katriss. Collins made a good excuse by saying about "owing" and that Thresh, if he wins, will have to go back to District 11 and explain about killing Katriss at that point. He would be killing her later anyway, so what is the point? Second, is the corny beauty pageant show complete with floats, interview portion and makeup. Third, is the cheesy love story. It reminds me of the tiring Twilight love triangle. Fourth, is the fact that the Hunger Games is a sick reality TV show viewed by the whole country. What I cannot understand is how come the country (most of the districts cannot afford to feed their citizens) is so poor but the Capitol can afford to provide high tech TV screen that can be viewed even inside a cave and monitors even when Peeta was deep in the mud or when Rue was right on top of a tree? Lastly, the man and boys in the novel are morons and wimpy while the girls (Katriss, Rue, Foxface) all rock! Is this because the author is a woman and most reading population (according to statistics)are women?Anyway, enough of what I hate about the book. For entertainment value (I finished reading the book in 2 days even working 8 hours each in the office) it gave me, I already bought the 2nd book - CATCHING FIRE (o, savings will have to wait) and I will be reading this in the next few weeks. I cannot wait to find what happens next to Katriss and who she will be ending up with - Gale or Peeta. LOL.

Next to Twilight, The Hunger Games was the book that introduced me to the addictive world of YA literature. I loved it so much that I wrote about it in my undergraduate thesis. Looking back at all the dystopian YA books I have read so far, it's probably justifiable to say that The Hunger Games is an outstanding piece of literature.In my thesis, I utilized theories of Feminism to illustrate how Katniss is one of the most empowered females in dystopian YA. Compared to other girls like Tris Prior, Mare Barrows, or America Singer, Katniss is the perfect epitome of female empowerment. She does not care about her looks, she can overthrow powerful dictators, and she doesn't need a man to protect her or make her happy. Yes, she has a romantic connection with Peeta, but I believe that she would still be okay without him. Come to think of it, it's Peeta who needs Katniss. The dependence isn't actually mutual. In totality, Katniss will always be one of my favorite YA heroines in light of her political, romantic, and personal empowerment.The Hunger Games is also the work that perpetuated various dystopian YA elements, such as perpetual camera surveillance, class/caste divisions, and as deadly competitions rigged by the bourgeoisie. I've encountered "Hunger Games Tropes" in popular series like Throne of Glass, Red Rising, and more. I am often annoyed by this lack of originality in books nowadays, but as other people say, "Imitation is the sincerest form of flattery."Overall, The Hunger Games holds a special place in my heart. It taught me the basics of what constitutes a dystopian novel, and it also set the standards for empowered YA heroines. In this regard, I wouldn't hesitate to call it a modern classic.

So I read this in October, but I just wanted to get a review out before the movie gets released. Clearly there is nothing new to be said about this book that hasn't been said, but I don't need to express myself in words. This is what I thought of it:Plenty of people, particularly people closer to my age, in their twenties, don't care for this book, or say the one person POV is limiting, or they hate the addition of romance, or they hate the lack of romance, or etc etc, you've heard it all.I was not one of those people. Before this book, I was kind of sporadically reading books, a sort of rare occasion thing, and at the most I could do about 20 pages a night, but that was a stretch. But then I started reading this, and every single chapter left off with a reason to go on to the next one, and I found myself staying up til 2 in the morning with this book even though I had to be up by 7, and I just could not get over how entertained and on edge I was. And yes, I had been a long time fan of Battle Royale already, but this still felt like something fresh and special, more intimate. Ah well anyway. Just simply my sappy diatribe to explain that this is the book that made me want to READ books again. And I have not stopped my reading momentum since. Huzzah, huzzah, and huzzah to you, Katniss Everdeen.

“Happy Hunger Games! And may the odds be ever in your favor.”
I'm sure you don't need me saying it- this is more of a confirmation for myself really- but believe the hype.The Hunger Games has:• A badass and smart protagonist who stays true to her character through her awful situation• A plot that keeps you on the edge of your seat and reflects on many things wrong in our society and what could happen if we ever became a whole lot more monstrous.• A realistic survival story (except seriously when did these characters ever pee?)• A sweet male love interest. This could have easily blown up in the author's face- since a lot of writers when creating a nice-guy type of love interest often make his only attribute to be- well nice. They are not so much complex characters as a personality trait personified. This wasn't the case with Peeta. He had an edge that seperated him from the norm of failed cases.• Great characterisation of main and side characters- never making one into a monster. • A lot of backstory provided by Katniss that was definitely needed and appreciated.•All of the food. Eat Read this with a snack. You'll get hungry.As one of the latest people to read this- I declare it a winning dystopian novel. 
  “Yes, frosting. The final defense of the dying.”

خب بعد از مدت ها یک کتاب خیلی قشنگ خوندم . " عطش مبارزه " از خیلی لحاظ کتاب فوق العاده ای هست . چه از نظر داستان و ایده داستان که خیلی نو هست و مشابه قبلی نداره ، چه از نظر نویسندگی که خیلی متبحرانه نوشته شده و چه از نظر روند سریع داستان که خیلی خوبه . جلد اول داستان مبارزه کتنیس در مسابقات عطش مبارزه و به نوعی مبارزه با کاپیتول هست .حتی به نوعی مبارزه کتنیس با احساسات متضاد درونی خودش هست . یک نکته خوب داستان روند سریع داستانه . داستان خیلی خوب و یکنواخت پیش میره.میشه گفت هیچ وقت از خوندن داستان خسته نمیشین . یک نکته جالب اینه که فصل بندی ها با دقت انتخاب شده . یعنی نویسنده جوری فصل ها رو انتخاب کرده که وقتی به پایان یک فصل میرسید یک اتفاق غیرمنتظره میفته و شما به گونه ای مجبور به ادامه داستان میشید !نکته موفق دیگه همون قضیه عشقی کتنیس با پیتا و گیل هست . برخلاف خیلی از داستان های دیگه ، کتنیس دوتا رقیب عشقی داره . شاید هم سه تا . سومین رقیبش خودشه . یعنی خودش واقفعا نمیدونه پیتا رو بیشتر دوست داره یا گیل رو . و به خصوص که کتنیس حتی نمیخواد هیچ وقت ازدواج کنه .اما ایده داستان فوق العاده هست . جنگ بین 24 نفر و هیجانی که توی داستان هست هر خواننده ای رو میخکوب می کنه .غم انگیز ترین قسمت داستان مرگ " روو " بود . و میتونم بگم شخصیت محجبوب من توی کتاب اول هم بود . اتفاقات غیر قابل پیش بینی داستان بسیار زیاد بود . شاید خیلی زیاد درباره این کتاب نوشتم . همه این ها رو میشد در یک کلمه خلاصه کرد : فوق العاده بود !

Αυτό το βιβλίο μου άρεσε πάρα πολύ, αλλά δεν με σόκαρε ευχάριστα όπως περίμενα, γιατί έχω διαβάσει πολλά του είδους του. Είναι άδικο όμως να το συγκρίνω με τα περισσότερα από αυτά, επειδή για τα περισσότερα από αυτά το «αγώνες πείνας» στάθηκε η βάση της δημιουργίας τους. Αυτό που μου έκανε εντύπωση στους αγώνες είναι η αφήγηση, διότι ενώ προτιμώ τα βιβλία δράσης να παρουσιάζονται από διάφορες οπτικές γωνίες ή από έναν παντογνώστη αφηγητή (για να μπορώ να βλέπω και να μαθαίνω τα πάντα :P ) εδώ ο μοναδικός αφηγητής είναι η Κάτνις και τα πάντα παρουσιάζονται μόνο μέσα από την οπτική της γωνία. Αυτό μου στέρησε πολλές δυνατότητες, και είχα πολλές ερωτήσεις όπως για το τι να συμβαίνει σε διάφορες φάσεις σε άλλες περιοχές ή σε άλλους ήρωες. Ταυτόχρονα όμως η συγγραφέας με αυτή την αφήγηση πέτυχε κάτι που μόνο ένας καλός συγγραφέας μπορεί. Ήταν τόσο μα τόσο καλογραμμένο, τόσο πρώτης τάξεως κείμενο που όσο το διάβαζα κόντεψα να γίνω η Κάτνις, τι έβλεπε, τι άκουγε, τι έτρωγε όλα με αφορούσαν, τίποτα δεν ήταν περιττό, συνέπασχα μαζί της. Μου άρεσε πάρα πολύ, δεν είναι ένα ακόμα, απλό δυστοπικό βιβλίο, αλλά ένα πολύ καλό λογοτεχνικό κείμενο, το χάρηκα.

I used to find Peeta flat and boorish. But after my second reread, I find myself FLAILING around my room with the name 'Peeta Mellark' stamped across my heart. Sweet Mother of Panem, how had I NOT fall for this sweet, self-sacrificing guy?Someone should slap the 2014-me with a wet fish.
Wow. Quit reading this review and go read this book. For reals.

games أو العاب الجوع. قرأت نسختها الإنجليزية إيمانا مني إن الأفكار بتكون أدق لو تم التعبير عنها بلغة كاتبها الأصلية و ده نتيجة تجارب سيئة مع ترجمات بعض روايات لستيفن كينج و ترجمة سلسلة توايلايت لستيفاني مايرز. و ده يمكن مش عيب مترجم قد ما هو مشكلة في نقل روح و تعبيرات الكاتب بشكل كويس.استثني من المترجمين طبعا أستاذي دكتور أحمد خالد توفيق و أستاذ هشام فهمي.نرجع لالعاب الجوع و أحب ابتدي بالغلاف. بحب جدا و أنا بقرأ إني كل ما أتعمق في الرواية أرجع أبص على الغلاف دتاني و اشوف فيه حاجات مكنتش شايفاها. طائر المحكي او mokingJay و هو طائر مصنوع أصلا في الكابيتول أو عاصمة دولة بانم الأسطورية ذات الطابع الروماني. طائر عملوه علشان يتجسس على سكان المقاطعات الغلابة في ثورتهم الأولى و كانت النتيجة أن الناس كشفته و غستغلتع بشكل بسيط إنه ينقل معلومات غلط.بالتدريج بقا طائر المحاكي هو رمز لشعب بانم المقهور في المقاطعات الإتناشر و كان في صورة غلاف الجزء الأول محكوم جوه دائرة و شايل سهم في منقاره لكنه مكسور و حبيس. في غلاف الجزء الثاني إتحرك فعليا و فرد جانحاته برع الحلقة الي كان محبوس فيها ووراه الحلقة المتقسمة 12 جزء. بالنسبة لحاكم بانم السيد سنو هي 12 ساعة ل 12 خدعة بيواجهها المتسابقين في ساجة القتتال،لكن بالنسبة للشعب، هم 12 مقاطعة متقسمة تبعا لنظرية فرق تسُد. في غلاف الجزء الثالث الطائر تحرر تماما و بعد عن الحلقة و الي مش باينه في الغلاف.الفكرة بشكل عام مستلهمة من مصارعة العبيد الرومانية، الأسياد بيشتروا عبيد يسلوهم في حلقة المصارعة و الأسياد هم الي بيحددوا مين الي يموت و مين الي يعيش بناءا على أداؤه أو رغبتهم الشخصية في رؤية المزيد من الدم. و الجانب الآخر طبعا من المصارعات دي هو إثارة الذعر في نفس كل واحد تسوله نفسه يتمرد أو يعترض.لكن لعبة بانم في معاقبة الثوار كانت ابشع من مجرد مصارعة عبيد. الموضوع بقا عقاب أبدي عبثي لناس فكروا يعملوا ثورة من 74 سنة! الموضوع بقا عداوة بتتبني يوةم بعد يوم و ثأر ما بيخلصش بين أبناء المقاطعات دي و بعض..كرههم لبعض هايخليهم عمرهم ما هايتوحدوا تاني ضد حاكمهم.شخصية كاتنيس افردين، مقدرتش أبطل مقارنة بينها و بين شخصية بيللا في سلسلة توايلايت. رغم إختلاف القصة بشكل كبير إلا أن كاتنيس المفروض إنها مبنيه على هيكل مشابه لهيكل شخصية بيللا، واقعة بين حب شابين واحد بتحخبه وواحد بيحبها. إلا إن شخصية كاتنيس تكسب! رغم برود الشخصيتين و إنهم عاجزين عن تكوين صداقات و طابع " الدهولة" لحد كبير إلا أن كاتنيس شخصيتها مبنية على أسس نفسية صحيحة خليتني أقتنع بدوافعها و رغباتها. اللي حب كاتنيس أو كرهها كان فاهم هي بتعمل كده ليه، و ده الصح في الأدب. كمان كرهي للروايات مفرطة الرومانسية خلاني أتحيز لسوزان كولينز لأنها حطت قصة الحب في مكان و مناخ مناسب جدا لتطورها و لتعقيداتها بعد عن المبالغة في المشاعر أو إفتعال الاحداث.الجزء الاول كان تشويق صافي رغم أن الفكرة كانت واضحة فيه جدا، الجزء الثاني تشويق مع مزيد من كشف سر الحبكة و سر العلاقات بين الشخصيات الي كنا فاكرينها هامشية زي هيمتش مثلا . ده بالإضافة لشحنة نفسية مدروسة تخليط تسب الكابيتول و سنو و اليوم الي عرفت كاتنيس فيه و خليتك تتمكلي غضب و إحساس سخيف بإن مافيش حاجة في إيدك و لا في إيد الابطال إنهم يعملوها غير الاستمرار.كمان عودة المقاطعة ال13 للظهور مرة تانية.أمل، شخصيا كنت قلقانة منه و خايفة الكاتبة تستخدمه كحل مقحم على طريقة الإله من الآله المسرحية.إلا إن سوزان كولينز ما عملتش كده، و في الجزء الثالث أضافت كتير أو لثقل المعنى الفلسفي للرواية و ماهية الثوار و الحرية و الثورة الحقيقية. و كشف تاني لعلاقات و نوايا غريبة و ملتوية أقرب فعلا للي بيحصل يف الواقع.الجزء الاول يستاهل % نجوم أما الثاني و الثالث فيستاهلوا أربعة أو أربعة و نصف . الثاني لأن الصدف فيه كانت كتير شوية زيادة عن حد المعقول علشان نقتنع. و الثالث للإستطراد و التطويل في بعض المواضع مقارنة بالجزئين اللي قبله، لكنه يمكن تطويل مش وحش لأنها ناقشت و فسرت كل الي ما تناولتهوش في الأجزاء السابقة.بقي أن اشيد بالفيلم إشادة خاصة جدا. الفيلم أضاف للرواية فعلا و فسر حاجات كتير جدا الكاتبة سكتت عنها في الرواية. من أول تأكيد تشابه الرواية المتعمد مع واقع الإمبراطورية الرومانيه إلى بعض الدوافع الي بتحرك الرئيس سنو و الفلسفة من ورا الألعاب ككل.تصميم الديكور و الشخصيات و أداء الممثلين ممتاز جدا. اللإافلام دي دليل لا يدحض على إمكانية إن الفيلم يضيف للرواية كتير حتى و الرواية ممتازة من غيره، لكن الكاتبة مكانتش بتوصف الشخصيات أو الاماكن بشكل كافي مثلا ، فالفيلم أضاف للنقطة دي متعة بصرية و فلسفية كويسة جدا.أكيد أنصح بقرائتها بأي لغة، و أنصح بالتفكير في الرواية بشكل متعمق لأن سوزان كولينز بإختصار نقلت واقع الثورات العربية بكل دقة بين دفتي كتبا. عرض مذهل مش مصدقاه لحد دلوقتي لكل الي مرينا و بنمر بيه من ساعة 25 يناير.أنظروا للأمور نظره طائر محاكي في السما و شوفوا الصورة الكبيرة و ماتضيعوش وقتكم في تفاصيل مشتته. إحنا وسط مباراة العاب جوع حقيقية كل يوم بيمر فيها واحد فينا بيتم إختيراه للإنضمام للقرابين.العاب الجوع فعلا مافيهاش فائزين، فيها ناجين مش أكتر و شتان بين الأثنين.ندعو الله إن الإحتمالات تكون في صالحنا دايما بس نطكون فايزين مش ناجين بس 

This is yet another novel which would not have come to my attention but for Goodreads and I would not have chosen to read it had it not been for the overwhelmingly positive reaction to the book of my Goodreads friends. I'm so glad that I did. For me, the most compelling aspect of the novel is what it says about our society. From the idea that rich and powerful people live on what is produced by poor people far away, to the concept of people being entertained by a reality television program the objective of which is survival at the expense of other contestants, to the depiction of a great “sporting” contest in which the success or failure of the contestants depends on their ability to attract wealthy sponsors, to the use of children killing other children as a weapon of control, these are all things that happen in the real world, right now. Certainly, the images are exaggerated*, but this only brings the reality of our world into sharper relief. I was engaged with the narrative from the very beginning. Although initially disappointed with Carolyn McCormick’s narration – I don’t think she does a great job with a number of the characters - I left my irritation with the narrator behind and fully entered the world of the novel. The details of the world are clever. For example, the depiction of the relationship between the Capitol and the Districts as akin to the relationship between ancient Rome and its empire is simply but effectively achieved by calling children who are sent to the Capitol to fight to the death in the Hunger Games “tributes” and by giving the Capitol’s inhabitants Latin names. Collins has also done well with the development of her characters. The novel is narrated by the sixteen-year-old heroine, Katniss Everdeen to whom Collins gives a very believable voice. Katniss is prickly, sullen and quite clueless about her own emotions, but she is smart, loyal and resourceful. It is interesting to watch her grow from resigned acceptance of the system in which she lives in general and of the Hunger Games in particular, to clarity about what those things represent, culminating in her light bulb moment, (view spoiler)[ when she refers to the killing at the Hunger Games by its correct name - murder (hide spoiler)]. Other characters are also well realised. This is particularly true of Haymitch, the alcoholic mentor and former Hunger Games champion, who shows the classic signs of a veteran with combat stress reaction. Successfully pulling off a first person, present tense narrative is no easy feat, given that the point of view has to remain solely that of the narrator. Collins achieves this without faltering. While Katniss speculates about what she can’t see and doesn’t know, the perspective remains hers. Even within the limitations imposed by this narrative style, Collins is able to let the reader know more than her heroine is aware of. As is to be expected from the subject matter, the novel contains graphic descriptions of violence. However, there is nothing about this which either encourages or glorifies violence - quite the contrary. The horrific situation in which the participants in the Hunger Games find themselves speaks for itself. Making choices in situations of adversity, friendship, loyalty and above all, what it means to be human are what the novel is really about.Overall, I found this audiobook riveting to listen to. The only reason I’m glad not to have read the book when it was first published is that I can go on to the second volume of the trilogy without delay. *There is no exaggeration in relation to the issue of children killing children. The plight of child soldiers has had a lot of exposure in social media in recent times. A friend of mine who works for the United Nations was posted in Uganda a few years ago, where his task was to re-unite child soldiers from the Lord’s Resistance Army with their families and communities. The sheer horror of what those children experienced trumps any fictional account of violence committed by and against children.

Lo estuve leyendo de nuevo y no pude evadir el recurrente (y muy persistente) pensamiento de que este libro habría sido maravilloso si lo hubiesen escrito en tercera persona y no desde la perspectiva de Katniss Everdeen.Todo el tema de la rebelión me parece muy interesante y de hecho no puedo decir que el libro no me haya gustado, fue de esos libros con los que, si mal no recuerdo, me introduje en el mundo de la ciencia ficción y el género YA.La razón por la que pienso que este libro habría sido mejor en tercera persona es por la subjetividad de Katniss. Puedo entender que de vez en cuando sea retraída y no se pueda dilucidar mucho sobre su personalidad, pero en ocasiones es más que eso, es como un resentimiento casi infundado y un miedo que la lleva a rechazar a quienes tiene más cerca y no nos permite ver cómo son realmente las personas de su entorno más que como ella las pinta, lo cual no es suficiente. Ese comportamiento no me gustó, el hecho de que estuviera siempre a la defensiva se ganó mi recelo pese a su determinación como persona. Era fuerte, pero no lo suficiente como para llevar ese peso en sus hombros porque le faltaba llenar muchos aspectos. Creo que visto desde fuera, así como lo he visto en la película, resulta un poco menos fastidioso.El romance no fue solo un poco fastidioso. Fue horriblemente molesto. Katniss se miente a sí misma y solo piensa en su familia, pero el que Peeta y Gale estén enamorados de ella le trae sin cuidado o peor, cree que (en caso de Peeta) es todo una farsa. Pues mira, en mi opinión eso estuvo de más, el amor se me hizo un poco falso y creo que va cogiendo intensidad a fuerza de necesidad, porque Katniss no parecía muy por la labor.No se explotó lo suficiente a los personajes y creo que esa es otra consecuencia de construir un libro en tercera persona. El problema es que me pareció que este era un libro sobre una adolescente con el corazón endurecido que es forzada a ir a unos tales juegos del hambre, en lugar de una adolescente que se ve atrapada en los juegos del capitolio y que ocasionalmente cae en el enredo del romance joven. El triángulo amoroso sobra. Sobra. Sobra.Y los temas de los que se debió hablar más, son los que abarcan como tres páginas a lo sumo. La chica se sumergió demasiado en su odio hacia lo superficial, así que cayó en lo mismo que el resto.No todo es odio para Katniss. La chica sabe cómo arreglárselas por su cuenta y el amor hacia su familia es impresionante. Es fuerte, es decidida y va a por su objetivo (a pesar de que se deje otras cosas importantes por fuera). Lo que me gustó de ella es que no se parece en absoluto a las protagonistas de otros libros y puede valerse por sí misma. El problema es que no se deja querer, y eso le cierra muchas puertas.La trama en sí es fascinante, y creo que por eso le doy cuatro estrellas. Como controlan todo a favor de los juegos y no de las personas, como las personas se ven obligadas a cambiar para sobrevivir y todo el tema de la rebelión me pareció excelente. No puedo explicar cómo la construcción de los juegos en sí me dejó absolutamente pasmada, la crueldad con la que el capitolio ejerce su poder me asqueó y me sorprendió en ocasiones, y puedo ver que este libro es como una plataforma para lo que se viene después.

The Hunger Games is written by Suzanne Collins and is a fictional book about fighting for life. Katniss Everdeen and Peeta Mellark grew up in the same district and went to the same school but couldn't be more strangers than they are now. Katniss is a 16 year old girl who lost her father at his work and has a never-there-for-her type of mother for herself and her sister,Prim and only has 1 friend,Gale. Peeta is a 16 year old boy who comes from a family with both of his parents and brothers and sisters, he's considered popular at his school and works at his family backery. Every year there is a reaping for a girl and a boy to fight for their life out of the 12 districts to be the only one living out of the 24 tributes selected. Katniss Everdeen and Peeta Mellark are the tributes for district 12 and figured that they won't win without each other. Right before they sacrifice their own life so they don't have to live without each other they are rewarded the victors of the 74th Hunger Games.This book is well written out. When I was reading this book I could tell how the characters were feeling and could picture in my head what all was going on. This book is by far one of my favorite books that I have ever read. During the games Katniss and Peeta come closer than they ever had and Peeta's true feelings for Katniss come out.They have to act like love birds so people from the Capitol will give them what they want. While Katniss is just pretending Peeta actually is falling for her. In the end they trick the people from the Capitol to thinking that they are the 'Star-crossed Lovers from District 12' and end up winning the games together instead of without each other.

Buddy read with Athena and Karleesi in Sanctum of Fantasy!First Hunger Games reread: August 2015If y'all didn't get the story the first time through, I was a latecomer to this series (and I mean LATE). The first time I read these books was in 2014. I devoured all three in less than a week and have since watched the movies countless times. I don't even want to talk about how psyched I am for November and Mockingjay part 2. But this is my first time revisiting the books since that first read last year. I'm glad I slowed down on this readthrough. It's a great story with suspense that is beyond addicting, but between being insanely busy IRL and wanting to take the opportunity to make sure I didn't miss anything, this was as great the second time as it was the first. The things that stood out so much to me last year remain bold this time around; the sense of continuity in Katniss' and Peeta's wounds, the sense of urgency, the excellent characterizations. I love seeing the world specifically through Katniss' eyes, even though the movies open the world up a bit more. The original books bring a quality of depth that the movies don't have, no matter how many times you watch them. Incidentally, I discovered while reading that this edition of the trilogy is the UK version xD words like "programme" and "colour" tipped me off, and I'll probably go back to my American trilogy the next time I pick the series up, but I LOVE these covers <3

با اینکه اول اولین فیلم این مجموعه را دیدم و داستان را می‌دانستم، باز هم خواندن کتابش جذاب بود و من را به دنبال خود می‌کشاند. در واقع چون از ایده‌ی فیلم خوشم آمد و برایم جذاب بود دوست داشتم اول کتابش را بخوانم و سراغ قسمت‌های بعدی فیلمش نرفتم. البته بعضی جاها توصیف‌ها زیادی می‌شد یا شخصیت اصلی داستان یعنی کتنیس به بیان خاطراتی می‌پرداخت که صفحه پر کن بود اما در مجموع خوشحالم خواندمش و لذت بردم.نمایش درگیری‌های کتنیس با خودش، توصیف احساسات متضاد و گیج‌کننده‌اش، سرراست نبودن این عواطف، آن جوری که واقعا درون همه‌ی ما هست، به جذابیت داستان می‌افزود.اگر از داستان هیجان‌انگیزی که به صورت اول شخص روایت می‌شود خوشتان می‌آید، این کتاب انتخاب خوبی است.

I really liked it. I read it when it first came out. Now I think it's gotten over-hyped, and now the producer director that was working on EVERLOST (Gary Ross) is now directing The Hunger Games instead, so are we smelling some sour grapes.... perhaps.... I'm going to reread it, though before embarking on books two and three.

This review will probably not be popular, but it's good to talk about these issues. It is taken from a longer article written for Mercatornet http://www.mercatornet.com/articles/v...War, persecution, abuse, suffering -- these are common themes in literature and I am not overly disturbed by them, at least in principle. Dark themes are a part of life, and even if they are difficult to face they can be invaluable for testing character, proving virtue, and drawing out what is most beautiful in human nature, as well as the worst. It all depends how they are dealt with.In a dystopian vision of the near future, Hunger Games is a terrifying reality TV show where twelve boys and twelve girls are forced to compete to the death. The Capitol has imposed the games on the children of the twelve districts under its control to remind them that rebellion is futile. Sixteen-year-old Katniss Everdeen steps forward to take her sister’s place, and though she sees it as a death sentence, she is determined to survive for the sake of her family.Author Suzanne Collins conceived the idea for Hunger Games while channel surfing between reality TV shows and news coverage of an actual war zone. It is not a particularly uplifting theme, yet Collins has many readers convinced that the book’s ethics are clear: it is a critique of the violent injustice it describes. I am not convinced.SurvivalIn the games, survival is the ultimate good and death the greatest evil; our heroine never questions this. She and the other characters do whatever it takes to survive, and for games contestants this means killing. Katniss is the good girl so she is subtle at first, dropping an insect nest on someone’s head so they swell up and die "naturally", or destroying another group’s food so they will starve. Her district companion Peeta confesses that “to murder innocent people costs everything you are”, yet indirectly and later directly, both he and Katniss still do it.The experience is like reading a first hand account of a Nazi soldier doing horrible things to others in order to stay alive. The fact is, sometimes survival is not the most important thing and it is necessary to be prepared to die rather than kill someone else.In Collins’ books, survival only loses its appeal when suffering makes death more appealing than life, justifying the suicide and mercy killing which are rife in the series. Towards the end the rebels—including Katniss—carry a suicide bomb in case they or their friends are caught. Failure to kill a captured friend is seen as a failure of friendship, and Katniss’ reluctance to use it is a sign of her weakness. Darkness–1; Characters–0.Desensitisation and “romance”Next there is brutal desensitisation so the characters won’t get so hurt (it is not acknowledged that this too is a form of harm), and romance used as a tool of survival.The games are televised and sponsors must be sought to provide the food and medicine contestants will need to survive. Body appearance is therefore important: each contestant has a stylist who must first assess them without clothes (Katniss ‘bravely’ resists the urge to cover herself), and then a full body wax makes them camera-ready. This is probably normal for reality TV, but don’t tell me it’s brave.At first, the other contestants mock Katniss with explicit offers and gestures because she is so "pure". But soon she "toughens up" and is able to laugh rather than blush at their provocative displays, and shows less of a concern to protect herself. As Katniss is "built up" (broken down), Collins seems to enjoy describing the loss of innocence; it’s quite nauseating.From the start, a fake relationship between Katniss and Peeta is played up to win sponsorship. "One kiss equals one pot of broth", so Katniss maintains a star-crossed lovers’ routine with long, lingering kisses and imaginary tears, and later the pretence that they are married and that she is pregnant.Peeta himself falls for it, but Katniss is just confused about what she feels. This doesn’t stop her from kissing, hugging and "comfort' bed sharing with Peeta, nor prevent her kissing her old friend Gale "to make up for all the kisses I’ve withheld, because it doesn’t matter anymore, and because I’m so desperately lonely I can’t stand it." This petty, selfish, mockery of love is all that is served up in Hunger Games.Not only did Katniss embrace her progressive desensitisation and confusedly false romance, but the book makes her a hero for it. Darkness–2; Characters–0.Feelings replace right and wrongNow to ethics per se. Actions are deemed right or wrong based on how the characters feel about them. For Katniss the pattern is repeated over and over: a catastrophic situation is followed by her passionate but often unethical reaction, then a soul-searching analysis of her feelings to deal with her guilt, followed by defiant justification that she had no choice, or, if she had a choice, that she was confused, which is the fault of those who created the catastrophe. Thus she becomes the victim-hero: none of the evil—including that which she did herself—is her fault: they made her do it.Is there not a little duplicity in someone who curses the horrible culture that sacrifices its children to settle its differences, when she herself has played along with it the whole time? Darkness–3; Characters–0.“Heroic rebellion”Some may claim that Katniss did rebel. First, her fake romance: What is rebellious or heroic about this self-serving tactic? Second, Katniss' and Peeta’s threat of double suicide to demand that they both be allowed to live: after killing so many others her effort to spare a friend rings hollow. Third, her placing of flowers on her dead friend’s body: but then she goes on to continue the games, fighting and killing…What about the grand finale where Katniss joins the rebels to bring down the Capitol? Running on hatred, bitterness and revenge, the rebels use bombs and guns to kill hundreds of innocent citizens who get in the way. Katniss may not like the large-scale killing, but she has no problem shooting a startled citizen who blocks her path. Still, we are reassured, it’s not her fault. Darkness–4; Characters–0.SensationalismReinforcing all the above is the seductive sensationalism of the storytelling. It is like watching a graphic news story that turns horrific events into entertainment, using excessive detail and twisting the narrative to wrench every possible emotion from the viewer, constantly driven to bigger and better shocks for impact. The screaming, the blood, the broken bodies, the instruments of torture and the damage they do -- when all this is no longer enough the emotional impact of the slow and graphic death of some poor, innocent character we’ve come to like is thrown in. I don’t know how on earth the movie will rate PG.How can this series be a critique of using injury and death for entertainment when it does the same itself?! Thanks to the gratuitous graphic detail not only the characters, but the readers too, are damaged. Darkness–5; Characters (and readers)–0.So, what do we do now?Readers should question the lack of freedom and responsibility of these characters. Could they have chosen to act differently? Are they responsible for choosing to act badly? Would we be right to do the same in their situation? Are they heroes for acting as they did? If there is still confusion, ask the same questions about Nazi soldiers.Also think about the effect of turning horrible things into entertainment. Parents may find some helpful analysis of the effect of desensitisation on our ability to love in Wendy Shalit’s shocking book A Return to Modesty: Discovering the Lost Virtue (1998).It will also help to look at alternative novels. Birthmarked (2010) by Caragh M. O’Brien is a recent favourite of mine. Though it’s also dystopian and deals with dark themes in a cruel future world, the beauty of characters’ actions transforms the story completely.The heroine, Gaia, is an ordinary person who must learn from failures and struggle to face her fears. Flash-backs to her childhood show that her parents’ depth and wisdom nourished her character so that she was ready to face difficulties with courage and selflessness. At one point her mother has doubts about something she did in obedience to the government. Gaia would excuse her for not having had a choice but her father corrects her: “You always have a choice, Gaia, you can always say no”. The story shows that the consequences of such a choice are not always pleasant, but sacrifice for what is right is a triumph of good over evil, which is far more heroic than doing evil for fear of getting hurt.Gaia’s own actions are true acts of rebellion: she risks her life by refusing to save herself before trying to save her parents; she saves a baby from dying along with its condemned mother; she rescues her mother and the child she is carrying... And when she is called to leave one victim for someone who needs her more, she is not governed by feelings but by trying to do what is right.The romance is realistic but perfect: the characters’ love for each other grows for all the right reasons. They learn so much about each other and their flawed but earnest characters are the antithesis of Edward/Bella sentimentally and Katniss/Peeta falseness. What’s more, they demonstrate very real sacrifice; there is no better sign of love.Somehow in the midst of evil’s triumph, sacrifice for what is good produces a hope that is even stronger than the evil that weighs upon it. Thus the characters are victorious, even when the darkness seems to have the upper hand.The style may not be as slick and addictive as in Hunger Games, and perhaps a lazy reader’s initial reaction may be that it’s not as good, but the characters positively shine by comparison. It’s worth thinking about the after-effect of books once the action fades and characters and story settle in your soul. That’s the part that stays with you.Another alternative is The Book Thief (2006) by Markus Zusak. In this interview the author describes the beauty of human goodness which can be discovered in the midst of great evil.There are so many more great novels which explore dark or difficult themes but clearly show protagonists taking responsibility for their actions. Trash by Andy Mulligan (2010), The Hiding Place by Corrie Ten Boom (1971), The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas by John Boyne (2006), The Scarlet Pimpernel by Emmuska Orczy (1903), A Rose for the ANZAC Boys by Jackie French (2008), Hotel on the Corner of Bitter and Sweet by Jamie Ford (2009), The Help by Kathryn Stockett (2009, mature readers), Anne Frank: the Diary of a Young Girl (1947), Sophie Scholl and the White Rose by Annette Dumbach (1999, mature readers), Amazing Grace: William Wilberforce and the Heroic Campaign to End Slavery by Eric Metaxas (2007), Left to Tell by Immaculee Ilibagiza (2006, mature readers), St Maria Goretti: in Garments all Red by Godfrey Poage (1998), Man’s Search for Meaning by Viktor Frankl (1946), Life Without Limits by Nick Vujicic (2010).Read and compare, and decide who the real heroes are.

I read this in one sitting, and then a few days later read it again just for fun. Perhaps I have some latent bloodlust lurking somewhere in my psyche. Comparisons to Takami's  Battle Royale (and the cult film adaptation by Fukasaku) are inevitable. The dystopian conceit -- a corrupt government punishing its citizens by sentencing children to fight each other to death in a public spectacle -- is almost exactly the same in Hunger Games. However, I guess it is hard to find a story that doesn't remind you of another story. Still...hmmm, Suzanne Collins, hmmm.Hunger Games provides a nice update to the Battle Royale idea and is a perfect fit for teenagers who have grown up in the era of The Real World and The Hills. I caught the first episode of Real World Season 283 a few years back and was struck by how stale it had become. Producers must be hard pressed to find show applicants who haven't seen the first 200 seasons, so the kids who show up are so meta its ridiculous. On the first day, two girls started making out in the hot tub while wondering who among the guys they had just met must be the token gay character. (Show editors must be tearing their eyes out in hopes of any legitimate story arcs). Hey, look at me, I'm so outrageous!Of course, there is more at stake in the Hunger Games arena than in the Real World house of debauchery. What most interested me in this book was how heroine Katniss used her accumulated knowledge of the Hunger Games, having watched it every year growing up, to manipulate her status and progress in the games. She is aware at every moment that she is on camera and does her best to use this knowledge as a weapon -- one arguably more effective than her skill with a bow and arrow.Katniss's first person narrative gives the story its immediacy and sense of excitement; however, I actually feel that this sole perspective limited the complexity of the book. It would have been fascinating to have also had Haymitch's perspective or perhaps some behind-the-scenes gamemaker's interpretation of events. Finally, it cannot be denied that the book ended REALLY abruptly. I know it is the first of the series, and yes I am left wanting more, but this book felt really unbalanced. I am more impressed when books in a series both work together and also stand alone as complete works.Still, sign me up to read the next one! Get cracking, Suzanne!

Ok I am new to Good Reads and this is my first review. I had to do my first one for The Hunger Games because it really was the catalyst that started me reading again. I initially heard about the book when I saw the teaser trailer for the movie. If you don't remember the first set of teaser trailers then I'll remind you that it was pretty sparse. It had someone running through the forest ,fire and then finally a emblem of a bird on fire. It intrigued me but I did nothing about it. Then , while away on vacation, I came across the book for the first time. Funnily enough it didn't have the cover sleeve so I didn't know it was called The Hunger Games but it had the symbol of that bird and I remembered seeing it before. I laid out on the beach with this book in tow totally unaware of what I was about to get into. I mean I read mostly romance novels before this book and it had been a long time since I picked up anything new. I also had never read a dystopian type novel before so I really had no idea what the story was going to be about. I opened the book and began to read it until I could fall asleep in the sun but that did not happen. The way the character Katniss spoke in the 1st chapter and the way she described her life in Panem was incredible. When she described what the Hunger Games were exactly I was shocked, alarmed, furious, sad, intrigued and confused . I had never experienced so many emotions in one chapter of a book ever. I literally read the first chapter a second time just to make sure in understood the setting of this series. I then thought that there is no way that this book was made for youth between the ages of 9-12 . I never read anything so adult at those ages. It truly is a master piece. I was so wrapped up in this book that by the end of my vacation I came home and ordered the whole trilogy via Amazon just so I could finish it. It truly was a moving series and this book was the one that started my journey into other dystopian novels. If you have ever even thought about reading this book for even a minute then you have deprived yourself for far to long. Don't hesitate and just jump. This book , the whole series , is a ride you don't want to miss. Enjoy ;)

Why did I wait so long to read this? It is worth all they hype! I loved it!I feel the author came up with a fresh story idea. Sometime in our distant future, our country is destroyed and 12 districts are born, to form a nation called Panem. The lower the district number you have seems to mean you are more fortunate. The higher districts live in extreme poverty. They have little food or possessions. A teenager, Katniss, has been doing the hunting for her mother and young sister for 4 years since her father’s death in a mine explosion. She’s lived a very harsh life in district 12People also live in fear of The Capitol. They can take you out at any time, and destroy your family or even your entire district. You can’t speak out against them or you will be punished. Every year they have a ceremony that is called The Reaping. They put names off all teens from ages 12 – 18, from all the districts and pick two ‘Tributes’ from each district. These Tributes must go to the Capitol and fight to the death in what is called The Hunger Games. Only 24 Tributes go in, and one will survive. They are put into an outdoor environment that is created by the Gamemakers, and have to survive harsh conditions, attacks by other Tributes, attacks by Gamemakers. The games are televised 24/7 for Panem to watch. I don’t want to give much away, but Katniss takes the place of her younger sister as a Tribute for District 12. The story is really fast paced, and it turns into a nail-biter at the end. I highly recommend this read! I cannot wait to pick up the second in the series.

A gripping, thrilling, shocking read. I'd heard about the Hunger Games, but still picked up the book slightly skeptical. Written in Present-Tense. First-Person. A dystopian, future-world perspective. Government with total control. Right, I thought, this is going to be strange. But it was great. I loved it from beginning to end, from the great start to the breathtaking finish. I finished it in two days (I had to!) and then looked frantically for the second. It's hard to put down, and impossible to forget. Even after the final page, you think about it for days. The prose is flowing and easy to read. The characters are reality at its finest -- though with so many twists to their personalities you will never fully figure them out, not even at the end. Every concept in the novel is amazing. The detail is sparse but vivid. The action is never ending (each chapter ending with words that make you keep going) and there's not chance for a break. The characters change, the emotion is rich and the plot twists countless times. There's even a dash of sardonic humour from Haymitch and Peeta. It's a book well worth the read.

(pre-reading)This sounds seriously intense and more psychologically brutal than something I might normally choose, but I loved Gregor so much I'll try anything she writes!(post-reading) Wow. Still out of breath. And somewhat . . . not unsatisfied, exactly, but wanting more. I'm definitely going to make sure I'm first on the list for the next in the series, though it's probably good for my adrenalin levels that I'm forced to take a break.I keep thinking about how throughout the whole book you keep pushing for survival, survival, survival. If they can just make it through the games! But at the end you realize . . . survival means you have to keep going, harder than it sounds in the world of The Hunger Games, where change seems impossible and the fight never ends.

User Name: David - proud Gleeman in Branwen's adventuring party
Review: I know I'm not exactly breaking new ground here by saying this book was good, but it really was an enjoyable read. Katniss is a very strong and likeable protagonist, and while the concept did seem a little too similiar to "The Running Man", Collins still added enough original ideas to make it her own. The book is divided into three parts, and while I loved the first two, I did feel it started to collapse under its own weight in the third part. Without getting specific, I'll just say that I thought the fates of some of Katniss's opponents were rather anti-climactic (one in perticular that caused me to yell out "That's it??? Really???) Still, despite limping to the finish line, this was an adventure/suspense novel definitely worth reading! Can't wait to see the movie now!

Katniss Everdeen "The Girl on Fire!" "May the odds be evah in yoah favah!"My wife has been after me to read the books, and I loved the movies; and of course my fave new actress, Jennifer Lawrence winning an Oscar was astounding. But I just could not get past a chapter or 2, of the books. Then I came across the audio book and my problem was solved.Suzanne Collins, in writing a young adult series, also appealed to adults (or adult children), my wife, now me. Absolutely astounding stories with a sci-fi edge, maybe giving a glimpse of what could be. Terrific, endearing characters that you want to hold on to and read the next page, chapter and books to find out what happened. My wife told me there were things in the books that were not in the movies, but I found them very close. Certainly, I was able to know what Katniss was thinking in the book, but the great acting made the feelings known on film. I am not in any way saying just watch the movie and you're golden, because reading/listening to Collins' creation was worth it.

Yes. I am giving five stars to The Hunger Games.Several of my friends, and my sister, told me that these books weren't worth reading. I honestly never saw what they meant. I couldn't turn the pages fast enough, I was always so excited to read this book!Granted, I'd seen the first Hunger Games movie before I read this first book (omg, how dare you, Jamie). I think the movie is awesome. As is the book. I really do think it WAS worth reading.The Hunger Games is an extremely enticing dystopic novel that taught me to really think about everything I have and to be thankful.

Going into "The Hunger Games," I heard all the hype about it, declaring it one of the best books of the year and possibly even a new classic. The problem with hype like that is it sets unrealistic expectations for me. As I sat down to finally read the book, I hoped I could separate the hype from the reality and judge the book on its own merits.And it is a good book. It's not ground-breaking but it's still quite good and a novel twist on the classic short story, "The Most Dangerous Game." In the near future, the former United States has been divided into 12 territories. Each year, tributes are selected from each territory to compete in the hunger games, a kind of brutal post-apocalyptic version of "Survivor." The winner gets to live and wins fame, fortune and food for his or her district. Our heroine, Katsiss volunteers for the role when her younger sister is selected. She's whisked away to the Capitol to train and then to compete, along with the son of a baker from her district. The two create a splash in the Capitol as they are introduced to the nation and prepare for the games.As an exercise in world-building, the first half of the novel is fascinating. Suzanne Collins gives us enough glimpses of the society she's created without hindering or taking away from the plot. The observations by the first-person narrator of Kat help the reader begin to slowly identify with her and offer up some criticism of the society as a whole. It's really once the game itself begins that things take a step backward. There is some suspense to the game, the pursuit and some twists and turns along the way. But the book loses some of its early momentum when Kat is turned loose in the game. Hearing about her strategy is interesting at first but given that this is first-person narrated story there's not much question who will win the game. Thankfully Collins gives us a twist that covers this, defying reader expectations. All of that said, I found myself wishing that this story was embraced more than a certain other series about shiny vampires. It's a better written story, better executed and shows more promise in one novel than that series has in four. It's not terribly new or ground-breaking but it's still a good story, well told.

I didn't think I would enjoy this book. I am not normally a fan of YA (Harry Potter is not YA, you shut up!), but decided to read this one anyway. I expected a fluff read where I would roll my eyes often. I have to say that I am honestly surprised by how well-written this book was.I don't see any point in going into the plot particulars; there are many reviews here that do that. But I would like to mention some of the things I loved about The Hunger Games.1.) The first chapter is packed so full of important information, and it is artfully and wonderfully done. The reader gets all the necessary background on Panem, the Hunger Games, the Reaping, Katniss and her family, and her friendship with Gale.2.) Although there were places where the book lagged a bit (days of Katniss sitting in trees during the games without any tribute deaths), those were few and far between. For the most part, this book hooked me early and kept me interested the entire time.3.) The heroine isn't your typical heroine. She is surly and distrusting. She really isn't even very likable. But she makes no excuses for that and continues on.4.) The "love story" isn't a love story. In fact, there is zero love on Katniss's part. Her goal is to get out of the games alive, preferably saving Peeta, too. Her motivation has nothing to do with romance, and that's nice for a change. 5.) The games brought out a hatred of The Capitol in Katniss, setting up the possibility of sequel books. Although this book would have worked just fine on its own as a single, it's usually a good idea to hook the reader into thinking of the continuation of a great story at a future time. The author did a fantastic job of this.All in all, I have to say that this book went way beyond my expectations, and I think I loved it. I am a fan of Katniss, and a fan of Peeta for completely different reasons. I will definitely read the other books in the series.

"You were about as romantic as dirt until he said he wanted you." Well guys. I did it. I managed to finish this book after 10 months. This is embarrassing. But I did it for my best friend! Yay! Go me. "I want to die as myself. Does that make sense?" He asks. I shake my head. How could he did as anyone but himself? "I don't want them to change me in there. Turn me into some kind of monster that I'm not."I did find that this book dragged on. A lot. And it did take me a very (very) long time to read it. I'll admit this probably won't be my favourite book. I was going to rate it 3 stars but near the end of the book it changed my mind. I'm hoping I'll like Catching Fire a little better. "Deep in the meadow, under the willowA bed of grass, a soft green pillow Lay down your head, and close your sleepy eyesAnd when again they open, the sun will rise. Here it's safe, here it's warmHere the daisies guises you from every harmHere your dreams are sweet and tomorrow brings them trueHere is the place where I love you.""Deep in the meadow, hidden far awayA cloak of leaves, a moonbeam rayFogey your woes and let your troubles layAnd when again it's morning, they'll wash away. Here it's safe, here it's warmHere the daisies guard you from every harm Here your dreams are sweet and tomorrow brings them true Here is the place where I love you."4/5 stars. :)

This is one of the best books I've read in a very long time. I was hooked from the first chapter and could not put the book down! Collins is a great story teller and writer. She does an awesome job of developing her characters and wrapping them around a story line that has you captivated the whole way through! I fell in love with Katniss, Peeta and Gale immediately, and my heart went out to them as they faced their struggles and challenges throughout the book. I love this book and would recommend it without hesitation!

The Hunger Games is disturbing, romantic, and entrancing all at the same time. I could not stop reading. The characters are beautifully developed and the setting is eerie (too real and too plausible). At first I thought it the dystopian society would be hard to believe, but Collins really sells it. I was with her from beginning to end. By the way, I cried at two scenes and nearly had a heart attach at a couple others. I read tons of books and for me that experience is very rare. Prepare yourself for an emotional fit!
this is an easier read if it's audio.

Those of you who have followed or friended me for a while will know that I used to regularly find different ways to tear this book to shreds. I have given up on doing that, and decided that my life is better spent looking for books that are not torturous to read.  Romance of the Three Kingdoms is looking pretty good to me.But I do want to raise one question about this book's mind-blowing popularity, because it's really that part that I have never been able to wrap my mind around. Twilight has an entire audience that hates it to death and is regularly targeted for being sexist and badly written. Even Harry Potter has received its fair share of criticism for technical shortcomings. Eragon is frequently derided for its lack of originality. Yet when a book comes along with the thinnest pretense of "feminism," it immediately escapes all scrutiny and is lauded not only for being empowering to women, but also a quality piece of literature?How is it possible that a book about 24 children fighting to the death is more famous for its love triangle than the way it deals with how one would lose their fucking humanity in a situation like that? How is it possible that this book's protagonist possesses almost zero agency and embodies almost every sexist cliche that comes with "strong woman," yet is smugly compared to Bella Swan as the real example of a feminist role model?
