How is it possible that what is really a high school romantic drama dressed up in dystopian clothing receives such critical acclaim? Is it because popular culture wants to believe that only the most superficial appeals to feminism are the end-all-be-all to deconstructing patriarchy? Is it because middle-class readers like to equate their everyday pain with people who starve to death and are oppressed by a totalitarian regime? Katniss is essentially a spoiled middle-class American teenager, just like Bella Swan is, but the only difference is that she's got a bow and arrow and some dirt.This is a book that panders to people. I do not mean to say that fans of this book are unintelligent or did not take valuable things away from it, but I do think that Collins is taking advantage of very convenient cultural trends to write a book that many people find safe to praise. As The Last Psychiatrist points out, Katniss's character is praised for having traits that any decent human being would have, in accordance with the popular idea that what makes a man normal would make a woman special. More interestingly, I wonder what were Collins's intentions behind this book. Did she write in Katniss's "I'm-the-center-of-the-world" attitude because kids fighting to the death is not dramatic enough? Or does she want to appeal to readers by pretending to deal with heavy themes like starvation, war, and survival but also write a romance at the same time?But my biggest question is: how do people not see through this? Perhaps I'm overestimating the accuracy of my own subjective experience with this book, but I find it hard to believe that so many people could have missed the complete lack of moral ambiguity that would inevitably pop up in this kind of story, how most of the important people in Katniss's life are men, how all the non-Katniss female characters have no real emotional lives. Is it that all we look for in literature are superficial markers? Is that what feminism means to us, just looking for things that fit a preconceived notion of feminism? Are our attempts to understand third-world suffering really just a narcissistic way to convince ourselves that the rest of the world is just like us?I've exerted every possible effort I can to understand. I've tried forcing myself to like this book, and have reread it multiple times. I've talked to many of my friends who love The Hunger Games. I've read countless positive reviews of this, hoping to find something to convince me that I'm wrong, because that would please me more than anything. So far I have not. I am willing to believe that Collins's other books may be well-written, as pretentious writing tends to be very deliberate, but for now, it's going to take a loooooong time for the bitter aftertaste of this to dissipate. (And it's already been years since I first read it.)Hmm. I said earlier I wouldn't tear this book to shreds. Does questioning the trends of popular culture count as tearing this book to shreds? Anyway, feel free to disagree. Although I know this review does little to help my case, I promise I am not as immature I was four years ago.__________ETA: I recently found this amazing blog post that articulates the problems with portrayals of gender in THG as well as popular culture more eloquently than I could ever do myself. Please do read it--I think it raises so many oft-ignored crucial issues about sexism (and racism) in media , the self-awareness of which we would all benefit from greatly._________Apparently I am incapable of refraining from criticizing this book. I'm doing my best to keep the vitriol out of my tone because I don't wish to discourage disagreement with my opinions, but I can't deny that this book seems more and more awful every time I think about it. Anyway, I feel obliged to note that the portrayal of poverty and economic disparity in this book is atrocious. Living on the edge of survival, contrary to what Collins may think, does not make you "stronger" or "better" than those of the upper classes. Poverty is extremely degrading. It wears down on people and saps them of their ability to find meaning in their lives and is often the source of huge mental health issues. This whole idea is also just seriously illogical. Think about it: rich people have access to food, education, healthy exercise, as well as strong social networks and family structures that provide stability as kids grow up. Poor people have to work themselves to death to bring in the most meager of incomes, raise families at the same time, struggle with food, limited access to education, get shamed for their problems by the upper classes for being "lazy," and often with no hope of the situation ever changing, stuck in an endless cycle of never having enough. Which of these two categories do you think is likely to turn out more successful?The only circumstance for being "proud" of a poor economic background is when you finally escape it and can look at the situation from the outside, comparing it to the better situation you have now. Fetishizing poverty is nothing less than utterly insulting to the millions of people in the world actually living in poverty, whether in 1st world or 3rd world countries. It frustrates me to think that readers of The Hunger Games will take one look Katniss's situation and applaud her for her middle-class snobbery because it affirms their expectations of "female strength." No. It's not inspiring that Katniss overcame starvation and it would have been equally valid, perhaps even more so, if it was a source of anger and shame rather than pride. It's horrible that she, as well as all the citizens of the districts, had to suffer this oppressive regime bullshit in the first place, and I cannot condone Collins's black-and-white portrayal of the Capitol as a bunch of empty-headed puppies and the oppressed population as pure and innocent angels. Nor does she ever develop, in reliably consistent depth, precisely how the totalitarian regime of Panem works; one minute the Capitol authorities are evil overlords, the next minute they're slaves to the entertainment whims of the Capitol population, so even one of the most basic premises of the world of Panem--the idea that the Capitol citizens are subjugated to the political authority--doesn't work as an excuse for Collins's lousy social commentary.__________And again I find myself unable to stop. The reception of The Hunger Games is often based on praise for conservative romantic views regarding Katniss, Peeta and Gale...compared to all those slutty YA female characters with normal teenage urges, I suppose. For one thing, conservative sexual tendencies is largely an upper class thing; there's a reason why teenage pregnancies are stigmatized in industrialized countries but not in poorer nations, after all. If Katniss is sexually suppressed because it's just her individual personality, then that is some extremely sloppy world building on Collins' part, because it prevents us from seeing her as a product of her society if that society isn't influential enough to shape such a basic and fundamental part of her worldview. Second, to laud a book because it agrees with popular political views is not a convincing argument for a piece of literature's quality. This shows some serious prejudice in media that our preferences are tilted towards stories that reinforce our social opinions regardless of whether they hold any weight. What does it matter if Katniss is a good role model if her portrayal is so anachronistic and inaccurate that it undercuts the environment she comes from (which is supposed to be some sort of insightful commentary on third world environments and the social/political/cultural consequences and circumstances of those environments?) Such a narrow portrayal of such weighty issues is surely a far more grievous error when writing to children than any submissive housewife like Bella Swan could ever be.

Note: These reviews are old and need updating. I might do that soon. 
  One of the best book series i've read. Great job Suzanne Collins :DWhen you love and hate something in a book with ALL your heart you realize how great that book really is, because it has to be really special for you to get to feel all these mixed feelings and still say that it deserves not only 5 stars, but .. 7.. or 10. The story is so complex, the characters are so well developed, the new world created by the author is absolutely fascinating, described so well and it seems so real it scares me, because is not the future I would like for human kind and it seems so possible. Suzanne Collins did an amazing job in writing this books which captivates you from the first pages in such manner that you can't let them go until you reach the very ending.The story is constructed around a young girl, Katniss Everdeen, who all her life tried to protect her family at all costs and now she must do the last thing she can do to keep her little sister safe: die in the hunger games..
  Well, you must be prepared because this is such a powerful story. It takes you in a carousel of emotions and the adventure so great that it makes you dizzy from the speed and all the sudden changes, and the insecurity of not knowing who the enemy is or who you could trust.There is something that really made me fall in love with the "hunger games", the fact that the characters seem so REAL.. they are scared, they make mistakes, they don't know who to trust or not, they cry for the loved ones, they are so strong in some ways and so week in the others. Also then the dialog feels so real, the descriptions are amazing, everything is revealed step by step keeping you there waiting for more, needing to know more.. It's all a big puzzle and every time you you feel you have it all figured out you get this big surprise that changes it all.I don't know this for sure, but I guess the first book is my favorite, because it sets the stage for the other 2 books and it has a bit of everything: action, suspense, romance, drama, humor.. The most important characters are presented here, and I don't know if it is just because you get to know them better though the story, but you really care for them and want them to be safe.You start by knowing that there is only one winner in this game, and Katniss is such a lovely girl so you want her to win.. and then you get to know also other people (like Rue and Peeta) and you just want them too so badly to find a way to survive, and you know that it's not possible and this really breaks your heart.And so, there is Peeta.I loved him in this book (the truth is that I loved him in the others too, but at the end of the first book I felt the most hopeful about him and Katniss, about their love). I would've probably loved to read something from his point of view, mostly I would've loved to read about the moments when he decided to stay with the Careers to keep Katniss safe (and this is funny because mostly he is the one saved by the other - even by Katniss), i wanted to know more about his reasons, how he managed it, how he really felt.. Because all we know about him is through the other characters and is not enough for me.But as litlle as I knew about him I couldn't make myself not loving him. From the moment I read the "bread story", from the moment he declared he loved Katniss, from the way he always tried to protect her, from the way he invited her to kiss him.. from the way he was so hurt by the fact that she didn't love him and only pretended to, but he was still there prepared to give his life for her.. Everything about him was so sweet in this messy world they were part of. Reading about him felt like a summer breeze in all the drama.All in one: this is such a wonderful book. I would recommend it to the entire world, it touched my heart and I know that I will keep it in my mind for a long long time.
  This review can be found at ReadingAfterMidnight.com____________________________________________Blog (EN) | Facebook | Twitter | Tumblr | Bloglovin' | Blog (RO)____________________________________________

Katniss Everdeen is about to be pitted against 23 other contestants, who will all battle to the death. This is Survivor meets Battle Royale. And I wish Nietzsche was alive to read this, because this is the kind of thing he talks about in On the Genealogy of Morals. But I'll save my philosophical rantings for another day.I love the idea of the Hunger Games, and I even think humans are just crazy enough to come up with this idea. My only problem with this book is that it didn't give enough of a detailed background for me to understand how their government system got put into place, which is always important in dystopian novels. Also, everything leading up to them being in the arena was so slow moving that I was hoping for one of Katniss's arrows to strike me in the head. But once they entered the arena, I couldn't put the book down.Katniss has easily become one of my favorite characters of all time, and Peeta is at the top of my shit list right now. You're in the middle of a kill or be killed competition and your only concern is whether or not some girl loves you back? Please stop. I think Katniss is exactly the kind of character I needed to read about. She may come off as cruel or harsh towards Peeta and some of the others, but is there a more caring person in this book? The way she tends to her family and even little Rue shows her true nature. Suzanne Collins did an excellent job with with her characterization, but I wish she didn't make Peeta come off as only caring about Katniss. I don't think it came off the way she wanted it to. If he was intended to be the pure hearted character like Samwise, she missed the mark.For me, this operates great as a stand alone novel, and I'm not sure if I will venture into the other two just yet. I enjoyed the concept, and the emotions in it were very real. I wish the book was from a third person perspective, looking in on each contestant's time in the arena. It would have been longer I'm sure, but much cooler to see what went on when Katniss was unconscious. If you enjoy dystopian novels, you will enjoy this. It's realistic, and it's fun, in a sick and twisted way.

The Hunger Games… I’ve been trying to figure out what to write about it.. I loved it, but I don’t know if that’s enough. I love lots of crap and I hate lots of –what’s the antonym of crap?—classics?—whatever, you get it…… and the 4 star rating might just make people think that this sucks because you know, I suck… What to do… what to do.A good YA story usually has one (or more) of these formulas:A. Teen has some sort of family tragedy/loss of parent to: major illness/car accident/murder/desertion/etc. You can expand with loss of sibling, pet, BFF, you know…B. Teen has to overcome some sort of horrific experience (usually having to do with A.) It could also be rape/incest (see C.)C. Teen has to deal with peer pressure; this could be sex, gang-related sex, girl on girl/boy on boy sex, bad sex (usually not good sex), D. Teen has self-esteem issues and usually has to go through some sort of awakening to realize their full potential. This usually is some sort of journey of self discovery.E. Vampires Now, I’ve always had a special place for the YA novel. From Ponyboy’s English assignment to Margaret’s quest for the ultimate bosom to Bella’s neurosis over her vampire lover. I am there; I’m along for the ride, baby. The Hunger Games is no exception to this rule. I was sucked in from Chapter Two. Can I really explain why? Probably not. It has most of the above formulas (okay, we’re veering away from vampires and sex, sort of) but the way that Suzanne Collins (sidenote: I hesitated on picking this up thinking it was Jackie Collins… you know, of Hollywood Wives fame? I wonder if I’m alone on that.) puts her protagonist, Katniss, through these ‘formulaic’ events is so subtle/not subtle that you can forgive the basics. I’ve also heard that this book isn’t all that original. That Battle Royale and The Game have similar premises. This may be so… I wasn’t all that surprised about the whole ‘Race/fight for your Life’ tournament concept even though I haven’t read or seen the above mentioned plots. So, again, I’m having trouble explaining why I loved this book.  I just did. Does that work? I’m sorry. It’s all I have at the moment. That and 'Screw you! It was awesome!' I’m hoping that I can get the second installment from the library soon. I’m excited to find out what happens with Katniss and Peetra and Gale. Sometimes I think I’ve never really grown up and, sadly, I’m okay with that.

I avoided this book like the plague for quite a while, because I hate anything that even remotely resembles a dystopian novel. They're soooo depressing and they seem to rarely end well. Soylent Green is made of people! I even hated The Giver. Yeah, that's right. I said it. I know, everyone looooves that book. Except me...and probably every kid in eighth grade who had to write a report on it. So there. Nayh. Anyway, my point is that I can't stand to read depressing stories about some bleak future looming on the horizon. I did not want to read Hunger Games. However, I have a goodreads friend, who shall remain nameless (cough) DORSI (cough), who has been basically pestering me for close to a year now to read this thing. She drove me nuts with it. Every comment she left me ended with a variation on the phrase, 'Have you read Hunger Games yet?'. Honestly, I considered de-friending her, but I was afraid she'd just hunt me down and show up at my door with a copy of this book in her hand. Ok, I'm kidding. Sort of.At any rate, I thought after a while she would give up on me as a lost cause, but noooooo. Like a rabid dog with a bone, she just wouldn't let it go. A few weeks ago, she finally snared me in her net. "So, it's been a while. Have you had a chance to read Hunger Games?". Gah! This time I had no defense. I was running low on new ideas for reading material, and in my paranoid state of mind...I was sure she knew it! She had me cornered. I could see that the year I spent skillfully tap dancing around her requests had all been for nothing. There was no escape. I felt the cold chill of defeat sink into my bones.So I read the book.(Pretty anticlimactic, huh? Yeah. I thought so, too.)Now comes the hard part. I have to apologize to my nameless friend.Ahem. (deep breath in...deep breath out)Dorsi...er, Nameless Friend, you were right and I was wrong. Hunger Games is a really good book. You are not a crazy person, and I am glad you shoved this book down my throat. The fact that I hate the entire genre and still ended up giving it 4 stars means that you have excellent taste. I bow to your superior wisedom. Happy?

After the first ten pages, I almost put this book down. The amount of terrible writing fit into those ten pages is absolutely phenomenal. It could have been written by a ten-year-old. It seemed that every sentence began with an "and." "And my dad died. And it was really sad. And I was a little girl. And my mommy must have loved my daddy very much." There was no emotion, no character development, and no surprises. I seriously felt that this was the worst book I had ever read. Period.Fortunately, I was reading this at the beach, and therefore was able to shut off the part of my brain that could ACTUALLY THINK. Once I did that, it was smooth sailing. If I were thinking, this book probably would have insulted my intelligence.However, I am still puzzled by the fact that everyone seems to like these books. This book felt so generic, I felt like I was at a pharmacy (and that analogy is probably better than any you will read in this book).What did everyone like so much about this book? The good writing? Nope. The good character development? Nope. The predictable plot lines? Nope. WHY DOES EVERYONE LIKE THIS BOOK?

Upon Reread:This is one of those books that I could reread for the rest of my life and never want to stop. I love it so much and I will never apologize for that.---------------------------------------Rereading this book was one of my favorite things I've done this year. The plot and the writing have held up over the years more than I thought they would. Seeing all the set up and subtle weaving of the story was so impressive and so wonderful!! Honestly, this story was just as good the third time around which is saying a lot. I don't have a single complaint. The only thing I noticed was that some of the romantic lines seemed pretty cheesy but honestly, the romance was supposed to look forced (at least partially) so I'm even okay with that! This book was flawless. I'm so happy that I reread it.

I picked this book up not expecting too much - popular Young Adult, likely to be mildly entertaining and all about girl empowerment. (Not that anything's wrong with either of those things.) Instead, I found an excellent dystopian science fiction world that gripped me from beginning to end. Note: The rest of this review has been withdrawn due to the changes in Goodreads policy and enforcement. You can read why I came to this decision here.In the meantime, you can read the entire review at Smorgasbook

Best apocalyptic YA teen novel I've read this year.
Fair warning, there's a love triangle, but I can handle it (and I can't stomach too many of those) . It's Mostly because Katniss does not feel for either guy and makes that abundantly apparent (until she has to fake a bit for the cameras). I appreciate that the smidge of romance does not overpower the novel. This plot doesn't solely hang on which boyfriend she chooses - it's more of a survive-and-maybe-you'll-see-your-family-again.Her pride and will to survive energized the novel. Katniss's love for her sister humanized the otherwise stiff character and kept me completely hooked.

Katniss is a hunter, a law breaker, and her family’s main breadwinner. When her younger sister’s life is placed at risk, Katniss doesn’t think. She acts. She steps forward and volunteers herself to compete in the Hunger Games.An annual, nationally televised event in which one teenage boy and one teenage girl from each of the 12 districts of North America must go to the Capitol to compete. And in which only one winner can survive.A sheer thrill ride of a story. With a killer of a premise. Brrr. But it is the small, humane moments that have the most power. Absolutely incredible.

Wow.This was an emotional journey for me.While it’s not the best written book in the world and the writing sometimes made me very confused and frustrated, some of the later action scenes make up for those poorer parts.I also dreamed about The Hunger Games after the first night of reading it. It prompted me to create an entirely new bookshelf. I dreamed I was in the arena watching the other tributes, and it was quite intense.I really enjoyed the first part of the book. Katniss’ self-preservation in the beginning really levelled out once she claimed her sister’s place in the Games. Katniss quickly became very admirable for me, even though I don’t approve of everything she did. I especially enjoyed the part in the novel where Katniss is treated like a princess. It was okay for this little fantasy to play out, because we all knew she’d be fighting for her life in a short time. Most times when heroines are spoiled like this, they don’t earn it, or want it, but they do love it. Katniss didn’t like it, didn’t want it, but was going to earn it regardless of whether or not she won the Games. (view spoiler)[And all the over-eating was actually essential to the plot later on, which I thought was totally awesome. (hide spoiler)]While I feel Katniss deserves her place on my shelf of kick-ass heroines, it’s not because of what she does in the Games. It’s because she can take care of herself outside of the Games. (view spoiler)[Inside the Games I felt that Katniss was way too much of a goody-goody. She killed four people, but it only feels like she killed one, and it’s framed in such a way that you’re supposed to cheer for that guy’s death because he brutally murdered Katniss’ child ally. The three other people, the two girls who died from wasp stings and the boy at the end mauled by the mutts were entirely her responsibility as well, but because the wasps were a case of you-didn’t-move-fast-enough and Cato’s death was out of pity, I guess it mostly gets glossed over. (hide spoiler)]I also felt that the reports that the violence in this book was beyond horrible were grossly exaggerated. But hey, I grew up on Animorphs. (view spoiler)[The deaths of the other tributes were often glossed over and mostly happened off-screen. I almost shed a tear when Rue and Foxface died, and my favourite scene is probably when Thresh killed Clove, but all up I feel the Games just weren’t that violent to the reading audience. Katniss’ tactic was to avoid the other tributes and let them kill themselves, and it was a great tactic. Not so great for an audience. (hide spoiler)] In fact I spent a lot of the time feeling like this was a survivalist novel, and worldbuilding what was safe to eat and how to hunt it, not a gladiator-style fight to the death.I felt that sometimes there was way too much contrivances on behalf of the plot. I almost felt like Collins was being a bit of a helicopter author. Yes, Katniss went through some horrible stuff, because she’s fighting for her life… but she always got what she needed in the end. (view spoiler)[I can accept the healing balm gift for her burns as essential to plot because she’d barely be able to move without it, but the sleeping draught for Peeta just stank of contrivance. There were other options she could have taken and maybe things wouldn’t have worked out so great. (hide spoiler)] It seemed to me that more than once, when given the chance to create conflict, the opportunity was missed.I labelled this book a romance but it’s not really. It’s not about her relationship with Peeta. It has romantic elements but basically I didn’t feel that Katniss felt anything other than affection for Peeta because they were from the same District. Certainly she’s not in love with him at this point but she does need his support from their shared experiences. I won’t deny that they have a bond, but Katniss spends the majority of the book completely ignorant of his feelings, or convinced he’s doing it just for the show.Speaking of show, I was very confused about the concept of the cameras filminf the Games. Katniss kept mentioning how she’d look to the audience and how her face should be visible and stuff like that, and I never once saw a camera or any evidence she was being filmed at all. She was even convinced she was being filmed in a cave. In a cave! There was no camera crew running around the arena, there were no hoverdrones filming anyone, no cameras stuck in trees or clothing a la The Truman Show. It frustrated me because as far as I was aware, from the information Katniss was feeding me, there was absolutely no evidence she was being filmed. Yet she was constantly aware of being filmed… and there was nothing there. Ever.For a long time I was very excited that Katniss was one of those rare heroines who, once she got into a fight, kept her wounds and scars and didn’t come out perfect and preened and primped and gorgeous-looking, like they haven’t just been in a brawl to the death. I didn’t get the feeling that Collins was deliberately trying to make or keep Katniss beautiful, (view spoiler)[especially faced with starvation, burns, wasp stings, dehydration and covered in blood,  (hide spoiler)] and I liked that. That’s why I’m a little torn about what I feel at the end. (view spoiler)[While I agree that Katniss earned her right to be beautiful, I disagree with her losing all her scars, especially the ones she earned pre-Games. (hide spoiler)]What I liked about Katniss was that she was intelligent and capable, and although she often felt despairing, she never gave up. Also, I like Effie quite a lot – her job must be absolutely horrible – but Cinna was my favourite secondary character, after Rue and Foxface.So in conclusion, although there were several things I disliked about this book, or that frustrated me (such as a lack of polish around dialogue construction), I thoroughly enjoyed this book and I very much would like to add the hardcover trilogy to my collection so that I can read the other two books.

In one sense, Suzanne Collins crafts a fast-paced, whirlwind guilty pleasure; on the other, it is only a nice attempt at creating something memorable that misses the mark.It really felt like Collins was trying to write something that would have the longevity and incredible following of Harry Potter series. The odd characters, their unique names like Cinna and Katniss and Prim (not to mention the muttations and the tracker jackers), just all scream Harry Potter to me. Even the villain’s name Cato looks a lot like Draco, don’t you think? Collins, though, just cannot make us become entranced with her world like J.K. Rowling does with hers. I am not especially intrigued, or even better really repulsed, by Panem, while I have imagined myself at Hogwarts—and I’m over 30 years old! While both books have to provide lots of backstory so we can understand the contexts of their world, only one gets it right. Rowling’s use of an outsider character is a brilliant device of narration; as Harry learns about Hogwarts and magic, so do we. The narration of Katniss, on the other hand, plods for me and at times seems unbelievable. Her observations and questions were often exaggerated, while Collins’ characterization seemed simplistic. Haymitch, for example, could have had much more depth than he did—his drinking could have been connected more to his damaged psyche having to live on after experiencing the horror that is the Hunger Games. In addition, those kids who actually survive the Games don’t seem especially traumatized. Yet, when Rowling's characters survive, they still feel like real kids facing a real adolescence along with trying to save the world. You believe it.I also think Rowling can write a better sentence than Collins. The descriptions of the extravagant food and fire-bearing clothing seemed like an attempt to just “color up” the world and make it memorable instead of providing real depth to the story; I was even bored at the long build up to the actual games. I was also bothered by the “new rule” added on page 244, and even more so by the concept of the sponsors, which seemed unfair and kind of lame. The love interest thread of the story was unnecessary, too, don’t you think? I mean, I thought Katniss was so badass throughout the whole story, and I hated that the author felt this strong 15 year old female character needed a love interest.It’s a bit unfair that the book I had just finished before starting Hunger Games was The Book Thief, by Marcus Zusak. If you haven’t read this YA novel, you should. It is poetic and heartbreaking and scary and epic—I hope I can get a few young folks to read The Book Thief when I know many will read The Hunger Games instead. Where HG is light and action-packed, BT is painfully realistic and heavy. In one sense there is no comparison. (Zusak’s book tells the story of a German orphan who befriends a Jew who is hiding in her foster home, where she learns both the awesome and terrible power of words.) But yet, when I picked up Collins’ book and read the outer flap, it says about the author, “she continues to explore the effects of war and violence on those coming of age.” I was first intrigued—but Oh, the overstatement! The Hunger Games could have really said something the way Shirley Jackson’s “The Lottery” says something or like “The Most Dangerous Game” says something. The Hunger Games could have come close to The Book Thief, but it is no way in the same league. A missed opportunity, I think.There are also obvious references our culture’s obsession to the reality show here. In a way, Panem’s ritual viewing of this despicable bloodbath surely is satire of our own low-brow viewing each week. The networks keep churning out the dreck, and we keep tuning in. While most reality shows out there are practically unwatchable, I find one of the first, Survivor, to have some real-life implications and some real parallels to Hunger Games. Sure, each season there are another 16 media whores trying to be the last one on the island and win a million dollars. But what we get to witness is a sometimes probing (but I’ll admit, ultimately shallow) look into human nature.Hunger Games could have been as clever or as well-crafted as Harry Potter or as powerful or as chilling as The Book Thief. But it ends up being only a YA book version of Survivor—a (sometimes probing, but ultimately shallow) guilty pleasure of a show I enjoy watching when it comes on but I know deep down I’d rather be watching Mad Men. But kudos for Collins for knowing which is going to sell more books. Millions more people tune into Survivor than either of these much more thoughtful fare. Just as millions more, I’m sure, will read Hunger Games before they try The Book Thief.

I knew about this book shortly after it hit the book store shelves. I noticed all the teens reading it in the doctor's office I worked at and just thought it must be a good book for their age. I finally asked one of my patients how the book was and I remember her gushing like I use to when the new issue of Teen Bop magazine hit the stands. All she said was something like "I love it. It's so good." I thought it was about a video game...Then the other books came out. Then the very first movie. Then Netflix got the rights to air it. I was bored one night, probably out of library books to read, so I saw it and decided to watch it. Really good movie. Not about a video game, in the least. I started seeing the shirts, towels, posters, costumes, music cd's and even notebook folders decorated with The Hunger Games stuff. Fast forward to two weeks ago... Catching Fire came out on Netflix. I watched it. Another excellent movie in the (now I knew it was a trilogy) series. Then a book friend of mine on this site told me she was reading the series, as she had not also read them yet. I liked the movies. Maybe what I will find out, what I always find out all the time when I read a book after the movie. That the book is so much BETTER than the movie, even if the movie was great. ALWAYS!!I look in my library. Nope, checked out. I'm put on a list of other teens/adults. Then today I got an email that my Amazon Unlimited subscription was going to bill my card again. It had been a few weeks since I looked at what they had. The Hunger Games was listed, the whole series was listed. SCORE!! I sync the series to my Kindle app on my tablet and off to reading I go. OMG... talk about mixed emotions. I cried, laughed, felt sorrow, rage and happiness! This book was an absolute roller coaster to read. One of those ones that goes real fast and scares the piss out of you fun roller coasters.What did Maouijenn learn...1. If you see a ton of teenagers/tweens reading the same book. READ IT!2. Buy it. Don't wait till it's your turn on the list to read it at your library.3. Read it again, know it front to back before the movie comes out.4. Gush about it with the teenagers/adults.5. Listen to the teenagers. They know good books. How does Mauoijenn feel...1. Like the book just kicked my ass with it's awesomeness and rage for not reading it until 5-6 years after it debuted...

تتحدث الرواية عن الكابيتول وهي السلطة المركزية التي تتحكم في 12 مقاطعة من العمال والمزارعين والطبقات الكادحة التي تعطي كل انتاجها للكابيتول وتأخذ هي الفتات وللمحافظة على استمرار سلطة الكابيتول تقام مسابقة كل عام يشارك فيها 24 متسابق من ال12 مقاطعة يحاربون بعضهم في ميدان اصطناعي حتى يفوز واحد منهم فقط وهو المتسابق الاخير الذي يبقى على قيد الحياة وهذا الناجي يأخذ هو ومقاطعته مكافئات ومعونات غذائية زيادة عن باقي المقاطعات وهذا مع التهديد ان المقاطعة التي تتمرد سيكون مصيرها كمصير المقاطعة 13 التي دمرها الكابيتول تماما 
  ------------تظهر الرواية أساليب الطغاة للتحكم في الشعوب اولا اشغلهم بالجوع والفقر والمرضاجعل الحصول على قوت يقيهم الموت جوعا هو محور حياتهم وعندها لا أحد يمتلك الوقت للثورة او العصيان او الاعتراض علي الظلم هذا بالطبع مع مراعاة استمرار الدعاية دائما التي تتضمن ما حدث للعاصين والمتمردين وعقابهم حتي يرتدع كل من تسول له نفسه الاعتراضولكي تكتمل السيطرة لابد من المراقبة الدائمة والدولة البوليسية والاعلام الذي يمجد المستبد ويدافع عنه ويبرر ظلمه وكتب التاريخ التي يكتبها الحاكم لتتلى على الاجيال الجديدة التي تتشبع بما فيها من افكار واخبار مصطنعة واخيرا وجود عبرة ينكمش أمامها الناس خوفا من ملاقاة نفس المصير ذاته مثل مقاطعة 13 فى الرواية او كما يقال عندنا "مش احسن ما نبقي زى سوريا والعراق " وهي عبارة تروجها السلطة استغلالا لاحداث وكوارث وقعت في بلاد اخري لذا علينا ان نحمد الله على اننا افضل حالا منهم ولا تسألني عن البلاد المتقدمة والذين افضل حالا منا بمراحل فلا تكن طماعا حاسدا كن راضيا طالما رضاؤك يعني بقاء النظاموفي الرواية لم يتوقف الاستبداد عند اجبار ابناء المقاطعات في سباق حتى الموت فقط بل انهم اجبروا الناس على الاحتفال بالمسابقة وكأنها كرنفال مفرح ! لقد سلبوهم حتى حق الحزن على اولادهم سلبوهم حتى حق الشعور بالذنب على ضعفهم وسلبيتهموكما قيل في الفيلم في مشهد غير موجود في الرواية هم يتركون المنتصر لحكمة فقد كانوا يستطيعون اعدام ال 24كلهم لارهاب المقاطعات لكنهم يتركون منتصر لأن الشعور الاقوى من الخوف هو الامل فكل مقاطعة تأمل أن يكون المنتصر منها ليتمتعوا بما يلحق ذلك من خيرات وامتيازات ولكن حتى الامل له حدود فالمطلوب هو مقدار قليل من الامل لأن اكثر من ذلك قد يقود لأشعار الناس بالقوة وامكانية تحقيق اى شئ وبالتالي يقود ذلك الى التمرد والثورة كما سنرى في الاجزاء اللاحقة من السلسلة ونلمس بأيدينا قيمة الامل عندما يقوى في قلوب الناسوأخيرا ربما تم التركيز في الرواية علي فكرة المسابقة والتشويق لكن فكرتها الاصلية عميقة للغايةالمسابقة هى المعني الظاهر لمعني اعمق بكثير هو عما تعنيه المسابقة في حقيقة الامر سواء بالنسبة للمقاطعات او بالنسبة للكابيتول .

Dystopian stories are disturbing in proportion to their plausibility. At first, The Hunger Games doesn’t seem particularly feasible, with an elaborate annual event that requires each of twelve districts in Panem (formerly North America) to offer up a boy and a girl as tributes for a match to the death in which only one will survive. The explanation given for this brutal practice is that it is the Capitol’s (not Capital’s) way of punishing and terrorizing the districts for rebelling seventy-four years ago. Far-fetched as that may seem, the idea of child sacrifice to propitiate angry gods is hardly a new one, and, horrifyingly, still occurs. And of course the ancient Romans enjoyed watching gladiatorial combat for entertainment, a reference Suzanne Collins drives home by giving many of the Capitol’s citizens Roman names. The modern twist here, though, is that the Hunger Games are a national reality TV event for the citizens of Panem. The subjects in the oppressed districts are forced to watch. The lucky citizens in the Capital, exempt from offering their children in sacrifice, enjoy the entertainment, and the bloodier the better. The Hunger Games are sort of Survivor meets Amazing Race meets Big Brother.Speaking of Big Brother, I couldn’t help but be reminded of the first season of the American version of the reality television show. During that season, the contestants were mostly fairly likeable, unwilling to engage in cutthroat antics like their more scheming counterparts on Survivor. America didn’t help much by repeatedly voting out anyone controversial or ambitious. By the end of the season, viewers were treated to scintillating scenes of the cast amiably putting together a jigsaw puzzle together. While that might speak well for humanity, it was a disaster for ratings. When the show miraculously came back for a second season, it had been completely revamped, with a far more competitive cast and nastier scenarios. Soon contestants were secretly cleaning toilets with each other’s toothbrushes, and ratings soared. The show is now in its 14th season.Would people really want to watch something as horrible as the Hunger Games? It seems ludicrous, yet round-the-clock Misery Channel coverage of events like Princess Diana’s death and the OJ Simpson trial seemed to initiate an era where we lap up disasters with an almost gleeful enthusiasm. Reality TV followed, with the nastiest, most scheming contestants bringing in the highest ratings. Perhaps it’s best not to think too hard about how such entertainment would be received.

I was going to continue Catching Fire today or tomorrow, but first I have to write this review. The Hunger Games is probably one of the strangest specimen I've ever come across. Okay, first we have Katniss. I was skeptical, but she actually is a strong female character. She doesn't take shit, she makes her own decisions, she's intelligent...and I like her. I like to read about her. I admire her for standing up for her sister -- sure, it seems like a plot device but it wasn't written in a way that came off like that. The world building was a little annoying, because it was inconsistent and didn't make much sense. Why would the districts be afraid of the Capitol? The districts import from the Capitol, so the Capitol can't do a repeat of District 13 without depriving themselves of something or the other. If all of the districts went on a strike, it'd be the Capitol saying "Ut oh". One line in the entire book stuck out to me,To this day, I can never shake the connection between thisboy, Peeta Mellark, and the bread that gave me hope, and thedandelion that reminded me that I was not doomed.The dandelion that reminded her she was not doomed? The bread that gave her hope? Oh come on, not even I am that much of a SAP.But other than that? The prose was consistent. I've heard more than once that Suzanne Collins rewrote The Hunger Games from third person to first, and for that she has a lot of my respect. But for other things...Such as...the love triangle...WHY? WHY DID YOU DO THIS? We didn't need any romance in the book! At first Peeta's crush on her was cute, and I was like "D'awww!" but then it got annoying. Especially when they began to force them together? That was just sick. Of course she's pissed at first, but then everybody keeps reminding her "Oh! It's just for the games! It's just for the games! You want to live, don't you?"ARGH!You want to know the truth about the pairings I support?! You really want to know?THE HELL WITH KATNISS PEETA/GALE!RUE AND THRESH!Yes, yes, I went there. Who cares? I'm sick of the love triangles with the heroine. Rue and Thresh are my favorite paring, got it? No moar question!Anything else I wanted to say?...Not about this book.It was good, but taking the romance from it would have made it great. Also, that ending was the worst in history. EDIT*Also, I loved Cinna.

Where’s Bear Grylls when you need him?Started this too late, I know. But better late than duct-taped to a chair and forced to listen to Rebecca Black’s “Friday” on an endless loop!I have to say that the people who organize these "games" are blood thirsty demons (you sick f*cks!)." Happy Hunger Games! Oh look fresh meat the new tribute. Rejoice everyone. Dinner entertainment is served!". The story is brilliant and got to me in more ways than one. Most of all it got me hungry. All that talk about yum food made me turn into a brain eating zombie!!! Oh nooo!!! Speaking of food and all… Will I burn in hell for thinking that all this starvation did well to the ever obese American children?Oh well… back to more serious matters…I liked Katniss’ attitude, her inner strength, the way she thinks, and the fact that she’s a realist. She has good logic and intelligence and isn’t even near the annoying level YA heroines usually reach. She is admirable and worthy of being a role model.Quick question. Where are the cameras? I imagine something similar to Spiderman Shattered Dimensions. There was a level where Deadpool trapped Spiderman on a platform in the middle of the ocean and forced him to save the crew while cameras filmed his every move. The cameras used to have propellers and were always buzzing around being annoying just like mosquitos. I doubt they’re done this way in the book but that doesn’t stop me from imagining them this way. And Deadpool being the host... The perfect show! Oprah would self-combust because of jealousy!The conclusion? A-f*ckin-mazing! Loved every second of it! Now I need a break, my brain circuits are dead because of the awesomeness that is The Hunger Games. Berries anyone?

“Happy Hunger Games! And may the odds be ever in your favor.”
Now that's a line, every one of us will forever remember. I love this book. I love dystopias, they are my personal brand of heroine. I don't know what I'd do without them. Most dystopias have that something real that some fantasy books lack and I think that's because of the drama being to much for you to notice the fact that it's all made up like every other book. Suzanne Collins has one hell of a mind and I can't begin to comprehend how she came up with such a complex storyline. She created a very badass heroine who's needed in every good book, and a guy who's like gold, literally. Twelve districts, twenty-four tributes. Katniss Everdeen & Peeta Mellark of District 12. Katniss did the unthinkable, something not done in quite a while. She volunteered as tribute when her sister's name was called up. Is there anything more selfless than the act of sacrifice in the face of tragedy? I think not.Most find Katniss spiteful and an angry person and Peeta too sweet. I just think that Katniss is a girl who's been through hell, especially after this book and if you say that Peeta has been through just as much I'll tell you that no every person has the same strength and personality. Every person is made of different material, for better or for worse.I like the way Katniss and Peeta's relationship evolves throughout the book. We see how Katniss begins to care for that stupid and careless but amazing boy and even though their romance is just a pretense she finds herself really caring for him. That was beautiful.Thanks for reading this!

I thought enough time had passed since I last read this book that it wouldn't make me cry when I read it again. Oh, how wrong I was! Because I was just as much an emotional roller coaster reading this as I was the very first time I read it. There is just something about this story. Something about Katniss and the lengths she will go to protect herself (and later Peeta) that just not only pulls on your heartstrings and makes you really feel, but it makes you think rather hard too. About things like freedom and oppression. About when it is time to say that enough is enough. This is a fantastic book that I think is important for everyone to read at least once.First reading:I picked this book up by chance a little over a year ago while I was browsing for something new to read. Right from the first chapter I was hooked. This is a story about survival, about growing up and finding yourself; dicovering who you really are by how you act in certain situations. The characters are amazing and the story and plotlines are just incredible. When Katniss is in the dome, struggling to survive; you feel as if you are with her every step of the way. You will come away from this book feeling as if you know the characters personally, you really care about them. I absolutely cannot praise this book enough for being so amazing. I would recommend this book to anyone, whatever genre of book you prefer, you will definately love this book

I freely admit that young adult novels are not my thing and, at the age of 30 something, I'm not sure that they should be. However, I appreciate that they are geared to a specific audience and they get that audience to read (and I did my time with Sweet Valley High and The Babysitter's Club *cringe* in junior high and turned out just fine--sort of). Typically, however, there's just too much teen angst, star crossed lovers, and sparkly men for my taste. Now, having said that, The Hunger Games was a great novel. Two teenagers are chosen from the twelve districts that make up Panem (what was once the U.S.) to participate in the Hunger Games, a fight to the death televised on national television as a reminder of who is really in control of this impoverished dystopian future. Suzanne Collins doesn't pull any punches--there is violence and there are several deaths in the arena, but they are portrayed with just the right touch (not too graphic, but also not too watered down). There are some nice plot twists (another complaint I often have with young adult--they're usually predictable to more sophisticated readers) and finally, finally, finally a strong female character who can take care of herself inside and outside of the arena. Cross posted at This Insignificant Cinder
