Awesome! I LOVED this book. Now where's the next one?

I bet all of you are like: PINKY YOU HAVEN'T READ THE HUNGER GAMES YET! YOU FINISHED IT NOW, HOW COULD YOU? That's like a YA Classic, what is wrong with you?  And its crazy because I haven't read this series for so long. And I owned the books for about 4 years. So i don't really deserve to have an excuse. But since there is a lot of confusion, I will tell you why I haven't read this series in so long.Year #1  One of my reasons as to why I haven't read this book yet is because the year I bought this book was the year it got severely damaged. Since I got the paperback edition, it was so easy to ruin it and crumple it. I wanted to read the book in class and took it to school on the worst possible day. It was raining and when I opened my bag, my book was soaked. I was so upset and I tried to open the book but it was so wet, the pages were ripping. So to avoid damaging it even more, I avoiding the book.Year #2  After that horrific experience, I didn't take this book to school on a rainy day. The next year, I took my book to class on the sunniest day possible. But I had a friend who thought it was funny to throw all of my things on the floor. My things as in all of my binders, my pencil case, and most importantly, my book. It was so annoying, I told her to stop and she did eventually but it was already too late. My book was so damaged that I left it at home and promised to read it when I got free time at home. I wasn't planning on reading my book at school anymore.  A few weeks later in the year, we heard about the Hunger Games movie which was going to release. Our teachers decided that it would be a great idea to take the students on a trip to watch the movie. I was so excited but I realized that I haven't read the book yet. I only had a week before we went to the trip and I was a super slow reader when I was younger. So I decided that I would read the book as fast as possible. In the end, I only managed to finish three chapters... After watching the movie, I had almost all of the first book spoiled. It was my fault of course, I didn't HAVE to go to the movies but I wanted to. I could have read faster, but I didn't. And I could have read it before this ever happened but I didn't. So it was my fault. (Til this day, I have a bookmark on Chapter 3 of the Hunger Games and I can't believe it's still in there!)Year #3  A year passed and I was getting ready to say goodbye to all of my old friends. We were all moving on to different high schools. I had it rough for the whole year, feeling sad and left out. I read books as much as I could but I never picked up the Hunger Games. I let the whole trilogy sit on my bookshelf, catching dust. I felt so out of place this year because I didn't know what I wanted for my future. (Still don't by the way!) And I had so many other book recommendations that I decided to read these books instead.  My school decided to go and watch Catching Fire and I didn't even try to finish the Hunger Games and Catching Fire. I was spoiled on almost everything of the first two books. By the time the year was over, I hadn't even thought about reading the Hunger Games.Year #4  My first year in high school, it was hard to find friends. I tried talking to people but most of them already knew each other. Everyone ignored me and I was super lonely. Luckily I had one friend, but we were lonely together. Even though we had each other, I had this hollow feeling in my stomach. I felt so sad, it's so hard to express how I felt. I never thought about books that much, sure I read a lot but I forgot all about the Hunger Games. It just continued to sit on my book shelf. Present  My second year of high school is where I lost my lonely, depressing feeling. I decided to talk more to others and be careful with who I choose to be friends with. My friend and I made so many other friends that I finally felt a little more included. I had so much fun and the is more fun that awaits me in the future. I have friends who I can talk about books with. I have friends who I can talk about anime with. I have friends who just want to talk about life. And all of these friends give me the happiness and recognition that I have never had before.  I talked to a bunch of my book buddies and I realized that I still haven't read the Hunger Games yet. I decided that it was finally time to pick up this book, instead of letting it sit on my shelf. It felt so good to finish the book and I am so annoyed with myself for not picking this up sooner. I missed out on so much and I have been spoiled on the whole series. But it doesn't matter because I have read the first book in this trilogy!And Now for the review!  I am pretty sure all of you know about the Hunger Games. But for those of you who don't know what this is about, it is about a girl named Katniss Everdeen who lives in District 12. Every year, two teenagers of the age 12 to 18 are chosen to participate in the annual Hunger Games. One girl and one guy are chosen to join the other districts in a game that is deadly. This is a game where all of the contestants have to fight til death. It is caught on camera and is known as entertainment to the Capitol. To save one that she loves, Katniss has no choice but to volunteer to participate in the Hunger Games. 
  “You don’t forget the face of the person who was your last hope.” 
 This book was so sad to read, there was so much that happened. It was so painfully good, I felt like I was in pain while reading this. I loved everything about it but it was just so sad. The things the characters have to go through and the emotions displayed among the characters was so powerful. It was interesting to read and although I knew everything that was to come, there were a few things that I didn't expect. I wish I read this book earlier, I would have enjoyed it more because I wouldn't have been spoiled.
  “Remember, we're madly in love, so it's all right to kiss me anytime you feel like it.” 
 The characters were great, I loved everything about Katniss. She was so powerful and epic, her character was just so strong. Her bow skills are amazing, and I enjoy reading about her. Peeta is another awesome character. He makes me laugh, even when depressing things are going on. He knows how to make a person laugh. Gale is another awesome character but I wish we got to read more about him. He is so nice and I love how he has Katniss's back. I love when he calls Katniss, Catnip. Prim is such a sweet character but I wish I got to read more of her too. Rue is so sweet I loved her so much. Cinna is an amazing person, I remember I felt the same way in the movies too. Haymitch is hilarious and he may not be amazing but I still like his character.
  “I am not pretty. I am not beautiful. I am as radiant as the sun.”
 The writing was beautiful, it flowed very nicely. I loved the things the characters said, the lines were so powerful. Reading about what the characters have to go through gives me the chills. It was interesting but I was scared to see what would happen next. This book was very bittersweet. 
  “Destroying things is much easier than making them.” 
 I highly recommend this book to anyone who hasn't read it yet. I doubt that there are many people who haven't read this series. I mean, it's a classic. I highly recommend this to anyone who wants a crazy book filled with adventure, and something that hits you hard in the feels. A book filled with the strongest characters that go through so much. 
  “Happy Hunger Games! And may the odds be ever in your favor.”

Goodreads doesn't need another review of The Hunger Games, probably, but I'm going to do it anyway. I read The Hunger Games a couple of months after it first came out, I think. I liked it, thought it had potential to be something more special than it was. I thought the fast pace was too fast to carve out all of the terroritories it could. Cut off the water supply and starve me out. Catching Fire came out, and then Mockingjay. Mockingjay got to me. Okay, so is is my case to read the rest of the series beyond The Hunger Games. It is worth it to read the whole story. They aren't perfect books but Suzanne Collins had something that she wanted to say and I think she did it. I used to read a fair amount of ya. I don't read it anymore. The last ya series I read was Patrick Ness's Chaos Walking. I loved the first one, liked the second one and loathed the final book. Something (and a whole lot more besides) about the supposed egoism of younger readers and heroics. I would have hated it when I was young too. I am hesitant to write off all of ya as easy route because of the assumed intelligence of the readership. But if author interactions on goodreads is any indication (the cat fights when adults call them out on their shit, for one), some authors count on the kids not giving a crap. They sell and when something sells it attracts the people who don't give a crap. Maybe they are just stories that I can't relate to anymore (there are exceptions. Melina Marchetta wrote two books that relate to my life as long as I've lived it). I want the piece in their lives, not some grand gesture that emasculates the whole thing.I liked this so much. Katniss Everdeen doesn't owe anyone else her whole life. She didn't owe it to anyone else to be the bad-ass female who comes in and saves their asses. For all that she is hoped or feared to be the girl on fire, Collins doesn't say that she had to be. My fondness of this series is a lot because of that. If I were a teenaged girl living in a war zone I would try to find a way to get used to it. Katniss had her name in the drawing for the reaping a lot of times (twenty or thirty something? Less than Gale's but not by many). She already had to live on a don't think about the future mode. What else did she have to look forward to? Working in the mines and possibly dying, like her dad. Her sister getting chosen in a reaping. If I were anyone living in the world with an abiding sense of all the shit floating on the surface I would still have to find a way to not fully think about it. If you live in a constant state of fear your heart will give out. She didn't have to be the heroine any more than anyone else from those districts did. I don't blame Katniss for caring about her sister before the rest of the districts. That's a lot for anyone's shoulders. Yeah, I did already know that. I don't leaf through history books and take it for granted the good others did before me. People dead in wars, in jail for protesting, poverty and no fun. If I'm not going to give up reading all day and the other stupid things I think are important why would I expect anyone else to? Everybody gets one life, if they are lucky. Anyway, I thought that was a worth while thing to say. The Hunger Games trilogy is about what the districts and people in history ask of people who have to give up the bits of themselves. Why do they have to look perfect while doing it? She didn't want to die. She wanted any life she could get. Wasn't volunteering for her sister enough? It's a story about one girl. There are lots of other books too and more than enough other people to think about. Collins picked Katniss because she had such a hard time getting what she could. That's gotta be true about a whole lot of other kids in the world who have to try and get what they can while they can. She had other things to say too. But that's what I got the most. Collins's books understood the weight. I would have liked the books more if she was less heavy handed about propaganda as a tool itself. They are written like best sellers, you know. Maybe I shouldn't try to review books I read years ago. But the right to NOT be a hero? Definitely. It resonates when you read all of the books and see how much Katniss loses because people thought she had to be the heroine of the world. I realize I just wrote a lot about the "message" of the books. What I liked about the books were the parts when Katniss had that little bit. Her sister, Peeta, singing, her friendship with Gale, hunting, the woods under a wire. All the moments stolen. Future? Stolen. The message in the ashes, under the brush and not blasted on mandatory television sets. I bet the other kids in the games had theirs too. I don't blame any of them for fighting. Peace of mind on the bonfire. Girl and boys on fire. (I think I would have killed myself like those girls in Battle Royale.) They didn't owe anyone else their skin. If they meet in a red room after the games they would not blame each other. The small lives for the bigger? They weren't volunteers. I know I couldn't ask it, anyway. Not for me.I'm no hero.P.s. Sorry if you're sick of The Hunger Games!

Why in the world did I wait so much to read this book? I seriously should be punished for this.The Hunger Games is one of the best dystopian novels I’ve read until now, maybe the best. It was so well done and interesting and fast paced that I didn’t want to put the book down but keep reading and keep reading.I had watched the movie and I had thought that it was okay but nothing special after all and I couldn’t understand why people were raving and raving about it. Now that I read the book I am the one who’s raving about it and wouldn’t stop talking for days.The world building was impressive and magnificent. Twelve districts and the Capitol, Panem. Every year they draw out a boy and a girl from each district to join the Hunger Games: all the tributes have to train, do interviews and then they are left in an arena to survive and kill each other. There can be only one winner. They are constantly watched by all the population which can follow every day the Hunger Games on special screens put in every district. There’s no privacy and no mercy. You can’t afford to say what you think or show your true feelings but you have to keep up to pretenses to survive in this deadly jungle and try not to lose yourself along the way.The Hunger Games are the tool to show people that they are nothing but pawns in the ends of the system, to remember of the past wars and what the Capitol is able to do just for entertainment. They are the spectacularization of cruelness, violence and strength. The Gamemakers, the sponsors and their gifts, the parade and the mentors, the rules and the history… Everything was so clear and detailed that it seemed more true than ever and while reading you can’t help but having a dreadful feeling that this could all be real one day.Now, on to the characters. Haymitch was just amazing. He’s the mentor of the tributes from District 12, he has gone through unimaginable horrors and won the Hunger Games and now he has to relive this every year. He is always drunk, trying to send the pain away but this time he could actually have winners and he knows what to do to let them shine and capture the attentions of the sponsors. He can also be lots of fun.Katniss was… complicated. She grew up taking care not only of herself but of her entire family after her father died in the coal mine. With her friend Gale, she spends her days hunting in the woods outside the fence, risking her life because it is forbidden but it’s also the only way not to starve. When her twelve-year-old sister Prim is called as tribute, Katniss volunteers to protect her and this was such a strong and full of love gesture. She was courageous, specially knowing she probably wouldn’t have made it back. But she did it anyway and it moved me. She’s smart and unbeatable with bow and arrows and that’s how she plans to survive in the arena. Plus, she’s the girl on fire. Anyway, I didn’t like her as much as I expected to. I was confused by her uncertainty about her feelings. She keeps comparing Peeta and Gale and that sent me astray because there is not much about Gale in this first book and I wasn’t able to pick a side as it usually happens in these love triangle situations. Peeta, on the other hand, was so sweet. He is conscious of his limits and his abilities and in the arena he did whatever he had to do to keep Katniss safe because he truly loved her and that made me roll my eyes every time Katniss wondered about Peeta’s feelings. How couldn’t she see it? He was just being himself while she was pretending to love him back to maintain the star crossed lovers’ illusion. I know she had to do it keep living and make it home to her family but I just couldn’t bring myself to like her.I was really impressed by the author’s ability to keep the story interesting throughout all the book. For more than one hundred pages, the reader is left only with Katniss and her thoughts and it could have easily become boring and flat without any dialogues but it never did.I was also taken aback by the contrast between the poverty of the districts and the uncontrolled luxury of the Capitol, where the Hunger Games truly are just an entertainment while teenagers are losing their lives for others’ fun.Surely, I can’t wait to read the second book, hoping to better understand Katniss and her doubts but also I want more of this dreadful world. Does it sound strange?Happy Hunger Games and may the odds be ever in your favor!

The thing is, i enjoyed reading the whole series and i read them so fast i thought i should wait to make the reviews. I was almost sure that my spontaneous enthusiasm would cover up all the flaws. When you read a book in a day and then read the sequel the next day and then the final book two days later than that, well, you can never be sure. So i thought i should process it first, realize what it had and made me like it so much. First of all, YA is not my kind of gerne. I've been disapointed by several things that i've read and what makes this book stand out of the rest YA that i have read is that, not only i loved reading it, but also that i still love it AFTER reading it.I cannot really judge Katniss. She is 16 and 16 is a stupid age on its own (i am sorry 16 year olds, i have been there, i know, you will understand when you get older). She is not a kid and she is not an adult and she is messed up and no matter how furious some of her choices made me, i will always like her. She made mistakes and she was not perfect and there were so much going on that she couldn't control. She seemed human and i like it when the characters in the book seem real and hurt and damaged when they actually are.I didn't really care about the romance, i believe it would be better if they were just friends. I have issues with the first person narrative in general but i don't mind it being there in the hunger games cz, it serves the book. It is not perfect by any means, but it works just fine and it feels just fine. The world building and the characters we are intoduced to are only through Katniss but even though i wanted more of everything, i liked everything cz not knowing what is going on IS part of the world building of the hunger games.Overall, the writing was kind of childish but it felt ok (i guess i am fangirling now), some likeable characters--> checked, the absolute form of fasicm and evil that rules eveyone and everything--> checked, totally enjoyable while reading it--> checked. Will i read it again in the future? Probably YES <3

Kids killing kids…for the “entertainment” of others…that’s what you get here. Did I like the concept of the book? Absolutely not, however, it was well written and despite being distraught, I was also intrigued, and kept on reading. I think because I’m a parent, just the thought of losing a child in any circumstance is inconceivable, but to have them taken from you, knowing that the likelihood of them returning is slim to none, would numb me beyond reason. That’s all I could think about while reading this, was the families of these kids and the “ultimate” televised death show that their children were forced to participate in, and there was nothing they could do to stop it. Needless to say, I was emotionally drained at the end of this book and there are 2 more to read. My therapy bill is going to be enormous. Yet, I find the need to follow this through to the end, morbid curiosity I guess. I really don’t have much more to say, other than if you decide to read this book, be prepared, what happens here is brutal, disturbing, heartbreaking, and draining. Human nature will have you flipping the pages, you know, the awful in life that pulls at us to watch even though it pains us, the wreck on the highway, this is that car accident.

I have tried to review this book many times but just could not string the words together. It has attained an iconic status among YA readers (including my son, at whose insistence I read this), while many serious readers have trashed it completely. When I look back on my reading experience, I find that I am caught between these two extreme positions.The Positives:1. A strong female protagonist and her "weak" love interest. I liked Katniss (in this book at least: in subsequent ones, her character was seriously weakened, IMO) and I absolutely loved Peeta. I have a soft spot for men who are not macho and strong, but soft and caring.2. The arena of the games. It is a video gamer's paradise, and it was interesting to see the kids devising strategies to survive.The Negatives:1. The story and the world which it takes place in. To me, a society which exists on repression and periodically exhorts its youth to murder one another as a way of coming up in the world simply does not seem credible.2. The narration. Very ordinary.Considering that this is an adventure yarn aimed at young readers, I will plump for three stars.

5 stars – Dystopian Fiction/Sci-Fi/Urban Fantasy/YAI’ve had this on my TBR Mountzilla forever and there are already a zillion reviews, so I’ll keep this succinct.There’s definite justification for all the hype and popularity. The Hunger Games is brilliant, brutal, poignant, gruesome, disturbing, and thought-provoking with jaw-dropping suspense and shocking twists.I can’t wait to see how they translate Katniss’s complex personality mix of courage, vulnerability, constancy, raw fear, and strength and depict such objectionable, emotional, provocative, and appalling cruelty and violence toward kids in a PG-13 movie.

I have now read this book three times (most recently after seeing the movie version because I wanted to compare the adaptation) and each time I cannot put it down. Katniss Everdeen is such a strong, grounded character, and the survival scenes in the arena are so compelling that the book becomes the same kind of addictive entertainment that it seems to be warning against.The Hunger Games is the best book in the series, and I wouldn't be surprised if, in a few decades, it gets the same canonical treatment that "Lord of the Flies" does.Third read: March 2012Second read: September 2010First read: October 2009

Looking back on this book, I can no longer let my previous rating and review stand. I haven't read it recently enough to re-review, but I recommend this chapter-by-chapter deconstruction for a bit of light reading - in particular, the writer's points about protagonist-centered morality and the weird gender dynamics in this book are obvious to me in retrospect and merit the loss of yet another star.

The more I read the books and think about it, the more I start to believe that the rebellion really started with Peeta when he said he didn’t want to be “just a piece in their Games.” Rue was the catalyst that forcefully spurned Katniss into action. Only then did Katniss understand what Peeta had been saying on the rooftop. I think the spark started during that chat and caught fire with Katniss during the Games after what happened to Rue.
“Happy Hunger Games! And may the odds be ever in your favor.”
An excellent book, couldn't put it down! :)

“Quando arriverà il momento sono sicuro che ucciderò come chiunque altro. Non posso darmi per vinto senza combattere. Solo continuo ad augurarmi di trovare un modo per... per dimostrare a quelli di Capitol City che non sono una loro proprietà. Che sono più di una semplice pedina.” Se avete la cittadinanza dello stato di Panem e vivete nella parte più povera del Dodicesimo Distretto, il destino non è stato molto benigno con voi. E se poi siete ancora degli adolescenti con l’acne, c’è il rischio che oltre ad andare a scuola vi tocchino delle alzatacce per cacciare nei boschi, piazzare trappole per conigli, fare affari al mercato nero e sfamare la vostra famiglia tutte le sere. Cacciare nei boschi è illegale, si capisce, ma voi dovete pur mangiare. Non si soccombe alla miseria, agli sberleffi del destino, se pure non è stato benigno con voi. Una volta nello stato di Panem c’erano tredici distretti. Adesso sono solo dodici, e il vostro è il più miserevole, il più deriso di tutti. Il Tredicesimo Distretto, qualche sfortunato anno fa, ha deciso che non ci stava più a soddisfare i capricci del governo centrale, ma quelli di Capitol City, centro pulsante del potere, non l’hanno presa troppo bene. Adesso il Tredicesimo Distretto non esiste più e quelli di Capitol City hanno ben pensato di ricordare a tutti gli altri il perché. Ed ecco il motivo per cui ogni anno si tengono gli Hunger Games, cruenta forma di tributo imposta ai cittadini e allo stesso tempo reality show, spettacolo agghindato per far piacere a quelli della capitale. Se siete ancora degli adolescenti con l’acne, sapete che quest’anno agli Hunger Games potreste esserci voi. Può capitare che il vostro nome venga estratto da una boccia di vetro insieme a quello di un compagno, che siate caricati su un treno e spediti come un pacchetto postale verso il mondo civilizzato. Lì vi renderanno presentabili e carini, vi insegneranno come parlare e camminare, vi riempiranno lo stomaco di tutti i cibi che nel distretto non sognavate neppure. E poi, dopo un periodo di addestramento e di vacanza, vi sigilleranno in un’arena insieme ad altri ventitré concorrenti, due per ciascun distretto. E vi lasceranno scannarvi e combattere finché ne rimarrà uno solo. Telecamere piazzate ovunque vi mostreranno a milioni di telespettatori mentre dormite, mangiate, soffrite la fame e la disidratazione, scalate alberi, fuggite dagli incendi, vi uccidete l’un l’altro con molta spettacolarità e violenza. Fuori intanto fioccano le scommesse: più bravi siete, più vi guadagnate sponsor. Meglio riuscite a fingere, più il pubblico vi ama. Ma non c’è tanto tempo per le moine: non vogliamo che una lancia vi trafigga da parte a parte mentre fate un inchino a beneficio dello show. Suzanne Collins costruisce la sua storia con molta intelligenza, trascinando il lettore nel vortice dell’azione senza annoiarlo mai. La parola chiave di questo romanzo è “essenzialità”. Essenziale è lo stile, asciutto fino all’osso, minimale, eppure mai insoddisfacente. I personaggi si definiscono più attraverso le azioni che attraverso i propri pensieri. Le informazioni essenziali sono centellinate qua e là, sulla base della loro funzionalità alla narrazione, e questo conferisce un ritmo veloce, intrigante. E giacché essenzialità non è sinonimo di povertà, il romanzo non manca di commuovere e di turbare e vi trovate con gli occhi lucidi senza capire bene il perché. Le pagine si illuminano di squallore e non possono fare a meno di prendervi alla gola. Essenziale è quello che la Collins mette in ballo. Ritorna alle origini, alla lontana storia dell’uomo o a quella storia che si svolge tutti i giorni, spesso lontano da noi. Tornano in gioco gli istinti basilari, gli istinti ferini che sempre ci muovono: la fame, la sete, la lotta per la sopravvivenza, l’istinto di conservazione, la furia, la vendetta. Valori di tutti i giorni, come l’amore e l’amicizia, vengono messi in discussione, minati da questi bisogni fondamentali e quasi da essi annullati. È difficile essere umani, quando ci viene chiesto di essere animali. È difficile, ma non impossibile, e Katniss, Peeta, Rue sono qui a dimostrarci proprio questo. Tra mille dubbi circa l’autenticità dei propri sentimenti, le proprie reazioni ponderate di fronte alle telecamere, sono qui anche a dirci che, se il destino non è benigno con noi, noi possiamo essere benigni con gli altri. Possiamo anche non fidarci completamente l’uno dell’altro, ma ciò non significa che dobbiamo essere disumani l’uno contro l’altro. Anche se il mondo in cui viviamo pretende bagni di sangue e sospetto e tradimenti, anche se ci vuole come merce commercializzabile, anche se ci vuole silenziosi ed inermi. Se avete la cittadinanza dello stato di Panem e vivete nel Dodicesimo Distretto e siete sopravvissuti agli Hunger Games, è chiaro che silenziosi ed inermi non potrete esserlo mai più. Troppo avete visto, troppo avete sentito e provato in quell’arena fredda come una notte novembrina e torrida come un deserto. Inizierete a porvi delle domande, a camminare con la testa alta, a non permettere che vi trasformino in giocattoli privi di una volontà e di un passato. No, io non credo che sareste disumani mai più. E saprete volgere il vostro furore verso i veri responsabili della vostra condizione. Non il destino, perché il destino non esiste. Ma uomini e donne come voi, che a destino si atteggiano senza averne alcun diritto.

First, I want to make it clear that I do think The Hunger Game(HG) is a well written story.But I still think Battle Royale by Koushun Takami is better.Once you had seen impressive things before, you simply won't be so easily thrilled by similar, tamer things.In the fictional universe of The Hunger Games, America had long been ruled by a totalitarian government. Said government divided its subjects into two classes, citizens from the privileged Capital, where people enjoyed wealth and power. The 12 Districts, where most citizens were forced into hard labors and starvation. Since the 12 Districts, along with the destroyed 13th District had once allied together and tired to rebel against the Capital, once the rebellion was suppressed, the Capital brought up The Hunger Games as a punishment for the failed Districts. A game that forced every district to select two teenagers and took them to an isolated Stadium. The selected teenagers were trained and forced to kill one another until there was only one survivor left, while the entire nation watched on.The heroine Katniss was a fatherless girl from the 12th District, when her younger sister was selected for the latest Hunger Game, she replaced her sister and went to the Capital with a boy, Peeta, who was also selected. During the training and preparation for the Game, Katniss formed a friendship with Peeta, who she must eventually kill along with the other teenagers if she wanted to stay alive and go home to her loved ones;and Haymitch, trainer of both Katniss and Peeta, also a former Winner of the Game.The Hunger Games, first book of The Hunger Games series, is cleverly plotted and well written, main characters like Katniss, Peeta and Haymitch are people you can very well related to. The ending is just brilliant. The action is quite good for a YA novel too.What I find lacking in The Hunger Games, probably is a bit of emotional depths and satire.I don't mean to say HG has entirely no emotional depth, for example Katniss' loyalty to her sister and mother, and the friendship/trust between her, Peeta and Haymitch looks pretty realistic. But once the killing started, you can't help feeling like you're watching an episode of a very twisted, deadly and violent Survivor reality TV game show.You just know that Katniss isn't going to die, and somehow she'd find a way to trick or kill her opponents no matter how strong or well trained those opponents might be. BECAUSE WE KNOW SHE'S THE HEROINE AND SHE CAN'T DIE TILL THE VERY END. So frankly it's a bit hard to feel TOO worry about her.As to those opponents mentioned above, they look more like opponents or pawns in a game show than a bunch of real people. We know hardly anything about them, probably saves for the little girl from the 11th District whom Katniss befriended and tried to save. Those other kids from the other Districts hardly had any personality or emotion that we might recognize, so it became difficult to feel anything for them when they died or when Katniss or Peeta was forced to kill them.We never got to feel much of the moral dilemma and guilt Katniss and Peeta had to endure when they were forced to kill other people, because those who died under their hands had basically nothing to do with them (again saves for the little girl from the 11th District). All of the tributes only first saw one another a few weeks before the Game starts after all of them were certain they must kill all of the other people in order to survive. The rule of the Hunger Game makes it crystal clear that they're supposed to be enemies, not friends and buddies.That's when I want to bring up Battle Royale. In my opinion, it's clear that BR had gone into a more hideous, uncomfortable area than HG by making the teenagers who were forced to kill one another classmates. It's a bunch of students who had known each other for at least a few years, who were familiar with one another, someone you see everyday going to school and using the same classroom. Some of them had even became friends and/or lovers. And you got those students battling one another till the last one standing? Then you got some real satire, cruelty, moral dilemma and vivid human drama going on, instead of just an episode of reality game show which the goal is to survive and to 'take care' of those opponents whom no one really cares about.More disturbing still, in BR the movie, they had the students' very own teacher to be the executive of such unimaginable ordeal, the satire on adults' violence became really heart-felt since teachers are supposed to be protectors of their students.Back to HG, despite the well written story, the author offers us little space to explore the social, institutional violence and injustice that had allowed the Hunger Games to be operated for years. Maybe those issues are saved up for the latter books, I'm not sure.My suggestion: It's a good book for teenagers or mature-enough kids; but for adults, it might be just a little too tamed. So do consider borrowing the book, you don't have to buy it.Edited@17/11/2015: here's an article to address the problems of Katniss being viewed as a strong female/role models for girls: http://thelastpsychiatrist.com/2012/0...Review for book 2: https://www.goodreads.com/review/show...

I was up till five in the morning, reading about Katniss Everdeen and her participation in the Hunger Games. Katniss lives in District 12 of a country called Panem, which used to be North America a long time ago. It's a dystopian world, one burdened by oppression and poverty. The capital of Panem is a wealthy place called The Capitol, which rules the remaining twelve districts with an iron hand. Once there were 13 districts, but then there was an uprising and District Thirteen was completely destroyed, and the rebellion crushed. To remind the other districts of their helplessness and subservience, the Capitol holds the annual Hunger Games, a sort of reality show-cum- gladiator ring, where two tributes from each district battle it out to the death until the last man (or woman) standing is declared the victor.Suzanne Collins builds this dystopian society with flawless delicacy. The people are bitter and oppressed, but at the same time, the tone isn't completely dark and depressed. There is an air of resignation, even a sort of acceptance for a way of live that has been the norm for as long as most people remember.The barbarity of the Hunger Games is balanced perfectly against the flightiness of people from the Capitol. There is the barest hint of a moral about oppression and suppression, but it is handled with the lightest of touches. And some of Collins' plot handling is beyond superb. She takes a sixteen year old girl and puts her in a situation where she has to kill twenty three other people in order to stay alive. She makes this girl humane, but not too soft-hearted. She's tough, and pragmatic but she has touches of tenderness. And so, despite the savagery of the entire situation, thanks to her skillful characterization, we fall in love with Katniss.It's not that Katniss doesn't kill in the Hunger Games. It's how she kills, without ever coming off as violent or inhumane, that reveals the true depth of Collins' talent. She kills for vengeance, in self-defence, out of pity. But never, ever does she kill offensively, with the sole aim of advancing herself into the ranks of glory.And Peeta. What can I say about Peeta without coming off as a gooey, big-eyed teenager (which I most definitely AM NOT) with a massive crush? It's not the romantic angle of the Katniss-Peeta relationship that has me so moved. It's just the way he's drawn, an idealist with so much compassion, and a sly sense of humour. For the first time in a long time, I found myself considering a male romantic lead as a person in his own right, instead of merely an accessory of the heroine. I'm not sure how much of a role Gale will be playing in the future books, I scent a triangle ahead, but I hope Suzanne Collins handles that with as much panache as she's handled the rest of the book.This books is definitely one of my top picks for the first millenial decade, and a treat you should not miss, if you haven't indulged already.

As dystopias go, Panem is vividly disturbing. We will observe it from the perspective of Katniss, a resourceful teenager effectively staving off her own starvation and that of her family in deprived and depressed District 12, a coal mining area very distant from the prosperous Capitol. These circumstances vaguely echo the disparity between London and the deprived and persecuted coal mining areas in the North of England. The scrabble to survive is barely leavened, and severely exacerbated by the annual enforced bloodbath and grotesque spectacle of the Hunger Games.Apart from being a little emotionally clueless (I can relate…), Katniss is the sort of kickass female protagonist every YA novel richly deserves, and it’s impossible not to root for her no matter what terrible things she’s forced to do (actually I felt that Collins did a lot to cushion the blow on that front, so I guess I’d feel able to recommend this to older teens). The emotionally smart, love-struck, artistic Peeta is the perfect foil for her (and I enjoyed the against-type gender dynamics throughout).Katniss experiences luxury in the Capitol, but to Collins’ credit, this luxury is not edifying, and the people wallowing in it are either unredeemably awful, completely vacuous, drowning their wits in alcohol, or quietly in revolt. While gender was de-emphasised in the scrabbling-to-survive context of District 12, in the Capitol patriarchal beauty standards suddenly impose themselves and Katniss is “horrible” until she has been stripped of hair from the neck down. The only things cast in a positive light in the Capitol are the food and Katniss’ mysterious, brilliant designer, Cinna, who seems intriguing and potentially rebellious enough to suggest a reappearence in the sequels. The Gamemakers, on the other hand, are repulsively decadent, and completely objectify the “tributes”. Katniss’ depilation is a small aspect of the Gamemaker’s agenda of dehumanisation, which culminates in the arena. Katniss, Peeta, Rue, and even Thresh, by resisting in their limited capacities the Gamemakers’ attempt to turn them into murderous (literal) tributes, an atrocity exhibition, undermine the state’s power to terrorise the population into submission. This is a story about commodified violence as a weapon of domination in which flowers (and compassion) as well as arrows are weapons of resistance. And, in clever ways, love wins again and again and again…

I honestly fail to see why so many people think this is a good book. From what I understand, this is Collins' first attempt (note the word "attempt") at a novel and it clearly shows. The idea itself is a cliche, and the only way to make a cliche work is to breathe new life into it. Unfortunately, Collins' plot is as unoriginal and contrived as the concept. Additionally, her characterizations are completely inconsistent. None of the characters (with perhaps, the exception of Peeta) had a solid or consistent personality. Katniss, especially, was like a blank, empty slate. She was as flat as a paper drawing.Additionally, Collins' writing style leaves much to be desired. Her vocabulary was elementary and her sentence structures were entirely unexciting. And from what I could see, absolutely no one copy edited the manuscript. If someone had, the myriad obvious mistakes would have been caught — mistakes that included: starting sentences with a figure instead of spelling out the number; mixing tenses; and screwing up the difference between "nauseous" and "nauseated."Maybe I'm crazy. But making it to the end of this "book" was like pulling out teeth: nothing short of agonizing.

(This is an updated book review. To view the original one, click HERE)5/5 STARS!!It took me a long time to start this book because of my long TBR pile. It stayed for a year on my bookshelf unopened. I just realized that I want to read it after I watched Mockingjay Pt 1.I found the book to be well written with a fantastic pacing. Their is violence in there, but not so over the top as to be distracting.This story was truly life changing. The premise of the story alone is enough for anyone to realize this will not be your run of the mill young adult novel.Overall, The Hunger Games is a fascinating read, even if the concept of a corrupt government abusing it's control over its citizens has been done in similar ways before, this book is certainly the most detailed and memorable one of the lot.

1 down, 2 to go! I'm having a great time reading this series again! As much as I love the movies, the books are so descriptive! And I forgot that the wolf mutts had the tributes eyes! I love this series!

I can't remember the last time a book had me so addicted. The Hunger Games is one of those rare books you stay up way too late reading, knowing you're going to pay for it the next day but not caring. Absolute perfection.
Loved it! A great story. I am so happy I am too old to play.
Loved this book. It's well written and I felt immersed in the world of Panem, not really a place you'd like to live but a great story.

OMGosh! :)Just watched the movie!I know a lot of you have already watched it but heck I was still excited!BEST MOVIE ADAPTATION OF A BOOK EVER.Felt that it was as close as the movie is going to get to the book!Well. :)So excited for the next movie.Will have to read Catching Fire soon.-------------------Dystopian books?Not really my thing.Wither was the first dystopian novel I've read and it seriously gave me a headache.It wasn’t because that book was poorly written but because I was just not comfortable with the fact that young girls were getting kidnapped and sold to rich boys in order to procreate.I have no issues with teen pregnancy but then the kidnapping part and them being sold was a lot like prostitution to me.There were a couple of instances where I swore I was going to put Wither down but I didn’t because I thought it would get better.It didn’t.After that I stirred away from dystopian books until Hunger Games.Hunger Games was another dystopian novel.This book has been on my to-read pile for so long that I almost forgot about it.Sure there were good reviews about it but since it was dystopian, I had to skip it.Then I saw the movie trailer.I thought the trailer was cool but still I didn’t pick the book up.I was still hesitant about the whole dystopian thing.I was afraid that it would turn out just like the other book I read.March 2012 was nearing.The movie was going to be in the big screen soon and that's when I told myself that I had to read it now!So I picked up my copy and began reading it after I got home from work.Chapter 1.OMG!Chapter 2.OMG! OMG!Chapter 3.OMG! OMG! OMG!Then I finished it!I would like to give this book a round of applause! A standing ovation if it's even possible.HUNGER GAMES was AWESOME!One of the best books I have read so far.It had all the elements that make a book fascinating.Despite it being a dystopian novel, I still love it.Completely loved and adored it.The setting of the Hunger Games was in a place called Panem.WHERE IS PANEM?Panem is a future nation that came from the ruins of what we all know as North America.It had twelve districts that were governed by the Capitol.Because of an upheaval that happened before against the Capitol, the Hunger Games was born.The Hunger Games would require tributes –- a boy and a girl whose ages were between 12 and 18 – and they will be chosen to represent their district on the Hunger Games.WHAT HAPPENS DURING THE HUNGER GAMES?The 24 tributes from the different districts had to face each other in the arena.They had to fight for survival.They had to outwit each other.They had to think before they act.They had to show everybody that they are the best.Why?Because only one of them will come out of the Arena.ALIVE.WHAT’S THE STORY ABOUT?The main protagonist is Katniss Everdeen who I loved almost instantly.She was a perfect example of a girl strengthened by poverty.She lived in District 12, which I think was poorest of all the districts.The time to choose the tributes came.Prim, her younger sister was chosen.Katniss loved her sister and volunteered herself in exchange for her sister.Katniss was now District 12’s tribute along with Peeta Mellark who was not really a stranger to her.The chosen tributes were then transported to the Capitol for the Hunger Games.They were prepped and introduce to everyone.Bets were on.People had their own bets to cheer on.Katniss was struggling.Katniss was scared but she couldnt let it show.She had to be strong.Who will she trust?What will she do to survive?How will she prevent herself from getting killed?The Games will change you.REACTION AFTER FINISHING IT:Flabbergasted. I think that is one word that would describe how I felt about the Hunger Games.It was full of action, suspense, drama, romance.What more could you ask for?Katniss was the perfect heroine.She is my type of lead female character.She had this courage in her that lights up like fire.Katniss, the Girl on Fire.I adore her.She wasn’t weak like most of the lead characters in YA books.She was strong, brave and courageous.She was also smart.She uses her head.I hate depended lead characters and Katniss was not one of them.While I can go on and on regarding my crush on Katniss, her male counterpart actually caught me too.Peeta Mellark, the baker boy who burned bread to give to his childhood crush. How sweet!Peeta was not as skilled as Katniss but he does everything to protect her nonetheless.Peeta.Peeta.Peeta.I hope you’re mine.You are a paradigm of a perfect boyfriend.Katniss and Peeta had perfect chemistry.You will always come across a book where the characters blend together perfectly.Katniss and Peeta were one of them.They were a smokin’ couple. (They were literally a smoking couple during the introduction of the tributes right? :D)Anyways, Peeta and Katniss were made to be together.I did have Katniss for hurting Peeta! Arrrg,I was told that the concept of the Hunger Games was not entirely original.I heard that somehow it was a bit similar to the Lord of Flies but I haven’t read that so I couldn’t say if it is true nor not but still I fell in love with the book either way.It was a mixture of everything I wanted and not knowing I wanted in one book.Not only did it have the action, romance, exceptional writing style that I wanted, I also felt there was a deeper meaning to the book that was hidden between the lines.The society that Katniss belonged to was very similar to the one that we have now.The status quo remained.District 12 symbolizes the underprivileged ones.It symbolizes the oppressed ones who didn’t have enough food to feed their families.It symbolizes the ones who had to take desperate measures to survive.The Capitol represents the rich people.They control the least fortunate ones with their money.They think they’re superior.I am not stereotyping.Not all rich people are bad while not all poor people are good either.It’s just a thought anyways.Don’t burn me at stake because I said that about the rich people. I know a lot of rich people who were more humble than me.I am not rich to make things clear.Hahaha.I’m part of District 12.Enough of that already.I didn’t know what came over me.THE HUNGER GAMES easily became my favorite.I’ve learned my lesson not to judge a book by its GENRE.If you are looking for an interesting read with a twist then I recommend this book.THE HUNGER GAMES did not disappoint.If this book could talk, I’m sure it will slap me in the face and say “Take that you b*tch for thinking that I am not worth your time reading!”Hahaha.I LOVE LOVE LOVE THE HUNGER GAMES!I can’t wait for the movie.A PERFECT 5!PS:The movie is coming out next year.I thought the girl who played Katniss seemed to fit the part.I am just not too sure about the guy who played Peeta.I had a different Peeta in mind.Maybe Chace Crawford or Alex Pettyfer?Not expecting him.I thought Peeta was supposed to be blond anyways?!ARRRRR!I really can't wait for the movie!

Unless you've been living under a rock for the past five or six years, you already know that THE HUNGER GAMES has been a publishing and motion picture phenomenon. The book itself is a fast-paced, nail-biting, extremely compelling read, with an extraordinary premise and the kind of gritty, underdog characters that easily capture the reader's interest and emotions. But there is something more going on here, something that I dearly hope readers will take the time and effort to truly comprehend. If you are willing to actually scratch the surface of THE HUNGER GAMES, you will see it bleed.The feeling that there was something important that kept narrowly but consistently evading me dogged me throughout the book. At first, I thought it was just that there is something uniquely and profoundly chilling about watching a child deliberately hunt down and kill another child. That aspect of the book made me feel dirty, like someone who should be respectfully averting their gaze from a gruesome car crash but couldn't quite tear their eyes away. That was part of it, but it wasn't all of it. Next, I thought the thing that kept nagging at the edges of my mind had something to do with the grotesqueness of these young human sacrifices being first primped, pampered, and made into beautiful and desirable celebrities before being fed to the wolves. The cult of celebrity is something I abhor, and I could see in THE HUNGER GAMES a very apt and poignant allegory for the way in which young celebrities in particular are "eaten alive" by the entertainment industry. Yes, this was also part of it, but it still wasn't all of it.It wasn't until I read a short interview with the author at the end of the book that the final piece fell into place. In this interview, Suzanne Collins described what had first given her the idea for a story that became THE HUNGER GAMES. She had been sleepily channel surfing late one night and kept flipping back and forth between the images of a reality TV show in which children were competing for prizes or prestige and the images of a news report on child soldiers, an appallingly real condition that exists in many parts of our world today, in which children are forced to become soldiers fighting real wars against each other. That was when I finally realized exactly what I had found so unsettling about reading this book. It wasn't just the disturbing IDEA of children killing each other, it wasn't just what the book had to say, ALLEGORICALLY, about the ruthlessness of the cult of celebrity. No, what really made my skin crawl and my mind shrink back defensively as I read was the apparently subconscious knowledge that THE HUNGER GAMES IS NOT FICTION.The characters of this book may be invented, the plot of this book may be invented, the book may be set several centuries in the future, but the conditions under which this story develops are right here, right now. In THE HUNGER GAMES, some of the child sacrifices have trained their whole lives for the competition and enter it almost willingly, whereas others are simply forced to compete and enter the arena feeling nothing but terror. In some parts of our world, children compete in what they view as a willing manner for status, image, and celebrity, whereas in other parts of our world, children are kidnapped, contained in a certain area, and forced to either kill each other or be killed. These things are not fiction, these things are happening all day, every day. They're happening as you read this. They're happening as you wake up in the morning. They're still happening as you go to sleep at night.It's easy to read THE HUNGER GAMES with a chill running down your spine at the thought of children fighting to the death - for status or simply for their lives - but the reassuring thought in the back of your mind that "It's just a story." But as I finally came to realize, the most important thing about THE HUNGER GAMES is that it's NOT just a story. It's a very timely warning that at every moment, in every part of the world, we are allowing our children to be exploited in the most brutal, gruesome, and shameful ways imaginable - ways so shameful, in fact, that we can really only face up to them when they are presented to us in the guise of fiction.

I wanted to read this book long time ago, literally years ago and yet I never did. Then the movie came out and I got annoyed. I had planned to read this eventually! And then there was this problem that I don't like watching the movie before reading the book. The book version is always my priority since some movies are capable of ruining amazing stories. And I can't enjoy a book with inaccurate spoilers chasing each other in my head. Anyway, I ended up watching the movie first and then I pushed myself into reading the book and despite knowing most of it, I ended up loving it. The movie is really good but I think it works better as a companion to the book. Everything has more depth and feeling in the book and there are very important details that aren't in the movie. I knew the events and I still cried when the little symbol of innocence perished and joined history.I really liked Katniss in this book. She was a strong heroine indeed. I liked her in the book better than the movie. In the movie, she is trying hard to be very cool while in the book, she is simply herself. An imperfect but strong 16 years old girl that still needs to grow. I could forgive her flaws considering her age and her situation. I liked the way her mind worked in this book. That she was antisocial, realistic and not very good with words.I am generally not a big fan of triangles but it didn't annoy me in this book and the story didn't focus on it. Thank god for that. I liked Gale, he is perhaps everything that many teenage girls find desirable but I couldn't help but love Peeta. The little boy with bread! He is perhaps too good to be true but I love him for this very reason. After all, a lot of things are a little unbelievable in this book. Why can't he be when it comes to his love for Katniss, the little girl who created the spark?I liked many of the supporting characters and while the story progressed, I came to really care about their fates. Creating interesting supporting characters with depth always wins me over. Effie, Haymitch, Rue, Cinna, Thresh...all of them are quite unforgettable. I have to mention that Effie and Rue gained very special places in my heart for being very different and unique characters.I really liked it that Katniss didn't become the spark by herself. She wouldn't have been as powerful without Cinna to dress her, Peeta to love her and Rue to seek her company. There is an entire world created in this book and characters equally influence each other. I love it when multiple characters work together to achieve something. It is really annoying when underage children save the world while all the adults hide under their beds. This wasn't the case here and I am grateful for that. The dystopia depicted in here isn't very realistic. I see a lot of problems with this government and the way it operates and frankly I don't understand how these districts did not rise against it much sooner but I tried to accept it and the book was well-written enough for me to immerse myself in the story. There is also the fact that most dystopian societies are symbolic and do have the tendency to exaggerate since they want to draw attention to certain issues and their consequences.I can also see the similarity with Battle Royale but I usually don't mind similarities that much as long as the story works and contains enough originality. I think it takes a lot of imagination and brilliance to build up a whole new world and a very different story line around a similar idea.You know what bugged me the most here? That years into the future, with all the technologies available, they still use WAX to remove extra body hair! WAX! Seriously Capitol? You don't have a painless permanent method? I am so disappointed in you. Hell, I am disappointed in humanity!With that out of my system, I will finish this review by saying that the story is gripping, emotional and hard to forget and I really enjoyed reading it. I believe in happy endings. I hope humanity wins this war and changes this violent cruel dystopia into a better place to live in. To hope and humanity!(And to something better than WAX!)

  A SIMPLE GUIDE TO HELP YOU READ THE HUNGER GAMES TRILOGY :
If you haven't read this book yet, and you intend to do so, you can follow those simple rules:A: BUY THE WHOLE SERIES AT ONCE.Beware: The Hunger Games trilogy is like a drug : HIGHLY ADDICTIVE! (no kidding)This will save you several trips to the bookstore or the inconvenience to have a 'break' in between book 1, 2 and 3 to do so.B: PLAN AHEAD A FREE GAP IN YOUR DIARY.Beware: Average Reader usually tends to skip sleep-meals-showers over this book: UNPUTDOWNABLE. (literally)5 days of reclusion are in order ( or less, according to how fast you are at reading), plan an extra day to digest and recover after Mockingjay. C: LET SOMEONE KNOW ABOUT YOUR PLAN OR PEOPLE WILL THINK YOU ARE DEAD.Beware: The story is such a page turner, so fast and engaging, that you'll forget there is a world outside District 12 or the Arena.You can switch off the mobile and tell the kids/hubs to fend for themselves, BUT you MUST update your GR status and cry/scream/sigh about it! ( your reader friends will be more than happy to re-live some of the most memorable scenes with you ;) )D:  KEEP COMFORT FOOD AT HAND. But it's a ride you never want to finish.The characters are so threedimensional, you can hug them. You will be so involved with their life you'll hurt when they hurt (..and they will *tears*), and you'll cheer with them when they succeed.PS: ..you will also sigh with them too. THIS BOOK CONTAINS ROMANCE TOO.E:  DON'T, UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCE, READ ANY SPOILERS BEFORE YOU START.Especially the ones containing these words:- BREAD/ BOY WITH BREAD-DANDELIONS-STARCROSSED LOVERS-PEARL-'REAL'(view spoiler)[ shoo, shoo! I said NO SPOILERS..look away.. (view spoiler)[ There is a boy in this book that MELTS my heart like no other charcter ever did...*lesigh* (view spoiler)[ I love PEETA. REAL  (hide spoiler)] (hide spoiler)] (hide spoiler)]F:  DON'T USE THE BOOK TO SLAP YOURSELF IN THE HEAD.You have heard about it. Your friens couldn't stop talking about it for months. Blog and magazines keep talking about it now.You will wonder WHY did take you so long to read it.( indeed. WHY ??!!)FINALLY:G:  DON'T BE SCARED OF THESE SYMPTOMS.(Yes, you are a NERD because of this, but who cares, you only live once!)-A sudden urge to book archery lessons ( even if your aim is crap and you have never been able to score a point with darts)-Do extreme sports ( even if the last time you moved a muscle, was to flip the last page of this book over)- Buy 'Down with the Capitol' Tshirt ( pretending is for your kid)- Follow the HG filming updates ( and complaint in vain about the casting choices)Follow this simple help guide if you like, and have fun!Good luck and.. 
  
    'May the odds be ever in your favor!'

“Only I keep wishing I could think of a way to…to show the Capitol they don’t own me. That I’m more than just a piece in their Games.”-Peeta MellarkI was so tired of hearing about this series that I finally caved and decided to read it before the movies came out. This was hard for me to rate because I had mixed feelings the entire time I was reading. I knew I loved it and couldn't put it down, but I also knew it wouldn't be one of my all-time favorites. In the end, it was a 5-star experience for me because I absolutely loved the leads and I'm a sucker for dystopian. The plot was fast-paced and the whole story was just so intriguing. Katniss and Peeta were what made the story for me, and the ending just left me shocked and wanting more. Katniss was incredibly strong, clever, brave, and independent, but clueless when it came to Peeta, which was my one main gripe with her. And for the record, I am Team Peeta. But I digress...This made me think about many things, especially the problems that can arise with societal control, greed, power, and the innate human desire we possess to exert that control over others. It’s a strange and disturbing thing. But as humans, we’re bent toward the need for order and organization, or surely chaos will ensue. Yet that control and power becomes corrupted and chaos runs rampant in its own kind of madness. It's all kinds of creepy. What makes you YOU as a human being? When everything is stripped away and there's nothing in your life but the clothes on your back and the will to survive, what defines you? That being said...this is dystopian literature. It's dark. It's a tough subject. It's equally dark because it could almost happen. It's depressing. I've seen many people complain about this, yet they read it anyway. Personally, I will always root for dark, depressing storytelling when it has purpose. Because I always believe it says something. Something important. The darkness always tends to make the light even brighter--a blinding light, one you cannot avoid. It's not always easy to look at, but when you do, it's liberating. I sensed that kind of light the entire time I read this, which was why I appreciated it and why I'm officially a Hunger Games fan now. If you like Young Adult fiction, you are a dystopian fan, and you enjoy plots that make you think and keep you on the edge of your seat, give it a read. I'm on to book #2 now and can't wait for the first movie.Much love to my friend Melissa for the lend!

While the party may have ended, the band has packed up their instruments and is boarding their bus back to Panem, the streamers have been torn down by the kiddos, and everything that could have been said about THE HUNGER GAMES has probably already been said, I still feel the need to review it. Why? Because I’ve never been very good at marching in step with the rest of the crowd. Plus, as I write this, THE HUNGER GAMES occupies #9 of the Amazon Kindle eBooks Bestseller List for only the 840th day.So how did Suzanne Collins create this international party with a rabid group of followers? By writing a damn good novel, and despite catering to the YA crowd, she held nothing back with the violence, as she dropped it across the blood spattered pages. As for her main character Katniss Everdeen, she is the real hero of this story, and she’s the glue that holds this entire novel together. Without being inside of her head every second of this novel, the entire structure on which it is built would fall apart. You can claim that this should have been written in third person, and that it would have added suspense, as well as rounded out the other characters. But it would have changed the focus of the novel entirely, and it would have lacked immediacy. In order for first person to work successfully, a novel needs a strong, well-defined main character. Check and check.She does a great job with world-building, and I was sucked right into the kiddie pool with the surroundings, circumstances, characters, districts, and everything else that she so expertly articulated. So what if the love triangle is overdone? Without it, the story would have lacked heart. Besides, if you really want to talk plot, there are only seven basic plots, according to Cristopher Booker. Sure, this number ends up being a bit arbitrary, but it’s not like authors have an unlimited number of plots to choose from. So what it really boils down to is execution. Over and over again this book proves its point with Katniss, the quick flip of the pages (or push of the button for us Kindle users), the action scenes, how far we get into Katniss’s head, and the world-building. If you haven’t already hopped on THE HUNGER GAMES phenomenon, you better board the bus now, or you’re liable to miss out on the after-party.Cross-posted at Robert's Reads

This book OH MY GOD. I was continuously waiting for myself to hate it, to see it as over hyped and yet I fell in love with the characters & Katniss' struggles and just wow. I can't wait to read catching fire.I FEEL SO BAD I NEVER WROTE MORE THAN THIS WOW, OKAY UPDATE TIME A WEEK LATER. So, while the writing wasn't prosy or flawless it managed to drag me in with its simplicity & occasional flares?? before this i had been reading poetry a lot and I have to admit the ease of this book was such a relief. I truly connected with Katniss in a few ways, especially the 'parenting her family' aspect and it hit me hard how I could truly understand her emotions. I think the icing on the top of this cake of a book is the characters, they are FLAWED you hear me? so damn beautifully flawed that they're effortlessly human. Now as I'm reading catching fire I'm seeing some flaws being dealt with correctly, characters learning to accept and fix their flaws and I'm just so amazed, I forgot what it's like to read a book with characters that feel human to me. Just the fact alone that Collins remembered to make her characters human was such an A+ for me. This book made me cry, it made me smile & it made me crave catching fire to the point I wanted to run to the store to pick up Catching Fire, I can 10000 percent see myself rereading this series again & again if the next two books are as good as this one.Now go off, and don't be me, don't be frightened by others opinions of popular books, give em a go for yourself!

DID YOU GUYS SEE THE TRAILER?!PERFECTION.March 5, 2012:As of now, I have read this book a total of nineteen times, sometime in June 2009 being the first; every time I love it more than the last. To some this amount of re-readings is most likely seen as excessive, but I truly love this story. The characters are so very deeply ingrained into me that I - at least upon the last three readings - cry at what most consider the most vile characters' deaths. (view spoiler)[Yes, that does include Cato and Clove and the boy that killed Rue. Never at President Snow's or Coin's deaths, however. Maybe one day, but yeah. I'd doubt it. (hide spoiler)]I concede that the recent HYPE absolutely engulfing this book had me on the fence as to whether I would even enjoy it anymore. (I attribute this to my very poignant hipster qualities.) But, as you will no doubt guess, this was my favorite of all the readings. I feel so attached to every one of the characters' thoughts, actions, and lives. I feel as if I still know what one character is doing even if Katniss is absorbed by something else. Honestly I don't read very many stories where I feel such a palpable connection but with this I do, and I cherish it.So, to all of you who are new to reading The Hunger Games, I encourage you to do so. I obviously cannot guarantee your entire enjoyment but I do think, especially if you plan on seeing the film, that giving it a go is a wise decision.

I can't and don't avoid hype where books are concerned so this one is no different. It's been on my to-read list for awhile for that reason alone because, frankly, the premise itself wasn't something that ever captured my attention (and I'm not going to go into it because so many other reviewers have already done it and done a much better job than I could). The only reason I read this book now was because my name finally made it to the top of the library's waiting list. And the only reason I added my name to that list was because everyone else was reading it too and I'm a follower. So what do I have to say for myself now that I've finally taken the plunge and read the latest YA crack pill that everybody and their brother is drooling over? Holy cow, it's about freaking time!My friends say...Five stars: 18 peopleFour stars: 8 peopleThree stars: 0 peopleTwo stars: 0 peopleOne star: 0 peopleThis book was so consuming and so utterly addicting, now I see why no one on my friends list has rated it less than four stars. That has to count for something, especially considering the bizarre assortment books I read, you can imagine the motley crew of folks I count amongst my goodreads friends.What a wonderful surprise this book was. I am very much looking forward to receiving notification from the library that it's my turn for the sequel!!!

“You don’t forget the face of the person who was your last hope.”SO I'm not really sure why I am bothering to write a review for this, so many people already have that mine will probably end up buried but oh well. I really enjoyed this book- I think the story, whilst not entirely original- was clever and provided interesting commentary on the potential for cruelty within any society. The start was quite slow moving and whilst this could have been 'setting the scene', I just found it to be boring. Katniss is a beautiful and strong character. I think what made her so influential and inspirational was that she is so obviously flawed. She is thrown into a scenario and expected to be some kind of hero when, in reality, she is completely normal. I enjoyed her perspective; seeing how nervous she was and the impact the events of the Hunger Games had on her. It was very interesting. Also, I really don't understand how there is any debate about Team Peeta versus Team Gale. PEETA IS SO OBVIOUSLY THE BETTER CHOICE I MEAN JUST LOOK AT HIM HE IS SO ADORABLE AHHHHH!Overall this story is great and entertaining. Whilst it is not necessarily a difficult book to read, I think it is pretty special.

This is one of those books that I read so that I'd have the experience to back up my opinions on a series that has been hyped up to a ridiculous extent. I have to say, I didn't have to work at all at being unimpressed. The idea wasn't all that novel, the writing was mostly telling instead of showing, and wasn't even that good to boot. Too many awkward phrasings and grammatical errors. And maybe it was the lack of description and minimal emotional conveyance, but Katniss' narration was very underdeveloped, in that she wasn't nearly as angry or scared or mindful of her horrible situation as she should have been. Peeta seemed to have more complexity to him, but it's unsure how long that will last. And the rest of the characters barely get five pages to them before disappearing forever, so it's near impossible to judge them. I know it's YA, but I've read much better YA. If you want a dystopia, go read The Giver or something. Much better use of your time.

It is probably the fifth time I read this book since I first read in 2011. So it's time to do a review.This is one of the better books I've ever read.It’s a fantastic, breathless and somewhat brutal read that once you start you simply can’t put down again. The story has just the perfect combination of action, drama, and romance. It has a great message that you can stay human even in the most inhumane conditions.Katniss is my favorite female character and one of the best heroines. She's strong, proud, clever, yet cold, calculating and soft. This is an exciting book that will keep you up late into the night and resonate with you long after you’ve finished.
